PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That Regulations and an Ordinance now before the Parliament amend the Customs ( Prohibited Imports) Regulations and the Customs (Cinematographic Films) Regulations and supersede the A.C.T. Objectionable Publications Ordinance in such a manner as to be harmful to society by removing from existing Commonwealth law
the power to prevent the importation and sale of hard-core pornography (e.g. X- rated videos) and publications which consistently incite the use of hard drugs;
the power to prevent the importation and sale of grossly obscene publications, including those associated with blasphemy;
the power to require imported video tapes/discos for non-commercial use to be registered by the Films Censorship Board.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled: should disallow the new Regulations and Ordinance and ensure
that the Attorney-General enforce existing laws;
that Censors more appropriately reflect responsible community attitudes;
that further measures be taken in association with the States to protect Australians, particularly women and children, from exploitation; and
that, because of the importance of this issue to society, a conscience vote be permitted to all Members of Parliament
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Bilney,Mr Cadman,Mr Dawkins and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Chiropractic Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows :
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice and does nothing to reduce the high cost of health care in Australia.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilizing chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr Hawker,Mr Leo McLeay and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) the large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that 'the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Charles,Mr Fisher,Mr Hawker and Mr McGauran.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and its future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a Referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman,Mr MacKellar and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the overwhelming majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian National Flag.

2. That we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, unless such proposed change is first voted on by the people of Australia and passed by a majority of voters in a majority of States.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:

1. They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to reject the recommendations of the Commonwealth Schools Commission contained in 'Funding Policies for Australian Schools', concerning proposed increases in State aid to private schools and the proposed community standard for education funding.

2. They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to declare a three year moratorium (1985-1987) on increases in State aid to private schools and on grants for new private schools and for increased private school enrolments.

3. They call on the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to re-affirm their primary obligation to government schools and to implement all 1983 ALP election promises for increased funding to government schools.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Charles and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law.
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901 and each point depicting a State and the Territories of the Commonwealth.
3. They know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to its form or to its acceptance as the sole Australian National Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
Will ensure that the existing Australian National Flag remains sacrosanct from change and remains the sole national flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Groom and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax: Confectionery
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that the current discriminatory application of sales tax on confectionery at the rate of 20 per cent is an unfair and unjust burden on this important manufacturing industry and your petitioners therefore pray that confectionery be treated in a similar fashion to all other foods, including snack foods, which are exempt from sales tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Humphreys and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to R.A.A.F. Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully shows:

That we, electors of the Commonwealth of Australia, view with extreme concern and express forthwith our complete abhorrence of the relaxation of the former Federal laws concerning censorship classifications to allow publication and importation of hardcore pornography. Therefore we, the undersigned, do fervently request the Federal Government to repeal the 'A.C.T. Classification of Publications Ordinances' as they affect publications and videos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that:

We hail as a victory for the not-so-silent majority, the decision of the Hawke Federal Government to now conduct an inquiry into the effects of hard core pornography and violence upon people and especially children.
We view with deep concern, and deplore the decision of the Government, to allow the sale of this objectionable material to continue and become even more widespread during the period of the inquiry.
We request the Federal Government to immediately re-enact the previous laws which banned the entry into Australia and the sale of hard-core pornography and violence in video and publication form.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:

That we sincerely believe that the new Commonwealth censorship procedures for publications and the A.C.T. Classification Ordinance 1983 standards for classification of printed materials, No. 1-February 1984 passed by the Senate last Wednesday, removing from existing Commonwealth law:
(a) The power to prevent the importation and sale of hardcore pornography (e.g. X-rated videos);
(b) the power to prevent the importation and sale of grossly obscene publications including those associated with blasphemy;
(c) the power to require videos for non-commercial use to be registered by the Films Censorship Board before release from customs.
Was a step in the wrong direction.

It is the view of the religious community on the north side of Brisbane, of which we are a part, that the new laws should be amended immediately to give protection to all Australians, particularly women and children from exploitation .

It is believed that those materials that come under category 2 classification should not be allowed to be made available to all, and the knowledge that this kind of material described under classification 2 is now lawful under the new regulations is nauseating.

We believe it is the duty of the Government to protect society from those who would incite paedophilia, child pornography, terrorism and extreme cruelty. We believe this protection should be extended to cover items such as are currently listed under category 2.
We respectfully request that amending legislation be drafted accordingly.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kangaroos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to stop the commercial exploitation of the kangaroo.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House re-apply the ban on the export of kangaroo products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Cadet Corps
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully asks:

That the Government of Australia be responsible for the staffing and financing of the Australian Cadet Corps as run in Government Schools. The undersigned pray that the Law be changed so as to allow all students who wish to take part, the opportunity to participate, regardless of their financial position.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Omega Base
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. Omega by sending low frequency signals, penetrating sea water enables hunter -killer submarines to establish their position and to launch a 'first strike' attack. Omega is also used by AWACs, the flying radar stations, and for other military purposes.
2. Omega is an important U.S. military base and a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Omega would have a disastrous effect on Victoria and Melbourne .
3. Omega and other U.S. bases in Australia endanger, rather than protect us. They add a new unnecessary menace to a nuclear arms race that must be stopped, if we are to survive.
Your petitioners pray that Members of the House assembled will close Omega.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Self-Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in November 1978 more than sixty two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a Referendum rejected the introduction of Territorial Government or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a Referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to Territorial or Local Government.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action or legislation in respect of Territorial or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Dr J. Martinick
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we are patients, colleagues and friends of Dr J. Martinick.
That she is apparently being victimized by the Department of Health and the Federal Police regarding itemisation in 1983.
That at no time in the last year the Department of Health Liaison officer or investigator had approached Dr Martinick to discuss any apparent problems.
That the Federal Police who are not a representative of the Department of Health made the first contact with her.

That we are perturbed that the normal procedure of investigating an irregularity was not adhered to in this case and we request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should clarify this situation and amend the Health Insurance Act if necessary to ensure that the Medical Practitioners in future receive a fair and just hearing.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Residential Colleges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the phasing out of the recurrent grant to residential colleges will be detrimental to the ability of disadvantaged and country students to receive a tertiary education.
That alternative arrangements to fund needy students will be of no net benefit to those students, owing to the higher costs of administering such arrangements.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the recurrent grant to residential colleges be maintained as the most efficient and equitable means of ensuring that all citizens, irrespective of background, have equal opportunity to receive a tertiary education.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That the introduction of Medicare has not resulted in a cheaper, fairer system of health care as promised by the Federal Government.
Rather, it is an expensive, bureaucratic scheme, depersonalising medical services and conducive to medical mediocrity.
While recognising the responsibility which exists to assist those in need, we humbly request the Government to review this system which moves towards the nationalisation of Australian medicine.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Western Australia showeth that the Attorney-General amended the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations under the Customs Act 1901, to permit the importation of obscene and indecent pornography into Australia.

Your petitioners therefore, humbly pray that: the Government will restore the former section 4A of the Customs regulation to prohibit the importation of material that is obscene, indecent or blasphemous.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Charlesworth and Mr Tuckey.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the citizens of Queensland respectfully show:
last year, over 3,300 people died on Australian roads;
alcohol is a factor in 50% of road deaths;
alcohol advertisements do not show the perils of driving after drinking alcohol ;
alcohol advertisements are glamorous and increase their effect on teenagers, indicating drinking alcohol as the social pastime;
Your petitioners therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament will legislate to ban the advertising of alcohol from commercial television and radio.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the citizens of New South Wales respectfully show:
last year, over 3,300 people died on Australian roads;
alcohol is a factor in 50% of road deaths;
alcohol advertisements do not show the perils of driving after drinking alcohol ;
alcohol advertisements are glamorous and increase their effect on teenagers, indicating drinking alcohol as the social pastime;
Your petitioners therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament will legislate to Ban the Advertising of Alcohol From Commercial Television and Radio.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of certain elected representatives and officers of Local Authorities in Australia shows considerable concern that the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program levy, at 2 cents per litre on petrol and diesel, was indexed in the 1984 budget, but that funds raised from indexation of the levy will go into consolidated revenue, and not specifically into expenditure on road funds.
It has been estimated that indexation of the levy will raise $491 million over the next six years to 1988-89, of which local Government could have expected to receive $58 million.
This is a further denial of funds to local Government, following $13 million lost this year from Personal Income Tax Sharing entitlements.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will amend the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act, so that funds raised through indexation of the levy will be placed in the Trust Fund, and used for much needed road construction work.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain citizens of Queensland, Australia, respectfully showeth that we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change the Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Down's Syndrome
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Whyalla South Australia, electors of the Division of Grey, respectfully showeth:

That an operation was introduced to Australia for 'Down's Syndrome' children. This operation consists of reducing the size of the tongue of the children which helps them to breathe through their nasal passages, and also enables them to speak much more clearly. There are certain setbacks. 1. the operation can only be performed in Melbourne at present. 2. the operation which in our opinion is a necessity for the well being of these children is not covered by Medicare. 3. the operation costs approximately two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500). We hope to change all this by producing this petition to federal parliament. We are signing this petition so that 'Down's Syndrome' children do not have to be denied this treatment and can live their lives to the best of their ability.

Your petitioners humbly pray. That the Government take steps to make this operation available under Medicare and the appropriate action to ensure that any loss incurred travelling to and from the service centre for such an operation are fully recoverable.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I know that you will appreciate this motion. I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House- (1) for the third time in as many months, condemns the Leader of the House for:- (a) his failure to provide opportunity for the business of private members,
(b) the failure to allow the traditional Adjournment Debate, the only regular opportunity for any Member to raise matters of concern, and
(c) the curtailment of the Budget debate to the least number of speakers for many years;
(2) calls on the Government to face the Parliament and justify its decisions by allowing free parliamentary debate, and
(3) condemns the Leader of the House and the Prime Minister for limiting open government by wanting only set-piece controlled discussions of matters of national significance.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr MILDREN

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

INTERJECT.PARA: That this House- (1) notes- (a) with deep concern the policy of the Opposition as announced yesterday by the honourable Member for Hume, whereby there would be no direct funding to local government for country roads; and
(b) that under this policy, councils will be solely dependent upon State Governments and their own ratepayers for road funds;
(2) deplores the callous disregard for the needs of rural industry and country people at a time when country roads are in such desperate need for upgrading, and
(3) notes with satisfaction the contrasting increase of 60% in road funding under the present Government to local government throughout Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House- (1) notes the arrest in Thailand of the distinguished writer and editor Sulak Sivaraksa on a charge of lese-majeste or defaming the Thai royal family;
(2) recognises and respects Thailand's reverence for its royal family, and
(3) calls on the Australian Government to convey to the Thai authorities the House's hope and confidence that freedom of speech and of discussion will continue to be protected by Thailand's laws.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House- (1) notes that- (a) in the final year of the Liberal/National Party Government 258 000 Australians were added to the unemployment benefits scheme, and
(b) during the first year of the Labor Government 51 500 Australians were removed from the unemployment benefits scheme, and
(2) congratulates the Government on pursuing sound economic policies that have produced this amazing turnaround.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House- (1) condemns the Government for its decision to phase out support for students attending residential colleges at universities;
(2) notes that this decision will most severely disadvantage students receiving the TEAS allowance, as well as country students;
(3) further notes that this decision makes a mockery of the Government's professed commitment to widening access to tertiary education for disadvantaged groups, country people included.
Mr O'Keefe-They don't care about the workers.

TALK.START.PARA: —They absolutely do not care about students, country people or the workers.
—Order! The honourable member, with his notice, is already getting close to the border of what is argument and what is motion. I suggest that he complete his notice of motion.
—Mr Speaker, I am grateful for your guidance, being a tertiary educated person yourself. I conclude:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) calls upon the Government to retain the subsidy so that free and open access to tertiary education is not denied to a significant number of disadvantaged and country, young people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House- (1) condemns the former Government's policies which brought about the virtual bankruptcy of the Australian National Line,
(2) deplores the confusion among numerous coalition spokesmen for transport matters as to whether the Australian National Line should continue to serve north Queensland ports, and
(3) condemns the Queensland Government on its failure to provide subsidies to allow continued Australian National Line shipping services to north Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House calls on the Government to give a firm and unequivocal commitment that it will not enter into any negotiations for any joint venture with the Soviet Union, involving the State of Tasmania, without the full knowledge and consent of the Tasmanian State Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House- (1) notes that semi-professional sportsmen, in particular footballers and cricketers, are disadvantaged by current tax arrangements applying to their sporting incomes;
(2) recognises that in general these people earn high incomes for short periods with relatively high marginal tax rates, and
(3) urges the Government to consider the question of tax averaging for sportsmen and women.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move :

SPEECH.PARA: That this House deplores the Government's failure to provide adequate finance for tertiary education, which has forced the withdrawal of $250 000 provisionally allocated to the Northern Rivers College of Advanced Education for funding an Associated Diploma course in Small Business Management.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) expresses concern that the reference to redundancy in the recent Arbitration Commission decision on job security includes dismissals relating to economic downturn and financial disaster, and

(2) in the light of the Government's support for this decision calls on the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to introduce legislation to at least protect employers who take this decision to save their business and the jobs of those remaining.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) notes that the honourable member for Dawson telegrammed the Minister for Transport on 8 August 1984 requesting the retention of the shipping service to north Queensland due to increased cargo over the past 6 months, and
(2) Condemns-

(a) the Minister for not replying to that telegram and for taking the easy option in cancelling a service in preference to the other option of reducing the costs of ANL to those of the international competitors, and

(b) the honourable members for Leichhardt and Herbert for their willingness to acquiesce so readily to the cancellation of the service instead of representing the interests of their northern constituents.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr McGauran proceeding to give a notice of motion-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member knows the rules about using material which should be used in debate rather than in a motion. I suggest that he reword his notice of motion.

DEBATE.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES GRAIN HANDLERS DISPUTE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House calls on the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to include the effect of such bans and limitations as the recent million dollar New South Wales Grain Handlers dispute in the highly distorted 'days lost to strike' figures that he presents to Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wells Mr D.McM.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House- (1) calls on the State Government of Queensland to submit to Commonwealth audit the books relating to the $23m special Medicare federal grant in order to establish that those funds have not been used for National Party anti-Medicare advertising or other party political purposes, and
(2) notes that if Queensland had a Public Accounts Committee, uncertainty on this question would never have arisen.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Tuckey having given notice of a motion-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The notice of motion is out of order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) condemns the Minister for Transport for his refusal to fund a feasibility study into the proposal by CSIRO for a high speed train linking Sydney, Canberra and Melbourne, and
(2) calls on the Government to display the same courage and vision exhibited by Dr Paul Wild, Chairman of CSIRO and fund a feasibility study on his proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) notes the new-found interest on the part of some Members of the Government in transport matters, but acknowledges that it has developed a bit late, and
(2) commends the Opposition for its far-sighted and national interest-based transport policies being espoused by the Shadow Minister for Transport.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, unless otherwise ordered, government business take precedence--

TALK.START.PARA: —Six speakers a side on the Budget.
—He is like a budgerigar. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, unless otherwise ordered, government business take precedence of general business on each day of sitting until the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1984-85, the Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1984-85 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1984-85 have passed all stages in the House.

This will not come as a surprise to members of the Opposition because it is exactly the same motion that they moved for several years. In fact, when I looked for precedents in order to see that the business of the House was conducted speedily and efficiently, I had to look no further than the precedents that had been set by the former Fraser Government under the magnificent House leadership of the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) who every year moved this motion. Of course, it will make way, in regard to this year's Budget, for what I see as one of the most magnificent speaking lists I have seen for a long time. I know that the person most immediately affected by this, of course, is the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), who was to speak during General Business at lunchtime. I know that some of us who have been affected by his speeches in the past are a bit disappointed that we will not hear him-not that he is so intelligent or coherent or that his speeches have so much detail, but he is not bad for a bloke from the bush. I see that he is the first speaker on the appropriation Bills; so we will at least have the opportunity of hearing him once today, and I think that that would be plenty for the appetite of anybody who is listening to the national Parliament.

As I say, we will be giving full opportunity for members to speak. There is a very long list of Opposition and Government members who wish to speak in the Budget debate. We will give them every opportunity to speak, not only at this stage but also in the Committee stage on each of the departments, in order to see that a full debate takes place.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a shambles, an absolute shambles.
—I notice that the name of the honourable member who interjects is not on the list.
—Yes, it is.
—Is it?
—Order! I suggest that the honourable member for Mitchell make sure that he is here for the Budget debate.

—He is eighteenth on the list. I would have thought that he had done pretty well to be listed eighteenth on the list of Opposition speakers, for all the yelling he does. Hopefully, he will be able to speak. I cannot understand why members of the Opposition have taken 15 minutes this morning in giving idiotic notices of motion in order not to be able to debate the Budget. One would have thought that they would have come here this morning, knowing that we have given over the full day for a debate on the Budget, and taken every opportunity to get into the debate as quickly as possible. Instead of that, we have heard all of those idiotic notices of motion which will never see the light of day but which they want to be able to propagate before the Parliament resumes its normal business. This is the sort of thing they run into. What we have done is no more or no less than what has been done by--
—Is this Parliament going to sit on?
—The honourable member should sit in his correct seat.
—When will we get up?

—We will get up when all of the business of the Parliament is completed . The Leader of the Opposition said to me yesterday: 'When are we getting up, Mick?'. I said: 'What is your hurry?' We have the Budget to debate and lots of Bills to introduce. One would have thought that all these magnificent parliamentarians on the other side of the House would be interested in debating all the issues that come before the Parliament.
—We want him to declare a cut out.

—A wet cut out! Not only will the Opposition have the opportunity to debate the Budget issues in the House, but also at some time in the not too distant future it will have the opportunity to debate them outside the House. We know that the Opposition will have some nasty things to say about us and in response we might have some nasty things to say about the Budgets the Opposition brought down in the last six or seven years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Labor Party is running to a precipitate early election. Labor is now intent on shutting up this place as soon as it possibly can. We know that yesterday the full papers on the Black report on an Inquiry into the Circumstances Surrounding the Making of a Customs Declaration were tabled in the House. Mr Black inquired into some activities by the Special Minister of State ( Mr Young), who is also the Leader of the House. We were very interested in reading a few things in the Black report. We will be commenting about them in due course.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget itself is also under scrutiny. We heard yesterday in Question Time how the Government had suddenly realised that the community is finally recognising it for what it is, namely, a high tax, high spending government. The Government knew when it introduced Medicare that the ordinary citizen would be affected. Medical standards were reduced. Costs to individuals went up. The Government knows that the people out there are beginning to realise that the Medicare package is a fraud. The Government is now in a position, by introducing this motion, to put into place its run and scurry tactic, a tactic that is designed to take all these people out of the House as soon as possible so that the activities of this House in scrutinising the Government will in some way be precluded. I say 'in some way' because I think it is important that we realise just what the Minister has done today.

The list of speakers for the Budget debate is interesting. It includes about half the members of this House. I know how concerned you are, Mr Speaker, that in your responsibilities you exercise your charge to care for the rights of the individual member. Why, the honourable member for Casey (Mr Steedman), I know, looks to you constantly for care and attention to the protection of his rights. So indeed do all of us on both sides of this House. If half the members of the House wish to speak on the Budget and we are told that the Budget debate will be closed tonight, I wonder just how the members of the back bench are to be protected. Of course, one of the other ways in which members of the back bench can be protected is by General Business motions. I think it is very commendable that so many members, not just from the coalition parties, although significantly from them, have been prepared to raise matters of concern to themselves and to their electorates. I commend to every interested member of the Parliament and member of the Australian electorate the notices of motion that appear on our Notice Paper.

I begin with one about which we have a motion to consider. What is it about? It is about uranium. Surprise, surprise! It is a motion that the Labor Party obviously wants to run away from. It is a motion which identifies the fact that it has the sort of policy which is totally in conflict with common sense, a policy which says that Roxby Downs uranium is sacred and can be exported, but that uranium from the Northern Territory, Queensland and Western Australia cannot be exported. We wanted to highlight for the benefit of the Australian electorate the fact that this Government has a uranium export policy which is anomalous and discriminatory and which shows direct political prejudice in favour of that hard pressed Labor Government in South Australia. I would think that even the honourable member for Casey--

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Casey agrees with that.

—How true it is! My colleague, the Leader of the Opposition, pointed out that he was sure that the honourable member for Casey would be delighted to speak on that motion. I think it is very unfortunate that the Leader of the House, in failing to care for the rights and privileges of individual back benchers, fails to give even his colleague the opportunity to speak. I am sure that if the Special Minister of State consulted with the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) he would find that he would love to tell this House what he feels about this Government's uranium policy. Perhaps the Minister for Defence Support (Mr Howe) also would be delighted to speak on uranium.

—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. I draw your attention to the fact that by talking about notices of motion the Leader of the National Party of Australia is attempting to go into the whole debate on every notice of motion. It must be out of order, Mr Speaker.

—Order! The Leader of the National Party is within the Standing Orders. If the honourable member reads the motion he will see that it is a matter of Government Business taking precedence of General Business.

—I am delighted that the honourable member for La Trobe has raised the matter because, no doubt, he also objects to the Government's uranium policy . That is what this is all about. This Government is running scared. That is why it is going to the polls. It does not have to go to the electorate to elect half the number of senators to take up office on 1 July next year until at least late April or perhaps early May of next year. So what is the Government doing? It is trying to avoid debate on uranium, and that of course is the product of today's debate.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is of some interest that we are not just talking about a debate on uranium. Do you know, Mr Speaker, that on the Notice Paper today we have 720 notices of motion? Those 720 notices of motion cover taxation, migration, roads, decentralisation, Medicare--

TALK.START.PARA: —Unemployment, youth.

—Unemployment, social welfare, youth, rights of women. They cover every known activity within Australia. Why does this Government want to call off General Business? It is because it is running scared. These notices of motion are important. Seven hundred and twenty of them will fail to see the light of day because the Special Minister of State does not want to see them debated in this place, where they should be debated.

SPEECH.PARA: But it is not just 720 notices of motion which are involved. We all know that within our Standing Orders we have two separate types of notices of motion. I commend to honourable members a look at the notices that are given for special sitting days. We have, as I have mentioned, the notice of motion relating to uranium which has been given by my colleague the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), and which condemns the Government for its illogical and damaging policies on the mining and export of Australian uranium. It identifies:

. . . possible retaliatory actions by the French Government and other European Economic Community nations such as the dumping of subsidised surplus agricultural products into Australia's Asian/Pacific Basin and Middle East markets.
That is a very important issue. If we have a look at the next notice of motion, it states in part:
(1) expresses its grave concern for the welfare and safety of West Papuan refugee William Mathew Mayer . . .

We know that yesterday the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr West) spoke on this issue. I would have thought that, instead of abusing Question Time as he tends to do, it would have been appropriate for him to come into the House and tell us the position of his Government in regard to our concern that Australia's relationship with Indonesia has run down under this Labor Administration. It would have been proper for the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to come in here and tell us what he is doing about his migration policy which has been the genesis of so much concern. Why, we even had the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), in Question Time the other day, talking about the Government's migration policy, trying to reintroduce the concerns in the electorate that we thought had properly been laid to rest. So that notice of motion would have been an issue that properly would have been debated in this place if the Government were not running scared.
We have another notice of motion which is most interesting. It states in part:
(1) rejects the appropriateness of Mr Temby re-examining the evidence given to the Senate Select Committee on the Conduct of a Judge.

That is a matter that I have been reading about this morning. Mr Speaker, I think it is important that we realise that this House will apparently be denied the opportunity to talk on a substantive motion about a matter which is the responsibility of the Parliament only, to wit the propriety of actions of a member of the High Court Bench. That question of propriety is specifically included in the notice of motion that has been put to this House by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), and it is one of those notices of motion which should be considered, were time permitted by the Government.

Then we have the question of tax. The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) gave notice of a motion relating to tax deductibility to be given to Australians to invest in companies established to purchase or lease areas of environmental significance. We know that this Government is not concerned with the environment. We know that it rejected all those in the environmental movement who looked to the Australian Labor Party in some way to try to solve the problems of the environment that supposedly so beset the previous coalition Government. What arrant nonsense! The Government is not genuine in its practice or in its rhetoric. Sadly this Government in moving this motion is denying us even the chance of considering what sorts of proper tax incentives might be introduced to encourage proper environmental and conservation measures on the part of concerned members of the manufacturing and private sector around Australia.

There are 720 of those motions plus the motions that are identified for special sitting days, which account for another 20 or more. It is important that honourable members realise that of course we have an alternative opportunity, in the Budget. We appreciate the generosity of the Special Minister of State. He has told us that we will have time to debate all the issues within the Budget. The only thing is that he has also foreshadowed that the debate will close tonight. So we are going to have one of the shortest debates on the Estimates that we have had for a long while and we will be precluded altogether from talking at all on all these matters. I think that that is very sad.

There is another matter that I wish to raise relating to the Standing Orders. This also concerns me. When earlier this year a recommendation on the new Sessional Orders was introduced into this Parliament, we were told that we would sit through lunch on Thursdays. On our side of the House we have always attended to our parliamentary duties and we have been quite prepared to concern ourselves with the way in which Parliament should be conducted and to maximise the time available for debate. But what is happening now is that we are told that we will have a Budget debate through the lunch hour. Frankly I do not know whether that is fair on the members who sit at the table, on the Hansard staff who service us , on your staff, Mr Speaker, for you have to maintain the House. I believe that it is totally inappropriate for a matter of such sensitivity as the Budget to be conducted over the lunch hour. It is not just a matter of the Government running away from talking about these General Business motions, it is a matter of its having changed the nature--

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you like to have uranium for lunch?

—We would far prefer to have uranium for lunch. We would be delighted to have yellowcake with it. It would be very important if we had an opportunity here not just to see the lunch hour set aside to talk about the Budget but also to talk about all those General Business items.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that we understand what the Government is about. It is about trying to run to the polls early. It is about trying to hide proper scrutiny of matters that are of concern to the Australian electorate. It is about stifling debate on uranium and stifling debate on the Budget and trying to run away from properly allowing members of this House to exercise their responsibilities, the parliamentarians' responsibilities, and Parliament's responsibilities for scrutinising the actions of the Executive. This Executive really bears so much scrutiny. In so many areas it is showing a tendency to move away from the charge which the Australian electorate believes it gave the Government. It is very important that people out there in the community understand this: All the matters that have taken place in New South Wales-Marmaduke, the Premier, and whatever-are all very much linked to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating). These notices of motion, which this motion seeks to preclude, are matters that are designed to give us, as members of Parliament, an opportunity to scrutinise them in public.

The Opposition cannot accept that it is appropriate in this instance for this motion to be supported. Therefore, we will be opposing the motion very strongly and very vehemently, as indeed we will the premature closing of the Budget debate tonight.
Question put:
That the motion (Mr Young's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (Budget Debate)
Debate resumed from 24 August, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are five specific issues to which I wish to address my concern in this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1984-85, and they are: The evergrowing burden of public expenditure; the mounting burden of public debt and foreign debt; the crisis looming in agriculture; and our declining competitiveness in trade. This Budget will exacerbate the growing concern in all these important areas. This Budget is an election Budget and nothing more. It has two objectives: To give some credibility to the prices and incomes accord and to win the election at the end of the year. It is an expedient Budget, it is a tricky Budget. It extends tax cuts of up to $7.60 a week from 1 November to pay back some of the additional taxation that the Hawke Government has ripped off the average taxpayer since it came to office. It has given tax cuts of up to $7.60 a week but has allowed for a 23 per cent increase in income tax revenue during the year. In fact there will be an overall 10.5 per cent increase in real terms in taxation revenue.
—Shame.

—It is a shame. The five-step income tax scale will ensure that a large percentage of wage earners will pay either 46c or 48c in the dollar. The rapid growth in the size of government expenditure this year will mean that it will reach 31 per cent of the gross domestic product.
—Disgraceful.

—It is disgraceful. This expenditure has to be paid for one way or another. Let no one believe that the easiest way is simply to leave the Budget in deficit. This is the hardest and most costly way for the Australian people in the longer term. Not only is the tax take the highest on record but we face a residual problem of having to pay for the Budget deficit by borrowing money at high interest rates. In the first two Budgets the Hawke Labor Government increased its public expenditure by 7 per cent in real terms-that is after deducting inflation-compared to a 2 per cent increase in real terms throughout the seven years of the Fraser Government. The Government has planned for a 10 per cent growth in the Public Service in its first two years compared to a one per cent growth in the seven years of the Fraser Government.

SPEECH.PARA: No matter how much the Treasurer (Mr Keating) tries to fiddle those figures, he cannot get away from that fact. The Government is living beyond its means. It is ignoring the capacity of the nation to pay the price. It is leaving a legacy of mounting public debt to future generations-to our kids and to their kids, and to hell with their future. It is living for the moment-the best political outcome at the end of this year-so that it can get out and try to maximise this Budget for political and election purposes.

This year's excessive Budget deficit will ensure continuing high interest rates , reducing profit levels in the export industries and it will maintain a higher exchange rate. The two huge Budget deficits of the Hawke Government will continue to add to Australia's growing debt burden. Already interest and capital repayments to overseas interests represent 35 per cent of the annual value of exports. This compares to 18 per cent in 1981-82 and 10 per cent in the 1970s. So since the 1970s we have seen interest and capital repayments increase from 10 per cent to 35 per cent of the annual value of our exports.

It is clear that as a nation we are borrowing beyond our capacity adequately to service long term repayments. A principal cause of high interest rates is the demand for borrowed funds by the public and government sector. The total public sector borrowing requirements are approaching $15 billion compared with $6 billion in 1981-82. The huge rises in the Hawke Government's spending will result in a lift in the Government's total interest bill of $9.2 billion. Sixty four cents-honourable members should look at a dollar note and just remember this-of every dollar governments in Australia borrow will go to meeting the mounting interest bill.

Indeed, public debt now represents nearly 41 per cent of the gross domestic product. The overall public debt, which includes the accumulation of all previous unpaid public borrowings, has grown from $14 billion in 1970 to over $ 75 billion in 1984. It is now estimated that the public debt will go to beyond $ 105 billion by 1985-86, even if the Government does not borrow another cent.

Australia's gross foreign debt in 1980-81 represented 11.2 per cent of GDP. Yet by June 1984 it had nearly doubled to 21.6 per cent. The National Institute of Economic and Industry Research has also released a report that claims Australia' s foreign debt has reached a level which could put Australia's long term economic stability at risk. The report shows that the interest paid on foreign debt has risen from 4.9 per cent in 1979-80 to 16.3 per cent in 1983-84. Put another way, in 1979-80 we owed 4.6 per cent of our GDP to foreigners but in 1983-84 we owed 25.6 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful.

—It is disgraceful and it is very dangerous. Our declining trade performance has been ignored by this Government. The failure to increase in real terms the Department of Trade's appropriation in this year's Budget is nothing less than tragic. This foreign debt problem would not be as serious if Australia had buoyant trade balances to help meet the repayments.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no good Ross Gittins or anybody else writing in the Sydney Morning Herald and comparing the position today with that of, say, 10 years ago because our trade situation at present is very critical and very serious indeed. We are facing the most severe competition in our traditional markets that we have ever faced. The world surplus of oil supplies has reduced our capacity to exploit our vast energy resources and our declining competitiveness is threatening our agricultural, mining and manufacturing industries. In spite of our record wheat crop last year we will finish with a small trade surplus of less than $300m-the first in five years. As I said, this is in spite of a record wheat crop that I doubt we will ever see the like of in the next decade. However, with the high cost of invisibles we will have a current account deficit of $6,697m, which is expected to rise to $8 billion this financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a poor wheat crop this year too.

—Indeed there will be. It seems incredible that the Government should have increased the funds available for the export market development grants scheme by only $10m when all eligible claims for 1983-84 will increase by $23m over last year's appropriation.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia must increase its export orientation. Unless we improve on our trade performance we will face the same problems as New Zealand, South America and the Third World countries. The rural industries account for nearly half of Australia 's export income. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics has estimated that our competitiveness in rural export industries declined by 8 per cent in the last 12 months to 30 June 1984.

Excessive Budget deficits, with consequent huge borrowings, mounting public debt and high interest rates, will continue to erode the competitiveness of our export industries. Australia's export industries are facing a crisis, with high internal costs, low profit margins and a declining ability to compete for markets. Responsible macroeconomic policy and a flexible wages policy are essential if Australia is to retain strong and competitive export industries- rural, mining and manufacturing.

The agricultural industries are worse off than other industries in respect of profitability. The five-year average profitability for manufacturing, the wholesale trade, retail services and mining has ranged between 9.2 per cent and 12.9 per cent. But the average for agricultural industries is just 2 per cent return on capital. Indeed, in the severe drought of 1982-83 the rate of return, including real capital appreciation, was minus 9.5 per cent. Even following the drought breaking rains last year, it rose to only a modest 1.5 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the drought breaks only once.

—It breaks only once. The total capital investment in Australian primary industry is estimated at $75 billion. A return of 1.5 per cent on capital, even in a rural recovery, is not adequate to encourage the degree of investment needed to maintain efficient production in order to improve productivity.

SPEECH.PARA: The sugar industry is in dire difficulties. In the wheat industry, unless one gets 24 bushels to the acre one does not break even. In the sheep industry today people are practically not making a profit in respect of fat lamb production or anything else. A new poor is emerging in the Australian scene and those people are out in the rural areas of Australia. The total capital investment in the mining industry is $25 billion. Last year its estimated return was only 5 per cent. This is inadequate to ensure that our mining industry is able to compete in the long term for overseas markets.

This pre-election Budget, with its further huge Budget deficit, will damage the important agricultural industries and the mining industries already hit by declining competitiveness. The resulting high interest rates, among the highest real interest rates in the world, will also place upward pressure on the trade weighted exchange rates. Our high interest rates are fuelling inflation which continues to run in excess of the inflation rates of our major trading partners of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. The National Farmers Federation pointed out recently:

The differential in the rate of increase in costs reduces the ability of Australian industries to compete on world markets at current prices. The reduced export opportunities are reflected in reduced opportunities for Australian producers of exports and related industries.

So, while the cost of a high deficit might not be immediately apparent, ultimately it disadvantages every Australian by reducing the capacity of our export industries to maintain existing markets and create new ones. The Federation explained in its submission in pre-Budget discussions that Australian producers have been unable to offset adverse cost differentials by securing higher product prices. In addition, the real exchange rate increased by about 8 per cent between the June and December quarters of 1983. Of course, it appreciated by a further 3.5 per cent in the March quarter. There has been a significant improvement since then but on a trade weighted basis it has not helped a great number of our agricultural export industries.

We cannot hope to sustain Budget deficits three times the size of the average deficit for the seven years to 1982-83 without jeopardising our position on world markets and in turn reducing real economic growth at home. The Government has failed to take responsible fiscal and monetary decisions. It has opted for a tricky pre-election Budget strategy. The dismissal in a summary manner by the Treasurer, in his Budget Speech, of the great primary industries is typical of Labor's concern for rural Australia. One would would have thought that the Treasurer would realise the importance of agricultural Australia to the Australian economy and its people. The contribution of the rural industries to the economic recovery, following one of the longest droughts this century, is well known. Although the farm product represents a small share of the gross domestic product, it makes a substantial contribution towards economic activity in this country. The Treasurer did not miss the rural sector last year in the May and August Budgets when the bulk of the expenditure cuts came from rural Australia. The gutting of the tax advantages and the income equalisation deposits--

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely neutralised them.

—Absolutely. The gutting of the tax advantages and the income equalisation deposits and the emasculation of the tax averaging system and the indexation of the fuel excises are just a few of the slugs that have been thrown at the farmers. The introduction of savage increases in export inspection charges, which were increased by as much as 200 per cent, remains a real slug to these export industries. The 42 per cent cut in rural adjustment assistance this year is a further example of this Government's regard for rural Australia. The increase of 150 per cent in prescribed minimum values for sheep, cattle and horses, and 700 per cent for pigs, will hit very hard indeed livestock breeders using the cost basis for valuation.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor's belated fulfilment of a promise to increase funds for wool promotion and soil conservation are mere sops to the rural sector, yet for every rural dollar produced a further $2 is generated. The 69.8 per cent increase in the gross farm product in the December quarter last year was the shot in the arm that commenced a national economic turnaround earlier this year. It helped reduce the growing level of unemployment. Indeed, for every $100m our agricultural export industries earn, over 5,000 additional jobs are provided. With indirect employment effects the export industries account for 11.4 per cent of total employment. Agriculture has traditionally provided between 40 and 50 per cent of all our export earnings. However, there are clear signs that the Hawke Government could not give a damn about rural Australia and the farmers. It is more concerned with satisfying the wants of the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

The Hawke Labor Government has had its chance. It has failed rural Australia. It has carried on from where the Whitlam Labor Government left off. It has ignored the facts that the terms of trade of farmers will deteriorate by 5 per cent in the current financial year; rural unemployment is two and a half times the average in Australia; farm incomes will fall 30 per cent this financial year ; rural indebtedness has reached $5.47 billion, or more than $32,000 for every Australian farm; and the cost of production has risen, making grain production increasingly unprofitable. Meat and beef markets have been ignored and neglected by a lethargic and nonchalant Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen) who has not even visited our largest trading partner this year, namely, Japan. Agricultural and mining industries provide more than 70 per cent of our export income. When one hits those sectors, one ultimately hits all Australians. This Government has ignored that. It has bequeathed a staggering budgetary problem to whichever party is elected to government at the next election.

If Labor is elected it will immediately restructure the taxation system for one purpose only, that is, to give greater income tax cuts to the ACTU as part of the prices and incomes accord. Capital taxation is high on the Government's agenda of priorities. It will not be a capital gains tax because that will not yield enough revenue. It will be a capital taxation which will be applied as a percentage levy on the assessed value of income earning assets. This fear was highlighted recently by reported statements of the honourable member for Melbourne, Mr Gerry Hand. He made no secret of what he and his Party intend to do about capital taxation after this next election. It is there for people to read and to see. His views have been supported at various times by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in another capacity and by at least seven other Ministers.

However, a capital tax or a wealth tax would be the last straw. It would cripple our farm industries, capital intensive as they are, and with very low yields to capital. Capital taxation would accelerate the indebtedness of farm industries, small businesses and the manufacturing and mining industries, reducing their capacity to invest, improve their productivity and compete on world markets. Capital taxation would destroy the capital structure of our private enterprise system in its current condition. It would accelerate the socialisation of the means of production. There is no room for any gung-ho approach by the Hawke Labor Government to our agricultural, mining and manufacturing industries. Yet this is the treatment they have received. I believe that Australia is on the brink of a very serious economic problem. I believe that the honeymoon is over for most Australians, and they need to know it. The honeymoon is over for the farm industries. At the rate this Government is going, it will not be long before it will be over for most Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), I was reminded that the National Party of Australia has learnt nothing and has forgotten nothing. His speech contained the same old rhetoric. Having listened to the protestations of the Deputy Leader of the National Party, I must remind the House that as the Minister for Transport in the Fraser Government he was one of the architects of the economic disaster that that Government created in this nation. He was a Minister in the Government that inflicted Australia with record unemployment, record interest rates, record taxation and record long term inflation. Now he seeks to blame this Government for the failures, the incompetence and the mismanagement of the Government of which he was a part. He reverted to true National Party form, that is, to divide, to confront, to set Australian against Australian, employee against employer and country dweller against town dweller, in an attempt to divide and conquer. Australia has turned away from those kinds of tactics. Last year the vast majority of Australians threw out that kind of strategy, the National Party strategy, and opted for the policies and views put forward by this Government, that is, the policy of bringing together Australians, consulting, working together, understanding the other person's point of view, and making this economy in this great country work better for all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking to the second Keating Budget, I want to refer to the strength in recovery that has produced a bright outlook for 1984-85. Economic activity will grow at a fast rate, creating significant new employment opportunities. Inflation has fallen to a level broadly in line with that of our major trading partners. Interest rates are on the way down. It is only 18 months since the Australian Labor Party came to power, yet in that short time there has been a complete economic turnaround. In my remarks I want to concentrate more on the role which transport plays in ensuring the maintenance of economic growth and the living standards of every Australian.

The importance of transport to the national economy can be illustrated by highlighting a few brief facts. It has been estimated that at least $1 in every $7 spent in the economy is on transport related activities, that is, infrastructure, fares, cars or freight. For the individual consumer, around $14 of every $100 spent is on fares and the purchase and operation of motor vehicles . By comparison, food accounts for $17 and housing for $18. Such a high level of expenditure on transport is not surprising in a country such as Australia. It is situated far from its international markets and has a small, widely dispersed population. Clearly, the Australian economy will not maximise its performance unless its transport sector is operating efficiently and effectively. The achievement of this vital objective has been my principal task as Minister for Transport.

Australia is a great trading nation. Last financial year our exports accounted for 15 per cent of gross domestic product, or some $28,000m. The nation's prosperity and much of its work force depend on this export performance. We must be able to supply overseas consumers with our products when they are required, reliably and as cheaply as possible. To this end, I have devoted much time and effort to improving the operation of our shipping industry. The Australian National Line has been given a capital injection to put it on a sound financial footing. It has been given new top management and a new legislative charter which gives it greater freedom and flexibility to operate commercially.

There have been extensive, ongoing consultations with sea-going unions, aimed at developing new shipboard practices to promote greater productivity and efficiency. This has not been an easy process but progress has been made and will continue to be made. Australian flag and Australian manned ships are becoming more productive and competitive by international standards. This process has been aided by new legislation which gives Australian shipowners tax benefits comparable with those available to their counterparts overseas. As a consequence of this approach, the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd has placed orders for the construction of three bulk carriers for the coal trade with Japan and Korea. That business is new business for this nation. We did not have the transportation of coal business previously. It would not have been gained without the goodwill that has been built up between the sea-going unions, government and industry and the availability of special taxation allowances for Australian shipping. These initiatives mean that Australian shipping now faces a brighter future. It has the prospect of becoming a self-sufficient, commercially viable industry competing on its own merits in international trades. If this enhanced efficiency is achieved, the nation as a whole will benefit. Exporters will gain from reduced costs. Local shipping operations will be more competitive . Importers will also be better off.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Crawford report.

—I acknowledge the interjection of the honourable member. He played a role in the earlier stages in the area of taxation allowances. We had a bipartisan view about it. I am happy to acknowledge his positive participation in that area. Although the primary focus of policy is on improving export competitiveness, it should not be forgotten that importing plays an important role in the economy. Imports expand the range and diversity of products available to Australian consumers. Imported plant and technologies support employment in a wide range of Australian industries.

SPEECH.PARA: Shipping is but one link in the Australian transport system. Shore based transport operations are also important, especially as they contribute significantly to trading costs. In the European wool trades, for example, shore based transport costs at both ends of the sea link can be as high as 70 per cent of total door to door costs. For many other export commodities it is up to 50 per cent. It is vital that our land based transport links also be up to the mark and operating at peak efficiency. It is for this reason that I sponsored a seminar early in July that focused on shore based shipping costs. A wide cross- section of Australian transport interests participated, including leaders and representatives of the stevedoring industry, port authorities, unions, shippers, shipowners and land transport operators, as well as government officials. A broad range of issues was discussed in an informed, open and frank way. Yesterday afternoon I was pleased to announce the establishment of an industry task force, headed by the Managing Director of Mayne Nickless Ltd, Mr Ian Webber , to examine the concerns which were expressed at the seminar and to propose practical measures to improve the general economic and operational efficiency of shore based transport and handling.

The railways also have an important role to play in the overall Australian transport system and our export performance. There are five separate rail systems in this country-a situation that has produced its own legacy of fragmentation and incompatibility, both in terms of equipment and practices. Direct Federal involvement has been much less in this area than in the shipping industry; nonetheless, Federal initiatives have produced significant advances. I have concentrated on encouraging a co-operative approach in this industry. There are significant operational economies to be gained from each of the different systems working together, in harness, not against each other. If the railways are to maintain their rightful place in Australia's transport system, it will be necessary to revitalise the industry and to restructure its operations to improve its efficiency. As a step in this direction I have actively promoted the Rail Industry Council, in association with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the rail system managements and State governments. The Rail Industry Council is intended to be a formal consultative mechanism to bring rail unions, government and rail management together on a national basis. This proposal will be further considered at the next meeting of the Australian Transport Advisory Council.

The operations of the Federal system, Australian National, have been closely scrutinised. With the implementation of the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1984, Australian National is expected to operate commercially. There have been continuing regular consultations with Federal and State rail union representatives aimed at developing modern work practices. Investment is being made in new rolling stock and improving the track system, particularly in Tasmania where the rail system has been neglected for so long. Australian National is being revitalised and made ready to take its place in a modern, efficient, Australian rail system.

Finally, there is the road freight industry. As with railways, there are tasks in which road transport has a natural advantage. Over the years there have been accusations that the road freight industry has engaged in unfair and costly competition with the railways to the ultimate detriment of the Australian transport user. In addition, the industry has faced a number of problems exacerbated by the recession, including an oversupply of capacity and poor financial prospects for many operators. To open up the issue so that the facts can be known and be properly aired for the first time, the Government established last September the National Road Freight Industry Inquiry under the chairmanship of Mr Tom May. That inquiry reported to me last week. Its report is now with the printers and I expect to be able to release that report in about a fortnight's time. Its report will be an important element in the development of an Australia-wide transport strategy aimed at striking an efficient balance between the land transport forms, whether they be rail or road.

So far I have focused on the people side of transport. This is an important aspect of an industry which employs large numbers of people throughout our nation. By tapping this human resource through co-operation and consultation among employers, unions, users and government, improvements have been made in developing more efficient transport systems at a low budgetary cost. Much remains yet to be gained from this approach. Efficient transport systems also need infrastructure.
