I will spend the remaining time available to me to outline briefly the major capital expenditures our Government has included in the transport budget.

Our Government will provide $1,245m under its roads funding programs this financial year. This amount represents an increase of 46 per cent on the level of Federal expenditure for roads provided in the last Fraser Budget. These funds will be spent on a variety of roads-maintaining and upgrading the national highway system, urban and rural arterial roads and local roads. I stress that better roads mean less wear and tear on vehicles, lower operating costs for motorists, businesses and industry, shorter travelling times and savings in fuel . The benefits that will flow from the expenditure on roads will be widespread. Road construction and maintenance also create jobs directly. The experience of Federal and State road authorities is that every $1m spent creates about 40 jobs in the road construction and associated industries. On that basis, Federal spending in 1984-85 on roads can be expected to support 20,000 jobs directly and a further 30,000 jobs indirectly.

In addition to those benefits, expenditure on roads and improved roads has road safety spin-offs. Current road casualty rates are a horrifying social problem. In addition to the human tragedy and trauma caused by the carnage on the roads, there are very real economic costs involved. It has been estimated conservatively that road deaths and injuries cost this nation some $3,000m a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tragic.

—I acknowledge that it is a tragic situation. On average each fatal road crash costs the community $300,000. By improving our roads we reduce one of the major causes of road crashes and we save the economy resources that can be used productively to improve our living standards. Road improvements alone will not, however, solve the problem of the road toll. Road user behaviour is a major factor that must also be addressed. Recognising this, our Government has allocated $2.1m for road safety promotion and research programs in 1984-85. A major initiative that will occur later this year is the National Road Safety Symposium, the first in more than a decade. This will allow interested persons and experts to focus on and define national road safety priorities.

SPEECH.PARA: Other major expenditure provided for in the Budget is a $26m grant to the Tasmanian Government for the purchase and modification of the Nils Holgersson to replace the present Bass Strait ferry, the Empress of Australia. This new ferry will double the passenger carrying capacity across the Bass Strait and will provide a major boost to the Tasmanian tourist industry. In addition to that, a sum of $29m is being provided for the continuation of the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme while it is currently under investigation by the Inter-State Commission. I deplore the attitude of some members of the National Party of Australia in attacking the provision of that $26m to Tasmania for the replacement of the Empress of Australia ferry and in attacking the provision of funds for cargoes across the Bass Strait under the Tasmanian freight equalisation scheme. I note that the Federal Liberal Party members from Tasmania have made no response to the National Party's attack.

Finally, I mention the $4.3m being provided for the construction of navigation aids marking Hydrographer's Passage. This is a new deep draught shipping channel through the Great Barrier Reef north-east of Mackay. The completion of this passage in 1985 will provide a more direct route for shipping through the reef. This is expected to reduce the cost of transporting Queensland coal to world markets by $7m a year and will help make that industry more competitive on world markets. It is an example of how a modest government transport expenditure can produce real economic benefits for an Australian industry.

I have briefly outlined the Federal transport initiatives for the past 18 months. The allocation of $1.5 billion for transport in the 1984-85 Budget consolidates these initiatives and provides for further advances. The result will be a more efficient and more effective national transport system. This will mean lower costs and greater competitive opportunities for our industries both at home and abroad. With this will come economic development and growth, new jobs and rising living standards. I reiterate that under this Government transport is making a positive contribution to sustained economic recovery. I commend the Budget to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Hawke socialist Government will go down as a government of record; that is, a government of record spending, record taxation, record deficits, record borrowings, as well as the all-time record for the greatest number of election promises broken over the shortest imaginable period. If the Guinness Book of Records does not have it in mind to list the cynicism of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) towards election promises, it will miss a golden opportunity to inform its Australian clientele of the abysmal, record shattering performance of the Hawke Government.

SPEECH.PARA: How about this for a sampling of promises broken in just 18 months under the present Government? Although the list is far from complete, it highlights the duplicity of the Prime Minister. There was the promise on attaining office-that is, immediately after 5 March 1983-to grant tax deductions to six million Australians. That promise was just as immediately broken. There was a promise that there would be no change to taxes on lump sum superannuation payments. That promise has been broken. The promise to maintain the housing loan interest rebate-broken. The promise to keep the health insurance rebate until the introduction of Medicare-broken. The promise to not means test pensions for those aged over 70-broken. The promise to not introduce an assets test on pensions-broken. The promise to not take money out of pensioners' cheques- blatantly broken. The promise to abolish the chemist prescription declaration form-broken. The promise to increase spouse and sole parent rebate-broken. The promise to maintain drought relief to help rural recovery-broken. The promise to reduce the price of petrol by 3c a litre-broken. The promise to reduce charges for private patients in public hospitals by $60 a day-broken. The promise that there would be no further job losses in the steel industry-broken. The promise that the level of real funding for local government would be maintained-broken. The promise that the tax threshold for ordinary income earners would be increased to $5,000-broken.

Then, given the contrived expectations today about an early election there was the daddy of them all-the Prime Minister's solemn undertaking, delivered no doubt while smiling with the corners of his mouth pointing to the ground and eyes unseeing and upturned into his Louis XIV bouffant hairstyle, that his Government would serve a full term of three years. The breaking of that promise was foreshadowed less than one year after he took office. That is just a grab bag sample of broken promises; it is by no means complete. There is a host of other broken promises and undertakings not kept, at least 123 in all at the last count. All this was from a Prime Minister whose self-professed integrity he believes should be beyond question. Let there be no doubt that the Prime Minister's integrity is only self-professed and has no basis in fact.

Despite well and truly broken promises which resulted in means testing of over 70s pensions and assets testing of pensions, effectively meaning that the Government has taken or will take money out of pensioners' cheques, we witnessed in this Budget the cruel and cynical attempt by the Prime Minister, lacking in any perceivable integrity, to buy back the votes of pensioners with a miserable $2.50 a week. They will not accept that as the bribe it was intended to be. Not only will that pittance not buy much for the Government, it will not go any way at all towards the need the Prime Minister feels to be loved at large for his non-existent integrity.

Australia's pensioners know only too well that the consumer price index is not a measure of the real inflation, of inflation as they experience it. They know that the CPI does not measure or reflect in any way increases in their costs of living. We could ask the pensioners or any housewife in Australia whether an extra $2.50 a week would cover the additional weekly cost of food in their supermarkets and shopping centres, even after taking into account CPI increments . As the Prime Minister does not intend to honour his promise to see out a full parliamentary term, it is surely not too much for pensioners to expect him to honour his promise to increase pensions to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings during the life of this Parliament. That was a reasonable expectation, but it will not be realised.

Since its election in March 1983, the Hawke Government has been more preoccupied with creating illusions than with creating good government. This year's Budget is but the latest attempt to distract less than well-informed Australians from the Government's real lack of economic skill and ability as well as from the direction to be taken at the behest of left wing ideologues who effectively call the shots. Any change to radicalism must be preceded by radical economic destabilisation. Let no one forget that the Prime Minister, when President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, presided over periods of unprecedented economic destabilisation in this country. Who can forget the Hawke -inspired wage explosions of the 1970s?

We have today a so-called accord, which promises to become discord. We have seen those pathetic television advertisements which portray events the wrong way round, in which the discord should follow the sweet music generated by the Fraser Government's wages pause. That discord is not far around the corner if we have learnt anything from this Government's outright vocal support for industry funded, non-contributory superannuation for, firstly, the building industry, and after that, all members of unions affiliated with the ACTU. Apologists for the Government will point out that the impost of superannuation on industry in no way breaches the infamous accord. Whatever they may say, it will add considerably to the cost of employment, as will this Government's advocacy of horrendous redundancy clauses to be written into awards, along with its reckless addiction to occupational safety.

These add-on cost imposts augment the launching pad that is wage indexation and will form a significant component of the fuel which will see skyrocketing employment costs regardless of the capacity of individuals and industry to pay. There is nothing in this Budget which will ensure that Australia's cost structure becomes more competitive. There is nothing which will mitigate a cost structure that is high by any international standards in a country which relies on international trade more than most others for its economic wealth and the wellbeing of individual Australians. Above all, there can be nothing more economically debilitating than tax hikes of the magnitude called for in this Budget. It might be said that they are necessary. Certainly, if a 16 per cent expenditure increase for the year to 30 June 1984 is acceptable, to be further increased by 13 per cent in this current financial year, one might be conned into accepting an increase of $6.7 billion, or 23 per cent, in personal income taxes.

Let no one overlook a 40 per cent increase in expenditure on health, some $1.8 billion this year, following the then massive 29 per cent increase last year. That is entirely attributable to the introduction of Medicare, that deplorable creature of obsessive socialists. Let no one forget this Budget's provision for a 29 per cent, nearly $1.3 billion, increase in interest payable on Commonwealth Government borrowings, bringing the total interest bill for the year to a staggering $5.6 billion, and increasing. Commonwealth revenue from all sources, including a further $6.7 billion from income taxes, will increase this year at a rate which is double the increase last year. Following a 9 per cent increase last year, this year will see the total grab by this socialist Government surge a further 18 per cent to a record $57 billion. Despite this record confiscation of money by taxes and charges from the otherwise disposable incomes of individual Australians and businesses, the Government remains unable to balance its books and has budgeted for the second highest deficit in Australia's history , a deficit exceeded only by the same Government's record of last year. Even the economically illiterate amongst the Government and its back bench must see the folly of spending so much in excess of revenue collected. The Government, as any other government would be, is forced to borrow to make up the difference. It borrows from overseas and from within Australia. Those billions of dollars being borrowed by the Government inside Australia are inhibiting the already inhibited accumulation of capital and its availability to the private sector for investment.

Because of an influx of foreign capital and because the private sector does not have the necessary confidence in the economic skill of this Government, there is now an apparent abundance of money. However, the extravagance of this Government and its consequential appetite for borrowing to offset its inability to balance the books have maintained interest rates at levels much higher than they should be. Further, the Hawke Government now has a considerable stake in high interest rates. If rates do not remain high, there is every likelihood that much of the foreign inflow which props up the current balance of payments will cease. Worse, there is the very real danger that short term foreign funds will be repatriated in large lumps very quickly.

This Budget furthers the socialist objectives of the Australian Labor Party in many ways. Nowhere is this stark reality more in evidence than in the delivery of health care. Few Australians will have failed to notice by now that Medicare is just one step along the road to nationalising an industry which hitherto has served Australia so well for so many years. If anyone doubts the intentions of the Hawke socialist Government towards nationalisation of doctors and deliverers of health care, let him ponder the words of the non-medical Dr Blewett, who is now the Federal Minister for Health. In 1982 he said:
Private fee-for-service medicine is deeply entrenched in Australian society, strongly defended by the medical profession and favourably evaluated by the population at large.
I could not agree with him more. He went on to say:
That is a fact of life and whatever changes we desire in that system will have to take place gradually and incrementally.

Those words-that stated intention-have not been retracted by the Minister. Indeed, they have been reinforced by his deeds and actions time and again. As has already been said, the first important steps have already been taken. Medicare has been born much to the discomfort of those who may have been lulled into believing that they would continue to enjoy the same treatment and standards as those which were in operation before the introduction of Medicare. The concept of fee for service is completely unacceptable to this Minister and to this socialist Government. They suffer privately insured patients only because it is expedient to do so. These apologists for sympathisers with the private sector in some other areas of economic endeavour have no such pretended scruples when their beloved but disastrous health care plans might be put in jeopardy.

Medicare and the manifestations of Labor Party dogma and doctrine in this Budget are complete anathema to the coalition parties. We hold that patients must be free to select the doctor of their choice, in or out of hospital, and free also to insure against the cost of higher medical expenses so cruelly prohibited under Medicare. We hold that individual doctors should be free, along with other Australians, to determine the rewards for which they can ask for their highly skilled services. Any doctor's first duty must be to his or her patient and not to a government and, above all, not to a coercive socialist government.

Of course, all these inroads into what was once an excellent health care system in Australia before Whitlam have their price. This is no better illustrated than by referring again to increased expenditure on health, which is up by a massive 80.5 per cent as a consequence of the first two Hawke socialist Government Budgets, and all because of Medicare. Claims and inferences of a one per cent increase in personal income tax by way of a so-called Medicare levy are patently meaningless. While there is an officially acknowledged tax hike of one per cent for Medicare, the cost of that abomination would necessitate a 1.7 per cent tax if the total cost of Medicare were to be recouped by a so-called levy. The cost of Medicare this year will be over $2 billion. Against this, the one per cent impost will yield less than $1.2 billion. The shortfall of $830m will be paid for out of other taxpayers' contributions. It is therefore an unofficial but nevertheless real additional levy, taking the total to 1.7 per cent and not one per cent as claimed. More accurately, it is part of the minimum $6.7 billion deficit which the country must borrow and which will be paid for by future taxpayers, with interest added. Tomorrow's taxpayers will have to foot the bill again for expenditure incurred in large lumps by a ruthless socialist government determined to buy its way into power at an unnecessarily early election.

The Hawke Government's ruthlessness is no more apparent than in the area of taxation. I refer not just to the secret taxes inflicted on a largely unsuspecting taxpaying public. Despite a massive increase of 23 per cent to be conscripted by way of personal income taxes, there has been no serious commensurate attempt to balance the Budget by containing expenditure. That tax hike on the earnings of individuals will be the largest since the dim, dark days of World War II.

This is most certainly a government of record taxation and record expenditure. Even the excesses of the Whitlam years pale into insignificance alongside this mob. This Budget takes big Government to record highs in terms of its tax grab. At the same time, the Government has studiously avoided the hard decisions which economic responsibility demands. It has left around the loaded gun that is this year's contribution to our indebtedness as a nation for innocent future generations to pick up. Worse still would be the mortal damage to our economic future if a Hawke government were given another chance by the electorate to pick up and pull the trigger of the loaded weapon it has left lying around by embarking upon another round of socialist extravagance.

Phoney tax cuts aside, it is the continued mammoth growth of Commonwealth taxes , expenditure and deficits that gives rise to grave concern for the future. This Budget is not shaping up as the political document it was intended to be in what is to be a premature election year. Over the past couple of weeks sober analysis of the Budget by responsible commentators shows that it has failed in its only real objective, which was to bribe the Australian electorate to vote again for this socialist rabble.

Australians are only too well aware these days that governments can give nothing that they have not confiscated from the earnings of others. Wealth measured by the gross domestic product or by any other means has first to be created by the enterprise of individuals and entities before those individuals and entities can pay tax to enable this, or any other government, to do the many things it was elected to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are many ways of measuring the effectiveness of the 1984-85 Hawke Government Budget. Undoubtedly the most important way is to measure the reaction of the people out in the electorate, the people for whom the Budget was framed. The electorate's response is that the Budget is very successful indeed. Another way is to measure the response of Opposition members to the Budget. Although I find this response in many ways most unsavoury, it does indicate the Government's success, for the Opposition can find no real failure in the Budget. Its strong tendency to spend most of the time available for analysis of the Budget in fearmongering about completely unrelated matters thinly veils its envy at our delivering a Budget which it was unable to do in seven inept years. I exclude the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), who led the Opposition debate this morning, from this charge of fearmongering. But quite frankly I am appalled at the immoral attitude of some Opposition members, most certainly not all of them. I am speaking of the irresponsible, noisy minority who appear to believe that any fear may be invoked, any misinformation perpetuated and any number of people hurt in the interests of getting a vote or just of scoring political points.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer in this context to the assets test inspection lie. I find it very irresponsible that pensioners have been told that inspectors will be going through their goods and evaluating them for the purposes of the assets test. As has been explained, in November, 70 per cent of Australian pensioners will receive a letter from the Department of Social Security telling them that they will not even have to fill in a form because records have shown that they will not be affected by the assets test. Of the other 30 per cent, it is gauged that half of these, only 15 per cent of all Australian pensioners, will even have to fill in a form. The evaluation for the purposes of this form will occur by means of discussion between the pensioner and the Department of Social Security. If evaluation is necessary it will be done in the usual way by taxation officers. Meanwhile, one Queensland pensioner took his money, $2,000, from the bank because of these lies that an inspector could come around-and that money was stolen. I find that disgraceful.

Another instance is the lie that Labor has encouraged pornography and the distribution of pornography in Australia. The Labor Government is the only government that has moved to introduce some sort of regulation of video pornography. We do acknowledge that there is more to be done here. We have set up a committee to look at this. But, again, I find it appalling that people have been misled and are writing to me saying that this is an area in which this Federal Government has acted detrimentally. There was no comprehensive legislation before the Federal Government organised meetings with all State Ministers, including Mr Tony Elliott, who represented the Queensland Government. He met with the Federal Government in July last year and April this year and he was part and parcel of the classification, which is now being used as some terrible weapon against the Hawke Government. In other words, all the State governments took part in the classification discussions at that time, including the one on the X classification, even though some have changed their minds about it since. The Federal Government itself will certainly move to ensure that this hard pornography does not remain rife and come into the possession of our young people.

I wish to look at the past only insofar as it is constructive to do so as a means of evaluating this Budget for the future. This Budget closes the gap between Canberra and the Australian electorate. The Government's commitment to the people out in the electorate, the people whom we represent, is reflected in our direct assistance payments to local government which include $37.2m for children's services, an increase of $14.9m or 66.8 per cent. That is an indication of this Government's commitment to the family. We have also allocated $25.2m for the aerodrome local ownership plan, which is an increase of $8.7m or 52.7 per cent. We have given $7.9m for aged and disabled persons homes, an increase of $629,000 or 8.6 per cent. We have given $4m for nursing homes, an increase of $1.6m or 65 per cent. This shows that we are concerned. There is more to be done here but we have shown our commitment in a most difficult Budget by increasing that amount by 65 per cent. We have allocated $2.5m for the delivered meal subsidy, an increase of $272,000 or 12.3 per cent. This is an excellent service provided by people out in the community in delivering meals to the aged and housebound.

This Budget is indeed a victory for the little people. In many instances it is a direct result of electorate representations. I mention particularly the move by the Government to exempt from debit tax cheques written by parents and citizens and parents and friends associations, local government and other organisations. The 10 per cent increase in the tertiary education assistance scheme will encourage parents to keep young people in tertiary education. The introduction of a new program, the basic education program, reflects the community's concern about the trend away from basic information revolving around the three Rs, that is, numeracy and literacy skills. This Government has put money towards a program which will look at children at primary school level, select those who are having trouble with numeracy and literacy and give them extra education so that when they come out on to the job market they at least will not be disadvantaged by not being able to spell, express themselves correctly or even do simple sums which, regrettably, has been the case in many instances in the past. The Government has looked at low income earners, particularly with its introduction of a graded tax scale which allows us more leeway in drawing the extra taxation money from people at the top of the earning level and giving relief, as the public is aware, to those in the middle and lower ranges.

We have also supported the dual education system. This Government acknowledges that education should be for the benefit of the child. No one who puts the welfare of our young people first can have any objection to funding based on need. This is truly a policy aimed at benefiting the family. With the community standard, every school will be able to afford standards which ensure that no child will miss out on quality of education. We in the Government, and particularly our Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan), know that there is no point in just giving resources to schools if we do not give them in such a way as to ensure that needs are met, that classes are not too large and that children are able to have that individual attention which will now flow from the funding based on a community standard.

Probably the foremost feature of this Budget is that it consolidates economic growth. It shows that the accord is working. There are many members on the Opposition benches who would like to pull down the good work done by this Government in calling together government, unions and employers, in effect, to sign a social contract with each other for the benefit of the nation. The accord is working and because of this success more funding is coming in through tax revenue and the Government will be able to move from the point of this Budget which consolidates the growth in last year's Budget to a situation where we can put more funding into specific areas to raise the quality and standard of living in Australia. In the past there has been reason for gloom. The Fraser Government did not acknowledge unemployment and therefore had no good policy and there was no improvement in the situation. Inflation was up to 11.5 per cent; depression yawned at our feet in Australia, but now there is reason for hope. The year 1983 -84 was one of strong economic growth. There was 5 per cent growth in non-farm gross domestic product. People bought more. There were 232,000 more jobs, a 3.7 per cent growth. The inflation rate halved to 6 per cent, not counting the Medicare factor, and there were fewer strikes, a matter which had been of great concern to many people in the Australian electorate. These people are now pleased to see that the time lost owing to industrial strife is down by 30 per cent. There were 30 per cent fewer strikes as a result of the policies of the Hawke Government.

This Budget maintains the course for 1984-85. There will be 5 per cent growth in the non-farm GDP. There will be more jobs, an employment growth of 2.5 per cent. Inflation is down to around 5 per cent. The accord is a major reason for the success and it is supported by tax cuts, increased employment and welfare spending. There is not the extent of welfare spending that we would wish to move to in following years, but our welfare spending shows that we are keeping faith with our commitment to people on lower incomes and those without incomes. We are introducing new policies for occupational health and safety.

The Budget also prepares for long term economic growth and I point particularly to the 40 per cent increase in the skills training program aimed at adult retraining. While we have had, and still have, concern for the number of young people who are out of work and who have never had a job, there is a new sector of people-males around the age of 45 years-who are being retrenched and cannot get other work. The Government is concerned about these people and has increased the allocation for a program to assist them as well as introducing many other job training programs.

Because we have kept our promise to introduce tax cuts, the typical Australian pay as you earn taxpayer who has been struggling to make ends meet now has some relief. Some members of the Opposition have attacked this Government for believing that it is time the taxpayer had some relief. We promised that we would give it to them and there is no way that we would have backed down on this major promise, even given the mess which we inherited and given the fact that we felt we must reduce the huge deficit, as indeed we have managed to do. We have also increased by 76 per cent, to $40.9m, funding for wage subsidy schemes to assist 21,000 long term unemployed adults.

Seventeen months ago there was no hope in this country. Unemployment was soaring-by a quarter of a million people in one year-and we had an inflation rate of 11.5 per cent when the rest of the world had 4 per cent. Today we see a superb contrast. There is reason for hope. Inflation is down to 5 per cent and growth is at 10 per cent-the highest in the Western world. Australia has moved from zero growth into a position of having the highest growth rate in the Western world. This means more jobs, and we have kept the deficit down and given the Australian public hope. The Australian people are not so stupid as to feel that their every little need should be met in this Budget. They are aware that we are on the way to achieving full recovery. It is hope based on proof that Australia is pulling out of the trough. The Government acknowledges that there is more to do but we are well on the way to doing it. This Budget will ensure a full economic recovery in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —To establish the credentials of this Budget, one has to examine its thrust and direction. Early to the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), one finds that it is indeed an election manifesto. It simply loads the Australian community with unparalleled debt so that the Government can make promises to its friends within the union movement. It is an example of how this Government is rushing to an election, 18 or 19 months after it was successful in 1983, to forestall the public's acknowledgement and understanding of what it is about.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget is a document to confuse to obtain its aims, and its confusion rests on two important paragraphs on page 3 of the circulated copy of the Treasurer's statement. In referring to what he terms as his Government's economic success, he said:
Central to that success was the Accord on prices and incomes between the Government and the Australian trade union movement.
He went on later to say:
This has only been possible because the Accord has given the Government an agreed basis of wage and price restraint.

That statement is pure and utter nonsense. My colleague the shadow Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the honourable member for Balaclava (Mr Macphee), made this statement on 16 April this year in relation to the accord:
It is a matter of great concern that, quite insidiously, Australians are being given to believe by the Government that full wage indexation represents 'wage restraint'.
He continued:
Labor has sought and obtained a compounded wage increase of 8.6 per cent for its partner in the accord, the ACTU, and that in only six months. Indexation cannot be portrayed as wage restraint.

That is from a colleague of mine in the shadow Ministry, and it might be said by those opposite that it is a biased political statement. Let me go to the heart of this matter by referring to the appearance of Mr Simon Crean on the Nationwide program on the eve of the Budget. He said:

There is therefore an arguable claim for productivity. What the trade union movement is suggesting should be done and responsibly suggesting should be done is to say, let's look at other means by which that wage increase can be taken.
He went on to say:
I don't think that people should dismiss the superannuation argument as an additional cost, rather it should be seen as another way of meeting the claims that are going to arise.

The union movement has no intention of standing by its part of the accord; it simply intends to press across Australia a claim that will cost every employer $ 11 a week. It intends to submit next year to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission a claim of large order in relation to increased productivity, and Mr Crean openly admits that that is another form of wage increase. The unions of this country have no intention of abiding by anything that the Government stipulates as their part of the accord. They are simply out to claim under another name the benefits of this short term increase in the country's economic capacity to pay. It represents a double dipping-a dipping in once by the Government for its taxation and expenditure purposes and a dipping in by the unions for wage increases under another name. That is quite openly admitted by one of the chief union spokesmen in this country.

Of course what this Administration is about is putting over the Australian community one of the greatest sell-outs to sectional interests ever known. This Budget represents a sell-out to the unions. The Government has no commitment in this community to the poor, to the average person or to future development. It has mortgaged this community's future development and, as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) said in his response to the Budget, Australian taxpayers will be contributing $17 a week to pay for the public debt which this Government has increased by 20 per cent this year. It is mortgaging the future to pay for December election promises.

This is a clear demonstration that this Government is committed to unions and not to the general community. That is not at all surprising when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is an ex-President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions , the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) is an ex-ACTU research officer and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) at one time was a union research officer. Is it any wonder that this Government is selling out this community to its sectional union backing? It is not surprising in the least. The National Economic Summit Conference held in this chamber took out of the hands of the elected representatives of the community the management of the Australian economy, putting it squarely in the hands of the union movement and its industrial wing which this Government represents.

That is where this Budget had its origins and they are its credentials. It is a union document which quite clearly ignores the plight of the unemployed and, as I say, mortgages the future to pay for election promises. May I say, too, that it mortgages the future to pay for the first time for the public funding of political parties. Such is the haste of the Government to rush to the polls that we will go to the elections without proper bound electoral rolls being available to the Australian electors. That demonstrates the Government's haste and where its priority lies.

I referred earlier to the rise in the national debt. The national debt has risen by 20 per cent to $46 billion a year and I repeat, as my leader has stated clearly in this House, that it will cost Australian taxpayers $17 a week simply to pay for the interest on the squandering of Australia's future. The election pay-offs do not simply reside in the sectional attitude of the Budget, of the frame-up of the economic future of this country in terms of the accord and the milking of the economy by means other than properly labelled wage increases; they reside also in the paying off of the union movement with conditions especially in relation to the repeal of section 45D of the trade practices legislation. That expresses the width of the Government's obligation to its industrial parent. In this regard it is interesting to see that the Government intends to remove this quite severe discipline on those unions which act outside the law and against the public interest; but, at the same time, its intention is to increase greatly the penalties on the other side of the equation, on the industrial front, and to make the penalties for other offences by companies and company officials much more severe than they are at present.

So the comparison is quite clearly there before the Australian public: Let the unions off, reward them for striking by support for superannuation funds and the like, but clamp down on the other side of the industrial equation and make it harder to run the machinery of companies and production in this community. However, the matter does not rest there in the industrial area. It gets down to individual and personal freedoms. The Canberra Times on 6 June this year carried the reference to Public Service staff being urged to join unions. The article went on to state:
The Public Service Board has told all heads of departments and statutory authorities to encourage staff to join . . . relevant unions.
In another paragraph it stated:

In a memo to all permanent heads and statutory office holders issued on Friday, the board announced it was developing guidelines in consultation with the ACTU which would spell out minimum measures to be taken in providing encouragement of union membership.

I draw the attention of the House to what has happened in South Australia under the State Labor Government. There department heads have been instructed to examine payroll records to see the number of government employees who are paying union dues and they are to advise the respective union managements of who is not paying union dues. That requirement has now been extended to school principals. Are we seeing here, in collusion with the ACTU, an agreement by this Government to do the same nationally as the State Government is doing in South Australia? We can assume that that will be the case if this Government should win the next election. That represents one of the greatest intrusions on personal freedoms that one could envisage-an examination of people's personal pay records to see whether they belong to a union. That is what is in store for the Australian community if this Government should unfortunately win office again in December. This has been followed by quite obnoxious moves, for instance in Victoria where the Government is noted for its compliance with union requirements. Honourable members would all remember with some humour the report of 18 April 1984 which stated:
The Victorian Government yesterday agreed to pay about $200,000-including free concert tickets to workers-to settle a building dispute which was disrupting the final stages of the Arts Centre.

The settlement includes tickets for a family of four for each of the 300 workers, and provision of the concert hall free for the use of unions once a year, probably on Labor Day. This will cost $100,000.

As I said, one would think that is something of a laugh, but in fact it is a reality. As one reporter said at the time, the bus drivers blocked the streets of Melbourne with 600 buses in an industrial dispute but they had no penalties applied to them, yet the trader who traded out of hours in Victoria was fined $ 500,000 under Victorian Government legislation. How dare he offer the public his wares and goods out of hours! What a disruptive influence! It is worth a fine of half a million dollars! But someone can take 600 buses into Melbourne and tie the place up in the costliest of industrial disputes and there is no penalty. These are the standards of this Government which sits opposite and which is, of course, a product of the Labor movement. It is in fact clearly before the Australian people if they have the opportunity to study what this Government is really about, and they will respond at the next election to these facts which show what a low standard this Government adopts in relation to the entire community, and the full width of its responsibilities.

The Labor Party is in fact a three in one Party. At its National Conference 41 members were from the Left, 31 from the Centre Left and 27 from the Right. That is where policy is made. The Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) knows full well, as a long time member of the Labor movement, that what his National Conference passes he must obey, and he would not want it otherwise. In the crucial votes that affect Australia, such as whether Australia will have a limited uranium industry or have none, I think the figure was 44 to 55 votes; the difference being 11. That means that if six people had voted the other way they could have changed the history of Australian development in relation to the uranium industry. The vote was somewhat different in relation to some of the other moves of the Left. It might have got down to 42, but six or seven members of the Conference of 99, voting a different way, could alter the development of this country-not the Ministers sitting opposite on the front bench. The extra- parliamentary members, basically of the union movement, control the development of Australia. They are quite clearly in full control of the events of this Government, as was demonstrated this year at the National Conference. The Left is five or six people away from controlling Australia. This is the Left which would say: 'No American bases, no uranium mining whatsoever'. There are only six of those sorts of people who keep Labor away from Australia's future in those respects. It makes a mockery, of course, of the somewhat humorous reference that 'Bob Hawke is the only thing that stands between Australia and the Australian Labor Party'. He does not stand between Australia and the Labor Party. There are six people unknown in this House, unrepresented here, who stand between the Labor Party and Australia and the Prime Minister will be powerless, if he should win office again, to stop their predatory moves on this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your fear frightens me.

—Well, it does frighten me, I tell the Minister. I am frightened, as so many Australians have been frightened in the past and will be again when the veneer of this Government is ripped away by reality and when they understand that this coming election is simply a fence between the reality of the Left, which has been kept at bay for a short period, and the reality of what will happen after the election when it is unleashed. The Minister for Territories and Local Government can hardly wait to get his leftish policies operating, to get his next National Conference going under another Labor Government and to see that the six vote the other way. He cannot wait. He is well-known for his leftish views. I say this: He is totally honest about his leftish views, which is more than can be said for some of his colleagues. He does not hide his views that Australia should be a socialist state-he does not hide them at all-but his colleagues do and they prate about the control of the Right in the Labor Party in Australia. It is the flimsiest partition against the road to ruin for Australia as regards the sensible management of its economy.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, Australia is at great risk in relation to this Budget because the debt is the main factor which hangs over it all. It is a prospect for this country of great future hardship that the interest must be paid on it. At some stage in the future the Government will have to take out of its revenues the amount to reduce the structural deficit and to repay past borrowings. It is an enormous burden to place on the Australian community, especially for the purposes of this forthcoming election.

The honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling), the previous speaker, talked about the success of the previous Budget last year and about unparalleled growth in the economy. In his replies in this House I believe the Treasurer (Mr Keating ) illustrated his surprise that the economy grew at such a rate last year, greater than he predicted. It provided the Government with opportunities which it has wasted. What has the Government done with this greater than predicted growth? Has it reduced the deficit in any real terms? What has it done? It has taken the fruits of a limited recovery and frittered them away on election promises. At the same time it has ignored the really poor of this community.

This is a peculiar Government in that its leader resents criticism. We remember the very pertinent criticism that the Australian Council of Social Service made of the Budget and the Government's neglect of the unemployed and the underprivileged. What did ACOSS get for its criticism of the Government? It got a virulent reply from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who hates to be questioned on this or any other matter. One only had to hear his response at a Press conference yesterday morning to some reporters who dared question him about something outside of the limited range of matters that were the subject of the conference he had ordered.

This Budget is a document which is quite callously aimed at winning votes for the Government. It is a lead-up to an election which is being held in haste before the Australian people, in the Government's eyes, have the chance to understand what this Government is about. But, above all, it is a document which has been prepared by industrial Labor both in conference and in the Cabinet room . This document is a cover for a union movement which is determined to get out of the economy of Australia a great increase in superannuation and payments for productivity which it believes is another way of increasing wages despite the Government's false claims in relation to the accord.

TALKER.NAME: Mr UREN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—Does the Minister wish to make a personal explanation?

—Yes, I do. The honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) referred in the speech he just made to a fear about what the Left would do if ever it gained control of the Australian Labor Party. In doing that he referred to me specifically as a Left Minister. Might I say that it is sad that a person with his experience and, in some respect, liberal attitudes--
—That is not a personal explanation.
—Order! Will the Minister show where he has been misrepresented?

—I was trying to be a little charitable to the honourable member. The honourable member raised the question of fear. I might say that fear is the last thing in the world that I would refer to. In fact, during my whole time as a Minister--
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I would like to know where the Minister has been misrepresented. I do not want to hear an argument which is simply put up in--
—Order! I ask the Minister to come to the point of his personal explanation.

—The honourable member said that there were fears about the role the Left would play. As a Left Minister-and I have been a member of the Left all my life-I have always acted to achieve a more equitable, a more just and a freer society. I have tried to do this in my role as Minister responsible for the administration of the Australian Capital Territory.
—I take a point of order. The Minister should not be able to argue by way of a personal explanation to combat my speech.
—Order! I think the Minister has finished.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) began his speech by saying that the Budget is a document which sets out to confuse. I would submit to this House that the only people confused about this document are in fact members of the Opposition. That is quite clear from the speech we have just listened to from the honourable member for Boothby. The honourable member hardly considered the Budget at all during his 20-minute address. He spent his whole time discussing his own personal paranoia with the unions and with the Left of the Australian Labor Party. One would get a very positive response if one asked the people in the public gallery or the people out in the streets what they thought about this Budget. The people out there are not confused because they can see the benefits of not only this Budget but also the 17 months of this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget is not a short term, pork barrelling election Budget, as it has been referred to by the Opposition. It is, in fact, just the opposite. It is a Budget with a long term strategy in view to keep on the path of non-inflationary growth in this economy. If members of the Opposition had bothered to look at the entire Budget package, instead of getting bogged down with their own paranoia, they would have discerned that what we have here is a Budget which contributes to the long term strategy of the Hawke Labor Government. That strategy is to promote economic recovery and maintain the standard of living for all Australians. That is why in this Budget we have tax cuts which will ensure the continued success of the accord. That is why this Budget provides major structural adjustments to the corporate tax regime and concentrates on the poorest members of our community.

There has been a tradition in past years, and I think that this tradition was reinforced by the seven years of the previous Government, for any recovery to be put quickly at risk by wage and price outbreaks. That will not happen as a result of this Budget. In fact, just the opposite will be the case. Wage and price pressures will be reduced because of the combined effect of the accord and tax cuts. It appears that the only people in Australia who are opposed to the principles and the results of the accord are members of the Opposition. That is why many of them will not be re-elected in any election, whenever it is held. They have no alternative policies. We have not heard any of those alternative policies put to us by any Opposition speaker, particularly the honourable member for Boothby. This Budget aims to create a climate for profits and investment as well as a rise in the number of jobs created.

I would like to take up the debate on tax cuts and the relative cost of living. Rather than just talk in vague terms, I want to look specifically at the position of a person on average weekly earnings who is supporting a dependent spouse and two children. Although these are the sorts of average Australians about whom we all talk, I do not think that members of the Opposition have actually even met anyone in this category.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one member of the National Party here. There is not one member of the Liberal Party in the chamber.

—Members of the Liberal Party-in fact, all members of the Opposition- are not interested. They have no idea of what ordinary Australians want or what their goals are. For the purpose of comparison I wish to refer to the December quarters in 1983 and 1984. The gross wage in 1982 was $324.80; in 1984 it was $ 370. If one deducts the tax on both of those amounts, adds the family allowance, deducts the Medicare allowances and the net housing interest rates, one finds that the nominal disposable wage for 1982 is $205.91 and for 1984 $255.65. Looking at it then in terms of real disposable wage, and taking into account consumer price index adjustments, we find that in 1984 there is an increase in the amount of money in the pocket of the ordinary Australian family of $21.12 per week. These are specific facts. I am not talking in generalities. I have made an analysis so that the House can see in concrete terms that the Australian people get a benefit from the tax cuts. These tax cuts were promised during the last election campaign and we have delivered on that promise.

SPEECH.PARA: We have not just given the people more money. We have also given them security. We have set the economy on the road to recovery. Jobs are now more secure. There is a regular six-monthly wage indexation adjustment linked to the consumer price index. There are lower interest rates and the first home owner scheme, and the list goes on.

Members of the Opposition have called this Budget an election Budget. Yet, the Government made a tough decision in the Budget-a decision to impose a wine tax. The Opposition was always too scared to introduce it. It was in government for seven years and yet it was not prepared to introduce a wine tax. Yesterday there was considerable debate in this House about the wine tax. There is no doubt that that tax was introduced on equity grounds. Every member of this House must acknowledge that on equity grounds we needed a wine tax. There was a 20 per cent tax on soft drinks, between 80 and 100 per cent tax on beer and even higher rates on spirits. What was happening as a result of that inequity was that there was a drop in beer consumption which was leading to a very significant undermining of the revenue base for government excise on beer. Things were getting distorted principally because of the inequity of not having a wine tax. Is that the sort of decision one makes if this Budget is purely pork-barrelling and purely an election Budget?
Over the last few days I have listened to the Opposition's attack on the Budget and I have tried to work out what alternatives it will present to the people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any?

—All I have been able to discern is that Opposition members attack the union movement, which we have heard here today. Their other prong of attack is to return to the old whipping horse, the Public Service. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), in his address last week at the National Press Club, devoted considerable time in his speech to discussing staff growth in the Public Service. Yesterday he put out another four-page statement taking issue with the size of the Public Service. This is how desperate the Opposition is.

SPEECH.PARA: The people in my electorate of Canberra, where 68 per cent of the work force are public servants, should be warned that, if the Opposition ever happens to gain government again, the first group to be attacked will be the public servants, once again. The old whipping horse would come out and the Opposition would blame the government sector all over again. It has started to do that. The people in my electorate should be warned what to expect if the Opposition ever happens to gain government in this country.

One very constructive area of the Budget that I wish now to discuss is the home and community care package. This three-year cost-shared program will contain a contribution of more than $300m over the first three years. This program focuses on services which will enable aged and disabled persons to stay in their own homes. This is a definite step in the right direction in caring for the aged. One of the glaring needs that I have identified in care for the aged is the need for crisis care-short term care, for example, for recuperation purposes after people come out of hospital or their carers need a rest or a holiday. This new home and community care package addresses this very problem. It also provides a respite care bed subsidy to approved hostels and nursing homes which may have empty beds because of temporarily absent patients. While this initiative does not absolutely solve the feeling of insecurity experienced by many elderly people, it is a definite positive beginning.

There is a myth about the aged, that they are all sick. That is just not true. What we need to do is to look constructively at our policy for the aged. If we look at the statistics from the last census on the problems of the aged, we find that the great proportion of them are healthy and want to live independent lives . We need to change the whole way of thinking about how we care for the aged. Sure, some of them have to go to hostels and some will have to go to nursing homes. But the great majority do not want to do that. That should be a last resort.

What we are doing by this initiative in the Budget is starting to set new directions in care for the aged. As a government we have a responsibility to look into the future. As we, the products of the post-war baby boom, age we will find that there will be an enormous increase in the number of aged people in our community. It would be very remiss of us as a government if we did not start to prepare for that. Many people will say that we have only just started. That is true; we acknowledge that. But it is a start in the right direction. It is a start to provide an environment for care for the aged which is appropriately based on their needs, rather than biases about the image of aged people in our community. This Budget is a beginning. It is a constructive beginning because for the first time it starts to take care for the aged seriously and to plan for the care of the aged in our community.

This Budget is to be recommended to the people in the Australian electorate. It has been extremely well received by almost everyone, except members of the Opposition, and I am quite sure that in the next few months the Australian public will receive the full benefits of this, Labor's second Budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr F.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the last election, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) stated that a Labor government would fulfil its three-year term. This promise, with others, will be broken when we go to the polls later this year. This Government has 16 months to run. What is it frightened of? No doubt it is frightened of the deteriorating economic conditions that lie waiting in the future from the policies brought down by Labor. The cost of this forthcoming election will be millions of dollars which the public will have to pay. The country should not be saddled with this expense at this time. Why does the Government not run the full period, as announced by the Prime Minister prior to the last election?

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget has created a massive problem for the future. It has set the scene for further increases in taxes and in the public debt for next year and the years to follow. It builds up long term commitments which taxpayers of this country will be called on to pay for, not only this year but also in the future. The Budget provides for a high 31 per cent of gross domestic product which clearly indicates the direction that it is taking. It is the highest taxing and spending government of all time. What a record to have! It is the highest living and spending government of all time. It represents a spending increase of 14 per cent in two Budgets and the raising of the tax burden to an all time high, adding nearly as much to the national debt in two years as was added in the previous six years.

The Government claims that the Budget provides tax cuts. This is a complete fabrication because total Budget receipts have increased by 27.9 per cent-the highest level in Australian history. The Government is having a punt on a large increase of pay as you earn receipts of about 10.7 per cent, which is not much more than the expected increase in average weekly earnings. This means storing up bigger problems for the future. Receipts through income tax come to over 53 per cent.

No effort whatsoever has been made to decrease the payment of income tax or to assist the people of this country, the average Australians. This Budget has failed to come to grips with the general community and the need that exists for the restructuring and a full investigation of the taxation system to reduce reliance on personal income tax. Income tax collections represent a high proportion of Budget receipts. This means storing up once again bigger problems for the future.

The Government argues that Medicare should be excluded from calculations of Government spending increases. In this matter the Government's spending has been deceptive. This Government came to power at a time when the economy of Australia was improving as a result of our huge wheat crop, our wool and meat, an improvement in the economy of the United States of America and the results of the wage pause being felt.

No government could have had it better. The United States economy has an effect on Australia. Many of our overseas contracts are written in American dollars. So we are very much affected by the economy of the United States. An improvement in the United States economy helps Australia. That happened when this Government came to power. It could not have had it better.

Seeing that Australia depends on the success of its wheat, wool and meat exports, one would have thought that assistance to primary producers would have been prominent and forthcoming in this Budget. However, there was no mention whatsoever of encouragement. The rural sector is vital to the economy because it contributes to Australia's overseas trade. The only mention of those industries in the Budget was the funding of wool promotion and the developments in financing by the Australian Wheat Board whereby the Wheat Finance Fund is to be wound up and returned to growers in July 1985. Another small item in the Budget referred to the funding of the brucellosis campaign. What about our sheep and cattle industries which, over past years, have brought in millions of dollars of export income? We have just seen the disastrous situation whereby meat export inspection charges have risen by over 200 per cent. This increase has had a serious effect on Australia's being able to compete in world markets. Australia is not the only nation which exports meat. We are up against our neighbour-New Zealand-America, Brazil and many other countries. We should be price competitive with those countries, but we are not because of the 200 per cent increase in meat inspection charges. Australia is the only nation in the world that adopts this attitude. Other nations fund the charges from the general revenue of the country.

These industries should receive a top priority in terms of investigation and financial assistance. Australia is the driest continent in the world. The Budget made no mention of creating or establishing more water resources. This problem should have been brought home to the Government during the last drought which lasted for over three years. That drought created problems not only for the rural industry but also for the Australian economy. The stock supply situation which occurred as a result of the water shortage should have registered with the Government; but, the Government being dominated by city members, no assistance has been forthcoming. What about the Labor members who have country electorates? They did nothing at all to promote with their Government the idea of water resources.

One of the most important employers of labour is the small business sector. This Government has completely ignored assistance to this important area. Ninety -nine per cent of Australian firms employ fewer than 100 people. Small business was not mentioned in the Budget, yet a short while ago our Prime Minister said that his Government was determined to do all it could to help small business realise its immense potential.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a hypocrite.

—Absolutely. Not a thing was mentioned about that in the Budget. It was a hollow promise which was made by the Prime Minister but which has never materialised. This Budget has failed to honour any of the Australian Labor Party pre-election taxation promises to small business. We have seen two Budgets and one mini-Budget in which Labor has ignored small business. Labor promised the full retention of profits to small companies where the funds were to be used for genuine purposes; the option of provisional tax being paid in quarterly instalments; the extension of the time for payment of sales tax from 21 to 30 days; to exempt industrial research grants from tax. Small business has been locked out of this Budget. Small business is a big labour employer in this country. It is a job generator. The Budget does nothing to stimulate growth and create jobs in the small business sector. Small business is giving a lot but is getting nothing back.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Government's decision on the assets test completely ignores the farmers and the small business people of Australia. The cost of administering the assets test will far outweigh any financial gains. It is an intrusion into the private lives of Australians. There will probably be 1,500 bureaucrats travelling around the country, knocking on doors and checking up on the farmers and the small business people of this country. The Australian people should refute and in no way support this measure. No farmer in Australia will be eligible for the pension. He will not be able to make himself eligible because of the re-investment of gift restrictions. The exclusion of the farm home will mean little, as separate from the rest of the farm it has little value. Gifting will be impossible because the restriction of $4,000 per annum is pitiful, particularly as this was the level which applied when it was abolished by the coalition Government in 1976. The farmer or the small businessman will be able to borrow the pension, but it must be repaid, with interest, after death. It becomes a sectional pay as you die death duty. Whoever thought that up. It amazes me and my colleagues. Country people have been completely forgotten. The major contribution made by Australia's farmers and small businesses to the growth of the Australian economy in the last 12 months has been ignored by the Federal Government in the Budget.

Personal income tax will increase by a record 23 per cent. Government expenditure will increase by at least 13 per cent. The Budget deficit will still be too high, with the pressure this creates on interest rates. Government expenditure will reach a higher proportion of national expenditure than occurred in even the worst years when Mr Whitlam was in control. The international competitiveness of our export industries, such as agriculture, will be further affected by the 22 per cent reduction in government assistance for export market development. This is a very serious matter indeed. Livestock farmers will pay more tax with the dramatic 250 per cent lift in the minimum tax value for natural increase to $1 a head for sheep, $5 for cattle and $4 for pigs, at a time when the rural cost price squeeze is intensifying again. The 42 per cent drop in rural adjustment funds to only $18.7m is particularly inappropriate. The further increase in the excise on aviation fuel, the third since Labor came to power, will also disadvantage country people, particularly in the far western regions of the country. Increases in fuel and excises are not shown in the Budget but are real, as they are indexed automatically. Protection from dumped European wine will be reduced by a 10 per cent drop in the tariff as well as the new 10 per cent sales tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Including people in your electorate.

—It will affect very considerably wine growers in the Hunter Valley. The Government continues to ignore the special education needs of country people by increasing the general tertiary education assistance scheme allowance and, more significantly, the living away from home allowance, by only 10 per cent. The secondary student's allowance has been increased by a more realistic 15 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the economic outlook. A comprehensive survey of the economic outlook forecasts that the Government's policies will fail by next year and that both employment and inflation will again be on the increase. That is why the Government is going to the polls this year. It is frightened of the economic situation that will exist in the future by reason of its policies. It is apparent that for this reason the Government is contemplating an early election, either late this year or even early next year. The problem is that as long as it expects to go to the polls early it will not even contemplate the wage moderation needed immediately to breathe life into the recovery in the long term .

It is expected that the annual rate of inflation will rise from 5.4 per cent to 9.2 per cent compared with the average of the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development of 5.7 per cent. Growth in the real gross domestic product will fall from around 5.1 per cent to 1.2 per cent. The unemployment rate will increase from 9.2 per cent to 9.9 per cent, compared with an OECD average of 1.8 per cent. These figures have not been conjured up. They were produced by responsible people who are examining the future economy of this country. The figures suggest that Labor is not fighting inflation and unemployment simultaneously. It is increasing them simultaneously. Clearly, Labor wants an election before its fundamental failure in economic management is revealed.

What is more, the faltering economic recovery is also expected to lead to a massive increase in the 1985-86 Budget deficit in the absence of massive tax increases or significant spending cuts in the August 1985 Budget. Since this is the Budget which will precede the next general election, Labor's desperation to bring forward that election is not hard to understand. Labor's indexation deal with the unions has placed a stranglehold on the economy which is squeezing the life out of our recovery. This stranglehold must be removed if grim forecasts are to be wrong. This is the awful tragedy of Labor's early election speculation . This election is not in the national interest. Labor must put an immediate end to this speculation and get on with making the hard decisions that people expected of it when they went to the polls just over a year ago. The high taxing policy of the Hawke Government is costing the average family $19 a week.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—It is costing $19 a week. Let us look at some of its policies. It abolished the home loan rebate and the health insurance rebate; increased excise duties and sales taxes, and in this field there are automatic increases every six months; introduced a new tax on superannuation payments; made changes to income equalisation deposits which seriously affected rural industries; abolished the 10-year write-off on capital expenditure for land clearing and swamp drainage; introduced an excise on grape spirit used in fortifying wine; abolished the rebate of up to $1,000 on dividends; introduced severe withholding tax on small businesses; made ordinary Australians on average weekly earnings pay 46c on every extra dollar they earn; introduced the one per cent special levy on taxable income for Medicare; and introduced an assets test on pensions. Of course, we hear so much about what the Hawke Government is examining for the future. It is examining the possible introduction of a capital gains tax, a wealth tax, death duties, taxes on job related fringe benefits, resource rent tax, and gift tax. One can name any area and the Government has it in its sights .

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the Medicare levy. The special one per cent levy on taxable income under the Medicare scheme means that most Australians will have more taken out of their wages this year than last. The Medicare levy will mean that the average wage earner will pay 47c in the dollar for every extra dollar earned . Labor's socialised Medicare will prove to be very expensive for most of the community. Those paying more will include many single people, two-income families and most of those who want to retain the same level of health insurance as they previously enjoyed. But when this scheme was first announced in 1982 the levy was to be 0.75 per cent. By the 1983 Federal election it had been increased by 33 per cent to the one per cent levy now being charged on taxable income. Yet it is widely recognised that the present Government will be unable to finance Medicare at this rate for any longer than one year. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) has already foreshadowed an increase in the levy after the coming election. It has been announced by consultants that the levy might be 2.48 per cent within three years if the Government is to cover the full cost of Medicare.

Under Medicare the average family will be about $1 a week poorer if it wants to maintain its previous level of health insurance, and families where the wife works are being hit hardest of all. Previously they could take out cover with the health fund as a family. Now both partners will have to pay the levy. My experience in the Paterson electorate has been that I did not receive a letter about the previous Government's health scheme, but since the introduction of Medicare I have received correspondence which indicates to me that people were happy under our health scheme and they are very unhappy under the present Medicare scheme.

The present Government shows clearly how the health portfolio has suffered because of the prices and incomes accord. Those worst hit are the elderly and the chronically ill. Under the accord Medicare is required to provide free services to many who could afford to take out private insurance, leaving the poor and the elderly waiting in the queues. The Budget is notable for the absence of measures to deal with problems caused by Medicare. No special provision is made for reducing queues of uninsured patients in public hospitals. I understand that in one Victorian hospital there are over 8,000 people in the queue, waiting to receive attention. The hospital reinsurance subsidy was cut from $100m to $20m last year and it remains at $20m for 1984-85. What a considerable reduction. It is a cut in real terms of about 6 per cent.

It is the cut in reinsurance that has forced the health funds to limit the hospital cover of contributors to a set number of days each year. People who have insured privately for years have lost their security. There is no provision for additional nursing home care to cater for those thrown out of hospitals under Medicare's 35-day rule, thus leaving the chronically ill, most of them elderly, with nowhere to go. The long-promised scheme for medicine to the chronically ill has failed to materialise despite continuing promises by the Minister for Health. The $300m home and community care program for the aged and disabled allocates only $10m in new programs. It will not go anywhere near fulfilling any need in this field.
(Extension of time granted)

Within 17 months of taking office-the Hawke Government has nothing to show against election promises of care for the aged and will still have nothing to show by July 1985. Medicare means massive tax increases. The first full year cost of Medicare can now be assessed against the cost of the former health scheme. Medicare benefits and hospital payments have risen from $1,224m in 1982- 83, pre-Medicare, to $3,245 in 1984-85, an increase of $2,021m. Taxes have risen by $2 billion to cover Medicare, a measure of the degree of socialisation involved. It is a socialist piece of legislation and we want to do all we possibly can to meet it. The extent of the tax increase has been disguised by calling $1.2 billion of it a Medicare levy which clearly bears no relation to the cost of the scheme. The accord and Medicare have therefore caused a massive increase in the size of government, a massive increase in taxes and grave inconvenience for the acutely and chronically ill. This Budget dramatises the money costs of Medicare but does nothing to reduce the human cost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with the colleagues of the honourable member for Paterson (Mr O'Keefe) in wishing him well and I was certainly happy to support the extension of time. But the great paradox contained in the remarks of the honourable member, of course, was that if as he asserts the Government is doing so badly one would think that the Opposition would welcome the opportunity of an early election. Of course it would welcome anything but.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise this afternoon to support the Budget. It is, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said a fortnight ago, a Budget which will consolidate and strengthen the economic recovery. The recovery with its strength and diversity is one of the truly great achievements of this Government in the 18 months since it gained office. Under Labor, all the economic indicators have moved in the right direction. All the indicators which ought to have fallen have fallen. The country has enjoyed falling inflation, falling interest rates and falling unemployment. All the indicators which ought to have risen have risen. The country is beginning to prosper after seven dark years with rising confidence, rising investment, rising employment and increasing growth.

It is a record of which this Government is proud, of which the Australian Labor Party is proud and of which the Australian community is proud. It is a record which stands in stark contrast to the Fraser-Howard years. The Liberal record of rising inflation, rising interest rates, rising unemployment, falling business confidence, falling investment, falls in employment and declining growth is a record that will not easily be forgotten by Australians. But great as the achievements of this Government have been much remains to be done. This Budget is another important step back on the road to prosperity and security for all Australians.

The major features of the Budget have, of course, been well publicised and well received. From 1 November all taxpayers will receive a reduction in tax with the largest reductions going to those on lower incomes. Pensions and benefits will rise. Additional help will be provided for pensioners who rent and for pensioners with children. Assistance for children will also go up. Before the next Budget a full scale review of assistance for young people will be undertaken and completed. but in the meantime, the tertiary education assistance allowance will be increased by 10 per cent and allowances under the secondary allowances scheme will be increased by 15 per cent.
