Under both those schemes the family income limit will be increased by 10 per cent. These measures, together with those announced in the Government's guidelines to the education commissions this year and last, will contribute greatly towards the achievement of the Government's objective to increase participation at all levels of education.

The Budget also contains a number of very important measures to assist business and hence, to improve investment and provide new employment opportunities in the private sector. I also support the very sensible changes which have been made to the taxation of alcoholic beverages. In particular, the reduction in tax on light beer should help to change drinking habits and contribute towards a reduced road toll. Across a range of important areas of expenditure assistance will be provided to those most in need and to generate jobs. The Budget provides $430m to new social welfare programs or improvements in existing ones. In a full year these measures will cost $683m. Expenditure on housing is up 21 per cent on last year's figure and by almost 70 per cent on the last Liberal Budget. Expenditure on the first home owners scheme, another important success in this Government's 18 months in office, will rise by 85 per cent. Fifty-five thousand first home buyers were assisted last year under this scheme and a further 80,000 will be assisted in this financial year. The Budget fulfils many of the promises made at the 1983 election. It provides a substantial and lasting cut in income tax, increased social welfare spending and a reduction in the Budget deficit. Above all, it is a budget that will get on with the important job of getting Australians back in jobs. By next June 400,000 new jobs will have been created.

It is against this background of achievement and positive hope for the future that this Government must be judged. I suspect that judgment day may not be too far off. But when that time comes not only the Government but also the Opposition will be judged. One might fairly ask, and indeed the Australian people might fairly ask, just exactly what policies the Opposition has for the last half of the 1980s. One would find few clues in the releases of Opposition policies to date, and even fewer clues in the Budget reply speech of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). But there are enough clues for the Australian people to realise that this is an opposition in crisis, an opposition suffering both a crisis of policy and a crisis of leadership. Its economic policy, when measured against the Government's policy, is a miserable failure. The architects of the $9.6 billion deficit did not have the answers then and they do not have them now. The Opposition's wages policy insofar as it has one, will take us back to high levels of industrial disputation, breakouts in wage increases and massive sackings in industry. Its taxation policy insofar as it has one, will mean massive indirect taxes on ordinary consumers. The aim of this Opposition is the destruction of consensus and the destruction of the accord.

This Budget will improve the lives of people in my electorate and in the western Sydney region, of which it is part. The needs of western Sydney have received proper attention only with Labor in government. Under Liberal governments in the 1960s and 1970s the region might well have never existed. But all this actually changed recently. The Leader of the Opposition actually visited western Sydney. Let me share with the House briefly the report of his visit on page 35 of the Blue Mountains Gazette of Wednesday, 29 August. It is headed 'Federal Opposition Discovers West'. The article describes a meeting between the Leader of the Opposition and the Chairman of the Western Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils, WSROC. What follows in a fairly long article is really a series of questions without answers.

The Chairman of WSROC, Alderman Kluin, asked the Leader of the Opposition for a number of assurances. He sought an assurance that the Leader of the Opposition would support, for example, the inquiry into local government finances currently being undertaken within the area of responsibility of my honourable friend the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren). There was no answer from the Leader of the Opposition. The Chairman ask the Leader of the Opposition whether he would continue to support initiatives such as the community employment program which is so important in the west. There was no response, according to the article, from the Leader of the Opposition. The Chairman stressed to the Leader of the Opposition that access to post-secondary education is very important to the region. He sought an assurance that the Leader of the Opposition would support this as well-no answer. He was questioned on child care and asked whether he would support the initiatives of this Government on child care in the region. There was no response from the Leader of the Opposition. The only response that the article contains from the Leader of the Opposition was a brief statement at the end when Mr Peacock said it was his desire to acquaint himself with the needs of the residents in western Sydney and described it as a unique part of Australia.

After that effort, the Leader of the Opposition can be assured that the region will not be unique in returning the majority of Labor members after the next election. It will certainly return Labor members in the three new seats created in that region. His visit, clearly designed to convey an appropriate measure of concern combined with maximum personal publicity, failed dismally on both counts . But I would not want honourable members to think that the Leader of the Opposition has been totally inactive over the recess. He has been busy in fact with a direct mail campaign. One of my constituents passed it on to me recently. It is a three-page letter accompanied by a rather crude, nevertheless interesting, leaflet. The letter begins with the customary litany of half truths about the achievements of this Government and then it quickly gets around to its main point. I quote:
I'll not beat around the bush
says the Leader of the Opposition-
Right now what I need urgently is the most generous donation you can afford . . .
You and I both know we can't leave the election to chance . . .
I'm not going to pretend it's going to be easy-far from it.

It's going to take all our resolve, but I know from your record you're not a quitter and that you'll be with us all the way. That's why I've gone ahead planning a pre-election campaign in the belief that you'll once again give your support.

That, of course, is the advertising campaign launched on the weekend. The Sydney Morning Herald called it beating the election rush, but I think it is more a case for the Opposition of getting the pain over quickly. According to the Liberals' Federal director, they are foreswearing what he calls the blitzkreig campaigns of the past. Blitzkreig campaigns they were indeed, but no one ever accused the Liberals of not moving with the times. But where is the money coming from for this campaign, to finance this feast of television that we have had since the weekend? The answer is in the Leader's letter. Let me return to it. There is a bit more news from the bunker. The Leader says:

Right now I have to get the funds to begin our campaign. My Strategy Committee is convinced a programme of DIRECT COMMUNICATION is essential if we're to get our message straight to the voters in the electorates-and that's Phase 1 of our strategy . . .
In short, we're going direct and that's the programme I'm asking you to fund.
At the bottom of the letter he says:

P.S. While I wish you could all visit Parliament House at Budget time that's obviously impossible so I have asked my Committee to consider ways of three couples to be present on Budget night as our special guests.
On page 3 of the leaflet, here is the offer. The heading is: 'A Truly Unique Experience'. It says:
Feel the heartbeat of Parliament House on Budget night as the special guests of Andrew Peacock and the Liberal Party.
Three lucky couples will win an all expenses paid trip to one of the world's exciting cities at its most exciting time.
2 days and one night in Canberra staying at the Lakeside all expenses paid
V.I.P. tour of Canberra and its historic sites
special gallery passes for the Budget debate
dinner in Parliament House on Budget night
special Budget briefing
luncheon cruise on Lake Burley Griffin with Margaret Peacock
visit the Federal Secretariat for campaign run-down.

You and a companion could win this exciting trip simply by supporting Andrew Peacock's campaign. Complete the coupon and post it together with your donation of $30 or more in the envelope provided by Friday, 17th August.
We have heard it all now. It is obviously going to be a raffle led recovery as far as the Liberals are concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who won?

—I do not know. But this device raises some serious questions. Along with other members, from time to time I have arranged seats in the gallery for visiting constituents, friends and groups but I have never been under the impression that seats in the galleries in these places were up for sale or could be raffled. I am concerned that a privilege of this nature, which is extended by the House and by the Speaker, should actually be put up for raffle by the Opposition. Imagine the spectacle if honourable members with tickets to the gallery for Budget night were able to go out into King's Hall and scalp them- sell them off to the highest bidder. I regard it as a highly improper practice and it is a matter which I will be pursuing.

SPEECH.PARA: In closing, let me leave this increasingly bereft and crisis-ridden Opposition with its crises of policy and its crisis of leadership. Like its forebears, the Liberal Party in 1984 has turned a deaf ear to the demands of ordinary people. This Budget meets those needs; it builds on the Government's fine record and it is another step on the road towards national recovery and reconciliation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity of participating in this budget debate. Far from sharing in the eulogies which have been delivered about the budget, most recently by the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Free), I do not believe it is an exaggeration to say that this Budget could well mark the turning point in the political and economic fortunes of this Government. It is no exaggeration to say that over the last 18 months on the propaganda front, this Government has got away with murder so far as the economy is concerned. It has received credit for doing things that it opposed when it was in opposition; it has received credit for improvements in the economy that would have occurred irrespective of which party had been in power; and, most importantly of all, it has lived off a lie about an inherited Budget deficit which the passage of time and analysis of facts has demonstrated to have been one of the most dishonest pieces of propaganda that has been perpetrated on the Australian public in economic debate in recent years.

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget represents the high water mark in taxation collections and expenditure of any Budget brought down by any government since the end of World War II. It is the largest spending Budget since World War II, accounting for 31. 1 per cent of gross domestic product on government spending. It provides for the largest taxation collections of 27.9 per cent since the end of World War II, and that is recorded on page 364 of Budget Paper No. 1. It provides for a deficit of $6.7 billion which follows the deficit of almost $8 billion delivered in Mr Keating's first Budget. That compares with the largest deficit under the Fraser Government of $4.3 billion and demonstrates beyond any doubt that the nonsense, the lies and the dishonest statements that have been peddled around this country about the fiscal inheritance of this Government represent nothing other than a smokescreen and a disgraceful excuse for the repudiation of so many of the Government's election promises.

This Budget demonstrates again that Labor governments have no stomach for expenditure restraint. It provides for an increase in spending in real terms of 6.1 per cent. That is over and above inflation. Spending this year will go up by 6.1 per cent and that follows last year when the increase was some 7.7 per cent. The rate of increase in government spending under this Government is running at treble the rate of increase in government spending under the Fraser Government. In seven years the average rate of increase in spending under the last government was just over 2 per cent in real terms. Under this Government it is running at more than treble that rate. So on both the budgetary counts, that is big spending and big taxation, this is a Budget that beats all its predecessors and indisputably stamps the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the long tradition of Labor Treasurers, that is one who believes in big government and big spending. So much for his credentials as somebody who represents a break with the long Labor tradition in government of high spending and high taxation.

The most important thing about this Budget, and why it does, in my opinion, mark the turning point in the political and economic fortunes of the Government, is that it is built upon an occurrence that cannot possibly be repeated next year. This Budget is built upon a temporary, once only, increase in revenue collections due to unusual fortuitous circumstances which everybody and most of all the Treasurer, knows cannot be repeated next year. It provides for an increase of no less than 10.5 per cent in total taxation collections in real terms. In other words, after inflation taxation collections this year will go up by 10.5 per cent, and that is not only after inflation, it is also after that tax cut that Mr Keating and the Prime Minister keep telling us about. The figure of 10.5 per cent is the largest increase in real terms in revenue collections of any Budget in Australia since the end of World War II. It contrasts most sharply with an increase last year of 1.9 per cent, a decline in revenue collections in the previous year of 1.9 per cent, and increase of 4.5 per cent, 7.2 per cent, 2 .2 per cent, 1.2 per cent and so on over the last 10 years.

This Budget stands out like the proverbial sore thumb so far as revenue collections are concerned, and that is due to one special, unique factor. Due to the breaking of the drought there has been a massive surge in collections of provisional taxation from farmers and other provisional tax payers. This year provisional tax collections will go up by no less than 44.7 per cent, which is staggering, astronomical increase which cannot conceivably be repeated next year , the more so because the Bureau of Agricultural Economics has forecast a fall of 30 per cent in farm incomes next year.

This Government, in plain, simple language, after giving a tax cut of $1.3 billion, has still enjoyed, as a result of this temporary surge in revenue collections, an additional revenue take of $9 billion. With that $9 billion it has provided a nominal reduction in the deficit of $1.2 billion and in plain, direct language it has spent the rest. It has done the worst possible thing economically, from a long term point of view, that it could possibly have done with this temporary revenue surge. Instead of recognising that the revenue surge was once-only, freakish and not to be repeated next year, instead of doing the prudent, provident, sensible thing by putting it aside against a change in circumstances next year it has gone ahead in the traditional, profligate Labor manner and spent it. It has created an enormous budget problem for next year.

As I said in my remarks on the sales tax Bills the other night, with a $9 billion surge in revenue collection, a Treasurer would have had to be a mug not to have been able to bring about some reduction in the deficit. For the Treasurer to run around the country saying what a great economic manager he is because he has achieved a reduction of $1.2 billion in the deficit when he had $ 9 billion to play with is really to stretch the credulity of the business community and the Australian public. He does not tell them that he has spent the other $7.8 billion. He does not tell the Australian public that he has locked this country into expenditure patterns next year that will present us with an enormous budgetary problem.

Next year only three options will be available to the Government of the day. The first option will be to cut expenditure and we all know darn well, on the basis of this Government's track record, every time it has occupied the treasury benches, that it has no stomach for cutting expenditure. Is the Government really telling us that next year, if it is re-elected, it will take the axe out to all those expenditure programs it has committed itself to in this Budget? Will it tell us over the next two or three months that it will cut education expenditure for example? It is boasting about how it is going to increase it. Government members are running around the country saying what great people they are, because they have committed themselves to an irrevocable education program. Are they going to tell the local government associations of Australia that they will cut general revenue grants to local government? Are they going to tell the people who want more money spent on roads that they will cut that? No, they are saying quite the opposite. The Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) was in here earlier today saying how much they had increased it and boasting about his Government's record. Are they going to tell us that they will cut expenditure on health when it has gone up 80 per cent in the two Budgets that the Treasurer has brought down?

Any suggestion that this Government will have a stomach for expenditure restraint if it is re-elected goes right out the window. This idea that in some way if the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer are re-elected at the end of the year, once they have an election behind them, we will really see some action on the spending front is not true. The honourable member for Melbourne ( Mr Hand) knows that that is not true and he is grinning approval at the comment that I am making about the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. He knows darn well that if the Labor Party wins the next election the left wing of the Labor Party will demand an even more expansionary--

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the Illawarra paper said about you, you are a liar.
—Order! I ask the honourable member for Melbourne to withdraw.
—I withdraw the statement that he is a liar but I will repeat that the Illawarra paper said that he tells lies, lies, lies.
—Order! The honourable member will withdraw unqualifiedly.
—I withdraw unqualifiedly.

—Any suggestion that, in some way, if the Government wins the election , it will be brave about expenditure restraint is a whole lot of nonsense. If anybody imagines that I am gilding the lily in saying that, let me just remind the honourable member of what one of his colleagues said. He was not part of his faction either.
—Which faction?

—He was not one of the alleged big spenders. He was not part of the Left faction. This was none other than that friendly, avuncular, kindly Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones). He had some real gems to tell us on the World Today program, three days after the Budget. I can promise the member for Melbourne, the Prime Minister and the Minister that this quotation of his will really do the rounds over the next three months. If ever a quotation gave this Government away, it was the remarks of Mr Barry Jones on the World Today program, a bare three days after the Budget Speech. I ask honourable members to listen because he said it better than I could ever possibly say it. Out of the mouth of a centre-lefter or whatever he is came this absolute gem. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: What I say; if you are talking about a 3 year Parliament-
and if the Government gets re-elected, that is what it would have-
without any possibility of an early election-
surely the Prime Minister, if re-elected, would not twice break his promise about parliaments running their full term; surely he would not do it twice, having done it once-
it means that in 3 year parliaments, you can spend money . . .
Whacko, we can hear him licking his chops. He said:

. . . you can spend money; you can raise money, perhaps by increasing taxation, or finding new sources of taxation to do things that are expensive that you would not be game to do, you would not be keen to do 3 or 4 months before an election.

Well, if Barry Jones is prepared to say that, we can imagine what the honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) and the other really big spenders in the Labor Party would want the Government to do if the Government were re-elected. It is beyond argument, that, if this Government is re-elected next year, the first of the options that are available-and that is cutting expenditure-simply will not be on.

The next option that is available would be to live with an unbelievably large deficit. Surely one would hope that in the unfortunate event that the Government were re-elected it would not go to that. We would be facing a deficit far larger than this year. The effect on the expectations of financial markets, interest rates and business confidence generally would be very bad indeed if a re-elected government were to do that. Next year the full year effect of the discretionary spending promises of the Government in this Budget and the taxation cut will amount to an addition to the deficit potentially of $4 billion. Presumably, even in its wider moments, it would not want to do that. That really brings us back to the reality that people face if this Government is re-elected this year-the reality that Barry Jones, the Minister for Science and Technology, was quite honest and candid about. He said that the Government will not be game to put up taxation three or four months before an election, but with an election behind it it will put up taxation so it can spend more. That is exactly what will happen next year. That is the only way.

If this Government is re-elected, there is no way on earth that it will be able to manage the economy other than by massive increases in taxation because next year it will not have a 44.7 per cent increase in provisional taxation collections. Next year it will not have the largest increase in taxation collections that this country has had since the end of World War II. We only break a drought once. We do not break it twice and next year the Government will not have the benefit of that temporary surge in collections of provisional taxation and, of course, this Government will resort to even higher taxation. Barry Jones has told us and whatever one thinks about his politics one can never doubt his integrity. No wonder he was dragged into that corner office. No wonder the Prime Ministerial finger was wagged at him. No wonder he was told to keep quiet and to leave economic statements to the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins). But I can tell the Prime Minister that we will not let the memory of Barry Jones's Budget litany be forgotten. We are going to hear a lot about Jones on the economy between now and the end of the year. Jones on the economy will become almost as famous as Friedman on the economy between now and the end of the year. What he really did in that candid honest way was to bring home to the Australian people just what will happen if the Hawke Government is re-elected.

Not only do I regard this Budget as representing something of a turning point in the economic and political fortunes of this Government but also I draw the House's attention once again to a very, erudite article by Maximilian Walsh in the Sydney Morning Herald of 1 September. Mr Walsh has certainly not been some kind of uncritical supporter of the economic policies of the Opposition-far from it. So he comes to this subject with some objectivity and some real credentials. It is an article that is headed 'The beginning of the end for the Hawke Government'. The most telling paragraph in this article states:

It is not too melodramatic to say that the second Keating Budget could well mark the beginning of the end of the Hawke Government. It can certainly be said that Hawke and Keating blew an opportunity in the Budget-an opportunity which may not come their way again.
Overnight they moved from being invincible to being opportunistic, expedient politicians.

That in many ways says it all. What he was drawing attention to was the thing that I have drawn attention to and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has drawn attention to from the very moment the Budget was brought down. It is a vote now pay later Budget. It is a Budget that is built upon an opportunistic approach to a temporary change in revenue fortunes. It is a Budget that next year the Australian community will pay very dearly for. Next year the average Australian will have to pay the cost of this year's political expediency. Next year the Australian public will bear the burden of the choice that will have to be made between those three options. Anybody who has studied the long history of the Australian Labor Party, both in government and in opposition, will know that it will not exercise expenditure restraint. We can guarantee that all of the expenditures that have gone up this year will go up again next year-for example, the 82 per cent increase in expenditure for the Human Rights Commission; the 40 per cent increase in expenditure on Medicare; the $300m increase, 15 per cent in real terms, in the Department of Administrative Services vote. That is a 15 per cent increase in real terms for public servants.

Does anybody imagine that next year this Government, if it is re-elected, will screw up the courage to do the things that it has been unwilling to do this year and last year? Of course it will not. The only option, the only alternative that the Government will have is, of course, the high tax, wealth tax, capital gains tax and perhaps death duty option. It will be left with absolutely no alternative but that. If one wants any evidence of that one has to go back to the remarks of the Minister for Science and Technology. He has nailed his colours to the mast. He said that what the Government ought to do if it gets back and while it has three years in front of it for people's memories to be dulled and fade, so that they can forget, is to jack up the taxes. It is as simple as that. It will jack them up so that it can spend a lot more. He has been saying that to his scientific lobby. No doubt he has been saying: 'Look fellows, science is not very sexy three months before a budget. There are a lot of other things that are far more important but if we win the election and we get that election behind us we will jack up everybody's taxes so we can spend a lot more'.

That is the message that comes to the Australian people from this Budget. It is not a budget of economic responsibility. Any mug Treasurer could have achieved a reduction in the deficit of $1.2 billion when he was collecting $9 billion extra in tax. He would have to be a terribly incompetent Treasurer not to achieve some kind of reduction in the Budget deficit. It is in every sense of the word an expedient, politically motivated, vote now pay later Budget but the payment will certainly come later and it will be borne by the broad shoulders of the Australian people and they will not like it in any sense, shape or form next year and they will wreak political vengeance on this Government whether it sits in the Treasury benches or where it belongs on the opposition benches.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand Mr G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). He has said that any Treasurer could have reduced the deficit but he had seven years and he blew it as no one else has ever done. In fact, just before the last election he was a couple of billion dollars out in his arithmetic. So I think he ought to learn a few basic areas of arithmetic and maths before he starts lecturing us.

SPEECH.PARA: The second Budget of the Government, the one which I am certain will be followed by many more, provides a continuing framework for improving the economic conditions and living standards of the vast majority of Australians. It is a Budget which has been framed within the wider economic policy of the Government, a policy built around providing for economic recovery and the development of a strong, stable, economic infrastructure after what can only be considered as the worse recession in this country since the 1930s. That was led by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

When Labor came into power in March 1983 186,000 people had lost their jobs in the preceding year. In Labor's first year 194,000 jobs were, in fact, created. In our first 15 months of office we have created in excess of a quarter of a million jobs and forecasts indicate that we will keep our election promise of creating 500,000 jobs within a three-year period. As a consequence, Australia's unemployment rate has turned the tide. In July 1984 unemployment was down to 8.8 per cent of the labour force compared with the frightful rate of 10.3 per cent at the end of the 1983 financial year. The Labor Government has been able to lift the shroud hanging over an ever-increasing number of Australians who have had to suffer the consequences of the pathetic excuse for economic policy which the Fraser-Howard duo handed out.

I would be the last person to suggest that our current unemployment rate is what it ought to be or that it is acceptable to the community. It should be zero . I am sure honourable members opposite would agree with that, even though they do not show much sympathy for the workers of the Borthwick company. Providing jobs for all Australians who are unemployed is and must continue to be the first priority for the Government and I believe we are off to a strong start. In terms of other economic indicators there is ample evidence that our economic policy is working as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) informed the House and the Australian people on Budget night last week. He said:
In the year between the June quarters 1983 and 1984, economic growth was over 10 per cent-the best performance in the 25 years for which quarterly accounts have been compiled.

Inflation fell to 6.5 per cent and is continuing to decline. This compares with the 11.2 per cent inflation rate of the last year of the Fraser Government, an inflation rate which was spiralling upwards, not downwards, when we became the Government. Let us remember the devastating effects of the previous Government's attempts to control inflation. Its policy not only failed but also in its implementation it caused massive hardship and despair for so many Australians. By contrast, Labor's successful assault on inflation has been made primarily through the highly successful prices and incomes accord, an instrument which far from bludgeoning the working classes has provided a framework for maintaining living standards via a number of interrelating mechanisms.

In addition, interest rates have fallen, housing remains buoyant and private sector investment has picked up. The Budget is based on the continuation of those economic trends. It is structured around maintaining expenditures initiated in our first Budget, which provided a much needed physical stimulus to the economy. This will be the first full year of the creation of many of those initiatives. Programs such as the community employment program, Medicare, the first home owners scheme and social welfare increases are all areas of government outlays which have had a direct beneficial impact on the community at large. In addition, the Government has introduced a number of new measures in the Budget and, at the same time, has honoured its commitment under the accord to provide income tax relief while also lowering the deficit.

Having addressed myself to the general economic environment created by this Government, via the Budget and other tools of economic policy, I now turn to the question of particular interest to me and that is the redistributive effect of the Budget. This must surely be one of the most important aspects of budgetary policy, although it was never high on the agenda of the Opposition when it sat on this side of the House. Redistribution of income and wealth for it meant only one thing-the rich in this country were handed an ever increasing share of the cake and the gap between the haves and the have nots grew wider and wider. The Government has made a start in reversing that trend. Via the Budget process a number of mechanisms have been employed. These include increased expenditures in the areas which will directly affect those people most in need, the targeting of assistance to specific groups in the community, a reordering of the Budget priorities and, lastly, the abandonment of a number of programs established by the Opposition and changes to the taxation system.

Let me mention some of the redistributive measures of the Budget in more specific terms. Social security and welfare benefit payments will increase by a projected $1.3 billion in the year 1984-85. While most of the increase is cyclical in nature an additional $400m available for new measures will benefit recipients in most areas of need such as the aged, the unemployed, single parent families, disabled people and the homeless. I am sure that everyone on this side of the House would join with me in saying that we would have liked to have seen those benefits increased even more substantially and to have come closer to our commitment to raise pensions to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. However, the constraints placed on us by the previous Government's mishandling of the economy have not allowed us to do that this year. It is interesting to look at the taxation system via the bottom of the harbour schemes. The people on the other side of the House and the Australian Democrats in the other place four times prevented that legislation passing. It would have brought to the Treasury coffers approximately $500m in revenue. That would have been of great assistance to the people in need in this country. Opposition members stand condemned for their support of people who have exploited the tax system over the years.

Even with the limited resources available, this Government has been able to do more for the needy in the 18 months it has been in office than the previous Government did in its entire term of office, seven years. Not only has the Government increased pensions since coming to office, but also it has made structural changes to the basis of those payments. The gap between people on this single unemployment benefit and those receiving other forms of benefits and pensions, has, in fact, been narrowed, thus providing more favourable and more equitable allocation of benefits. Significant measures introduced in the Budget to help those most in need include removal of the discriminatory practices against 16 and 17-year-olds with dependants; a 50 per cent increase in the supplementary pension assistance paid to pensioners and long term sickness beneficiaries who are caught in the private rental market trap; a 16.6 per cent increase to families receiving the family income supplement and raising of income limits under FIS so that more people can benefit; a 55 per cent increase in expenditure over 1983-84 for children's services and child care centres; the expansion of community-based care programs for the aged and disabled via a $10m home and community care program provided jointly by the Departments of Social Security and Health; a 15 per cent increase to improve and expand supported accommodation services for young people, women and the chronically homeless.

The other aspect of the Budget I want to emphasise, from the perspective of having a redistributional effect, is taxation. In our first year we have introduced a number of changes to the taxation system to make it more equitable and fair. Measures in the last Budget in respect of tax avoidance, sales tax, excise and superannuation lump sums all had this effect. This year we have introduced a number of new measures which will also serve to make the taxation system more equitable by easing the burden on the pay as you earn wage and salary earners. The most significant taxation measure in this Budget is the personal income tax cuts to take effect from 1 November 1984. In conjunction with the tax cuts the Government has extended the personal income tax rate scale to five steps. Other changes to rebates effectively raise the tax threshold to $ 4,783 for single beneficiaries and $7,898 for married beneficiaries on unemployment, sickness and special benefits and also substantially raise the tax threshold for pensioners.

The income threshold below which the Medicare levy is not payable has also been raised from $7,100 for single persons and $11,803 for couples. At the other end of the income scale the maximum levy payable has been increased to $750. Thus, while the greatest taxation cuts in monetary terms may not be going to the lowest income earners, the effect of these and other measures is that in percentage terms the lowest income earners in our community have had the greatest reduction in taxation. The combined effects of tax and social security arrangements in the 1984-85 Budget have redistributed income from those in the top bracket of income earners, those earning in excess of $35,000, and those on salaries below $20,000 have benefited most from the Budget. Let us be quite clear about this. The net effect of tax cuts is to provide substantially more benefits for income earners on salaries between $7,000 and $20,000 than tax indexation would have. Equally, the measure provides substantially less benefits for income earners on $35,000 and upwards than tax indexation would have.

Far from being phoney, as the Opposition Leader so weakly tried to suggest, the taxation measures introduced in this Budget will be of direct benefit to the majority of Australians on low incomes and that is where we have to start. Moreover, these measures should be seen in their proper context as interim measures introduced prior to the review of the total tax system which will take place next year. They should also be seen in the context of the Government's honouring of the accord which called on the Government to restructure substantially the income tax scale to ease the burden on low and middle income earners. The measures introduced in the Budget have set the process in train. Likewise, this Budget has gone a considerable way towards meeting the social wage aspects of the accord.

I turn my attention now to Medicare which in this Budget comprises the largest single item of government expenditure. Since its introduction on 1 February 1984 , Medicare has proved to be an extremely efficient and highly successful scheme of universal medical and hospital insurance which has benefited all Australians, particularly those two million or so who were previously in no person's land, unable to afford private insurance, just praying that they did not become ill. I believe it is a great credit to the Government that Medicare was introduced as swiftly and as smoothly as it was and that under this Government all Australians are now entitled to basic hospital and medical care without fear or favour.

In concluding, I would like to say that while I welcome the initiatives taken in this Budget which have begun the process of income redistribution, it is imperative that we not lose sight of the fact that there is still a long way to go. In this place it is all too easy to obliterate the real world from our minds , to become cut off from the people we are here to represent. But I remind all honourable members that is exactly what we are supposed to do here, represent all people within the community. In my electorate of Melbourne one does not have to look very hard to see poverty, not just isolated pockets, but widespread areas of great hardship and need. Much of that poverty can be attributed, I believe, to the heartless, economic, fiscal policies of those men and women on the other side of the political arena. When in Government they were blind to the needs of those least able to defend themselves in our society. Since coming to office we have been able to offer some hope and concrete assistance to those people. I look forward to that continuing in future Labor Budgets which I am sure will be brought down for many years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to enter the debate. Of course, one listens with interest to the remarks of the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand), who has his ideology and philosophy. He adheres to it and follows it strictly, and of course, he throws bricks at people who may think differently.
—I never mentioned you.

—No, the honourable member did not mention me specifically; but he says that we do not care for the sick and aged, and so on. One could refute that and debate it with him. However, as regards Budgets, we were in government seven years, and I remember speeches from honourable members from the other side against the Fraser Budgets, and they were pretty hard and hard hitting, and condemning most of the time. I have been listening to most of the speeches and analysing what has been occurring out in the open arena about the handing down of this Labor Budget. Most people are really worried only about what concerns them. They analyse what is going to happen to their pay packet and what will happen to the amount of money that they have to spend. I suppose that that, in essence, is what a Budget is all about-budgeting and trying to determine how much one has to spend after one pays one's accounts and bills, et cetera.

SPEECH.PARA: I have spoken to many people recently, and some think that the Budget has been good for them, but others have been very strong in their condemnation because it does not do anything for them. But that is what we are about. As politicians, we have to tune in to what our people think about certain things and then air their grievances, and, if one can, the praise that is necessary. I suppose that I thought to myself, 'Bruce, you can join in and start hammering and bashing away and doing this and that, and a few people outside might listen to it', but most of the people that I represent are just ordinary average people who have money with which to pay their accounts and who have all the other problems associated with most electorates in Australia. The honourable member for Melbourne says that we do not care for the poor and the needy.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't.
—I just do not think that is correct. We do care, and we deal with them from day to day.
—Why did you let their conditions deteriorate in such a manner?

—We did not allow them to deteriorate. It was difficult. Incidentally, the ones that I deal with at the moment that are poor and needy have not seen any real improvement after the Labor Party has been in government for two years; they have not seen anything at all. I heard the speeches earlier today about the aged and the sick, et cetera, and the big deal for them. It has all just happened now, as if to say no one in the past has ever thought about the elderly, the aged and the sick and their problems. I can assure the honourable member than many have, and many have been very concerned about them, and many also have not tried to politicise that section. But it can be easily politicised; there are people that want to politicise it, and that is what happens. Honourable members talk about the increase in the age pension. It is not very real and it is not very great, and it will not assist most of the pensioners that I know. So let us not get carried away with what Labor members have done in their Budget for the aged, the sick and the elderly, and goodness knows what else, and for the people who are poor and needy. They have not done very much at all. They make some glib remarks about it, but we will leave it to the people to judge for themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: I have an opportunity today to talk about the capital works program. First, in respect of that matter, I would like to pay great tribute to what occurred when the Fraser Government handed down its Budget. There were three Ministers concerned from Tasmania-the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Groom) and the honourable member for Bass (Mr Newman). When I have made comparisons with what the Hawke Government has allocated to Tasmania, I have seen just exactly how much influence those three had and what work they did for Tasmania. It saddens me to think that we are losing two of them, the honourable member for Bass and the honourable member for Braddon. The honourable member for Bass has not been well for quite a few months , but, in his normal tenacious way, he has fought on and represented the people of Bass in a most diligent way, dealing with all their day to day problems. One has only to talk to the people of Launceston to realise that he is very well respected in every regard. He fights hard, and he will be a sad loss to the House of Representatives and to the people of Tasmania. The people of Tasmania should remember what he did and the influence that he had on the Fraser Government during those seven years. A lot of people have said that there has been a fair bit of pork barrelling in Tasmania to keep seats, et cetera, but that is just not true.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would not be true. You would not approve of that.

—No, I would not agree with that. But they fought very hard to get an allocation of the Budget, and they got it. The people of Tasmania should be indebted, first, to the honourable member for Bass. Now I turn to my good friend the honourable member for Braddon, who, again, was another good Minister. I think that he got raw treatment from the Fraser Government. When he lost his ministry, I could not believe it. I do not think that many people realised the work that he did. He worked in a very hard electorate. Braddon electorate is a difficult one to work. He did it diligently and conscientiously, and he was respected by everybody. That is why his vote went up each time. Also he is an extremely capable person. I am very, very sorry to think that he is not standing again, for extreme personal reasons. His wife has just had another child-number six in the family-and Ray Groom, only a young man, has decided to give away all the flowery and nice things about parliament, et cetera, to lead a normal life of being a father. I applaud him. He has made a very courageous decision. Many would not make it, because we think that this is a great life. But anyway, Ray has done that. I wish him all the very best. He should be very proud of what he did for Tasmania in the allocation of funds to Tasmania in the previous Fraser Budgets.

SPEECH.PARA: The people of Tasmania just have to look at what was allocated. For example, in the year 1982-83, $35.7m was allocated to Tasmania, providing work opportunities for people that have found it very difficult to get jobs there and, of course, building materials and all the other things that flow from that. But these were the gentlemen-the honourable member for Braddon, the honourable member for Bass, and the honourable member for Denison, too, with his portfolio as a Minister-who all did a good job in making certain that funds were allocated to Tasmania. I believe that that is the function of a politician-to work for his electorate, to work for the people that vote for him, and to try and get the best deal that he possibly can. That is what we tried to do. I am sorry that they are not standing again. They would both retain their seats very easily, because they are so greatly respected in Tasmania. But they can feel very proud of what they did for their State. They can also feel very proud of the job that they did on the floor of this House, because they have gained the respect of all honourable members.

I come to a good thing in the Budget-the $25m that has been allocated for the new vessel that will ply between the north of Tasmania and Melbourne. That will be a great asset to the people of Tasmania, and most people, of course, are pleased about it. And I am trying to be fair about the Budget. They are very pleased with that, because that is another way that Tasmania can be opened up and people from the mainland can come across and see what a beautiful island it is. The tourist industry will boom. We desperately need jobs in Tasmania at the moment. Unemployment is running at about 10 per cent to 11 per cent. We have all tried desperately to provide jobs for people that cannot get a job, and this allocation of funds is a positive step. I am not going to argue about where the vessel started from, but it will be a good vessel for Tasmania. It will be of great help to the people of Tasmania, and I applaud that item in the Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tourism. For jobs, better than dams.

—Tourism is terribly important to Tasmania. The honourable member raised the point about the dam. Just let me tell him that at the next election, although he may think that the dam issue has been forgotten, it will not have been forgotten. It will be resurrected. It is fermenting in Tasmania. People are not saying very much about it, but they still feel very strongly about, first, the dam, and, secondly, the fact that the present Labor Government trod very hard on the people of Tasmania, and made a decision that we believe was an incorrect decision. The honourable member brought up the subject of the dam, and he is a pretty fair fellow. It will be an issue at the next election. We shall certainly resurrect it, so do not let anyone say that we will not do so.
—There are more jobs in tourism, Bruce.
—You will resurrect it.

—Of course; I will resurrect it. I will do it on every street corner , so do not worry about that. But that $25m will be a great asset to the people of Tasmania. It should bring more people from this big mainland to the little isle of Tassie to see what it is all about, to see what the people are like, and , for once in their lifetime, to see a gem, which is what they will see. So that will be great, and we appreciate that in the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: But honestly, what about the $3.5m that this Government has allocated for capital works in Tasmania in this Budget? It is trying to tell the people of Tasmania that it can win seats down there. The Labor Party definitely will not win seats in Tasmania with an allocation like that, because I assure the House that people are making comparisons in Tasmania now. They are saying: 'What did we get from the Fraser Government, and what are we getting from this Hawke Government?' They are making those comparisons, and let me repeat that, at the next election, the Labor Party will find out the reasons why it will not win a seat in Tasmania. With its re-distribution it thinks that it will get rid of one or two members, but it will not. We will be back again, and we will be telling the people of Tassie that just because Mr Hawke hates us and gives us only $3.7m --

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! 'The Prime Minister', thank you.
—I am sorry. Just because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) hates us, took away certain rights that we believed in--
—What?
—On the dams issue, the State rights issue.
—Order! The honourable member for Calare is going to speak next. I think he had better save his powder.
—I do not mind a few interruptions. It is good.
—The High Court had something to say about that. Are you a lawbreaker now?
—One could say something about the High Court, but I will not--
—Order! I invite the honourable member for Franklin to ignore the interjections.

—Certainly, Madam Deputy Speaker; they are very distracting. The people of Tasmania will not forget this miserable allocation of $3.5m, which includes $300,000 for a start on the new Australian Broadcasting Corporation building. It is just not good enough. It is not enough. It is the lowest percentage allocation of any State in Australia. We desperately need an injection into Tasmania of Federal funds. That is the only way that we can provide jobs in the building industry, the construction industry and the other associated industries. So for that this Labor Government will be remembered. That is one part of the Budget. I have praised one good part; now I am condemning the other side.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the ordinary, average worker is saying to me: 'Bruce, I am no better off. There is a lot of facade going on. There is a lot of talk about less tax on my pay packet, et cetera, but it is just not there.' That is what this Budget is all about. It has been a bit of a con. It is an election Budget. It seems to be a smooth sort of a document that will not upset very many on this side or the other side, but it has not done what the Government said that it would do, and that is to make a better way of life for the average person in Australia, and, of course, the Government has not done it for the people of Tasmania.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having the interesting distinction of following the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) today, I can only assume that the creators of Laurie Jackson Jackson, a show that is currently featured on radio stations throughout Australia, must have used him as the series inspiration in view of some of his exaggerated comments this afternoon. I do not want to dwell on some of the comments of the honourable member for Franklin. He is certainly entitled to make those remarks in respect of his particular electorate of Franklin. My remarks this afternoon are directed towards rural Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is little wonder that farmers and farmers' organisations as well as the rural media have reacted favourably to the 1984-85 Budget, for, despite some claims that there is a level of dissatisfaction in rural Australia with the macroeconomic approach of the Budget, reality is not always honestly measured against such an allegation. As the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) said on 21 August:

An objective assessment of the 1984-85 Budget will show that the Government has acted with equity, has supported primary industry in a substantial and appropriate way and has laid the groundwork for a more stable and viable primary industry sector.

Of course, one can never be completely satisfied with any Federal Budget. However, I believe that this Budget continues this Government's constructive approach to our primary industries. Despite the rhetoric of the National Party of Australia-after all, it is more interested in pursuing 'agrarian socialism' and 'gross pork barrelling' in a manner similar to the way in which its New Zealand counterparts carried on that practice in the past-that approach is not one which the Hawke Government wants to follow. Rather, we want to ensure that our primary industries continue to provide almost half of our total export income, and, as a result, contribute significantly to our relatively high standard of living. To achieve this objective, the Government will continue to fund rural infrastructure, such as soil conservation, to make sure that our rural sector can enjoy long term stability and profitability.

As there has been some ill-informed comment about the macroeconomics of the Budget, I think it is worthwhile canvassing some of these aspects of this year's Budget. The Government wants to make sure that the fiscal year 1984-85 will build upon the successes of 1983-84. Opposition members are still embarrassed with the economic success of the policies of the Hawke Government over the last 18 months. Despite their bleating, it is an undeniable fact that our Government inherited the worst set of economic circumstances in more than 50 years when it won office last year. These circumstances involved a potential deficit, as we have so often reminded them, of $9.6 billion, sky-rocketting levels of unemployment, double digit inflation, soaring interest rates and negative growth , to name just a few.

Let us examine the current economic circumstances. Over the last fiscal year there was strong growth in output-6 per cent year on year growth in total gross domestic product. A responsible projected deficit of nearly $8.4 billion came in more than $400m below that projection. The largest ever annual increase in employment, of 232,000 people, occurred, reversing a directly opposite trend of the past few years. Even when the Medicare effect is taken into account, the underlying rate of inflation was reduced by more than four percentage points, and all indications suggest it will fall to about 5 per cent this financial year . Interest rates have fallen and this downward trend seems set to continue. In other words, 1983-84 was a year of strong growth in output and employment, coupled with declining inflation, and despite the protestations of the policy- less knockers of good government on the Opposition benches-a geographic fact of life they appear to be confronting for many years to come-this year's Federal Budget will consolidate this welcome economic position.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) criticised the Government in his speech to the House two weeks ago by noting that at the recent national conference of our Party only six minutes was spent discussing the primary industry platform. What he failed to note was that the proposed platform was so acceptable to conference delegates that little change was necessary-yet another glowing tribute to the work of a dedicated Minister for Primary Industry. But what did the Leader of the Opposition promise the rural sector in his five or six lines of rhetoric? He made a vague promise on the income equalisation deposits scheme. He issued a throw-away line about the Primary Industry Bank. He promised 'massive' assistance to the fishing industry, and, not yet fully comprehending the fact that the drought is now over, he made an offer to improve drought relief assistance. There was not one acknowledgement of the broader macroeconomic perspectives in which our primary industries operate, but yet another indication of the lack of direction in overall as well as specific economic reality for Australia's primary industries.
I now turn to some of the microeconomic aspects of the Budget, because these are also important. In the National Farmer of 23 August, this comment was very aptly made:

At the microeconomic level, agriculture did well from the Budget, gaining a surprising number of small concessions, providing evidence that the sector's importance to the economy is at long last achieving better recognition and adding to the laurels of Primary Industry Minister Kerin in the Cabinet struggle for resources.

Wool promotion is now funded on a longer term basis and, therefore, a more predictable basis. From this financial year and for the next five years, the Federal Government's contribution will be equivalent to 1.2 per cent of the gross value of the wool clip, resulting in $26m in 1984-85 and an average payment over the five year period in excess of $28m. This means that there will be a 30 per cent increase on the $20m spent annually over the last four years. Since the value of the wool clip is reasonably predictable, the decision provides a useful basis to determine the Government's contribution to promotion funding.

Nearly half a million dollars has also been provided on a contingency basis related to exotic livestock diseases. I know that my colleague the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) is particularly delighted with this component of the allocation, which will see joint State-Commonwealth programs aimed at developing and testing strategies for the eradication of feral animals, particularly feral pigs. His efforts over the past few months, including his highly successful 'search conference' on the subject of feral pig control, obviously assisted the Minister during pre-Budget discussions.

One should also not forget the value of tax cuts to primary producers. Opposition members have sought to suggest some sinister plot between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions over this initiative. Whilst it is certainly true that many unionists will benefit enormously from this tax relief, it is also true that many farmers will benefit from that decision as well. Taking into account average farm incomes in Australia, many farmers are likely to see their taxation liability reduced by nearly 17 per cent in 1984-85.

But there are other tax initiatives that will positively impact upon the rural sector. Provisional taxpayers will now have a reduction from 11 per cent to 10 per cent in the automatic increase in the assessment of the current year's income over the previous year's income. The effect of this decision is to reduce the proportion by which provisional taxpayers' income is assumed to be increasing and so reduce their provisional tax liability. The estimated cost to revenue of this decision will be about $70m in 1984-85, and a significant proportion of this cost will accrue as savings to the rural sector because most, if not all, primary producers are provisional taxpayers.

Another welcome measure in this Budget is the decision to increase the depreciation rates on income-producing buildings from 2 1/2 per cent to 4 per cent. As far as the rural sector is concerned, this now means that primary producers will be able to increase the rate of depreciation of such income- producing buildings as shearing sheds and grain storage facilities.

Primary producers will also benefit from the decision to extend the period of qualification for the 18 per cent investment allowance. While structural improvements are not within the scope of this concession, primary producers will be aware that fences for excluding stock from soil erosion areas, improvements for the purposes of conservation, and conveyancing of water and storage facilities are defined as 'eligible property'.

The Government is now well and truly back in the business of soil conservation after the scandalous decision by the Fraser razor gang in 1981 to scrap Commonwealth initiatives in this activity-a decision obviously supported by the National Party. There can be no doubt that soil degradation should be viewed as a national problem. Soil erosion does not recognise State boundaries, and it is clearly just as much a responsibility of a national government as it is a responsibility of respective State governments. Last year's Budget provided a small amount to begin the process of long term planning incorporating sound land use management principles. In co-operation with the States, landowners and other interest groups, a framework has been established to satisfactorily plan an expansion of the program. This decision will result in a substantial strengthening in the efforts directed at overcoming land degradation, which represents the most serious long term threat to Australian agriculture.

There are numerous other decisions that impact upon the rural sector. Indexation of diesel fuel excise, additional funds for rural research, market development research, and so on. No matter how one approaches any analysis of the 1984-85 Federal Budget, from either the microeconomic or, indeed, the macroeconomic approach, one can only come to the conclusion that this Budget is good news for rural Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 104, as amended for this session. The debate may be resumed at a later hour.
—I inform the House that the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) left Australia early today--
—They are all leaving.

—The only difference is that we will all be coming back. I inform the House that the Minister for Aviation left Australia early today to travel on the inaugural CAAC direct flight between Sydney and Beijing and to undertake the formal signing of the bilateral treaty with China. The Minister for Transport ( Mr Peter Morris) is Acting Minister for Aviation until the Minister for Aviation returns.

—Is the Special Minister of State satisfied with the capacity of the Australian Federal Police to cope with organised crime? Can he satisfy the House that there is no concern at the deterioration in the last 12 months in the capacity of the Federal Police to cope with organised crime?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I can give the House that assurance. In fact, the resources that have been put at the disposal of the Australian Federal Police in the two Budgets of the Hawke Labor Government go far and beyond the facilities and resources made available by the previous Government. They come as a result of very detailed submissions from the AFP and after very lengthy discussions between the Government and the AFP. Of course, it is true to say-this would be true not only in the Commonwealth but also in the States-that there would be no end to the resources the police forces may need. There is always the argument that we saw displayed last year when we discussed at a seminar in the Senate chamber the validity of the establishment of a National Crime Authority. There were those people who argued that the resources being put into the National Crime Authority should be put into the police forces of Australia so that normal police methods of investigation could be enhanced.

ANSWER.PARA: I can assure the honourable member for Boothby that not only are we satisfied with the resources being put at the disposal of the Australian Federal Police but also the Australian Federal Police has had a great deal of success in its fight against crime in this country under this Government as it had under the previous Government. Of course, there are problems with housing the Force, including problems as to location. The Force had before the former Minister a submission on the siting of the Australian Federal Police headquarters in this Territory. We have had also to deal with the placement of a number of the operations of the Australian Federal Police in new establishments since we came to government, but overall there has been a very large increase in the financial resources made available to the Australian Federal Police.

Just a few months ago I attended the largest graduation ceremony ever held by the Australian Federal Police, or the Commonwealth Police as it was then called. The honourable member for Boothby, as the shadow Minister, has access to briefings from the Commissioner if he requires them. He would find from the Commissioner and the AFP that they have been well satisfied with the resources that have been placed at their disposal by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question which is directed to the Prime Minister is appropriate considering the preceding question. I refer the Prime Minister to the National Crime Authority. Is the Prime Minister confident that the handover from the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union to the National Crime Authority is and will continue to proceed satisfactorily?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the honourable member for his question. It is the wish of the Government to see an effective transition from the proceedings and processes of the Costigan Royal Commission to the National Crime Authority. It is clear that Mr Costigan and the National Crime Authority have a different view on the adequacy of the transition arrangements. While Mr Costigan appears to believe that there will be problems with the transition, the National Crime Authority has advised that its members 'disagree' unanimously with Mr Costigan's assessment of the situation. Clearly this is a matter between Mr Costigan and the National Crime Authority. I am pleased to say that to assist the House I will table later this day the full correspondence from Mr Costigan and the National Crime Authority on this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: Having made that announcement, Mr Speaker, if you will allow me, I want to put a question through you to the Opposition. As we are tabling the correspondence between Mr Costigan and this Government, it would of course be a matter for the Opposition and for Mr Costigan whether they would agree to the tabling of the correspondence between Mr Costigan and the former Government. I take it that by his silence the Leader of the Opposition agrees that the Opposition will accept that course of action.

TALK.START.PARA: —He doesn't look happy.

—The honourable member said that the Leader of the Opposition does not look happy. Would you? As to the final report of the Costigan Commission, decisions on the tabling of the report will be made as soon as possible after the Royal Commissioner submits his report.
—Ha!

—I advise the honourable member not to laugh, because he has nothing to laugh about, I can assure him. We will make every effort to maximise the extent to which the contents of the final report can be made public. In accordance with normal practice, we will need to have regard to the security classification accorded to the contents of the report by the Royal Commissioner and, of course, also to such factors as the potential to prejudice ongoing investigations. The Opposition's approach to the release of the report is completely hypocritical. I would like to remind the House of the history of this matter. To date, Commissioner Costigan has submitted five interim reports. The first four interim reports were received by the previous Government. Of those four, only one, interim report No. 3, was tabled in full.
—But you've seen that.

—Yes, it is one of the privileges one has as Prime Minister. One does have access to this material. It is a privilege, I can assure the honourable member, that neither he nor anyone else on that side of the House will enjoy for a long time to come. Interim reports No. 1 and No. 2 were not tabled at all. Interim report No. 4 was tabled in part. Interim report No. 5 was received by this Government. Volume 1 of that report was tabled, but volumes 2 and 3 were not tabled because of the risk to the fair trial of certain persons who had been charged with criminal offences and because of the risk to certain future investigations. It is very strange-no one on this side of the House can follow it-but the Opposition seems to be suggesting or attempting to suggest that there will be some mileage for it in the next Costigan report. I warn it to be very careful, because history is not on its side in this matter. We on this side of the House look forward to the next and final Costigan report. But on the basis of history, the people on that side of the House should not look forward to it at all.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the House that in a major contribution to the affairs of this country Commissioner Costigan exposed the sellout of the previous Government to the tax avoidance industry of Australia. I remind the House of the devastating findings of report No. 4 of Commissioner Costigan. That report showed that the previous Government and its Attorney-General over a period of many years had failed to institute prosecutions against tax avoiders promoting illegal bottom of the harbour schemes, schemes which cost the taxpayers of this country hundreds of millions of dollars each year.

Now, and at least we can give them full marks for consistency, under this Leader of the Opposition those opposite have caved in completely to the tax cheats of this country. I remind the House of the Opposition's disgraceful blocking of our bottom of the harbour legislation on four separate occasions and that blocking on the Opposition's part will cost the honest, legitimate taxpayers of this country, the overwhelming majority of our citizens, some half a billion dollars.

I conclude by saying that the Leader of the Opposition and the others opposite are apparently seeking to make an issue of the relationship between the citizens and the Government on the subject of tax. I welcome their attempt to make it an issue because we will take it up and they will choke on it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Special Minister of State, relates to the question asked of him at the commencement of Question Time today by the honourable member for Boothby. He asked the Minister whether he was satisfied with the capacity of the Federal Police and whether he was concerned at any deterioration in the last 12 months. The Minister, in a full reply, said he could assure the House that there were no problems at all. In view of this, I ask the Minister how the Government answers the charge of the Office of the Special Prosecutor, Mr Redlich, in his annual report for 1983-84-Labor's year in Government-when he says:

QUESTION.PARA: An immediate cause for the gravest concern is the gross incapacity of the Federal Police to respond to and cope with the multifarious facets of identified Federal crime, whether 'organised' or not.
Mr Redlich concludes that section of the report by saying:
From my perspective, the capacity of the AFP to deal with Commonwealth crime has deteriorated since my last Annual Report.

I ask the Minister to request the Attorney-General, in view of the thwarting of Commissioner Costigan, in view of the ending of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, in view of the failure of this Government adequately to provide for the transition to the National Crime Authority and now in the most damning way, in the words of the Special Prosecutor, in view of its failure to provide for the Federal Police--

TALK.START.PARA: —These are not my words that I have quoted; they are the words of the Office of the Special Prosecutor.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition having quoted those words should go to his question.
—I ask the Minister to have his ministerial colleague the Attorney table the Redlich report and answer the charges today.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think anyone could ever say that in this portfolio all the problems have been overcome. When a response is given to some of the things that have been said about the responsibilities that have been placed on the Australian Federal Police, one should understand the dramatic changes that have taken place in regard to its responsibilities.
—But Redlich says there has been a deterioration.

—That is right; but because there may have been a massive increase in medifraud or in social security fraud, areas in which the resources of the Australian Federal Police are required. One has to understand the additional responsibilities which have been placed on the shoulders of the Australian Federal Police in a very short period, starting under the last Government. The establishment of the Costigan Royal Commission placed new and very exhaustive responsibilities on the Australian Federal Police. All the other commissions such as the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking and the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Activities of the Nugan Hand Group and the setting up of the Commonwealth-New South Wales task force on drugs, all of these additional responsibilities take resources away from the Australian Federal Police.
—You are contradicting yourself.

—I am not contradicting myself at all because if the honourable member were to look at the results of the work of the Australian Federal Police he would find that we all have to be grateful to the members of the Australian Federal Police for the way in which they have carried out their duties. But it has meant that a lot of senior people have been taken from the Australian Federal Police to carry out these responsibilities and it has meant that the demand on the Government for an increase in the intake has had to be met over the last two years in the Budgets, and it has been met. The additional manpower has been met in reply to the request and the submission made to us by the Australian Federal Police, and those responsibilities are being carried out. The establishment of the National Crime Authority will have to be looked at by the Australian Federal Police in terms of what it means for its resources and what it will have to do to assist the National Crime Authority to carry out its duties.

ANSWER.PARA: Yesterday the Deputy Leader of the Opposition asked me about the material that has been handed over by the Costigan Commission to the National Crime Authority. A great deal of that material may require quite lengthy investigation. A great deal will be handed over to the Australian Federal Police to continue that investigation so one cannot say on any given day, 'Here are the duties of the Australian Federal Police and here is the number of people we have to carry them out at these levels', because its duties and responsibilities may change from week to week. The previous Government understood that. We have had to learn of the difficulties the AFP has in dealing with all these matters, and that is exactly what we have done.

No Minister responsible for the Australian Federal Police can ever say that all the problems have been overcome. Some of the names that have been bandied around Australia as being those of some of the top Australian criminal activists go back to the Menzies Government, and they are still being chased. I do not think this Government can be held to blame for the fact that those things have not been pursued to their logical conclusion, but they will be, irrespective of what may have been the attitude of the previous Government. As I said in answer to the honourable member for Boothby, we have made the necessary additional resources available to the AFP in the last two Budgets and the AFP is carrying out its duties to the best of its ability.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism aware of recent media speculation that a number of new sports are to be introduced at the Australian Institute of Sport? Can the Minister inform the House as to the validity or otherwise of this speculation?
—It is in the annual report.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not in the annual report. I think most Australians, and I presume that includes everybody on the other side of the House, are pretty proud of our Institute of Sport, which is fast developing, I might say, into the best of its kind in the world. Certainly its achievements in Los Angeles speak very highly of it.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been a deal of speculation about new sports. Perhaps I can cast some light on that speculation by telling honourable members exactly what the situation is. Honourable members may have noticed that in the recent Budget an amount of $600,000 was set aside to introduce new sports to the Institute. I can tell honourable members exactly what is happening. As from January 1985 rowing will be introduced into the Institute of Sport here in Canberra, at a half- yearly cost of $273,000. That will fund 12 men and 12 women rowers. It is worth noting that our rowers performed extremely well in Los Angeles, winning two bronze medals and one silver medal.
