Water polo will be coming to Canberra in March 1985, at a cost of $80,000 for the half year. Our water polo team is now ranked fifth in the world, which is a considerable improvement on its standing in previous years. In line with our attempts to decentralise the Institute of Sport to let all Australians wherever they live see sport and the working of the Institute in all its proper manifestations and, with the co-operation of the Queensland Government, we will be decentralising squash to Queensland in January 1985 at a cost of $140,000 for the half year. I think it is reasonable to suggest that squash has one of the highest participation rates in Australia. We do have the current world women's squash champion, Vicki Cardwell, who, by the way, will be a member of the Australian Sports Commission when it is announced next week-there is another leak for honourable members-and we have Ken Hiscoe and Geoff Hunt who have been world champions in recent years. Diving, where Australia has reached extraordinary heights in the last couple of years, will also be decentralised to Brisbane in November 1984, at a half-yearly cost of $ 121,000. Those with mathematical minds who have been adding up will see that adds up to $614,000 for the half year.

I think it is reasonable to add a cynical note. I have announced these sports, the money is there and it will happen. That contrasts rather sharply with the rather flamboyant announcement made by the previous Minister responsible for sport, who is deeply in conversation with his mate over there, on 3 March 1983, about two days before the election. That was when he announced that rowing and cycling would be coming to the Australian Institute of Sport. The only people who did not know about it were the sporting organisations. In this case, after very deep consultation between the board of the Institute of Sport and the sporting organisations, these plans have now come to fruition and these sports will be in the Institute at the times I have announced.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Attorney-General to the report of the Office of the Special Prosecutor which this Government knows to be damning of the Government and which it is not tabling in this Parliament. I refer to some of the words used by Mr Redlich when he says in relation to the establishment of the Director of Public Prosecutions by this Government:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the Director's faculty to exercise civil remedies has been grossly and unjustifiably circumscribed.
He then goes on to talk about his pleadings. Those are his words-the pleadings.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition is allowed some latitude in his question, but I hope that he rounds it off soon.
—Mr Speaker, I hope that you will use those remarks when dealing with Ministers when they answer questions.
—Order! I suggest that the Leader of the Opposition look at the Standing Orders in regard to questions and answers. He might appreciate the tolerance that is allowed him in presenting a question.
—I accept that, Mr Speaker, as I have accepted it before, but what I am not accepting is that you are allowing this man to run untrammelled, without calling him to order.
—Order! I suggest that the Leader of the Opposition not challenge the Chair. He is aware of the rules with regard to answers. I suggest that he carry on with his question, not with his speech.

—I am making a simple suggestion to you. I remind the Minister that the words that were used were that, despite Mr Redlich's pleadings in the 1982- 83 annual report, the Bill for a Director of Public Prosecutions Act was drafted , and he described how inadequate it is. Will the Minister make the annual report available? Will he indicate to the House what action will be taken to accept the viewpoints of the Office of the Special Prosecutor to give the Director of Public Prosecutions the powers that he quite clearly needs, and not allow crime to go on virtually unabated, as it is under this Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I am not aware of the detail of the report of the Office of the Special Prosecutor but I undertake to get in touch with the Attorney immediately as to the contents of it, why it could not be tabled and also the other aspects to which the honourable gentleman has addressed his mind. Let me make it very clear: In the concept of dealing with crime, this Government has left no stone unturned. The Opposition might look at the fact that the reason it is where it is is its failure to prosecute crime.

ANSWER.PARA: We are very mindful of the fact that in respect of some of the reports that have recently come to our notice there was a fair amount of telephone tapping, which was all illegal, going on under the previous Attorney-General. The Opposition might address its mind to that and to the fact that matters which it is now anxious to exploit in the Senate came from telephone tapping in 1981 and 1982.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister is writing a response for you.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition has already asked his question.
—The Prime Minister is making the point that you were in government for too long and that is why we have to clean up the mess that we have inherited.
—Has he told you why he was at the Nugan Hand Bank?
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease defying the Chair.

—The Leader of the Opposition has a tendency to try to overcome his own shortcomings by making continual interjections. Let me make it very clear. We are talking about crime in this country. We have set up a National Crime Authority and the Leader of the Opposition's questions this week have done nothing but try to denigrate that Authority. That is his contribution and he knows that that is the position.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me make it very clear. The Attorney-General has left no stone unturned in dealing with legislation and all other matters relating to the pursuit of crime. The Opposition's record is abysmal. I make the point that it is about time the public of Australia looked at the Opposition's behaviour when in government, when it engaged in illegal activity to intercept telephone conversations and, worse still, put an informer in the New South Wales police and paid Commonwealth money to that informer. That is all a matter of record. And the members of the Opposition are the people who talk about being worried about crime.

TALK.START.PARA: —So the tapes are authentic?

—Yes, you are very worried about it. Have a look at the Greek conspiracy case, and what the present Opposition did in that case. It really approved of criminal action being used by allowing telephone interception. It prosecuted a large number of innocent Greeks, none of whom were convicted-not one. This is the sort of ability honourable members opposite have in government and that is why they are in opposition. I make it very clear that the Attorney- General has nothing to hide. In answering the detail, I will get a written reply for the honourable member.

—Is the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware of a proposal put forward by the Opposition spokesman on the environment that members of the conservation movement should each contribute $10 to ensure that Australia's environment is preserved? Could the Minister provide this House with the Government's views on this proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have recently heard of this proposal by the shadow Minister for the Environment that the 500,000 conservationists should all dob in $10 to save the Daintree. It is a novel method of government that whenever we have a problem to solve we will have what is called the whip-round system of government. It is called government by collection. The only person I know who has been absolutely enthralled by the idea is the Treasurer. He thinks that now if we want a new plane we will just take the can around in a pub and we will solve the problem. He is very attracted to the idea, but I am afraid the rest of the Government is not. I suppose the next thing the Opposition will be suggesting is that we have chook raffles in pubs to buy ourselves a new--
—Order! I doubt whether chook raffles in pubs are relevant to the question. I suggest that the Minister proceed with his answer.

—The honourable member for Bradfield has absolutely stunned the environment movement, not only with his lack of understanding of the proper role of government, but also with his economics. The Daintree covers 350,000 hectares and that part of it which is selling is selling at $26,000 per hectare. So we would need slightly more than $5m to buy it. We calculate it out at $9 billion. We can be thankful that the honourable member was not a Minister when the problems of the Great Barrier Reef came up or those of Kakadu National Park or South West Tasmania. He would need an awfully big hat to solve those environmental problems.

ANSWER.PARA: He has been running around the country trying to cultivate the environment movement over its concern about the Daintree. He has attacked me for not consulting, but that is what I have been doing non-stop for the last 12 months with the Queensland Minister. He knows that the only powers we have in this area are those under the World Heritage Properties Protection Act and he knows that his Party will not touch it under any circumstances. Honourable members will recall that the Opposition attacked this Government for introducing the Act and for using it in the South West Tasmania case. It is quite clear that under no circumstances would a Liberal-National Party government contemplate using the Act. The honourable member for Bradfield has totally abdicated his responsibility to come up with a policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. I refer to the voluminous documents tabled yesterday by the Prime Minister relating to the Young Customs affair. Why did Customs officers on 6 July, that is five days before the items were valued, provide the Special Minister of State not only with a list of goods for valuation purposes, but also with the tariff items and the applicable duty rates in handwriting alongside each item, while at the same time explaining that if the duty exceeded $500 the goods would be seized and the Minister prosecuted for a breach of Commonwealth law? Is it normal Customs Service practice to provide such a guide on how to avoid prosecution? Is this consistent with the statement to the House on 21 August by the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce that the Special Minister of State was treated in exactly the same fashion as any other person making a false Customs declaration?

—I would have thought that this case was well and truly buried. I am sure everybody bar the poor little Deputy Leader of the Opposition, who carries the conspiracy charge way beyond the realms of fantasy, considers this matter to be buried. But in order to satisfy his curiosity about this alleged conspiracy and some special treatment for the Special Minister of State-which of course was not accorded-I will check the matter out with the Minister today and furnish the honourable member with a full response from the Bureau of Customs. I think it is high time members of the Opposition got on to something more constructive. I believe the rest of Australia will be of the view that they are pursuing something which is absolutely ridiculous.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Is it true, as the Leader of the Opposition said in his response to the Budget on 23 August, that under the assets test government bureaucrats will have the right of entry into every pensioner's home simply to check the valuation of their personal possessions? Also, can the Minister give an assurance that 70 per cent of pensioners will not even have to fill in a form and that the assets test will be self-assessing for the remaining 30 per cent of pensioners--
—Order! The honourable member has actually worded her question in a way which provides an answer for the Minister. I will allow the Minister to answer the first part of the question.

—Given the position of the Leader of the Opposition, the claim he makes must be one of the worst examples of the rather irresponsible and exaggerated statements on the operation of the assets test being peddled around the country by members of the Opposition. No, it is not true that government bureaucrats will have the right of entry into pensioners' homes to check the valuations of their personal effects.
—They have to knock on the door first.
—Order! I suggest that the Minister not go on with his reply until the House comes to order. It amazes me that members ask questions and then do not listen to what is being said. I call the Minister.

—If honourable members knew anything about the Social Security Act-I will come back to that point in a moment-they would know that at the moment it gives no authority at all to officers of the Department of Social Security to enter pensioners' premises, and that will not be changed in any way following introduction of the assets test. I can assure honourable members and the public that in no circumstances will officers of the Department be authorised to enter a home to check or value assets. The assets test has been deliberately designed so that pensioners will basically be able to self-assess whether or not they will be affected by the test. The only case where valuers will be used is to value property such as vacant land, holiday homes, farms and businesses.
—Why do you hate the farmers?
—What about antiques?

—Order! I suggest that the Minister take a seat until the House comes to order. When the House comes to order, the Minister will be allowed to answer the question. Question Time cannot go on while members continue to behave in a disorderly manner.
—But what about the farmers?
—Order! The honourable member for Maranoa will remain silent.
—Well, it is true, Mr Speaker.
—I warn the honourable member for Maranoa. I call the Minister.

—As I was saying, in no circumstances will valuers be used to value personal possessions or household contents. As we have constantly pointed out, in these cases the self-assessed values will generally be accepted by the Department unless there is strong evidence of over-valuation or under-valuation. In those situations, if the issue is significant it will be resolved in discussions between officers and the pensioner concerned.
—The stand-over!
—Order! The honourable member for Hume might have shifted from the front bench to the back bench but I can still hear him. I warn him.

—The test will be administered in such a way that some 70 per cent of pensioners will not even receive an assets test form to fill in. In early November they will simply be sent an assets test guide explaining the way in which the test works. If, having studied that guide, they believe they fall above those very generous levels provided in the test, they come back to get an assets form. We expect that most of those 70 per cent of pensioners will need to take no further action, and in fact if they make no application for a form they will continue to be paid their pension entitlement. A further 15 per cent of pensioners will be sent both a form and an assets test guide but again, if having read the guide they find they do not fall above those levels, they do not need to apply or send the form back. Again, they will continue to be paid their pension entitlement. Only some 15 per cent of the pensioner population will be required to return the form and most will still be unaffected by the assets test . It is estimated that only some 40,000 pensioners will be affected by the assets test and most of those are well able to meet the demand. Despite all the noise, these are the facts about the way the assets test will be administered. There will be no entry by departmental officers into pensioners' homes. The test is largely self-assessed.
—They will come around for a chat and say they have come to help.
—Order!
—They will come to the senior citizens hall.

—Order! The honourable member for Dundas will cease interjecting. I offer a general warning. I have reached the limit of tolerance with regard to warnings for interjections. On the next occasion I have to act, I will name the honourable member concerned.
—As I have stated, most pensioners will not have to fill out an assets test form. Given the sort of noise that we have had--

—Mr Speaker, in view of the length and the detail of this answer, could I suggest as a point of order that the Minister make a statement after Question Time instead of using Question Time in this way?
—The only reason for the time taken is the noise from the other side.
—Order! There is no point of order. I suggest that the Minister might have been able to finish his reply much more quickly but for the interruptions.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. It is possible for the House and the general public to judge clearly the genuine concern of this Opposition for social welfare issues because yesterday we had clear and total proof that the Opposition has no real interest in social welfare measures. At 10.40 a.m. yesterday, it introduced a series of amendments to the Social Security and Repatriation (Budget Measures and Assets Test) Bill but at 6.35 p.m. it withdrew all of those amendments on the ground-it apologised to the House for this-that it had misread the Bill.
—One amendment.

—All parts of the amendment. Members of the Opposition did not understand the social security legislation. Never as a government or as an opposition have they had any genuine interest in social welfare; they simply seek to exploit particular issues for their own political gain.

—My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade. As 17 months have elapsed since the expiry of the Anthony-Okawara beef agreement, will the Minister indicate when a new four-year Australia-Japan beef agreement is likely to be signed? What is the reason for the delay in settling the new beef agreement with Japan? Will Australia's new agreement honour the assurances that the Japanese Prime Minister gave our Prime Minister, that is, that Australia will maintain its share of the Japanese quota beef market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a matter of record that what was said was that Australia's share would not decline, and that is the position. But let me make it very clear that the honourable gentleman has gone through the length and breadth of this land saying that the present arrangements, which we were endeavouring to improve on, are no good to the meat industry and that I have not gone to Japan frequently enough to try to negotiate.
—That is true.

—Well, that is a matter of judgment as to what we are about in terms of the negotiations. The honourable gentleman has been hoist with his own petard because the meat industry feels that there should have been, according to him, an arrangement better than his Minister was able to achieve in 1979.
—They were happy with the agreement then, but you have not got an agreement.

—It is about time the honourable gentleman faced up to the facts . He has been attending meetings all over Australia and suggesting that the arrangements are not good enough and that they will have to be improved. Let me look at the former Government's arrangements. Firstly, in 1979, when that Government entered into the arrangement, it was for a particular quantity of beef which, of course, excluded Australia in respect of high quality beef. As a result of the woeful negotiations entered into in 1979, what happened? In the process the then Government started off with 106,000 tonnes and by 1983 that amount had dropped by 10,000 tonnes.
—That was your year when the drop occurred.

—No, it was before our year. The tonnage dropped every year and the honourable member has to understand why it dropped. It dropped because of the negotiations the then Minister entered into. He said to the Japanese that Australia would bind tariff entry of $30m worth of manufactured goods to Australia, and we are bound by that. But what did we get in return? He automatically excluded Australia from the high quality beef market. The records show that in 1978 the Japanese told the then Minister that they proposed to increase the United States entry of high quality beef to 30,000 tonnes, and they did that. By the Japanese doing that, Australia's market share continually fell. When the honourable member addresses the people he knows who are interested in the cattle market and its future, he should address his mind to the fact that every year from 1979 Australia's share of the market has dropped. In 1979 Australia had 79 per cent of the market and when we took office Australia's share had dropped to 67 per cent. That is the position. The Opposition can shout and argue as much as it likes, but it is a matter of record. When Mr Anthony realised that he had been outmanoeuvred on the issue of high quality beef he made a late effort and asked the Japanese to try to increase Australia's market share of what is called frozen aged beef, and they declined.
—Why haven't you got an agreement now?
—The reason we have not got an agreement is that we have been asking why we cannot get the same chance as the Americans. That is the position.
—You left it too late; you have not done anything about it.

—It requires negotiation. We have not lost any of the opportunities that were given to us to negotiate on a basis that would improve the present position. But I make it very clear that from 1979 the United States export of high quality beef has improved substantially and the new agreement for the United States will improve it even more substantially. The Opposition knows that. On the question of whether we can compete in that market, the answer is no . The Opposition knows that. So why does the honourable member go around the country making these outrageous allegations that he feels he could have done better? Let me make it clear that never once did Mr Anthony go to Japan.
—What?
—Never once did he go to Japan on beef negotiations.
—The Japanese came here because he was a good operator.

—They did not come here. Never once did Mr Anthony go to Japan on beef negotiations. It is a matter of record that Mr Anthony-to give him his due-was anxious to try to improve the position put to him by the Japanese. I shall read from the notes. It was indicated to Mr Anthony that the Japanese had reached a tentative agreement on beef arrangements with the United States 'which involved the following elements: Increased imports of high quality beef-up to 30 ,000 tonnes by 1983 . . .'. That is why the honourable member ought to go back and do his mathematics. We are anxious that we should not be discriminated against. We have a legitimate cause of concern with the Japanese. They discriminate on the basis that we have no right of entry to the high quality beef market. We are not likely to win that position. When the Opposition has a chance to listen it will find out, in technical terms, that the Japanese take only four of the 12 cuts of the high quality beef. Because of the large domestic market in the United States there is a capacity to absorb the other eight cuts. That does not apply to our high quality beef producers. They cannot see that they can possibly enter the Japanese market, where they can sell only four of the 12 cuts. The Opposition has to understand a little bit about beef to understand what I am saying on this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: It is about time the Opposition faced up to the fact that we would very much like to have the same opportunities as were given to the United States, but we start from a very low base. In 1979, when Australia's arrangements were one year behind those of the United States, the then Government accepted a position in which it said: 'Look, this seems to be reasonable from the point of view of what we are about in Australia'. When we have to renegotiate the position we face the fact that this is deemed to be an honourable solution. I make this point: When the United States was able to negotiate its arrangements, what do honourable members think Mr Anthony said in a media release? The media release stated:

(Mr Anthony) today welcomed indications of a settlement of a number of outstanding trade issues between the United States and Japan . . . He said that it was understandable that, since the Strauss visit was concerned with ways of easing Japan's considerable balance of trade surplus particularly with the U.S.A ., the communique should emphasise high quality beef mainly provided by the U.S. A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. This is a terribly long response. Cannot the Minister make a statement instead?
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I have just read a report. The result is this: The mismanagement of the National Party of Australia resulted in Australia's exports of quota beef to Japan falling from 106,656 tonnes in 1979 to 95,244 tonnes when we took office.
—We reopened that market after the Whitlam debacle, and you know it.

—The Opposition had no success. I do not want to delay the House for too long. When the agreement expired in 1982 the then Government did not renegotiate it. It took it on a 12 months basis because it could not renegotiate it. That is the position. So what do we have? We have a bankrupt arrangement where the then Government negotiated all the rights away and the Opposition now expects us to improve on its abysmal performance. Let me make it clear that I think we can improve on it on the basis that for the first time the Japanese will give us a fixed quota in the chilled beef area-I hope honourable members can hear this-and also a fixed base in what is called frozen aged beef. I would welcome the Opposition's support for that because I am not going to go into negotiations with Japan with the suggestion that the Opposition does not think they will be adequate unless there will be an improvement to what it thinks is the market share. I will put it on a better basis: What we need is an improvement each year in our quota. That would be much more satisfactory.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I crave your indulgence to add to an answer I gave yesterday.
—Yes, if it is relevant to the answer made yesterday I grant the Minister that indulgence.

—Yesterday the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) asked me a question about the involvement of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust in the Portland aluminium smelter project. I undertook to provide any further information I could. I can now inform the House that the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust signed a Heads of Agreement with the Victorian Government, Alcoa of Australia Ltd and the Hyundai Corporation on 23 August 1984, enabling it to negotiate up to a 15 per cent interest in the project. That agreement does not commit the Trust to participate in the project and allows the Trust to withdraw for any reason.

ANSWER.PARA: A considerable amount of further investigatory work and analysis will be required before the Trust will be in a position to decide whether to enter into the binding legal commitment should the investigation support that judgment on commercial grounds. The Trust has engaged a technical adviser and a financial consultant to assist in the further investigatory work. Before reaching its 'in principle' decision to participate in the project, the Trust took advice from its technical adviser and financial consultant. Although there is always uncertainty about the expected yield on projects of this nature, given the commercial factors involved, the Trust considers the likely returns will be attractive. Importantly, the project affords an opportunity for greater portfolio diversification.
The honourable member for Bradfield suggests that the Trust's--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is the financial consultant?
—The honourable member seems to have been sidelined on this issue. What does he have to say about it?
—I am just trying to find out some facts.

—The honourable member should make up his mind; I do not mind which one I have to deal with. All honourable members opposite can be the shadow Minister if they like. The honourable member for Bradfield suggests that the Trust's 'in principle' decision in relation to the Portland project was politically motivated. Such a suggestion is unwarranted and clearly without foundation. The Trust would be in breach of its trustee responsibilities if it were to enter into such a project other than on sound commercial grounds. It is for this reason that the Trust has yet to commit itself to the project and why it is obtaining the best and most professional commercial advice available to it before reaching a firm decision.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member for Bradfield refers to an estimated 9.9 per cent return on investment in the project. I am informed that the Premier of Victoria has foreshadowed real rates of return-that is, after allowing for expected rates of inflation-for the State of Victoria in the range of 9 per cent to 15 per cent. I emphasise that these are the Victorian Government's estimates of the rate of return to that State-they are not necessarily the rates of return for the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust or, for that matter, the other participants in the project. As I have already explained, the Trust expects that the rates of return will be attractive. Nevertheless, while it is recognised that the expected rates are highly sensitive to several factors, including the world price of aluminium, these are matters that the Trust will weigh carefully in deciding whether to proceed. Finally, the Trust has assured me that it will not participate in this or any other venture unless the expected returns to contributors are satisfactory.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

—Mr Speaker, in the Senate on 4 September I was disgracefully misrepresented by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) who said that I had made the outrageous claim that the Hawke socialist Government would assess the gold in people's teeth. The truth is that in a statement on 8 June this year I pointed out that gold was a precious metal; that one of Australia's leading dental surgeons had informed me that elderly patients who have had extensive dental reconstruction performed may easily have at least $500 worth of recoverable gold at today's prices; that under the legislation as drawn gold fillings were clearly assessable assets and that, as a matter of law, this was so whether the elderly person was alive or dead.
—Senator Grimes was correct.
—Order!
—Oh, but--
—I can do without the honourable member's assistance.
—Mr Speaker, my statement was not outrageous and I point out to the House that, in the legislation going through the Parliament right now, military medals--
—Order! The honourable member is now going beyond showing where he has been misrepresented.
—Sir, will you hear me please?
—Well, the honourable member had better get quickly to the point.
—I will get to the point. The Government has amended the Act to exclude military medals but it has not amended it to exclude gold fillings!

—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

—The Minister claimed that I was suggesting that the private sector, through companies established by the environmental movement, should be able to buy back the entire Daintree. That is a grotesque misrepresentation of what I said. If people want to read the Press release or the speech I made last Sunday in Melbourne they will see that I referred specifically to those rare parts of the south Daintree which are currently alienated and on the market. It is estimated that there is some 3,000 hectares in that general area of development. Obviously it cannot all be bought. The proposal that I put forward, namely, that --

—Order! I think the honourable member has pretty well corrected any personal misrepresentation. He is now going into a rather detailed explanation of his proposition.
