DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Mackellar ( Mr Carlton) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The progressive destruction of Australia's excellent health care system caused by the introduction of Medicare.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I shall demonstrate to the House that Medicare, the scheme that is billed as the simplest, the fairest and the cheapest health scheme Australia has ever had, is neither simple nor fair, nor is it cheap, but more seriously than any of these characteristics, it is bringing about the progressive destruction of what has been the best health system in the world. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his 1983 policy speech, made the following commitment:

SPEECH.PARA: 9 out of 10 Australians will pay less for the health needs of themselves and their families.

Let us take a look at the weekly effect of Medicare on the finances of a family which has maintained its private hospital cover after the advent of Medicare. I give as an example a family consisting of a man earning the average weekly male earnings for Sydney of $384 a week with a dependent spouse. I could take as an example a double income family or any combination of incomes adding up to $384 a week. The average weekly cost of health insurance on the most commonly used private table of three major funds in New South Wales, after deduction of the 30c in the dollar tax rebate applying before Medicare and allowing for the consumer price index adjustments to insurance rates to bring them up to an assumed May 1984 level, was $11.56 a week for that family. That is pre-Medicare. After Medicare the average weekly cost of the three funds for the same level of private cover, excluding medical cover which is now covered by the levy, is $8. 77.

Of course, there is no tax rebate. Add to this the one per cent Medicare levy of $3.84 a week, plus the secret levy of 0.7 per cent, which I shall explain shortly, of $2.69 and we get a weekly outlay in total of $15.30 against the original $11.56. Thus, the additional cost to that family on average weekly earnings is $3.74 a week. I have not taken into account the likely additional cost of meeting the uninsurable gap between the schedule fee and the Medicare rebate for medical services, which could add quite substantially to the extra costs if there were chronic illness in such a family. The claim that nine out of 10 Australians would pay less for the same cover was always a fraudulent claim. The Government had no capacity to deliver on this promise and I take no pleasure in pointing out that millions of Australian families have been cheated by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and the Australian Labor Party.
Let us examine another Medicare claim. The Medicare leaflet states:
Medicare will be paid for by a 1% levy on your taxable income.

Again, this claim is simply untrue. The Budget Papers tell us that medical and hospital benefits have risen by $2,021m compared with the old scheme. The levy brings in $1,191m, leaving a shortfall of $830m. Thus a secret additional levy of $830m, equivalent to 0.7 per cent of taxable personal income, is being taken from taxpayers to pay for Medicare. It is clear that the one per cent levy relates to no particular expenditure. It is a meaningless figure in all but one sense, that is, its role in creating an illusion of low cost for our national health.

The Minister's commitment to maintain the levy at one per cent is therefore quite meaningless. While he takes our money openly at the counter, at the same time he is secretly milking our bank accounts of the funds he needs to keep the shop open. People did not realise that the plastic Medicare card was not a guarantee of health care; rather it is the Hawke Government's version of instant money transfer, secretly transmitting money from the taxpayer to the Treasury. Some might ask why we should continue with private hospital insurance when the Medicare leaflet told us:
If you go to a public hospital, Medicare will provide free accommodation and treatment by doctors appointed by the hospital

One obvious reason people would want to maintain private cover is that they would wish to choose their own doctor or to change their doctor if they were dissatisfied. Anyone who has gone through a period of serious illness and has not been totally satisfied with the attention received will understand why so many people consider being able to choose their doctor worth the extra insurance cost. However, those who have met the extra cost rightly become infuriated when they find that a person on equal or greater income who has not insured privately is charged nothing for a public hospital bed, while the insured person, through his or her insurance fund, is charged $80 a day by the same public hospital for the same kind of bed.

They become even more infuriated when they learn that there is one rule for ordinary people, and another rule for Canberra residents and Ministers. In Canberra, where the Federal Minister for Health bears ministerial responsibility for the hospital system, it seems that people can have their cake and eat it too . Under the Minister's direction Canberra residents can dodge the Medicare rules provided they can persuade an unrostered doctor to perform the operation. The Minister himself has made use of this loophole to exercise choice of doctor without having to pay, as other Australians do, the cost of private insurance. When a member of his family required an emergency operation at a Canberra public hospital recently, the Minister arranged for an unrostered doctor to come out in the middle of the night to perform the operation.

I fully understand why the Minister would want to choose his own doctor. Many Australians, myself included, would want to do so, and this is why under Medicare rules they take out private insurance cover at additional expense. In an interview with Ita Buttrose on the Sydney radio station 2UE on 5 January this year the Minister gave his views on this question of choice. I quote his words:
We think something like half the population will be content with the cover provided by the levy. I certainly will be, it will certainly be cheaper.
Ita Buttrose then raised the question of choice of doctor in hospital. The Minister replied, and again I quote his direct words:
. . . Under Medicare everyone can choose to be treated in that way-
that is, using the hospital doctor-
but if they wish they can take out that extra private insurance to have the choice you talked about.

Now the Minister has made it clear by his directions to the Capital Territory Health Commission, and by his own actions when the good health of a member of his own family was at stake, that what is good enough for the vast majority of Medicare patients in the capital cities of Australia is not good enough for Canberra residents or for the Minister. The Minister was quite happy to pay only the levy, provided he could in reality have a choice of doctor not available to most levy payers.

Medicare, like the British national health scheme before it, is open to manipulation by the well-off, the articulate and those capable of manipulating the system. It leaves the poor and the inarticulate at the end of the queue. The Minister should set an example. He should follow the same rules that he set down for the vast majority of Australians. Yet he has adopted double standards. He has attacked me for raising this matter affecting his family, and certainly I have done so with the utmost reluctance. I spoke to the Minister directly about it before I raised it in the House on Tuesday. But this kind of manipulation of the system is what is so rotten about nationalised health schemes. They claim to look after the weak and poor, yet they are always manipulated by the wealthy, the powerful and the cunning, leaving the weak and the poor out in the cold.

I am sick and tired of Labor Ministers and members accusing the Liberal and National Parties of heartlessness and lack of concern for the weak and the poor. We have been in charge of the Government of this country for 30 of the last 35 years, and we and our predecessor parties have set up most of the social welfare systems in this country. It has been a land of opportunity and also one of compassion. We will not allow these fraudulent Volvo and champagne socialists to turn it into a country of sordid manipulators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Penthouse Left.

—Penthouse Left, as my friend the Deputy Leader of the Opposition so correctly says. So, will a bed be provided if one is uninsured, as promised by Medicare? The bed may be free, but it is available only at the end of the queue. In Victoria at the moment there are 8,000 patients on waiting lists for public hospitals. The two-year waiting list for orthopaedic work in public hospitals in Victoria is reminiscent of what happened in the British national health scheme. It provides free health at the end of the queue for the poor and the inarticulate. The organised and the articulate will manipulate the system to get ahead of the queue. Influence is used. That same influence is being used every day already in Australia to get around the Medicare rules. It has been used here in Canberra. Those who can afford private insurance are occupying the beds that the poor and the inarticulate cannot obtain. Those who are most in need are left out in the cold. The Health Minister, in his letter to those compulsorily enrolled, congratulated them on becoming members of this compulsory scheme earlier this year and said:

SPEECH.PARA: You are now enrolled with Medicare, the simplest and fairest health insurance scheme Australia has ever had.

Is Medicare simple? Whereas previously Australians could get all their health insurance in the one place at the one shop, if they now wish to continue with private health cover they have two-stop shopping. They have to go to the private health insurance office and also to a Medicare office.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is, if you have a shop.

—Medicare offices, as the honourable member so rightly points out, are few and far between, especially in the country. Is Medicare fair? The chronically ill cannot insure for the gap. They find it difficult to pay for the gap. There is a $150 limit, but it applies only to individual patients. If there are a number of children in a family it is necessary for each one to get to the limit before claiming the 100 per cent rebate. Also, the system is very complicated.

SPEECH.PARA: Is it fair when the elderly and the chronically ill, after years of membership of funds, find that because of the reduction in the government reinsurance subsidy of $80m they are denied the private cover they expected? When they are most in need they find that there are limits to the number of days that they are privately covered, even though they have paid into funds for years. Is it fair that the long term sick, many of them elderly, are forced out of public or private hospitals under the 35-day rule or have to pay a great deal out of their own pocket? Is it fair that doctors are threatened with a $5,000 fine or five years in gaol if they incorrectly sign the section 3B form under the 35-day rule to say whether or not a person is in need of acute care? This 35-day rule was brought in for economic reasons without working out what would happen to the people involved. At the same time, there has been a freeze for 15 months on nursing home bed approvals. There has been a new set of rules for nursing home bed approvals, but in effect the freeze is still on. The extra domiciliary support that was promised is non-existent. Chronic psychiatric patients are being forced into bewildering expense because of the reduction in subsidies for beds in private hospitals.

Medicare is not cheap; it is not simple, nor is it fair. It has been fraudulently advertised and incompetently and cruelly administered. Medicare is a giant step towards the nationalisation of health. Medicare is damaging the whole system of health care delivery, built up to a very high standard over the last century. It is destroying the motivation of those working in the system to provide good service and to achieve excellence. Public hospital budgets have been squeezed to the point of inefficiency, poor patient service, and loss of staff morale. Private medical practitioners, whose contribution to health care is a vital ingredient of the quality of the Australian system, have been attacked professionally and financially and subjected to unwarranted abuse by the Prime Minister, who compared them with the Builders Labourers Federation, by the Federal Health Minister and Labor State Health Ministers.

Medicare has provoked the first doctors' strike in Australia's history and State legislation to complement Medicare has led to mass resignations by doctors . Bulk billing by doctors has been extended beyond necessity, turning doctors into employees of the Government rather than professional consultants to the patients, reducing doctors' incomes quite unfairly and tempting patients and doctors into excessive use of medical services. The campaign against fraud and overservicing has been turned into a crusade, with the vast majority of doctors going about their work ethically and professionally, feeling threatened and unjustly tarnished in popular esteem.

By discouraging self-provision, increasing the proportion of health funding provided by the taxpayer and removing disincentives to overuse of services at the doctor-patient level, Federal and State Labor governments have created a system that has become obsessed with cost at the expense of quality, security and comfort. With fewer private dollars going into the system and with more calls on the Budget to meet health costs, Labor governments have centralised control and have tightened the screw on expenses without regard for real patient needs. It is a system run by bureaucrats and bookkeepers without feeling for the patients, the doctors, the nurses and the other professionals and workers who make up the system. What has taken 100 years of effort, skill and talent to build up into the best care system in the world is being eaten away by the cancer of socialist mediocrity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will ask the House to judge this matter of public importance by the record of the Liberal Party on health issues and by the scare tactics which have now become a common feature of the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). He devoted most of last year to making a series of sanctimonious smears about Medicare, nearly all of which have been proved incorrect. His speech today was simply a second version of the efforts of last year. I want to deal with that so that the House can judge the shadow Minister and, of course, the Opposition in relation to health matters. The terms of the matter of public importance state:

SPEECH.PARA: The progressive destruction of Australia's excellent health care system caused by the introduction of Medicare.

I suppose the first question we should ask is: Which of the various systems is the Opposition referring to? Which of its five health schemes was this great system from which there has been a progressive deterioration? The former Government could never decide for more than 18 months which health scheme to place in this country. I have some difficulty in making a judgment as to which particular health scheme the Opposition is talking about. I noticed that the honourable member for Mackellar tried to pick the best bits out of each of the five muddled schemes in order to produce a comprehensive answer, which I will come to in a moment. Members of the Opposition, when in government, priced health insurance out of the reach of nearly two million Australians. I quote from the Australian Bureau of Statistics' health insurance survey in March 1982:

. . . 1,953,000 persons were without health insurance cover and were identified in the survey as not having access to special Commonwealth health benefits provided to pensioners, the unemployed and low income earners.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many of them opted out, you intellectual liar.
—The honourable member for Moreton will withdraw that remark.
—He is not intellectual.
—The honourable member for Moreton will not flout the Chair . He will withdraw the word 'liar'.
—I withdraw.

—The reason two million Australians were without health cover was that the former Government's policies led to the most savage increases in the cost of health cover for ordinary Australians which we have ever seen. The change in 1981, the fifth of the former Government's health schemes in seven years, led to increases in basic health insurance costs of from 50 per cent in Victoria and New South Wales up to 80 per cent in Western Australia and Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: Now members of the Opposition weep crocodile tears for the imagined pressures which they say Medicare is placing on the health system. Yet they are the ones who, by their cuts to the State hospital systems in 1981, are the source of most of the problems which the public hospital systems now face.

Let me remind the House of what the former Government did in 1981. In the financial year 1980-81, the States received $1,230.1m for their public hospitals and other health initiatives from the Commonwealth Government. Two years later, in 1982-83, they received only $1,010.9m from the Commonwealth Government for those purposes. That was a flat money cut of $219.2m in two years, representing a one-third cut in the real level of funding from the Commonwealth for public hospitals. If one asks any State Health Minister in this country-it does not matter which party he belongs to-the source of the problems in the State hospital systems he will say that it began with those cuts in 1981. We have not been able to redress those problems to any great extent, except in Queensland, where we have begun to make some additional moneys available to make up for the cuts that took place in 1981. The Opposition is complaining about these problems in Medicare, particularly in relation to the public hospital system, when the source of the public hospital system problems in this country dates from those savage cuts made in 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. The Minister is misleading the House and the country by suggesting that the cuts--
—There is no point of order. The Minister is answering a matter of public importance which has been brought up by the Opposition.
—The Minister is putting to the House that the hospital crisis came about because of cuts in the hospital budget.
—There is no point of order.

—I simply suggest to the honourable member for Warringah that he ask the various State Health Ministers as to the decisions made by the Commonwealth Government at that stage regarding the source of the problems that have flowed into the State health systems.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter I want to consider concerns the kinds of tactics employed by the honourable member for Mackellar over the last 12 months. As soon as we get the facts his exaggerated fears and scares are proved to be wrong. I will quote his statements of last year so that people can think about the statements he has made today which are equally irresponsible and reckless. Firstly, on 10 May 1983 he claimed that as a result of Medicare there would be net unemployment in the private funds of 3,250 persons. In his more exuberant moments he even reached 5, 000 as the figure for unemployment. There have been minimal redundancies in the private funds as a result of Medicare. In my own State the private funds have indicated to me that there has not been a single case of a redundancy produced by Medicare. I would like to thank most of the private funds for the co- operation which they gave to the Health Insurance Commission in dealing with this very real problem so that we have been able to avoid any serious redundancies. The scare tactics which were used last year were simply gross exaggerations of what would occur.

Scare No. 2 from the honourable member for Mackellar was contained in what one would have thought was a reasoned and thoughtful speech. It was not simply a matter of public importance; it was his major speech on the Medicare legislation . On 14 September 1983, he said that Medicare would rob the pensioners. He stated:
They will miss out on pension increases in 1984 of about $2.30 a week for a single pensioner and $3.90 for a married couple.

In fact, we have paid $2.50 for a single pensioner and $4.20 for a married couple. We have responded and provided a full cover for those pensioners. They have in no way been affected by the impact on the consumer price index of the Medicare effect; that is, they have been fully compensated, despite the allegation made that we would rob them. The pensioners have also gained, in addition, the advantage of lower inflation owing to wage restraint, which is the result of our policy in relation to the prices and incomes accord and the CPI reductions.

Scare No. 3 was again contained in the same speech of the honourable member, when he said that there would be 'a fresh rush of patients in public hospitals'. The utilisation of public hospitals appears to be slightly down since Medicare. Instead of any great rush of patients into the public hospital system, as the honourable member alleged, in order to whip up fears and scares, there has been a slight downturn in public hospital utilisation since Medicare.

Scare No. 4 referred to the difficulties of 'two-stop shopping'. He went on about all of the problems of people having to go to a Medicare office and then to a private health fund office. There has scarcely been a single complaint about this issue since Medicare started to operate. Indeed, our honest critics admit that Medicare is the simplest and most efficient payment system seen in this country. People have no contributions to pay in. They can get 'pay doctor' cheques which means that a patient need never go to a Medicare office. Again, many private hospital payments are dealt with directly between the hospital and the private insurance fund. So we have had these tales, but when we look at the facts we see that the problems that the honourable member alleges have not been produced.

He alleged further that there would be queues in doctors' surgeries as people would have to queue up because they would be getting all of these services free under Medicare. Again, that has not occurred. There have been no problems of pressure in private doctors' surgeries. The kind of scare tactic used has been totally unjustified when the system has been seen in practice.

The honourable member promised in that speech 12 months ago that he would tell us what his alternative policy would be. It is tremendously important to try to get out of this Opposition what its alternative health policy would be, because we all remember the kinds of promises it has made in the past. In 1975 it made the great promise to maintain Medibank, which it then proceeded to tear apart. I am not surprised that it is very coy about these issues. However, the honourable member for Mackellar has told us some of the things that he would do. Twelve months ago-he has been very quiet ever since, but these are his words and they are very powerful ones-he told us:
We cannot live with bulk billing for general patients as opposed to the disadvantaged.

This means, therefore, that some 20 per cent of the population will lose their access to bulk billing. I hope he goes out on the streets of this country and says to those 20 per cent of the people who are now being bulk billed that ' under us that bulk billing right will be denied you'. He stated:
We cannot live with so-called free hospital beds regardless of patient means.

That means that the Opposition would reintroduce into our public hospital system means tests for patients and the cost of a bed today would be $140 a day. That cost is subsidised under the Medicare system, but under his system there are to be means tests and people will go back to paying $140 a day. One can begin to imagine the kind of health insurance rates that would result from those proposals.

Interestingly enough, of course, the Opposition does not say hard things like that today. Of course, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has made television commercials which are soft soap commercials. He makes three vague promises but says nothing about denying all of those people their bulk billing rights and nothing about introducing means tests back into public hospitals. That would be too difficult in a pre-election period. The Opposition will do so, of course, and the honourable member for Mackellar has said clearly today that his policies are to get rid of bulk billing for all except the disadvantaged and to reintroduce means tests into public hospitals. He has made that clear, but his leader has not. His leader says: 'We will have full cover, a simplified claims system and a choice of doctor'.

I will deal with two of those claims. In regard to the simplified claims system he says that the Liberals will somehow introduce a claims system which will be better and more simplified than Medicare. I do not even know what that means. It is extremely difficult to conceive of a more simplified claims system than the one we have, unless there is some old-mate arrangement with the private health funds somehow having a direct relationship with doctors' claims. One of the great successes of Medicare has been the high quality service provided by the Health Insurance Commission in the fast and efficient settlement of claims. Claims are being paid in well under five days. We said that we would turn them around in five days. We have managed to get well under that time.

What about the cost of handing back medical insurance to 60 private health funds so that they could do what one fund is doing in an efficient way? In 1982- 83 private medical funds' administration expenses were $163m. In 1984-85 the HIC will provide a superior service for $114m. That is nearly a $50m administrative saving by doing it through one fund rather than 60 funds. Who would pay for this waste and duplication that would result from the honourable member's daydreams? Of course, the taxpayer would pay increased private insurance rates.

The last promise is this promise of doctor of choice. This, of course, is where the costs really start to pile up. Apart from a few committed, responsible doctors, most members of the medical profession will only provide their services in hospitals on a doctor of choice basis if they are fully remunerated on a fee for service basis. That is a much more expensive proposition than the sessional contracts or modified fee for service arrangements currently negotiated for treatment of public hospital patients. Once we begin to analyse and look at the facts behind the soft, hollow promises of the Leader of the Opposition, they disappear. But behind them lies the honourable member for Mackellar with his hard line policy of means tests in public hospitals, payment of bed day costs of $140 a day in public hospitals and the denial of bulk billing rights, even when the doctor chooses to bulk bill a patient, unless the person is arbitrarily classified as disadvantaged. The only good thing about the soft and the hard proposals is that this Opposition will get no chance to practise them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the sake of the previous speaker, the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), and the next speaker, I will read the subject of today's matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The progressive destruction of Australia's excellent health care system caused by the introduction of Medicare.
I believe it is appropriate to refer to an article which appeared in an appropriately named newspaper called the Guardian in July, an article provided by the Minister for Health. The article states:
I have always said that this Labor Government will need a second term to ensure that Medicare is working properly and is here to stay.

I repeat that he stated: 'I have always said that this Labor Government will need a second term'. That suggests beyond doubt that what we have seen to date is only half of what the previous speaker, the Minister for Health, has in mind in terms of nationalisation of health in this country. His is a doctrinal approach, born in the University of Adelaide. I notice that the next speaker from the Government side is also an intellectual giant from the University of Queensland. The bedside fairy people, the doctrinal people, who see things in terms of textbook procedures instead of the realities of this world, prescribe a system of health care for this country that intends to round up people like cattle and to round up the medical profession like cattle. Their approach is to use computers, and press a button here and there. There is a number for every illness. Then a cheque will spurt out and perhaps in the long term it will find its way back to the doctor's surgery. This is the way the Government is approaching the situation.

I am absolutely convinced that the Minister at the table, if he is given the opportunity, will allow the private health funds, which are providing additional cover in hospital care for the private sector, to get the chop. I am also absolutely convinced that the Minister at the table, in the name of mediocrity, has in his mind the ambition to wipe out the non-government hospitals, the entire private sector group of hospitals. I am also convinced that the Minister at the table, if given his way, will ensure that every doctor in Australia will end up receiving a salary and that the relationship which currently exists between doctors and patients will be destroyed. This Labor Government will ensure that the doctors are salaried. The service will be similar to people lining up in a public hospital. I am absolutely committed to the acceptance of the fact that that is the Labor Party's long term health care plan.

The recent difficulty in New South Wales when, for the first time in this nation's history, the medical profession went on strike was an indication that the medical profession is aware of what the Labor Party has in mind for it. It is rather interesting that the newspaper in which the quotation from the Minister appeared and to which I referred before also has an article describing that newspaper's survey of between 460 and 470 doctors. It was established that in the Sydney area of the survey only 16 per cent of doctors were actually bulk billing. Yet earlier this year this Minister, day after day, tried to give the impression in this House that over half the doctors were bulk billing. The Minister for Health can shake his head, but we all know that that was not true. That was the impression that he tried to create in order to stampede the medical profession into accepting bulk billing, in order to make people put pressure on their doctors to introduce bulk billing. That is one of the reasons he will not open Medicare offices across this country. He is trying to break down that doctor-patient relationship and to encourage and force the doctors to bulk bill for all their services. The Minister is a pathetic little man. He is reported in this article in the Guardian as having suggested to doctors that they may be better off bulk billing and forgetting about the discount because they will get their money in three days instead of maybe three weeks or five weeks. Does the Minister think the medical profession will sell out its very future on the temptation that he offers of a few measly extra cents per service? Does he really believe what he said in this article? The thing that grieves me is that he really believes in what he is trying to do.

The previous system which existed in this country certainly had some shortcomings. The Minister said that two million people were uninsured under that system. The fact is that many of those people were well people, young people, strong people. They made a deliberate decision not to be covered. The Minister plucked that figure out and used it to try to bolster his claim that the previous system did not provide cover for almost two million people. I willingly concede that some of these people probably should have had a better system of cover, but probably three-quarters of them had opted out of health insurance. They felt they did not need health care or health care cover. The Minister's dishonesty in his attempts to justify what he is trying to do knows no bounds.

The next speaker on this issue is also a Queenslander, so I guess this afternoon we will have the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Wells) repeating his question about what happened to that $20m that was given to Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good question. What has happened to it?

—The honourable member has indicated that it will be on. I tell the honourable member for Petrie that he would have to be a mug to accept the brief to speak as a Queenslander for the Government in this debate; only he would have been crazy enough to accept the opportunity. We have only to turn the hands of time back a few months to recollect the Minister at the table with so much egg on his face as a result of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) stepping in and offering Queensland extra millions upon millions of dollars. Because the Minister was trying to reduce the amount of money to be given to Queensland he almost had to go on oxygen for a week to recover from the Prime Minister's facesaver. He nearly suffocated. I see we have another Queenslander in the chamber, the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), so I will buy into this particular argument; I am forced to. We all remember that the Minister was offering Queensland $15 a head as the amount it would receive from Medicare. The Queensland Government, to its everlasting credit, stood its ground and fought.

SPEECH.PARA: But we still have an anomalous situation. The next speaker, the honourable member for Petrie, may like to answer this question. Why is it that for every person in New South Wales this Government pays out $60, in Victoria $57, in Western Australia $60, in Tasmania $68 and in South Australia $79, an average of $65, yet for every person in Queensland the amount that this Government pays is $46 a head.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—What kind of intellectual contribution from the honourable member will we have after that response at this early stage? Finally, I say to the Minister: The one per cent levy in itself is a farce. Not only has the Minister imposed that levy, but also he has imposed it on people who retired last year before Medicare even came in. The Minister is ripping into their pockets by making it apply to them. He has also wiped out the health rebate. That has gained the Government an extra $700m to $800m. People were previously given the incentive voluntarily to provide for their health care. The Minister has not only collected $1,100m or so from the pockets of people by this one per cent levy but also added another $700m to $800m that he has taken from people's pockets by not returning it to them as rebates on tax returns. So, in reality, people in the work force are already paying a 1.7 per cent levy, not a one per cent levy. It will not stop here.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wells Mr D.McM.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister at the table, the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), asked a question a little while ago. He asked: Which of the five health schemes of the previous Liberal-National Party Government does this Opposition want to go back to? We did not get an answer from the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron), but we did get a certain amount of illumination. The honourable member referred to the remark made by the Minister that 1,953,000 Australians were uninsured prior to Medicare. The Minister said that as a result of Medicare there are l,953,000 Australians for whom personal tragedy will no longer be compounded by financial disaster. In response to that, the honourable member for Moreton said that he conceded that perhaps some of those people should have had better care. In other words, the honourable member for Moreton does not want to go back to any of the schemes that the Opposition had in place previously. He wants to go back to something else, but he is not prepared to tell us what. There are pamphlets from the Opposition saying what is wrong with Medicare and what the Opposition would do. One such pamphlet says:

SPEECH.PARA: Details of the Opposition policy are being worked out as part of our complete review of all policies and will be announced at the appropriate time.

When is the appropriate time? The appropriate time is presumably when the Opposition gathers the wit to work out what it is going to say, but that will not be for some time. Fortunately, the country does not need the Opposition to tell it.

Some 1,953,000 Australians who previously did not have coverage are now insured and have coverage under Medicare. If honourable members opposite are unmoved by statistics as they often are, perhaps they would be moved by the sight of a single family. If the honourable member for Moreton would like to come across the river to my electoral office in Petrie to meet a particular Australian family, I will show him a family which was unable to insure against medical disaster before Medicare came in. I refer to a family which, if the Opposition came into power again, would once more be unable to insure itself because of the cost. If the plight of that family does not move honourable members opposite their hearts are very hard indeed. Honourable members opposite are prepared to tamper with the very lives of Australians. They are prepared to say that they will wreck and pull down a scheme which has been operating very well for 12 months. They will pull it down but they cannot tell us what they will put in its place.

The honourable member for Moreton went on to give us a string of statistics. He said that people in New South Wales were getting a certain amount back from Medicare and people in Victoria were getting a similar amount-$60.57-and he pulled some arbitrary figure out of the air as to what Queensland was getting back. The honourable member for Moreton cannot count and he cannot figure things out either because the figure he referred to is not what Queensland is getting back. What he did was choose, at the direction of the Premier of Queensland, a man whom he admires so much, a figure which does not represent what Queensland is getting under Medicare. That figure represents a particular column of a particular set of statistics. The honourable member has pulled out figures from one column when he should have added together a number of columns.

The situation in Queensland is slightly different by virtue of the fact that it had an existing publicly funded hospital system, and the Commonwealth funding went in part into that system rather than into the column of figures that the honourable member for Moreton was talking exclusively about. I will tell honourable members what we have in that column of figures. I will tell honourable members not just in terms of the ordinary citizen walking in off the street and getting treatment which he would previously have had to pay for, showing his Medicare card, walking out and forgetting it. That is not the only advantage that people get under Medicare. The other advantage is that the funds to the public hospitals in the States of Australia have been much improved as a result of Medicare funding.

I will take one State which is as close to the heart of the honourable member for Moreton as it is to mine, the State of Queensland. In the last year of the Fraser health scheme-one of the schemes that the Opposition might like to go back to if it can work out which of the five it would go back to and with what amendments; that confused health scheme which that gaggle of silvertails sitting opposite on those plush green benches wants to go back to in order to put two million Australians back out of the health insurance system-Queensland was getting $93m. In the first year of Medicare Queensland was getting $184m, a virtual doubling of the funds to public hospitals. Queensland has been getting so much money-this is a matter that the honourable member wanted me to refer to, and I will-that it does not even know how to spend it. Of the $50m Medicare special grant which was paid specifically to Queensland, $23m has already been paid, and the Opposition cannot tell us what has happened to it. The Queensland National Party Government will not tell us what has happened to it. It is not prepared to submit the matter to an audit to demonstrate what has happened to the money.

Queensland has received enough money to enable it to wipe out unemployment in the nursing profession. Yet, frequently, I go to nursing graduation ceremonies in my electorate and I speak to young women who have just graduated and who have not yet received placements. Meanwhile there are long queues in public hospitals in the area in Brisbane that I represent. There are long queues which could be ameliorated by the employment of more medical staff-more nursing staff in particular but also more doctors.

The funds which the States have received so far would generate a great deal of lifesaving therapy. Yet where are those funds being spent by the Queensland Government? We do not know. I refer once more to the fact that the fate of two million Australians depends on the continuation of Medicare because those are the people whose lives, not just the quality of their lives but sometimes their very lives, will depend on having health insurance and being able to go to a hospital. In an emergency, of course, anyone would go to a hospital. But what about elective surgery? Two million Australians, half a million Australian families, prior to the introduction of Medicare had to choose not to have elective surgery because they would not have been able to afford it.

We heard a list of figures from the Opposition again telling us that Medicare was costing Australians more than the previous system did. If the Opposition will forgive me for saying so, it is a trifle dishonest because what it omitted in the figures is the fact that the cost of the private health sector was about to increase when Medicare came in. Straight after the introduction of Medicare there was a 12 per cent increase in the schedule fee and a 15 per cent increase in hospital costs. Of course, these increases showed up in the insurance tables. Hospital and medical insurance companies also included a range of services in the top level of cover which had previously not been included. This raised the level and gave the impression that the figures that the Opposition was quoting were comparable. Today, if we make allowance for those factors, the previous system which was in operation, the last Fraser-Carlton health scheme, would cost a family $16 a week to maintain if the system had just gone on as it was going. That is a good deal more than people are now paying under Medicare.

We have heard a great deal from the two Opposition speakers about how important it is for people to be able to choose their own doctor. We on the Government side could not agree more. It is very important for people to choose their own doctor, and they have only been able to do that since Medicare came in. I say that because now the people from the State which the honourable member for Moreton, who is trying to interject, and I represent are able to go to the doctor of their choice. They are able to walk into that doctor's office, show their Medicare card and have their treatment. Previously they were unable to go to any doctor they chose because many people had to put off elective visits to doctors.

What honourable members opposite are really talking about is that they want to introduce a health scheme that gives people a choice of surgeon. They are talking about the choice of doctor in hospital. Let us get that matter clear, because choice of doctor does exist under Medicare. Honourable members opposite say they want a scheme in which people can go into hospital and have their choice of doctor. That is fine, but that would cost $1,000m if added to the health scheme. I think a fair question to ask the Opposition is: Where will the money come from for all the inflated promises that it is bringing forward? It is better at this stage to allow the private health funds some scope to provide optional insurance for people who want that particular service, and at the same time keep the costs down.

I did receive a small amount of coaching before I began this speech. It so happens that my mother is in the House today. She called me over before I spoke and she said to me: 'I do not know whether this will help, but when I went into hospital recently, I did not have to pay a penny'. My mother went into hospital for a quite serious operation and when she came out she did not have to pay a penny; it was all done on Medicare. She looks as bright as the day today.

Medicare is a system which has helped ordinary Australians. It is a system which has helped those two million people in particular who were previously unable to get coverage, and I recommend its continuation to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The discussion is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUGMENTATION OF TAXIWAY SYSTEM, SYDNEY (KINGSFORD-SMITH) AIRPORT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work:Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Augmentation of Taxiway System, Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, New South Wales.

The proposed work is for construction of new taxiways, reconstruction of an existing taxiway and provision of larger fillets at taxiway and runway intersections to facilitate more efficient handling of aircraft on the ground and to reduce taxi-ing delays and operating costs.

The main elements of the proposal are: Firstly, construction of additional entry and exit taxiways to both runways; secondly, enlargement of fillets at taxiway/runway and taxiway/taxiway intersections to allow higher runway entry and exit speeds and increased taxi-ing speeds; thirdly, reconstruction of existing taxiway G; fourthly, construction of partial length of parallel taxiway to the existing 07/25 runway; and lastly, associated reconstruction of sections of the Sydney Metropolitan Water Sewerage and Drainage Board main sewer, additions to the existing stormwater drainage system and various roadwords and re-establishment of disturbed areas.
The estimated cost of the proposal at June 1984 prices is $16m. I table plans of the proposed work and commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposal before the House is to increase and improve the taxiway system at the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. The estimated cost of this proposal at June 1984 prices, as the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford) has just pointed out, is $16m. We are, of course, concerned with what is a fairly major development at Kingsford-Smith Airport, a major existing airport. We have heard a great deal from this Government about its plans for a second airport and I regret that the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) is not here, but is presently enjoying a tour of Peking. I would have thought that out of sheer decency and a sense of commonality of interest he would have invited his opposite number to join him, in which event I would have declined because my duties are here, not in China.

SPEECH.PARA: The question that obviously arises is this: Here we are proposing to spend quite a large amount of money on Kingsford-Smith Airport. It is perfectly plain that Kingsford-Smith Airport will remain a feature in the Australian aviation industry and, one would think, the major airport. One knows that there are 14, 000 jobs immediately dependent on that airport and the question that obviously arises is: When will we learn about the second airport site; where will it be; what will it do, that is, what functions will it perform; what airlines will have to go there; and what will it cost? There has been a great deal of speculation as to where it might be and the Minister has assured us that he regards this matter as an urgent task. Therefore, it is somewhat astonishing that after 18 months we are no wiser about the Government's proposals.

The critical question is: What functions will the new airport perform? We do not know that. Before one chooses an airport site one must understand what functions it is going to perform. I raise this question because the development of the second airport must be viewed together with the improvements made at Kingsford-Smith. While I have not had an opportunity to look at the detail of what is proposed, if the taxiway system is to be improved that would seem to be in principle a good idea because it would speed up the exit and entrance of planes on to the runways and so, one hopes, reduce congestion.

I would like to know from the Minister whether there is any proposal to change substantially the functions of Kingsford-Smith. In light of what the Government is proposing it would seem that the answer is that there is no such proposal underfoot and that the 14,000 jobs are safe. This gives rise to another question . If I recall correctly, and I regret to say that I do not have the article with me, the Minister was quoted in one of the newspapers a few weeks ago as saying that the new airport would produce some 7,000 jobs. I do not know whether he was correctly quoted, but that is my recollection. I would like to know whether this means there will be 7,000 additional jobs to the 14,000 which depend on Kingsford-Smith, or whether 7,000 of the Kingsford-Smith jobs are to go and, if so, what implications that spells out for the future of Kingsford-Smith. If we are to have, in fact, 7,000 new jobs, when will we have them and who will pay for them? Presumably the taxpayer will have to pay for them, coupled of course with the poor unfortunate air traveller who will have to contribute his bit under the cost recovery system.

Since the Minister for Housing and Construction is very closely connected with any decision about the siting of airports because he will be responsible in large part, at least over the next few months, for supervising any preliminary plans-he would certainly be involved at an early stage in the detail of site selection-I ask him what progress the Government has made and when we can expect an answer on the site of the second airport. Or, is it the case, as I suspect, that this decision will be deferred until after the next election because it is altogether too unpleasant a question to resolve this side of the next election? I would also like to know whether we will see a continuance of Kingsford-Smith, as I understand we will, as the major airport, with 14,000 jobs intact, or whether some of those jobs will be lost? Lastly, are we looking at 7,000 new jobs, making a total of 21,000 jobs directly dependent on airports in the Sydney area?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on this referral because the matter concerns me. I welcome the referral to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works of these proposed works at Kingsford-Smith Airport. Like the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), I would very much like to know the Government's intentions for this airport. The matter mainly concerns me because of the air commuters who live in country New South Wales. The numbers of these are increasing particularly at the moment because of the train problems we have experienced. The general travellers of New South Wales have indicated that they do prefer air transport to Sydney. Naturally, as I represent a country electorate, and because $16m is quite a large amount of expenditure on behalf of the taxpayers, I would like to know whether it is the intention of the Government to proceed very soon with the new airport for the Sydney metropolitan area. We should know this, not only because of the number of people who are involved with works-they may be put on or replaced-but because of the position of New South Wales. One only has to look at Queensland. It has four international airports serving the coast, but New South Wales basically has only one, and the Sydney Airport is falling behind those of other capital cities of Australia. It is high time that a general decision was made on this aspect.

SPEECH.PARA: I make my plea because there are numerous air services in the country being held up or kept back at great expense to the travellers and the companies concerned. I would have loved see the Minister come here today and say that the Public Works Committee was looking at a new runway for Sydney Airport. That is what I feel the people are really seeking.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I just remind the House that what we are looking at is the matter of a proposed work being referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. It does not really refer to a new airport or a new runway. The Chair has given quite a lot of latitude to both speakers and I hope they appreciate it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Madam Deputy Speaker, I am grateful for your remarks pointing out to the House the terms of this motion. All these questions can be raised at hearings of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. In regard to the irrelevant speech of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) I say that the Government is giving attention to the needs of a new Sydney airport. We waited for that decision during seven years of the Fraser Government, while it dithered about. But now some action is taking place. Proper negotiations are taking place with the Government of New South Wales on that subject. When those consultations have been properly carried through and proper identification made of the various options that are available to the Government, the proper surveys have been carried out on those particular options and the Government has had time to consider that work, it will make a decision because it is a government of action . One of the manifestations of that action is that we are bringing this particular proposal, costing $16m, to the Public Works Committee as a first stage of undertaking this work.

SPEECH.PARA: We are dealing with an Opposition whose members at this very time are taking part in the debate on the Budget. One of the arguments in that debate is that the Government has not properly applied itself to cutting government spending. That is the Opposition's message. Here is another example of this Government being prepared to undertake essential government spending. It will be using resources that are plentiful because there are unemployed people and unutilised bricks and mortar in this country. It is a worthwhile operation which would not be carried out if this country was suffering the mismanagement of the Liberal and National parties as it suffered that mismanagement from 1976 to 1983. I repeat that we are happy to be referring this matter to the Public Works Committee for its assessment and I am happy to say that the Minister for Aviation (Mr Beazley) is doing his duty in considering whether a new airport for Sydney should be commissioned.
In ending, I draw to the attention of the House the fact that the honourable member for North Sydney made a mean remark about the Minister for Aviation and his absence from the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not intended as a mean remark; you know that. I do not begrudge him a one-week trip to Peking.
—Especially on a Chinese aircraft.
—Order!
—I hope the honourable member does not want that remark in Hansard, although it is now in Hansard. He ought to be more responsible than to make a comment like that.
—Do you know the service is bad?
—Order!
—I did not make a mean remark; you know that.
—Order! The honourable member for Mackellar continues to flout the Chair. The Minister has the floor. The honourable member for North Sydney asked his questions and he can listen to the answers.

—I am happy to accept the assurance of the honourable member for North Sydney that he did not intend his remark to be a mean one. I would not have expected that of him and I do accept his assurance. But people who read Hansard and those who are listening to this debate might not have noted the tone of voice of the honourable member or seen the twinkle in his eye when he made that remark. So, it is necessary to draw to the attention of the House and those taking an interest in its proceedings that the Minister for Aviation is at this time doing his public duty concerning the commissioning of a new direct service between this country and Beijing. I am sure that he is improving the relationship between China and this country in doing so. Madam Deputy Speaker, thank you for your tolerance in this debate. I am pleased that we are referring this matter to the Public Works Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF NEW COMMONWEALTH OFFICES AT SYDNEY (KINGSFORD-SMITH) AIRPORT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of new Commonwealth offices at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, New South Wales.

The proposed work is for the construction of a multi-level office complex on a site within the airport boundary to accommodate on-airport Commonwealth functions associated with the operations of the international terminal building and cargo complexes. The departments and functions to be located in the proposed building are the Australian Customs Service, Australian Federal Police and the Departments of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Defence and Administrative Services. The proposal is designed to overcome present unsatisfactory aspects of operations and provide appropriate facilities to meet needs to the year 2000. I should add that these services are being provided in order to facilitate the public's needs.

The proposed building will be of five levels and provide some 4,800 square metres nett of air conditioned office space, together with a cafeteria and recreation facilities. It will be of reinforced concrete frame construction with external cladding of material highly resistant to corrosion and staining by industrial fallout and salt laden air. External parking will be provided for visitors and employees. The estimated cost of the proposed work is $6.9m at May 1984 prices, which includes internal fit-out to normal Commonwealth standards. I table plans of the proposed work and commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the reference of the work concerning the construction of new Commonwealth offices at the Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport to the Public Works Committee for examination. I make some brief observations following the discussion that preceded this matter, in relation to the other developments to take place at Sydney's Kingsford-Smith Airport. It needs to be understood that this Government, like the previous Government, is committed to the ongoing development of important facilities at Sydney's Kingsford-Smith Airport in order that it can be properly utilised as an international airport. It needs to be understood that, while there has been on the part of the previous Government and this Government a search for a suitable site for a second airport , Sydney's Kingsford-Smith Airport is still an important part of the total airport arrangement for New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford) spoke on the last matter before the House, he was somewhat unkind to the Fraser Government by his reference to the fact that it was unable to secure a second site for Sydney's airport needs and had not come to a conclusion as to the way in which they ought to be met. It needs to be drawn to the Minister's attention and it needs to be clearly understood by all honourable members that the reason why a decision had not been reached previously on this matter is that the Wran Labor Government in New South Wales refused to continue its participation in the major airport needs of Sydney studies commenced by the former Government. Those studies were designed to bring this question to finality in a co-operative way. When the MANS committee was nearing the completion of its work, the Wran Labor Government, for the most base political reasons, withdrew from the study so that it would not have to be committed to the only logical decision-the one with which this Government is proceeding now because it is faced with the responsibilities of office-that is, to ensure the ongoing utilisation of Sydney's Kingsford-Smith Airport. This important work has been initiated to enable the airport to continue to be used in an effective way. That needs to be understood. We saw a great deal of politicking by honourable members opposite when they were seeking election to this place. That included the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch ), who thought he might be able to capitalise on the concern expressed by some people in his electorate about having to live near an airport. He now has to recognise the situation, as explained by Liberal governments, that Sydney's Kingsford-Smith Airport is important from the point of view of Sydney and its future. This view is now accepted by his own colleagues. That is reinforced by the fact that we have before us today two important works, one designed to augment the taxiway system and the other to enable the construction of new Commonwealth offices at Sydney's Kingsford-Smith Airport. When that is understood, the political activities that surrounded Sydney's airport can then be clearly seen for what they were.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: 132kV Subtransmission development, Tuggeranong, Australian Capital Territory.

This proposal is for extension of the existing subtransmission system to cater for continuing urban growth in the Tuggeranong area of Canberra. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, for those who have looked at the Budget of the Government and for those who are looking to the Government to solve their economic problems, I am afraid that the illusion and the practice stand in marked contrast. In its first 18 months the Hawke Government took great care to endeavour to present itself as a government of economic credibility and responsibility. Because it was able to rise on the back of the Fraser-Anthony wage pause, the breaking of the drought, and of course the recovery in the American economy, people felt that it had a fair degree of success.

SPEECH.PARA: Two weeks ago that all changed. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) walked into this place on Budget night and stood opposite where I now stand, basking in the smile of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). As he spoke, under the glare of the television lights, his economic credibility and integrity evaporated, layer by layer. In the end all that was left was an economic husk-a neat, dapper husk, with just the right coloured tie, but still only a husk.

In only about 60 minutes, the Treasurer effectively destroyed a reputation for economic competence that he had tried so hard to establish since March last year . In the presentation of his Budget he exposed the fact that this Government is no different from any other Labor government this country has suffered under. It is a big taxing government; it is a big union government; it is a big spending government; and it is a big deficit government. It is a government which puts its big union mates and its electoral survival far ahead of its responsibility to the ordinary Australian.

I would like to examine for a little while-and there is only a little time available-three aspects of what I see as a particularly cynical, irresponsible and dangerous Budget for the long term economic wellbeing of the people of Australia. The first area I would like to look at is its effect on the nation as a whole; secondly, its effect on the people whom the National Party of Australia represents; and thirdly, its effect on the now sadly ailing Australian Defence Force. Of course, I have not time to deal fully with all of these matters. However, what I would like to do first is to nail once and for all this Government's hypocrisy, its attempt to deceive Australians and its irresponsibility. There is no better way of showing the Government's hypocrisy and deception than by examining its so-called tax cuts.

Every one of us around the Australian community worries about the amount of our funds, income and earnings which go to the Government. We are worried about the extent to which, through taxation, we are penalised in the things we would like to do in terms of the disposable percentage of the money which we would like to call our own. But what, of course, has happened is that this Government has given with one hand but is poised to take back what it has given and more before the year is out.

The so-called tax cuts are worth $1,300m-a maximum of $7.60 for those few select taxpayers in that identified group. But over the course of the year the Government expects to take a staggering $4,753m in extra personal income tax out of the pockets of Australians. That is an increase of 23 per cent, or nearly $23 for every taxpayer in the community. On top of that, it will take an extra $826m through the Medicare levy. That levy is to be applied on top of the new tax on lump sum superannuation payments. As my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) who is sitting with me in the House at the moment identified so effectively this afternoon, through Medicare costs to the community are rising and hospital benefits are deteriorating.

Of course, part of the tax rise occurs because of the forecast continued recovery, to which I will return. A major contributor, however, is that great ally of Labor Treasurers, fiscal drag. This occurs, of course, as taxpayers move into progressively higher tax brackets during the course of a year and honourable members might remember how enthusiastically this device was embraced between 1972 and 1975 by Gough Whitlam, the present Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade (Mr Lionel Bowen) and even by the aspiring Prime Minister, the present Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden).

According to the Budget statistics, more than one million taxpayers, in fact, will move into higher tax brackets this financial year. To illustrate that, look at the cases of those Australians earning $17,000 a year now. That is hardly an enormous amount and quite a pittance by the standards of the Treasurer and his colleagues. Yet these taxpayers, who are now in the 30 per cent tax bracket, will find themselves paying 46c each in tax on every extra dollar they earn by the end of the financial year, giving only a relatively small rise in incomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Plus Medicare.

—The tax plus Medicare. Of course, as I mentioned, that Medicare bill will amount to about $856m this year. The tax on every extra dollar they earn will rise by more than 50 per cent. At the same time, they will be paying more in indirect taxes because of the decision in the last Budget to index excise duties on items such as tobacco, alcohol and petrol. I thought my colleague the honourable member for Paterson (Mr O'Keefe), who spoke in this debate a little while ago in what sadly might well be his last speech in this chamber, identified that totally unjustified cost very effectively indeed. At the same time, the real cost of the average citizen's home loan has never been higher. The lower to middle income earners are truly the forgotten Australians in this Budget. For them, the so-called tax cuts are a complete and total fraud.

SPEECH.PARA: That brings me to what I see as the total irresponsibility of the Treasurer's Budget package which is best summed up in the words of the business editor of the Melbourne Age, Mr Terry McCrann, who wrote on 22 August:

Despite the overall veneer of fiscal responsibility projected by the substantially reduced deficit, Paul Keating's second Budget is a deeply disturbing document which is tied to a very high risk strategy for sustained economic recovery.

The fact is that the real value of the Government's revenue is expected to increase this year by 10.5 per cent-triple the average of the previous 10 years. Total Budget revenues are expected to increase by $8,600m. Clearly, there was room for a massive cut in the deficit. Importantly, there was room for setting the stage for Australia's economic future. Importantly, there was room to create a stimulus to the private sector if spending was to be included and that stimulus, of course, could have been far better attained by reducing expenditure , not by increasing it. Yet, of course, what happened was that the deficit came down by only a paltry $1,200m. The rest went on increased spending. Again, this was an increase of more than three times the average rate under the coalition Government. This massive increase has made necessary an even larger increase in borrowings and, sadly, much of those are to be overseas borrowings at a time when our export earnings are under threat. Public debt interest is to rise by over $1,200m, or marginally less than the entire defence vote.

The particular dangers in the Government's approach were spelt out in a speech published in Australia on Budget day by the Managing Director of the International Monetary Fund. Warning of the urgent need for governments to cut fiscal deficits, he said:
The more time passes, and the more debt accumulates, the greater must be the tax increases or expenditure cuts needed to contain the size of the deficit.

One need not be an alarmist to visualise a situation where it becomes politically very difficult to introduce enough tax increases or enough cuts in non-interest expenditure to neutralise the growth of interest expenditure.
When this happens the pressure on governments to inflate their way out of the problem becomes irresistible.

This is a warning which the Government has completely ignored. It ignores it not just to its own electoral peril but to the cost of every Australian citizen. The Government has thrown away a vital opportunity to slash the deficit and at the same time to reduce the real tax burden on Australians, so putting the economy on a firm foundation, just for the sake of trying to win some votes in the election which we now seem certain to have in December. If there was ever an election that was not needed it is that which this Government precipitately is rushing the Australian electorate towards.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be so scared.

—I can assure the honourable member that I am not. As the Australian Financial Review headlined it, this is a Budget to just last an election. Of course, that is what it is about. This Government knows that if anybody is scared it is members of the Government themselves. All one needs to do is look at the faction fighting that is taking place on the Government side. I know how concerned the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) is about the way in which some of those within his Party take positions which he regards as unacceptable. How reconciled are a few of those in the socialist Left behind him to the views and attitudes of the Prime Minister? Why, the antagonism between the socialist Left and the Prime Minister is as great as it would be between any two individuals in Australia. The situation is quite incredible. This precipitate rush to the election, of course, is taking place merely to try to contain the Labor Party before it finally erupts about us.

SPEECH.PARA: As I was saying, the Australian Financial Review headlined this document as a Budget to just last an election. Shoddy and jerrybuilt job as it is, this Budget is built on foundations no firmer than the Prime Minister's promises. It is built on growth expectations which even the Budget Papers describe as uncertain. If that growth does not materialise-and there is a very real danger that it will not-we will be faced with a massive deficit blowout and enormous problems for all sections of the economy and all Australians. Growth aside, on-wage costs have snowballed since the prices and incomes accord, ranging as they do from so- called special allowances in a few select industries to superannuation payments of about $11 a week for members of the Builders Labourers Federation. As a result, deficits and unemployment loom large for the future.

The impact of this cynical, irresponsible and dangerous Budget hits hard at that most vital sector of the economy-our productive export industries. There were some useful measures for both the rural and mining sectors which, I am sure , we all welcome. But the overall thrust of the Budget seriously undermines the international competitiveness on which the prosperity of all the Australian industry sectors is ultimately based. The rural sector, which provided the major stimulus to economic growth over the last 12 months, received some small handouts, but its major problems were ignored. The growth expectation that the Treasurer has spoken of is predicated on the drought breaking twice and I would have thought that even the Treasurer would realise that, frankly, that just cannot happen.

There are two measures in particular which pose real long term problems for the rural sector. The first is natural disaster funding. Currently, the States are responsible for initial funding for drought and other disaster relief. After their spending reaches a predetermined ceiling, the Commonwealth steps in and contributes $3 for every $1 spent by the States. The Commonwealth has drastically increased the ceilings on initial State spending overall by more than double-to $57m. So much for the care and consideration this Government has for federalism! But, in addition, it has changed the cost-sharing arrangements so that from 1 July 1985 the Commonwealth will provide assistance on a dollar for dollar basis up to 75 per cent over the base amount, and on a three for one basis after that. This will increase Federal-State wrangling over drought relief and ultimately put drought-stricken farmers and small businessmen-indeed all those in drought-affected or potentially drought-affected areas-in greater jeopardy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another broken promise.

—Another broken promise. The second measure of long term concern relates to water resources. There is, in fact, not one word on water conservation in the Budget, which is an extraordinary situation in the world's driest continent one year after the breaking of one of the worst droughts in Australia's history. But there is an appropriation for $64.3m for national water resources; that at least is welcomed. But the clincher is buried in an accompanying statement by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh). He has announced that from next year the Commonwealth will help the States with water projects only by providing loans for revenue producing works. The grants will steadily come to a halt and the cost of water and new projects will, of course, skyrocket.
—They will tax rain soon.
—At the rate the Government is going I do not doubt that it will, together with capital gains taxes and everything else.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say a few words on defence. We have seen further examples of what again can only be described as the Government's cynicism and irresponsibility. In dollar terms the increase in defence spending in this year's Budget was the lowest since 1972-73. Honourable members will remember the first Labor Budget under Whitlam. The real increase, according to the Budget Papers, was only 1.5 per cent-the lowest since 1977-78. Of course, the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) has claimed that the real increase was 3.3 per cent. He has made this claim, however, only by resorting to an obvious fiddle. He has brought forward funds already spent and added them to this year's figures. This ignores the fact that the Minister already counted this spending in his response to attacks on the Government's lamentable approach to defence funding last financial year. It is a double whammy. The Government claimed the benefit last year; it puts it in this year and claims the amount it is spending has increased accordingly. This is a clear case of double counting. The Minister cannot have it both ways.

The fact is that this Budget marks a slowing of the rate of progress in several significant areas of defence activity, and unfortunately in areas which have been significantly helped over the last few years. The rate of real increase in total outlays has been slowed. On any measure, real growth in the defence vote fails to sustain the rate of increase needed to finance the Government's five- year forward defence program. All members in this place will know that the conflicts within the Budget allocation for defence lie between the funds available for capital procurement, the funds available for manpower and the funds needed to sustain exercising and training capability. What has happened is that the funds for the five-year defence program are being so pared that they will fail to sustain the rate of increase needed. At the same time there will be manpower cuts and pruning in the amount of money needed to sustain the competence and efficiency of the Defence Force. Even if the five-year defence program were fully implemented, it would leave the Government, by its own admission, with little room for initiative and would allow major gaps in Australia's defence capabilities.

Of course, this is at a time when the Minister for Foreign Affairs is one moment in Geneva and the next in South East Asia, placing Australia in an increasingly non-aligned position-a position which, of course, the Prime Minister has long since taken on Australia's behalf. But with non-alignment, with the alienation of the United States of America and with a New Zealand Labor government threatening the very survival of ANZUS, Australia's defence capability is to be run down.

There are many failures in this year's defence Budget which deserve examination , but I have time to refer in detail to only one.
