It is one of the most pressing in terms of day to day operations and readiness of the Services. What is clear from this Budget is that the stringent restrictions on training and exercises which have bound all the Services will continue, and could even worsen.

Before I go on to detail the results of the Budget itself, we have to go back nearly 12 months to the decisions that were taken to scrap the Fleet Air Arm, the fixed wing capability that sustained the air support of the Royal Australian Navy. Of course, it is said that properly we need to look at the overall capability of the Australian Defence Force. But what happened was not this Government's decision taken against a carrier that so critically hurt the Australian Defence Force: It was the decision to scrap the existing fixed wing capability which provided, in two particular types of aircraft, a unique capability. That unique capability is now lost to the Australian Services. The A4 Skyhawks and the Tracker aircraft were unique in their particular roles in the Australian Defence Force. What has happened now, we learn as a result of the Auditor-General's report, is that by disposing of the A4 Skyhawks the Navy is no longer able properly to test those missiles it uses to develop a capability against low level projectiles fired at a ship of the fleet. In other words, by disposing of the A4 aircraft it is no longer possible to conduct properly naval training and exercises to maintain even a reasonable measure of self-defence.

Of course, the sad part of that is that not only is the A4 useful in that role but also it is the only aircraft within the Australian Defence Force which has an intrinsic capability of self-refuelling. In other words, it can be used in a ground defence role, a ground attack role or to help in the naval exercises necessarily undertaken by the ships of the RAN; and there is no replacement for it. At the moment we are told that that, like the anti-submarine warfare capability of the Australian Defence Force's ships, does not matter.

Of course, if we look at the Budget, we find the relevant Budget categories show negligible real growth. We know that what the Government is doing is paring existing capability and providing no funds to redevelop it. The total of money in this Budget for supporting equipment and repairs and maintenance is $654.6m, an increase of only 5.1 per cent in money terms. But, of course, that means only 0.1 per cent in real terms. If inflation holds at 5 per cent as is forecast, that will be what is left.

TALK.START.PARA: —If.

—'If' is certainly so right. If it is anything more than 5 per cent, and anyone realistically looking at the economy ahead is very foolish to assess inflation at that level, we will finish up with a reduction in the amount of money provided for supporting equipment, repairs and maintenance. Planning for the five-year defence plan required real growth in this area of 2 per cent a year simply to cover the additional costs of the increasingly sophisticated new equipment now entering service.

SPEECH.PARA: Defence has been done again. Australians will pay the price for that in the years to come as they will pay the price for the whole Budget strategy. This is a vote now, pay later Budget. It marks, as a noted political commentator stated last week, the beginning of the end of the Hawke Government. That judgment is underlined by the resignation of the Secretary to the Treasury in his vilification of the Treasurer and the Budget. The Government has put the nation' s economic future on the line in its determination to go to the polls early. Australians know that and they will give their reply in December. The Budget is a failure and the people deserve to vote against it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate that took place in the lead-up to this year's Budget and in its aftermath provides an interesting study of contrasts with the comparable debate that took place last year. Last year, for the first time, the Government had to confront the reality of a massive blowout in the Budget deficit which was a consequence primarily of the recession. The so-called cyclical component of the Budget deficit increased enormously. It flowed from the economic conditions which were generated, in the first instance, by the previous Government. This Government had to contend, for the first time, with this very substantial growth in the Budget deficit. I state the obvious: It reveals the hypocrisy of the Opposition screaming about the burden of the public sector debt and the magnitude of the outstanding government debt as a proportion of gross domestic product.

SPEECH.PARA: The conditions that led to that substantial blowout arose, in the first instance, from economic conditions which the former Government was responsible for creating. As a result of that substantial blowout, the reality of which was being confronted for the first time, we had a very major debate about the significance of Budget deficits, what ought to be regarded as acceptable ceilings on Budget deficits, what their importance would be, and what consequences would flow from them. A range of viewpoints were expressed. Some people said that the Government was overly concerned about restricting the Budget deficit. Others argued that drastic measures should have been taken, even more than were taken originally, to rein in that Budget deficit. I remind the House that the no policy change projection for the 1983-84 deficit was $9.6 billion. As a result of this Government's actions and decisions the figure was ultimately reduced to $8.5 billion. As has been revealed in the Budget Papers, we ended up with a Budget deficit outcome for 1983-84 marginally under $8 billion.

Last year the central issue of the debate on the Budget concerned the broad macro-economic strategy, the importance of Budget deficits, what they would do to interest rates and inflation and how much benefit they would provide in real terms by way of stimulating the economy. This year, by contrast, I think it would be true to say that the debate on broad macro-economic strategy has been far less extensive. In part that is a consequence of the fact that we do not have the same array of information that became available as a result of the National Economic Summit Conference. Last year we had a full set of information on revenue and outlay growth which enabled us to look at the Budget deficit and see what its significance would be. There was the exercise whereby the Budget deficit was split into cyclical and structural components and we were able to have a debate about that. We could not do that this year because the same information base was simply not available to enable us to do so. That is one obvious facet of this contrast.

The other consideration is that to some extent we have all become used to large Budget deficits. It has become clear that the calamitous consequences which some people predicted would flow from the large Budget deficits have not, in fact, occurred. A very substantial bond selling program was undertaken by the Government. That program coincided with a fall in interest rates and a significant fall in the rate of inflation. If we are to accept the economic orthodoxy propounded by the soon to resign Secretary to the Treasury, Mr John Stone, who argued in a number of publications that large Budget deficits inevitably result in heightened inflationary expectations which in turn have consequences for interest rates and also consumption and investment expenditures , we would not have expected the economic performance that has occurred over the past 12 months.

I remind the House that that economic performance has been extremely favourable . We have seen very substantial real growth, the fastest in member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. This performance has coincided with falling inflation and interest rates and very strong employment growth. Notwithstanding some edging up in the participation rate, it has also coincided with a significant fall in the rate of unemployment. I would suggest to the House that all these improvements are, in large measure, a consequence of the move away from the severe fiscal contractionism of the Fraser Government.

These developments created a totally different climate to the one which surrounded the debate on last year's Budget. There is no question that in the lead-up to this year's Budget the major issue that we considered was the magnitude and shape of the tax cuts that were to be offered. We all know about the negotiations which took place in the lead-up to the Budget. The Australian Council of Trade Unions put forward a claim for a $1.3 billion tax cut. That would have been the total aggregate cost to the Government in revenue terms of the ACTU's proposal. That cut has been more or less delivered, at least in terms of its aggregate magnitude. No doubt the Opposition would regard it as a very scandalous development that the trade union movement had been successful in securing agreement from the Government on this matter, but anybody who attaches any weight to the prices and incomes accord realises that significant tax cuts are a necessary precondition to the accord's survival.

It was announced yesterday that there would be no national wage case in October of this year. That came about as a direct consequence of the effect both of the falling inflation rate and the introduction of Medicare on the movement in the consumer price index. There was a fractionally negative CPI movement for the first six months of the year. Obviously, in a situation such as that, the trade union movement will insist on some compensating measure to ensure that there will not be a fall in real disposable income. That request has been delivered in the form of income tax cuts. I think that any rational economic observer would have to agree that the preservation of the prices and incomes accord at this stage ought to be, and is, a key Government objective. Those tax cuts are an essential part of that accord.

The other aspect of the tax cuts that attracted some debate was the actual form which they would take. The Australian Council of Social Service expressed some concern in the period leading up to the Budget as to the way in which the tax cuts would be structured. ACOSS was concerned that a significant proportion of the tax cuts would go to people who were in a relatively high income bracket. I thought that was a legitimate concern. I believe it is important that the distributive effect of the tax cut be looked at explicitly. I am pleased with the shape of the tax cut, as it has been brought down, with a cut in the marginal rate from 30 to 25 per cent for people in the lowest tax bracket, with a flat rate covering the income band in which most income earners fall, and a falling off thereafter. I think that a tax cut structured in that way is good in terms of equity. I believe a detailed analysis would show that it will have some effect, albeit a marginal effect, in improving the equity of the overall tax system.

As I indicated at the outset, there is a contrast in the nature of the debate that took place on budgetary policy prior to last year's Budget in comparison with the debate on this year's Budget. There has been a strong contrast in the nature of the debate that has taken place. One thing that has remained common on both occasions has been the vacuity and arithmetic absurdity of the Opposition's attempted critiques of those Budgets. It is astonishing to sit in this chamber and listen, day after day, to speeches such as the one we have just heard from the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair).

On the one hand, members of the Opposition reject all the measures that the Government has instituted in order to save revenue. They reject out of hand the assets test and the lump sum superannuation changes. They bemoan the alleged inadequacy of the income tax cuts. They bemoan the lack of real growth in defence expenditures. The Leader of the National Party whinged bitterly about the fact that there have not been adequate increases in defence expenditures. Yet, on the other hand, they continue to clamour about the magnitude of the Budget deficit and how the Government is not really serious about reducing it. They say that they would do much more. The fact is that those statements do not gel. They are an absurdity and ought to be regarded as such by the electorate at large.

If one looks back in history at the magnitude of our total outstanding public sector debt one will see that as a proportion of gross domestic product it is not all that much out of kilter with what we have had in the past. Since the late 1960s and the early 1970s the ratio has not changed significantly. In fact, it is smaller now. If one goes back further in history one can find plenty of instances in which the public sector debt, as a proportion of gross domestic product, has been substantially higher.

I regard this whole argument as an absurdity. If we look at the OECD countries as a whole, our public sector debt as a proportion of gross domestic product is one of the lowest-I think it is the third lowest-of the 23 OECD countries. So this sort of alarmism about the magnitude of that public sector debt, which arose in the first instance out of the recession of which the Opposition was the architect, is sheer dishonesty. Certainly, its proscriptions and critique of the Budget measures put forward by this Government are utterly laughable.

I will say no more on that, other than to note with pleasure the fact that John Stone has announced his resignation as Secretary to the Treasury. A great many of the restrictionist policies pursued by the former Government and a great deal of the obsession about the Budget deficit flowed directly from his intellectual dominance of that Department. I think his ideas are bankrupt and untenable, and that is a view shared by a range of economic commentators. I will refer to one- that is, a paper prepared for the Brookings Institute, which is a prestigious United States-based research organisation, by Rudiger Dornbusch and Stanley Fischer. They prepared a paper that was presented to a conference earlier this year, a contribution to a survey of the Australian economy. They criticised the Treasury view in these terms:

The Treasury's starting point is the fact that the increase in the deficit increases aggregate demand and thus puts pressure on prices. Consequent fear of inflation may reduce the increase in aggregate demand produced by the deficit. But if aggregate demand were to end up lower than it started, there would be no cause to fear inflation other than pressure from the adverse expectations associated with the deficit itself rather than with the induced inflation. This would be a case of deficit hysteria, rather than a rational calculation based on the actual effects of deficits on demand. If such hysteria were universal, the United States would not in 1983 be enjoying the most rapid recovery of the post- World War II period.

In other words, those two observers from the Brookings Institute, in evaluating the Australian economy, Australian economic policy and the Treasury's approach to those things, characterised its position as deficit hysteria, which is an extraordinary condemnation, in my opinion.

I had intended to talk a little more about the prospects so far as the reform of the taxation system is concerned. But it is obviously not possible to do so in the time remaining to me. I make one observation: In this Budget we have seen a marginal extension in the indirect tax base; that is, the inclusion of domestically produced grape wines and ciders within the ambit of the wholesale sales tax, the wholesale sales tax being the only broadly based consumption tax operative in Australia at the moment. One thing that has been commented on by a number of observers of Australia's tax system is the fact that the proportion of revenue derived from broadly based consumption taxes is one of the lowest in the OECD area. One of the proposals for tax reform has been substantially to increase that base. What we have seen in this Budget is a marginal increase in that tax base by the inclusion of wines and ciders. There is a substantial controversy about that within the trade union movement. There is what I believe to be a legitimate concern on the part of the trade union movement, and a concern that is embodied in the accord, that the introduction of a very broad- based consumption tax would have the consequence of significantly reducing the equity of the overall tax system.

I comment at this point that in referring to remarks made by people like the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), who is known to be in support of the introduction of a broad-based consumption tax, even business representatives at meetings of the Economic Planning Advisory Council who have commented on this issue have insisted that, if we are to have a significant extension of the indirect tax base, in order to restore equity into the tax system and ensure that the overall outcome is not to reduce significantly the equity of that system it needs to be coupled with the introduction of taxation of other forms, such as taxes on capital gains, wealth or wealth transfers. I will conclude by quoting a couple of comments which occur in the Treasury paper prepared for EPAC and presented in December last year. On the question of capital gains tax it states:
Australia stands almost alone among OECD countries in its treatment of capital gains.
This is a further quotation dealing with taxes on wealth and wealth transfer:

Australia (along with Canada) is now virtually alone among developed industrialised countries in imposing no general tax on wealth or wealth transfers; and Australia is unique among OECD countries in having no general tax on wealth, wealth transfers or capital gains.

I simply make the observation that the Opposition's position on tax reform is utterly untenable because it wants to introduce a broad-based consumption tax which will have the effect of reducing the equity of the overall tax system without introducing other compensatory measures to restore a degree of equity. That, to me, signals its utter bankruptcy on the whole issue of tax reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal with the matter of employment. It is very appropriate to begin that way today because of the fact that the August unemployment figures have just been released. I quote from the main features as they are identified by the Australian Bureau of Statistics:

SPEECH.PARA: In seasonally adjusted terms, total employment fell by 23,300 between July and August 1984 with little change to the level of full-time employment, but a fall of 27,800, mostly males in part-time employment. Seasonally adjusted unemployment (634,300 persons or 8.9 per cent) showed little change. An increase in the number of unemployed males of 23,300 was offset by a fall in female unemployment of 17,400. The seasonally adjusted participation rate fell by 0.3 percentage points to 60.4 per cent.

Of course, the labour force comprises all persons who, during the survey week, were employed or unemployed and who are within the category of persons seeking, and who are eligible for, work. The labour force participation rate for any group in the labour force is expressed as a percentage of the civilian population aged 15 and over in the same group. In that regard the Bureau goes into great detail about the nature of the civilian labour force. I draw the House's attention, in particular, to those aged 15 to 19 years. In January this year when the school leavers were beginning to register and look for employment, the unemployment rate was 25.4 per cent. It did rise by almost a percentage point in February but it was only 0.4 per cent lower in August than it was in January. How disturbing that must be for those who plan to leave school at the end of this year and for the parents of those children, when one also takes into account the fact that the length of periods of unemployment is greatly rising. Those who are unemployed are facing being unemployed for longer periods.

Yet what is the Government doing? We have just heard from the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin) that the prices and incomes accord is the focal point. We have heard it time and again. It is the linchpin of this Budget, the previous Budget and the entire economic policy of the Government. The parties to the accord-the Government and the trade union movement-are concerned to improve, apparently willy nilly, the quality of working life and apparently the real disposable income of those in a job and give no attention whatsoever to those who do not have a job. It is a very grave reflection on the Government's sense of priorities that it has been directing its attention to supporting union claims which add to the cost of employing people. Most recently we had the Australian Council of Trade Unions job security case and we have had the Government's blessing on the $11 deal in the building industry which we know, and which I have exposed in debates before, is a wage increase under the guise of being non-contributory superannuation-non-contributory by the employee. It is a wage increase of the order denied by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in accordance with the accord. But the Government and the ACTU have bowed to the industrial muscle of the building industry unions and have denied the employers any protection against that muscle.

Today's increase in unemployment underlines the fact that the unemployed are failing to benefit from an improving economy. It is a disgrace that, despite the breaking of the drought and the benefits of the wages pause, neither of which had anything to do with this Government, and despite improved international conditions which again were not the result of the work of this Government, unemployment remains so high. The policies of the Government are not targeted to the unemployed, yet for years it ranted and raved about the need to help the unemployed. The Labor Party created the expectation that in government it would do just that.

I suggest that it is very alarming to look at both the figures I have quoted, because the rise in male unemployment is a very serious one. In one month that rise was 0.5 per cent. The fact that the overall unemployment figure is not significantly worse is not a matter for the Government to preen itself on. What it means is that females, in particular, and some older workers, both male and female, have given up registering for employment because they have had so much experience of being discouraged by not getting the jobs they were seeking. That is the case with many older workers who have had much the same job year in and year out and who have lost that job because of various economic circumstances. It is certainly the case with a number of married women seeking to re-enter the work force. The percentage of hidden unemployed therefore has risen; the number of discouraged job seekers has also risen. But statistically it appears that they have moved out of the unemployment category.

The figures relating to youth unemployment which I have cited are deeply disturbing, yet the Government has done nothing to improve the position of young Australians in the job market. We now have in the middle of this year, despite the ending of our worst drought, the benefits of the wages pause and the beginning of the American-led economic recovery, 25 per cent of our young people out of work. What does the Budget say about that? It forecasts:
. . . a further modest decline in the unemployment rate over the course of the year.
In more detail, the Budget Papers explain:

Allowing for some modest 'encouraged worker' effect on the participation rate, a variable which has been subject to considerable volatility of late, growth in the labour force over the course of 1984-85 would be a little less than that in employment. If so, the measured level of unemployment would decline slightly over the year (implying, in year-average terms, a decline of around one percentage point in the unemployment rate). As always, there is a large margin of uncertainty attaching to these labour market estimates.

To talk about a modest decline of one per cent when Australia has had the benefits of the wages pause, the end of the drought and the American recovery is indeed not just disappointing, but quite tragic. It is a disgrace for this Government which created so many expectations when it campaigned at the last election. The one section of the community to which the benefits of the accord between the ACTU and the Government were not passed on, the one section which got no benefit from the economic recovery, was the unemployed. As of today 634, 000 Australians are still suffering the indignity, the hardship and the distress of unemployment; that is, 8.9 per cent of the work force and 25 per cent of our teenagers are unemployed. Furthermore, the Budget Papers state:

Despite the fall in total unemployment, the number of persons who have been unemployed for more than a year continues to rise and the mean duration of unemployment has also risen. This pattern is typical of the early stages of recovery. There is therefore a group of the long-term unemployed which is still growing and which has not yet been reduced by the general lift in the economy. Long-term unemployment particularly affects the older unemployed. Of the unemployed aged 15 to 24, around 25 per cent have been unemployed for more than a year; for those aged 35 or more the ratio is over 40 per cent and it is even higher for older age groups. The recovery has encouraged people to re-enter the labour force and re-entrants tend to provide the bulk of the increase in employment in any month.

That, of course, is what is happening. That is what the now Government knew when it campaigned at the last election and when it said that it would create 500,000 new jobs over a three-year period. It knew very well that there would be a natural growth in the work force and there would be some growth in the creation of employment. But it was pleased to create the impression that the 500,000 new jobs would be an automatic reduction of 500,000 in the number of unemployed; of course, that is not so. The growth in new jobs is barely keeping pace with the growth in the number of people seeking to enter the work force and find employment. There is another key statement of the Government's advisers at the Treasury on page 12 of Budget Paper No. 1 which is:

Beyond that, sustained growth in the Australian economy will depend heavily on a continuing recovery in private business investment, which in turn requires a reduction in the public sector borrowing requirement to take pressure off financial markets and reduce real interest rates.

This is the advice the Government received. What did the Government do? The gravity of this statement lies in the fact that the Government is widely acknowledged to have missed an opportunity to reduce not just this year's deficit, which the honourable member for Sydney referred to, but also the structural deficit. It is the fact that the Budget Papers themselves show that over 50 per cent of all net new jobs created, to use the Government's term, in the year to May have been publicly funded jobs. Over 50 per cent of new jobs are publicly funded. That has a massive impact on the structural deficit, the recurrent expenditure, year in, year out. It is one thing to run a deliberate deficit to stimulate the economy with things such as capital works; it is another to build in recurrent expenditure by public sector employment because the consequence of that must be to deter private sector borrowing, investment and job creation. So the prospects for the unemployed are jeopardised by this Budget's strategy.

I refer the House to table 6 of Budget Paper No. 1, headed 'Employment by Industry'. If one looks at that table and considers the employment figures in just three areas of public administration one sees that, as of May 1984, 81,200 people were employed in community services in the public sector. That is a rise of 7.8 per cent in this financial year over the May on May comparison for 1983- 84. The rise in employment in the public administration and defence areas is 8.3 per cent and that in the electricity, gas and water industries 5.5 per cent. If one takes just those three categories of public sector employment one can see that over 113,000 of the 217,000 new jobs which the Government claims to have created are non-productive jobs funded by the taxpayer with recurring expenditure Budget after Budget. This increase, by the Government's own admission, cannot be allowed to continue without a catastrophic effect on the deficit and, therefore, on interest rates, investment and employment creation in the private sector. In the end, it is that private sector employment which is the only meaningful and sustainable employment.

What do we find was the treatment given to the Budget? In the Australian the day after the Budget was the heading 'Boost to work schemes raises hopes for jobless'. The article went on to recite the Government's own claims that there had been a rise of 44 per cent in expenditure in job creation and training programs. I will show in a moment that that in fact is a fraud upon the public and a most misleading statement. There has in fact been a reduction of 5 per cent in the Government's expenditure in job creation and training programs.

I want to examine first of all what the Government believes it is achieving in the job creation programs organised under the community employment program. Are the jobs improving the skill level of any of the participants? Is the program making them more competitive in the labour market? What happens when the wage subsidy expires? Quite apart from the highly doubtful value to the community of some of the projects funded, I suggest that experience shows that the community employment program is not providing either experience in terms of skill which makes people compete better in the labour market or sustainable jobs. Therefore many of the hopes of those who get six months or twelve months employment under subsidy are dashed at the end of that period. The money would be far better spent in increasing real training to lift people's level of skills to make them more competitive. Of course, a different budgetary policy not based on the prices and incomes accord would increase the rate of growth of private sector jobs. So those whose skills had been lifted through training would in fact be able to compete for more jobs with other people in the labour market.

When we come next week to a discussion of the estimates of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, I will go into much more detail on the community employment program. Suffice it to say now that, looking at the Budget Papers statements on labour and employment and at the figures cited, one can see that the community employment program has received an increase in funding of 43. 7 per cent but the wage pause employment program introduced by the previous Government is now taken off the books. The effect of that, even when one takes into account the commendable increases to the skills training programs, is that funding for the combination of job creation and training programs does not amount to an increase. If we take specifically the allocation to the job creation programs we see there is a reduction. In 1983-84 the wages pause program and the community employment program had expenditure of $434m. In 1984- 85 when the wages pause program will no longer operate, the community employment program allocation is down to $412m, a reduction of $22m or 5 per cent. The rise in funding for trade training, skills training and youth training programs is, as I said, commendable but it is modest. I would rather see expenditure on the community employment program go into the trade training area.

I wish to conclude my remarks by dealing with another part of my responsibilities which involves the status of women. The Government presented a very elaborate document-in fact the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) presented it- claiming to have assisted women greatly in this Budget. I put to the Government that that statement was an insult to women and that the benefits in the so- called women's Budget program are largely illusory. The Government claims that women will gain substantial benefit from the revised personal income tax structure, given their relatively poor earnings position; but in fact, because of their substantially lower earnings women will still receive less actual cash in hand than men even when the tax cuts are taken into account. The average weekly earnings figure for females is substantially lower than that for males and on the tax scales far fewer women than men will get the benefit of the $7.80 reduction.

The Government's proposals on child care are again most inadequate and far short of the expectations that it created in opposition. These proposals do nothing to increase the availability of part time and occasional child care. So they do not meet the needs of women wishing to re-enter the work force on a part time basis or of those who may need occasional care and temporary relief from full time parenting. Even when the provisions for full time care are taken into account they fall far short of the expectations created by the Labor Party at the last election. In fact they are grossly inadequate for the actual needs of children. For example, in New South Wales there are currently over 70,000 children under five who have working mothers but who are not placed in licensed child care centres. The newly announced centres will provide places for only 1, 800 children. Many of the letters to the editors of newspapers have testified to the inadequacy of these proposals.

The restrictions on the first home owners scheme will effectively reduce the eligibility for assistance to those who have no chance of affording the mortgage repayments anyway. One can almost say that the scheme will no longer apply to any single person. Yet we now know that about 20 per cent of people in the community are likely to remain single for all of their lives. They are certainly entitled to the benefits of a home ownership scheme. Likewise, to say that the dependent spouse rebate being extended to de facto relationships is a benefit to women is wrong because in most cases it is a benefit to men. This is a most serious situation. Every women's group from every shade and spectrum of feminist opinion asked for an increase in family allowances. Instead we find no increase but merely the extension of the rebate for dependent spouses to people in de facto relationships. The Government has ignored the opinion of women's groups and has failed to meet expectations which it created. This is another example of pandering only to the influential people in the trade union movement and of not listening to the average person in the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayer Mrs H.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the years of the previous Government, the Commonwealth policy in schools funding was a supreme example of the Fraser habit of saying one thing and doing another. While preaching the principles of market forces and user pays on the one hand, on the other, government support for the most important of our nation's infrastructure systems, public education, fell drastically relative to the huge support given to private sector schools. The needs principle introduced by the previous Labor Government became cynically distorted and national needs for the future were ignored. The Commonwealth Government took little or no interest in the quality of educational offerings and outcomes in the public system, preferring, in fact, to denigrate the public system by a series of vicious attacks on teachers who, through their organisations, fought and are still fighting for the right of all Australian children to attend schools of the highest quality.

SPEECH.PARA: Since March of 1983 the previously ignored issues of quality of education, community standards of resources and retention rates have been addressed, and addressed in such a way as to begin the restoration, not only of equity but also of confidence in the public system. There can be no doubt that this Government recognises that non-government schools have become dependent on funding from the Commonwealth Government for their continuing existence and that parents with deep religious and ideological convictions should be able to make the choice of education which combines religion with learning, however, the Government's obligation to the public system which provides the majority of our nation's education foundation is clearly recognised in this Budget.

The common per capita grant tied to the community standard will have an additional 10 per cent loading for government schools to recognise the requirement of these schools to provide education for all children, whatever their circumstances, with the extra costs which this entails. General recurrent programs in government schools will be provided with an estimated $335.6m to the States and to the Northern Territory, an increase of 5.7 per cent in real terms. By 1992, there will have been a real increase of 50 per cent in his area over 1984. This contrasts with the reduction of 1.9 per cent in government schools funding during the Fraser Government years. Increases for participation and equity programs and computer education programs of $19m and $5m respectively will improve the coverage of these programs and provide opportunities for schools to improve the quality of educational opportunity.

This Budget also includes an allocation for the basic learning in primary schools program. This triennially funded program, starting in 1985, will provide $6.7m each year, $5.3m of which will go to the government schools. I recall that in 1972 when I was teaching in secondary schools in Victoria, I wrote several times to the previous Prime Minister, then the Minister for Education, pointing out the need for funding for libraries in primary schools as a start towards improving the basic levels of reading in those schools. I was told on each occasion that that was the business of the States, that is, until November 1972 when I received a letter from the then Prime Minister promising for that purpose , a sum which would have provided about $25 to each primary school for a library .

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that all?

—Yes. The sum of $25 was a pretty startling amount even in 1972, was it not? Changes in funding during the previous Labor Government enabled the States to make provision in this area and the basic learning program will provide the extra resources to enable schools to tackle the situation of children in need of assistance with basic learning before that problem becomes a life determining one for the child. That seems often to be forgotten. Unless the schools have the resources to tackle those problems as they arise, the child is forever handicapped by a failure to meet his or her learning needs early enough.

SPEECH.PARA: Seventy-five per cent of the capital program of $159.1m will go to government schools, assisting the States in the building of new facilities and the refurbishment of the deplorable old buildings which still exist. My own personal experience of teaching at Brunswick Technical School in Victoria was very interesting. That technical school was built in 1916. When I was teaching in it it had two-inch cracks in the brick walls through which you could see the street . It also had a very dodgy roof indeed, with leaks in every room, and for 13 years the previous Liberal State Government had promised to do something about Brunswick Technical School. Six months after John Cain came to power in Victoria the refurbishment and restoration of Brunswick Technical School as a decent building in which children could learn started, and that is now nearly complete. It just goes to show the difference in understanding of the needs of various groups of children.

The special purpose programs allocations of $144.8m for government schools represents 80 per cent of all Commonwealth special purpose funds. This funding provides, for the very successful participation and equity program, $39.9m. That program has provided schools with the opportunity to fund the programs that are specific for the children they have at those schools and to make sure that their own communities are well served by the teaching going on in the schools. The computer education program of $5m is again very important because it will provide hands on experience for children in those schools which do not have a private income available to them for such riches as the computer centres which I have seen in some non-government schools. Over $50m has been provided for English as a second language program, a program which is of fundamental importance in enabling children whose home language is not English to carry on their education as smoothly as possible.

The disadvantaged schools allocation of $28.7m provides needed support for those schools whose responsibilities include many children who find schooling very difficult for a number of reasons. My personal experience in a disadvantaged school, a school in which the family income for more than half the children was provided by social welfare benefits of various kinds, was that the level of nutrition, variety of life experiences, failure in their early schooling, or socially disruptive influences all made the disadvantaged school grants a lifeline for those young people. The increase in those fundings for disadvantaged schools is very welcome. The predictability of funding for a period of more than one year is equally important for government and non- government schools, allowing government schools to plan for this part of their funding over a reasonable period.

However, the Government recognises that simply making funds available is not enough and that it needs to direct those funds to the best possible outcomes. To do this it has established a Quality of Education Review Committee chaired by Professor Peter Karmel. This Committee will report on terms of reference which include the attainment of a satisfactory standard by the great majority of students at successive stages of their schooling; a review of student groups in the greatest need of specific assistance, improved relationships between secondary education and further studies and employment opportunities; encouragement for girls to opt for a wider range of studies enabling a greater choice of further studies or employment and a number of other terms of reference of very great importance and of a wide-ranging nature. Given both those terms of reference and its membership, which is very distinguished indeed, this Committee will be able to advise the Government and should be of the greatest possible assistance in achieving a national goal of an educated population, which individually and collectively can meet the challenges of the future.

There is no doubt that, when we came to government, education, like the economy , was in a mess. In the same way that the economy, industrial relations and employment have improved since this Government came in, so has the fundamental basis of education. Years of funding one small sector of the school system in this country while regulating the larger component, years of denigrating the public system and years of taking no responsibility for this vital national resource are one with the divisive counterproductive policies of the previous Government.

This Government, in contrast, has accepted its responsibility, with the States, for providing real choices for parents; choices between good schools, both government and non-government; and choices which will reflect restored confidence in the neighbourhood school with all the advantages which that implies both for the child and for the child's parents. Freedom of choice, after all, is choice between things of equal value and that is the choice of schooling that the parents and children of Australia should have.

There is still a long way to go to produce a properly functioning education system in this country, and this will be a continuing challenge both to the Commonwealth and to the States and Territories, but this Government has taken up the challenge and is equal to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this week I was interested to read in the Age an article by Max Walsh. In it he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not too melodramatic to say that the second Keating Budget could well mark the beginning of the end of the Hawke Government.
He went on:
When every nation in the OECD is desperately searching for ways to reduce the Government sector and the size of the national debt, the Australian Government goes the other way.

It is worth noting now, as was the case 10 years ago, that whenever we have a Labor government we go the other way. Let me illustrate. In 1983-84 the public sector borrowing requirement rose to 8 per cent of gross domestic product, while the Commonwealth sector deficit rose to 4.8 per cent of GDP and Commonwealth outlays rose to 31.7 per cent of GDP. This year it is forecast that Commonwealth outlays will increase by 6.1 per cent in real terms while receipts are forecast to rise by 10.5 per cent in real terms, significantly faster in both cases than any realistic estimate of GDP growth.

While over the long term the trend has been for the public sector to expand, an acceleration of that trend when we should at least be trying to move in the opposite direction has serious adverse implications for all Australians. There are a number of reasons why the size of the public sector has increased. One of these has been the desire of the Government to ensure that every member of society is protected against the principal risks of life. All too often, instead of using the instruments of public policy to enable as many people as possible to look after themselves, governments have become providers for an ever- increasing proportion of the population. New programs are justified on the ground that there is a need to redistribute resources towards the truly disadvantaged. Experience has shown that it is not long before they become programs which redistribute resources to an increasing proportion of those who at any given time are not in the employed work force, as well as to those in need of health care, housing or education.

The way in which taxation is imposed to fund these programs, which were originally conceived as a means of protecting individuals and families against circumstances for which they have not been able easily to make adequate provision, means that they become the reason why others are prevented from making the provision that they need to meet in similar circumstances. As a result, a large proportion of public sector expenditure is returned in cash or in kind to the original taxpayers. Sometimes this occurs in the year that the tax is paid. In other cases expenditure is incurred either in anticipation of the fact that the beneficiary will later become a taxpayer or because he has been a taxpayer in the past.

In addition to public social expenditures, there are substantial private expenditures of this kind. They are made in the form of transfers, in cash or kind, to dependent spouses and dependent children, as well as on school fees, health care and housing costs. Changing levels of community affluence, as well as changing community values, have a significant effect on the extent to which we as a nation, by individual or government decision, allocate our gross domestic product to social expenditure. I have no doubt that the majority of Australians want a society which ensures that nobody is excluded from essential health care, which provides adequate educational opportunities to all, which makes available housing of an acceptable standard and which, above all, ensures that all have incomes sufficient to enable them to live with dignity and independence.

The expansion of government social expenditures has created a substantial dependency on public services and transfer payments. The result of this has been that most of the benefit of such expenditure flows to those who as taxpayers finance it. Social expenditures by government are sometimes justified by reference to what is described as the market's failure to guarantee outcomes which meet society's equity objectives. It is wrong to assume that this failure is always the fault of the market itself. All too often it has occurred as a consequence of the distortions caused by the actions of government. Even more important is the lack of affirmative government action to develop and implement policies which make it possible for these equity objectives to be achieved to a greater extent through individual and family self-reliance.

The insensitivity of the tax and social security systems to the desire and latent capacity of many to fend for themselves has led to the present substantial dependency on public transfer payments and services. If governments are to achieve viable Budget strategies while being responsive to what may be described as the worthy aspects of the welfare state, they will need to put more time and effort into those reforms which facilitate and enable individuals and families not only to discharge the responsibilities which are currently theirs but also to undertake an extended role.

In Australia over the last 20 years or so public sector social expenditure on such things as pensions and benefits, health care, education and housing has increased at a rate more than twice that of GDP growth. This rise in public sector social expenditure has been the result of political decisions, most of which have been expedient and had not taken into account medium and long term community objectives. They have been taken not only at the expense of the desire for lower average and marginal tax rates and the growth potential of GDP itself but also at the expense of the private sector and of individual freedom. In curing one truly disadvantaged patient, governments have caused many others to catch the complaint because they have made it impossible for them to provide themselves with immunity. The result has been that the extra cost of curing these additional patients has caused a further increase in the proportion of social expenditure borne by the public sector; and so the process goes on in a vicious circle.

In my view the time has come for all Australians, especially those of us in positions of leadership, to evaluate and assess the changing relationship between public and private social expenditures, the direction and cause of that change and the extent to which it occurs as the intended result of government actions or as their unintended side effect. We need also to assess the impact on personal freedom of what I have described in this House on other occasions as the soup kitchen or meal ticket mentality. Such mentality results when increased public sector social expenditure is incurred on the provision of benefits in kind.

The great majority of Australians would prefer an adequate income to spend as they please. This is so whether they receive that income from employment or from pensions, benefits and allowances or private provisions that they draw on during periods of dependency. They want freedom to send their children to the schools of their choice, where there is no price disadvantage. They want freedom to be treated by the doctor of their choice, in the hospital of their choice, where they do not have to pay their taxes and then pay the cost of making that choice. They want freedom to choose whether they will take the fringe benefits now available to pensioners or spend the money value of those benefits on the goods and services of their own choice.

The prime responsibility of government should be not the provision of services but the implementation of policies which ensure that all Australians have adequate incomes. It is only by acknowledging the interrelationship between employment, taxation and social security policies that it is possible to develop the comprehensive program which will meet the income requirements of all Australians and to the maximum degree possible enable them to provide for themselves. The structure of the income tax system should no longer be seen simply as a means of raising revenue. Nor should the social security system be regarded as charity for a small but needy minority. Both, along with employment policies, should be seen as aspects of public policy aimed at enabling as many Australians as possible to live with dignity, with personal independence and with a maximum degree of freedom of choice.

In framing this year's Budget, the Hawke Government has ignored the single most important cohesive force in Australian society-the family. This second Labor Budget, like the first, has done virtually nothing to help families. It is as if the Australian Labor Party does not know that most Australians are members of families who live in household economies. The Hawke Government has ignored these little aggregates and has left them out of the public debate. The Labor Party has failed the family. We in the Liberal Party have not, and will not. We believe in initiative and enterprise, incentive and self-reliance, and rewards for effort, and recognise the importance of having fair and equitable tax and social security policies which do not penalise families. Not so the Labor Party.

In this year's Budget, Labor has overlooked many glaring inequities and has created or confirmed others. Under Labor, average Australian families are paying $22 a week more in tax than when Labor came to office. This Budget contains the infamous Clayton's tax cut of $7.60. It is an attempted con trick, exposed for what it is when account is taken of the $22 a week tax grab. This illusory tax cut does little to redress the fundamental inequality that exists between single -income families and two-income families. In spite of its pre-election promises, Labor has not increased the spouse rebate; nor has it lifted the tax threshold. It penalises not only those women who choose to be home makers, those who believe it is right that they provide their children with full time care, but also those forced to stay at home because they cannot find a job. Under this Labor Budget, single-income families pay more tax than two-income families with the same income. It is unfair that any family be required to pay additional tax simply because its income is derived solely by one of its members rather than two.

Yet under this Budget the single income family with a dependent spouse and child and a household income equal to average weekly male earnings, will pay $10 a week, or 20 per cent more than a two-income family with the same household income. Single income families with an income equal to average male earnings plus average weekly female earnings will pay $72 a week, or 56 per cent more than a two-income family with the same household income. By ignoring the needs of families the Labor Party has seemingly rejected the advice of the Institute of Family Studies. In its annual report that Institute drew attention to this fact:
The most basic resource for family survival is an adequate income.
Yet if one looks at the way this Budget will tax single income families, one would wonder whether any member of the present Government has read that comment. The Institute went on to state:
It is disturbing that economists seem unable to devise a system that will maintain the value and dignity of human life.

Whilst the Institute sees it as a dilemma, it is clear from what I have said already that it is my view that 'so-called needs based funding exposes families not yet at risk to pressure which can be borne for only a limited time'. There is no doubt in my mind that prevention and general support must be the goal. Governments must recognise, as the Institute does, that every family has basic needs and the economic system must operate to guarantee those needs if supporting the family unit is to be anything more than rhetoric.

The impact of government on the family is all pervasive. Taxation, social security, employment and housing policies, along with a vast range of other policies and programs, have an impact upon the ability of families to function effectively. Firstly, the Labor Party has done nothing about the major problem of our present system of taxation so far as it affects families. Families of the same composition and total income continue to be liable for substantially different amounts of tax. A family's tax liability is not assessed according to taxable capacity. It is largely determined by the proportions in which each spouse earns the family income. Secondly, Labor's tax and social security systems make inadequate allowance for the cost of maintaining dependent children , wives and husbands. It regards most expenditure on these dependants as a way in which taxpayers choose to enjoy their after-tax income and not as a measure of the increased needs of the family or its reduced capacity to pay tax.

Though it has now introduced two Budgets, Labor has not increased family allowances to a realistic level to take account of the cost of maintaining children, nor has it done anything to help families through tax reform. I believe that all families should be taxed on a partnership basis or the spouse rebate should be increased and supplementary rebates introduced so that one income families are on the same tax footing as two-income households with similar incomes. In applying the capacity to pay principle, account should be taken not only of the taxpayer's income but also of the extent to which others are wholly or partly dependent on that income. To make the tax and the social security systems fair and to lessen the drift from private sector to public sector dependency, the tax burden of those supporting dependants should be reduced by the amount paid by the public sector by way of pensions for adults and children totally dependent for their income on the social security system.

Full income splitting for tax purposes can be achieved either by allowing families to be taxed on a partnership basis or by means of rebates to achieve the same result. Equality of tax treatment is introduced for all couples with similar incomes. Whichever method is chosen, rebates should be used to ensure that sole parents, taxpayers who live alone or two-income families who incur costs earning a second income, are not at the same time adversely affected or unfairly treated. Not only did the Budget fail to help families, it also failed to recognise the needs of many who lack a sufficient degree of economic independence. The current social security pension and benefits scheme has the effect of providing the vast majority of adults with a guaranteed minimum income . The largest groups not covered by our categorical income maintenance system are: Unemployed married women, mothers of young children, other home makers and some full time students. This is because in providing income tested pensions, benefits and allowances, it is, in the case of married women, assumed that half of their spouse's income is available for their support and, in the case of students, that their parents will and should provide for them, whatever their age, up to the age of 25.

It is my view that our income security system should be made more comprehensive . As a first step, something should be done for women by converting the spouse rebate into a cash allowance so that women who are at home and who have no income of their own are given some degree of economic independence.

In the light of what I said earlier, I want to conclude by pointing out that I believe that tax and social security benefits paid to taxpaying families should be categorised as tax refunds and not as social expenditure. In this Budget Labor has failed women who are not engaged in paid employment, and it has failed children and it has failed families.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1984-85 Budget can, I believe, be categorised by three important features: Firstly, it provides taxation concessions for the vast majority of Australians; secondly, it extends the assistance given to the poorest sections of our society by substantial increases in expenditure on welfare, housing and health; and thirdly, it has reduced the size of the Budget deficit from $8 billion in 1983-84 to an estimated $6.75 billion this year. As a proportion of gross domestic product the deficit is estimated to decline by a full percentage point to 4.3 per cent. The Budget has therefore achieved what the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia thought impossible. Their view has always been that the Government could not increase social welfare expenditure without further increasing taxes or the size of the Budget deficit. This Budget has proved them wrong again.

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget will demonstrate that increased government involvement in the economy is not only desirable but crucial to the health of the economy and that this can be achieved in a way which is non-inflationary and productive. This Budget, I believe, needs to be examined in the context of the overall performance of the economy since the Australian Labor Party came to power 18 months ago. The gross domestic product in 1984 is forecast by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development to grow by 6 per cent, or at least one percentage point higher than every other OECD country.

More jobs have been created during the period of the Labor Government than during any other period in Australia's peacetime history. Since last April the number of jobs has increased by 234,000. Unemployment has fallen from 10.3 per cent in April 1983 to 8.9 per cent according to the latest figures. The job loss in the manufacturing industry area has been arrested and the same number of people were employed in manufacturing jobs in May this year as a year ago. We should compare that with the 100,000 jobs which were lost in the year before Labor gained office.

In the period of the Labor Government industrial relations have been more stable and more co-operative than in the memory of most Australians, and inflation has fallen from 11 per cent to 7.5 per cent. The latest consumer price index figure shows the lowest 12 month increase-3.9 per cent-for any quarter since the March quarter of 1973, over 10 years ago. During the period of the Labor Government business investment has risen by more than 5 per cent.

Commonwealth expenditure in the very important area of public housing has increased by 50 per cent. There has been a trade surplus of $282m in the year ended last June-a turnaround from a trade deficit of $950m in the previous year. That is a truly outstanding record for a government. It is a record of which this Labor Government is proud. With that record in mind perhaps it is little wonder that the Liberal Party and National Party leaderships are running scared in this latter part of 1984.

This Budget follows the Labor traditions of allocating a substantial commitment to extending assistance to the poorer sections of Australian society. I would like to address some of my comments to the contribution that has been made in this area. This Budget is an important and long overdue step in stemming the tide of poverty which has gripped an increasing proportion of the Australian population, the scale and extent of which has reached alarming proportions. Nine years ago Professor Henderson completed his inquiry into poverty in Australia, the results of which showed that 1.3 million Australians lived in conditions of severe hardship-that is, even below the austere poverty line threshold established by the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty. Since then, more recent surveys carried out by social welfare organisations indicate that this figure has more than doubled. One such survey conducted by the Australian Council of Social Service in 1982 estimated 2.8 million or one in six Australians lived in poverty, and that is said to be a conservative estimate. Accordingly, ACOSS recommended that the poverty line should be raised by 20 per cent above the Henderson poverty threshold as it was found that most people with incomes less than this amount were in crisis.

A major cause for the rapid increase in the numbers of impoverished Australians over this period was undoubtedly the rise in the growing army of unemployed whose ranks were swelled by a quarter of a million people during the period of the Fraser Government. The responsibility for this tragedy clearly rests in the hands of the Liberal and National parties as a result of the policies they pursued and which directed their priorities in Budget allocations, taxation concessions and fiscal incentives to the wealthy and vested interests which they represent. However, not content merely to condemn a quarter of a million people to the dole queue, the Liberal-National Party Government aggravated those conditions of poverty by pursuing ruthless cost cutting measures, such as freezing the single unemployment benefit and other allowances, during its period of government.

We heard it all again today when the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) talked about the soup kitchen mentality. He impliedly criticised Australian Labor Government expenditure in this important and vital area of social security . Members of the Opposition often trot out criticisms under a veiled and sophisticated title. However, when it comes right down to it, the Liberal and National parties have followed consistent policy of blaming the victims and hurting those who can least afford to bear the brunt of economic crisis. The legacy of the policies pursued by the Liberal and National parties is still with us today. An indication of the desperate situation which faces many Australians was recently provided by the results of a first six-monthly survey of applicants for social welfare assistance in New South Wales carried out by the New South Wales Department of Youth and Community Services. Items covered by social welfare assistance in New South Wales include clothing, blankets, cash assistance, rental assistance and transport concessions. This survey indicated that this scheme which was set up to function as a means of providing emergency grants and support to people in crisis, has now become a way of life. Thousands of people just cannot make ends meet because of the crisis they are in. As I have already indicated, quite clearly that crisis has resulted from the free market, heartless policies that the Liberal-National parties pursued during their period in government.

How can members of the Opposition possibly reconcile the philosophy of efficiency in resource allocation, which they purportedly follow, with the evidence of eight years of Liberal and National Party practice? Where is the efficiency in an economic system which consigned a quarter of a million people- the most productive agents on this planet-to become a wasted resource in the a queue? The most shameful aspect of their policies is the situation of the young.

I want to speak about another friend of the Liberal and National parties who burst into prominence in the media last week. Of course, I am speaking about Mr John Stone who, in a speech which received much publicity, made a great appeal for the plight of the unemployed. I am not subject to the proprieties that constrain the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), whose loyalty to Mr Stone has been unbelievable in the face of gross disloyalty by that gentleman to them. It is my view that Mr Stone's beliefs were cynical and hypocritical. They emanated from a man who quite clearly presided over 10 years of economic decline and whose economic policies--

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I respectfully suggest that this matter should be the subject of a substantive motion. There is nothing worse than a member of this place attacking somebody outside this place. I suggest that if the honourable member is going to attack a great Australian such as Mr John Stone he should do so by way of a substantive motion.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—The honourable member for Denison has raised another point that should be answered. Those who purport to be the greatest defenders of traditions in this country and the greatest defenders of the establishment and propriety are the first ones to tear down those pillars of the establishment when it suits them. The honourable member for Denison is one of the first to do that, be it his support for his Party's attacks on the judiciary and the breaking down of the Westminster system, his attacks on the principle of the independence of the Public Service or the role that his Party plays in attacking the Australian Constitution as it did very effectively in 1975. The very ones who purport to defend traditional principles are the first ones to tear down those traditional values when it suits them for some opportunistic reason.

SPEECH.PARA: I was saying that I believe Mr Stone's comments were very cynical and hypocritical because, as a senior officer of the Treasury, he presided over a period of Liberal government that was responsible for massive unemployment among young Australians. It is my belief that the demise of Mr Stone represented the end to that free market Mafia in the Treasury which promoted the outdated irrelevant creed of monetarism, the failure of which is evident not only in Australia, Britain and America but also in other parts of the world. This Budget , as I have indicated, is a further important step towards correcting some of the major inequalities and injustices in Australia. Much more, however, needs to be done. I am convinced that the economic policies of the second Hawke Government will be as successful as the policies of our present Government. As I have already indicated, it is not surprising that the Liberal and National parties are running scared.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the report is true that this Budget debate is to be terminated tonight, I must protest on behalf of very many of my colleagues who will be denied an opportunity to speak. If this is the case, this will have been the shortest Budget debate in history. I guess the Government's attitude is understandable because the more this Budget comes under scrutiny the more its inconsistencies, fallacies and deceptions are exposed. Opposition speakers have eloquently and accurately exposed these things and apparently the Government has no answer but quickly to terminate the debate. What we are seeing is part of the Government's unseemly haste to get to an election before it comes apart at the seams, and the symptoms of that disintegration are legion and are increasing daily.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened very intently to the contribution of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). He delivered an apologia which will convince no one. As the honourable member for Darling Downs (Mr McVeigh) has clearly shown, and as I will indicate as I speak, the primary producers of Australia have been forgotten and betrayed. All of the optimism for recovery and stability is predicated on a viable primary industry. This Minister knows that all he has done is to add more lead to its saddlebags. He was left with nothing but an apologia to present. Despite his pretty words, not one primary producer in Australia will be in any doubt about that. The Government knows about, and even takes credit for, the breaking of the drought. That has been its salvation. How does the Minister now justify reducing rural reconstruction by 42 per cent? What a Minister he is! Despite what the Minister now says, there is no doubt in the minds of the sugar growers and the sugar industry that this Government as an election promise committed itself to an underwriting scheme for that industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is it now?

—Well, the Government and the Minister may engage in whatever semantics they wish, but I know what the industry believes. The industry believes that it was given an assurance, a commitment, and that that solemn promise has been completely dishonoured. So the Minister should not come into this House time after time and claim that he has been misrepresented. He should confront the sugar growers. I have heard these words loudly and clearly from the sugar growers that I have met: 'We know what was said. We know what has happened . The promise to us has gone into the waste paper basket, along with a host of other spurious promises'.

SPEECH.PARA: Today the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) spent much time listing a score or two of those broken promises. Another Budget strike against primary producers is the revelation that minimum livestock value in tax returns will be more than doubled. The effect of that is not lost on dairymen and stock owners because, without any trading at all, in the first year there could well be by valuation increase alone an increase in taxable income. No matter what the year is, good or bad, the Government can catch them if they use the minimum taxation values, even if they do not sell a single head of stock.

This Budget is a confidence trick which has failed. It is not a blueprint for a stable national future. It fails to come to grips with the structural deficit. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has clearly and often shown this . It is based on premises and projections which are not sustainable. It is the harbinger of a 1985-86 Budget which, the other side of an election, will expose all of the fallacies, miscalculations and dangers in the documents we are now discussing. But the nation will not be hoodwinked by cliches. It will condemn the architects of this Budget. I will address some of these matters in more detail as I proceed.
This is the twelfth Budget I have seen presented as a member of this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twelfth?

—It is the twelfth and it is the worst. I have always found the documents headed 'Budget Statements' very fascinating. They give the basis of calculation, the reasoning for projections and some indication of Treasury's thinking. They let the cat out of the bag. In all of those years, I have never seen such suspect premises, such unsustained and indeed quite often contradictory projection bases. Nor have I ever seen so clearly expressed the qualifications placed on revenue and expenditure estimates. It contains a great big 'E and OE', metaphorically, in red letters. I recommend to Government members that they refrain from rereading the speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating ) and spend some time reading those statements and doing a big of figuring. I assure them that it is not the good news document that the Treasurer would have us believe.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer's sums are wrong and his projections grievously in error. For instance, has he heard of the desperate plight of the great sugar industry, dumping by the European Economic Community, no International Sugar Agreement, falling prices and second and third generation sugar producers sold up in bankruptcy?

TALK.START.PARA: —They have to go to the bankers to get their permission to draw their cheques for groceries.

—Indeed, that is true, and the situation is getting worse. The convoluted mathematics of the Treasurer, when faced with record Government expenditure, the massive proportion of gross domestic product, must perplex and dismay Australia. He says 'You should not count Medicare; you should not count the national debt interest' and so on. Before he has finished he will deny responsibility for any spending. However, the fact remains that in seven years of the Fraser Government average real growth of Federal Government outlays was 2 per cent. In less than two years of Hawke Government, the average real growth rate is 7 per cent-a turnaround indeed, but not the sort the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer are talking about. This is a turnaround that they do not want underlined.

SPEECH.PARA: Even the big spending Whitlam Government must dip its hat in awe at the profligate capacity of the Hawke Government. For all of the Treasurer's talk of a strengthening economy, it is fact that employment, consumer spending and growth rely on the health of small business. Small business provides the jobs. It is the cornerstone of regional and national prosperity. In this Budget nothing has been done to encourage or support small business.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the biggest employer of labour.

—It is the biggest employer of labour. As I look around the electorate in which I live I see no expansion. I see increasing numbers of small businesses going to the wall, with employees being thrown out of work.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government of Queensland has shown real initiative and real concern in setting up its small business advisory services. But what does this Federal Government provide? It provides simply a provision for the taxation treatment of losses-prophetic, is it not? One can make mileage by assisting the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and the motor vehicle industry, but, quite frankly, the short-sighted neglect which shows no concern for small business is what will weaken our economy and stability and cause more unemployment. That neglect I condemn.

What about our school leavers? The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) expresses eloquent concern and talks of a great future for them in technological advance. But he came out of the Budget discussions with little but the seat out of his pants. We must face reality and not dream dreams or engage in hyperbole and political grandstanding. Our school leavers, so many of them with little prospect beyond community employment program schemes or the dole, deserve far better than that. This Budget does not do one thing to come to grips with that. There is no attention to structural deficit problems, just a few clumsy band-aid measures to get past an election. All that stands between this Government and national bankruptcy is Australia's primary producers and small businesses. Yet this Government goes on kicking them in the teeth and this Budget is a classic example of that.

All of the flowery language and hyperbole about supposed tax cuts falls absolutely to the ground. The Budget Papers show that pay as you earn taxpayers will provide 53.1 per cent of the Budget receipts. Those average wage earners, whom the Government is supposed to be supporting, are revealed in the Government 's Budget statements to have their tax bill increased by a hefty 23 per cent. Some tax cut! I hope we never get an increase. With more and more workers reaching the 46 per cent tax bracket for additional income, we have reached the level where we do not have taxation; we have confiscation. The supposed tax cuts will not operate until 1 November anyway, and that is just before the elections.

What a tissue of misrepresentation and a farrago of nonsense are the Treasurer' s and the Prime Minister's claims that there are tax cuts and taxation relief in this Budget.
