If we add the surreptitious automatic twice-yearly increases in indirect taxation, we see further proof of the magnitude of our taxation burden which has not been honestly addressed, despite all of the promises.

The Treasurer made a statement in answer to a question in this House, which is totally unacceptable and completely illogical. When talking about the growth in outlays he said that we can really deduct 2.2 per cent because:
We have taken a private charge, Medicare, which was formerly paid by people over the counter to health insurance funds.

What an astounding statement that is when we look at it. Firstly, he is paying out what he is first collecting from the taxpayer. A ledger has two sides. If he wants to use that rather amazing method of bookkeeping, he must also admit that the private charge, Medicare, which he has taken as he describes it, is financed by a very hefty levy or tax. In the Budget statements at page 366 we read:
Notwithstanding the impact of tax cuts from 1 November 1984, personal income taxes are expected to rise to an historically high level.
The Treasurer said this-
relative to GDP in 1984-85; in the main, this reflects the full year effect of the Medicare levy and the strong growth in primary producer incomes in 1983-84.

Further, if the Treasurer thinks his statement will be happily received in Queensland, he will be very sadly disillusioned. I remind him that in Queensland people receive free hospital and medical treatment without private health insurance. To them, Medicare is not a substitution; it is a new and additional tax. Many people who want the services of their doctor in private hospital accommodation are hit twice. They pay the Medicare levy, not instead of but in addition to sizable private health insurance.

The Treasurer's claim is spurious. He has substituted single entry bookkeeping for double entry bookkeeping. He has also neglected to say that in Queensland, in particular, he has not taken over outlays previously paid to private health funds; he has added a brand new tax on to them. Queenslanders are slugged by this Treasurer for the same service which the Queensland State Government provided free. Worse still, there is no family rate. Every individual taxpayer pays the levy. Some families pay a double penalty. His cavalier approach, when faced with the fact that revenue tax collections are the heaviest and the highest since the war, is to make nonsensical claims such as this. There is no way the people of Australia will fall for that pea and thimble trick, certainly not when they are filling in their income tax forms and realising the full impact of the Medicare levy in the radical reduction in the refunds they are receiving from the Australian Taxation Office.

Let us look at the legacy which is bequeathed to this nation by governments which are committed to big spending, a mushrooming bureaucracy and socialist centralism. For a government to come into this House extolling the virtues of an unacceptably high deficit is disastrous news for taxpayers, present and future. The Australian people had best take heed that a warning is sounded in the Budget statements that revision of the accounts may reveal that revenue might be overstated and expenditure understated. So if ever figures are admittedly rubbery, those are. That is the Budget's assessment of its own veracity. That is the alibi in advance. When we get to the stage where interest on the national debt is within much the same parameters as the appropriation for defence, should we not worry?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is more than for education.

—As my colleague says, it is more than education. Young Australians, some of whom are just starting to pay tax and some of whom are not yet taxpayers , are being faced with a huge future repayment which is achievable only by way of increased taxation. They are being betrayed by a government which is piously proclaiming it cares for them. Despite the hyena laughs directed from the Government benches at the probing questions by the shadow Treasurer about the next Budget, the truth will out. John Stone said:

SPEECH.PARA: Growing public debt could defer-if not fundamentally impair-the chances of lasting recovery in the longer run.

He pointed out that there is a price of $5,000 on the head of every man, woman and child in Australia as a result of Australia having to borrow more money than we collect in revenue. Although the Government has benefited by the breaking of the drought, it is fallacy to expect that the primary industries of this country can continue to replenish the coffers.

The Prime Minister and the Treasurer have trumpeted forth that this Budget helps the family man and the disadvantaged. They have also claimed, in talking of their iniquitous assets test, that by curtailing payments to those in better circumstances more assistance can be given to those in greater need. Let us test the honesty of those claims. We find not only a glorious inconsistency but also another attack on the family and the institution of marriage. Did the Government do anything about the family allowance? Did it increase the spouse rebate allowance? No, it did not. These are areas of need and are worthy of support. The Prime Minister, in a characteristic charade, said that it would cost too much. What did the Government do? It quite willingly saddled the taxpayer with the cost of extending the travel rights of members' spouses to de facto partners . Without a thought to cost, the Government has extended the spouse taxation rebate to include de factos. Quite plainly and bluntly, that is the equation. That is the Government's priority. It costs too much to increase the family and spouse rebate allowances. But apparently the further attack on marriage and the family by extending this largesse to de factos is a legitimate cost to load on to taxpayers.
Government members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite can laugh if they like. Those may be the priorities and the values of the Hawke Government, but they are not mine and they are not that of many decent Australians.
—And National Party members, of course.

—Certainly National Party members. Already we are seeing the inevitable extension of that line of thinking. Demands are being made for similar extensions to homosexual partners. Surely, sometime, somewhere, the Government must take some sort of stand. Apparently the family is unworthy of consideration or support. Extra-marital relations are subsidised and apparently encouraged. The Government's boast that it helps those in need, and those worthy of support, is patent nonsense. Like every other claim, it falls down under scrutiny. The Government's priorities are questionable. Its sense of values is terribly warped.

SPEECH.PARA: For all of the Dorothy Dix questions and the notices of motion propagated by the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) which extol the first home owners scheme, we now see clearly the hollow concern of this Government in this Budget. Land prices are frightening. Building costs have escalated and continue to escalate. Young couples have to defer having a family because both partners have to work to get a deposit to begin to pay off a home. Interest rates and repayments are high. Young couples face monthly repayments of $300, $ 400 and much more. How serious is the Government in its claim that it wants to help people, and young people, buy their own homes? What about the tax rebate on mortgage interest? We know what the Government did about that. Was increased help made available to assist people to put together an adequate deposit in view of increased costs? Not on your life! Fiddling around with the income limits ensured that many people were denied help. Fewer couples qualified; not more. That is a simple matter of mathematics. Single applicants have had the allowable income limit halved. That is how this Government is helping.

So much for the Government's spurious boast that it wants to help home ownership. So much for its claim that it wants to stimulate the home building industry. Where is the consistency or honesty in that exercise? How the Government's claims crumble when we put them under the searchlight of analysis. No wonder the Prime Minister and Ministers seek to divert questions which probe their record, by charade, vilification, sarcasm and red herrings. The Government 's own Budget statements condemn its projections out of hand. After reading about recovery and a great rosy future, on page 71 we read:

A country like Australia, whose terms of trade are highly sensitive to commodity prices, would be particularly vulnerable to any major falling off in the level of world economic activity and associated slowing in world trade.

On page 69 we read that exports are forecast to grow strongly. This statement is linked with prospects of a record sugar crop. As I have already said, there is a crisis, if the Government does not know it, in the sugar industry. That industry has seen dumping, oversupply and falling prices. The monthly paper published by the Department of the Treasury, which was quoted in the Brisbane Courier Mail of 22 August, forecast some very grim things. It stated that if we can sell our coal we cannot expect increased prices. It said the same things about wheat, sugar, iron ore and alumina. Thus the Treasury view is that Australia's growth will be impeded as many of our commodities sell overseas at historically low prices. Let the Government deny that. None of this sits very happily or comfortably with the song which the Treasurer is trilling.

I condemn this Budget. The people of Australia will condemn it. Already there is evidence of it. As each new day dawns and the truth emerges, that resentment increases. The Budget is no blueprint for recovery. It is not a plan for sustained growth or economic stability. It is the epitaph of the Hawke Labor Government which has failed this nation and failed it miserably.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to use my time, speaking to Appropriation Bill (No. 1), to take up a number of major criticisms made by the Opposition in this debate and to repudiate them. The first one to which I refer is the charge that this Budget is a big spending Budget. That charge is patently false. If one looks at the overall terms one will see that outlays increased by 13 per cent, which compares with 18.5 per cent in 1982-83, the last year of the previous Government. On the basis of the nominal figures, our increase in outlays is far less than the increase which occurred in the last year of the Fraser Government. If one looks at real terms, certainly the picture is a bit different. Inflation has fallen considerably under this Government, but still we see there is a lesser real increase under this Government than in the last year of the Fraser Government. Real outlays have gone up by 6.1 per cent in this Budget, which is less than the 6.5 per cent real increase in 1982-83.

SPEECH.PARA: So in either nominal or real terms the increase in outlays in this Budget is less than in the last year of the previous Government. So much for the charge that in overall terms there is a big spending Government. It is obviously spending less than the Fraser Government did in 1982-83.

With regard to compositional factors, the House should be aware that there are special factors built into our increase in outlays which indicate that this is a very tight Budget on the expenditure side. There has been a big increase in public debt interest expenditures which has been referred to by previous speakers. These have grown rapidly over the last two years. Indeed, expenditure on public debt interest has gone up by 94 per cent over the past two years and in that time has added $2.5 billion to outlays. This year the increase is $1.3 billion and represents 18 per cent of total expenditure. This big increase in public debt, it must be emphasised, is not attributable to the present Government. The reason we have this enormous increase in public debt is that we have had a very large increase in the Budget deficit, a situation which this Government inherited, and also that we had in the first half of 1983-84 a large private capital inflow which had to be soaked up, and I will come to that in a moment.

Let me go back to the deficit. The fact is that when this Government came into office it inherited a situation in which the Budget deficit for 1983-84 was headed for a figure of $9.6 billion, an enormous blowout and a situation which we, as an incoming government, picked up. It was a result of the Fraser Government's Budget in 1982 and also because of the enormous recession into which the economy had been plunged largely because of the policies of the previous Government. We took action immediately to reduce the deficit. In 1983- 84 the deficit ended up $1.7 billion less than the figure which the Fraser Government was heading for when we came into office; that is, $7.9 billion instead of $9.6 billion. The deficit in this financial year is another $1.2 billion below the 1983-84 level; in other words, in two years we have reduced that deficit by $3 billion below the figure that the Fraser Government was heading for in 1983-84.

We also took revolutionary action to end the private capital speculative inflow last year which created the need for some $2.5 billion to $3 billion of government securities to be issued to soak up the large amounts of private capital which came in, speculating against a revaluation of the Australian dollar. By floating the dollar in December we stopped that private capital inflow and that, of course, was a revolutionary action. Since that time there has been no problem. The previous Government, of course, would never have taken that action. We took that dramatic action and it has been very successful. But in the interim period before we did so, we had, as I said, to put out government securities to the order of $3 billion to soak up the money supply impact of that private capital inflow. Those securities created a debt interest expenditure for this year's Budget of $300m to $400m.

Those are the factors which have created this enormous increase in public debt interest. For the Opposition to squeal about this Government being responsible for it, of course, is an absolute absurdity. We have taken dramatic action on the deficit side and in terms of the exchange rate fixation procedures to prevent that situation from becoming worse and to redress it considerably. The other factor which must be taken into account-the other compositional factor-in regard to our expenditures, of course, is Medicare. Medicare was introduced in 1983-84, but 1984-85 is its first full year. It added $1.4 billion to outlays in this year's Budget. But this is not on top of private expenditures as is the way with normal government expenditure. It replaces what was previously a private expenditure, so it is a special one-off factor that will not be repeated in terms of an increase in government expenditure in future years.

Those two expenditure factors-public debt interest and Medicare-added $2.5 billion to government expenditures in this year's Budget and accounted for 34 per cent of the total increase in government expenditure. Alternatively, one could say that it accounted for 4 per cent of the 6.1 per cent increase in real outlays. Outside those two exceptional areas, the Government has clearly been very restrictive on its outlays. All other outlays account only for an increase of 2 per cent in total outlays. So we can see that there is no big spending. Once one leaves aside the two special factors with which the Government was faced, we had very tight limits on expenditures. Opposition charges about a big spending Budget simply do not stand up.

In regard to overall tax levels, the Opposition points to a rise in overall individual income tax receipts of 23 per cent. But this is totally misleading in regard to what is actually happening to the tax obligations of wage and salary earners. Again, there are a number of special factors involved. The Medicare levy applying for a full year for the first time pushes up receipts on the Medicare levy by 226 per cent. The Medicare levy stays the same, at one per cent levy of taxable incomes, but receipts are well up because of its being a full year of operation. Provisional tax receipts are up by 45 per cent, mainly because of a big increase in farm incomes in 1983-84 and also in other business profits, and the fact that the taxes are raised on those in this financial year. The prescribed payments tax also has a 39 per cent increase in receipts this year, not because it is being increased, but because it is its first full year of operation.

In regard to pay as you earn tax payments, the taxes which are relevant to most wage and salary earners-that is, the tax taken out of the pay packets of wage and salary earners during the year-are up by 10.7 per cent, far below the 23 per cent figure that is talked about by the Opposition. The claims by the Opposition that the tax cuts in the Budget are not real, that they are a deception and that they are less than tax indexation are, of course, absurd. The fact is that the tax cuts that have been given in this Budget are undeniably real for the overwhelming majority of taxpayers. If one looks at the overall level of expenditure, one can immediately see that that is the case. The cost of tax indexation-tax indexation being adjustment of the tax scale to stop the tax obligations of people going up when their incomes are simply keeping up with inflation-would have been $985m. The cost of our tax cuts is $1.3 billion; that is, 32 per cent more than tax indexation.

If one looks at the structure of the tax cuts, one sees that most wage and salary earning taxpayers will receive tax cuts well in advance of tax indexation . Indeed, all taxpayers earning between $135 a week and $540 a week, which is 80 per cent of taxpayers, obtain tax cuts in excess of tax indexation. All taxpayers earning between $240 a week and $375 a week, which is 36 per cent of all taxpayers, obtain a tax cut which is over three times the level that tax indexation would have given them; that is, they get $7.60 a week instead of the $2.30 that they would have got from taxation indexation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which demonstrates those points.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. This table demonstrates the points I have made and shows that most wage earners will receive very real tax cuts. The table also shows that tax cuts are equivalent to very substantial wage increases. For those earning between $240 and $374 a week, the tax cut represents the equivalent of a wage rise of $10.86 a week; that is, it gives the same amount in the pay packet as a wage rise of that amount. For those earning between $375 and $540 a week who are in a higher marginal tax bracket, the tax cut represents the equivalent of a wage rise of $14.08 a week. So for the overwhelming majority of taxpayers, the tax cuts are undeniably real. It represents a very substantial tax cut. The third criticism which is used is that the Budget deficit is too high. The Opposition claims that the Budget deficit is too high by about $1 billion to $1. 5 billion. In regard to that claim, let me say this: Firstly, the deficit for this year is almost $3 billion less than that left to this Government by the Fraser Government for 1983-84. Secondly, the Opposition's claim that the deficit should be reduced contrasts totally with its calls for increased expenditure and reduced taxes in a whole host of areas.

SPEECH.PARA: I will give some examples. In the course of this debate we have heard calls by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) and his minions to increase expenditure on family allowances, child care and pension levels; provide an increase in the spouse rebate and home ownership assistance; the abolition of the assets test and the superannuation lump sum tax; increased investment incentives to business; increased expenditure on rural industries and rural centres; and higher tax cuts. We have had all of those claims for increased expenditure and reduced taxes from the Opposition at the same time as it berates this Government for having a Budget deficit that is too high. How can one possibly put together those two sides of the argument? The answer is, of course, that one cannot. The Opposition has absolutely no credibility in this debate because at the same time as it condemns the Government for having a high Budget deficit, it calls on us to take action which would clearly, on the face of it, blow the deficit way out and create a situation which is totally the opposite of what it is calling for.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting, I was describing to the House the illogicality and hypocrisy of the Opposition's position in this Budget debate. On the one hand it has called for a reduction in the deficit by another billion to a billion and a half dollars, and on the other hand it has called on the Government to increase expenditure in a whole host of areas and to cut taxes in a whole host of areas. Both those actions, of course, would have increased the deficit. The Opposition is in an impossible situation in this debate. None of its contributions to this debate has sought to bring about some overall rationality in its position. It has in no way sought to bring together those two divergent arms in its debate. It remains totally without credibility on its economic position.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition clearly has no economic policy to speak of. It simply has a lot of rhetoric, many arguments and much criticism to make about the Government on a whole host of areas. If we try to put it together, it simply does not make a credible argument. Opposition members obviously went out of government totally bereft of any economic credibility. A year and a half later they are still totally without it. None of their contributions to this debate in any way would have convinced anyone in this country that they have learnt anything from their year and a half in opposition.

I will refer to one other area in which the Opposition has been making accusations against the Government. Those accusations are completely without foundation. The Leader of the Opposition, in particular, and other Opposition members have been declaring that the Government has taken action which has led to declines in living standards for Australians generally. The effrontery of the Opposition in raising this allegation is quite amazing. It is not only patently wrong but also amazing that those who presided over policies designed to reduce living standards when in office now seek to accuse the Government of such action . When Opposition members left office they had in place a wage freeze which, in the face of inflation of 11.5 per cent, was clearly designed to lead to a fall in living standards. They had in their period in office slashed living standards of many lower income earners, particularly those on the unemployment benefit, and particularly the single unemployed. Of course, they had created many unemployed while they were in office and that had led to greatly reduced living standards for those people. In contrast, this Government has taken a whole series of actions designed to protect and improve the living standards of ordinary Australians.

In regard to a wage policy, we broke the wages freeze, but not in any irrational way. We instituted a wage indexation system designed to protect living standards of wage and salary earners. In regard to tax policy, we have given tax cuts, as I indicated prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner , well above tax indexation to most wage and salary earners and other lower middle income earners. We have introduced Medicare, which has reduced the cost of health insurance for many Australians and ensured coverage to many who had no such coverage before. In the interest rate area, we have reduced mortgage interest rates by one per cent to 2 per cent which means that the cost of housing repayments on a $30,000 loan, for instance, has fallen by between $24 and $48 a month.

We have reduced the level of unemployment by 100,000-odd from the peak in September last year and so considerably improved the living standards of those people who now have jobs who did not have jobs previously. We have reduced the inflation rate from 11.5 per cent when we came into office to 3.9 per cent now. If we exclude the Medicare effect on the CPI the inflation rate is 6.5 per cent. Either way, it is a very substantial reduction. People with fixed assets or fixed incomes are now having those assets or incomes reduced by the impact of inflation by a much lesser rate than was the case prior to our coming to office.

In the social security field we have increased the value of all pensions and benefits faster than inflation. We have increased the value of the single unemployment benefit much faster than inflation. Indeed, by May of next year it will have increased by 30 per cent in the two years since we came into office. We have increased the dependent children's allowance by 40 per cent for pensioners and beneficiaries. We have increased the supplementary assistance for low income pensioners renting privately by 50 per cent. So quite clearly we have improved the lot of welfare recipients, particularly those most in need. So it is absurd to argue that this Government has been reducing living standards. The opposite is quite clearly the case.

Finally, I would just refer to the Opposition's failure in this debate to acknowledge economic reality. Throughout this debate the Opposition has argued as though the economy were in the deplorable state it was in when it left office . Of course, the facts are completely the opposite. There has been a dramatic improvement, far better than anyone could realistically have hoped for. The last year of the previous Government, 1982-83, was the worst year for the Australian economy since the Great Depression of the 1930s. By contrast, 1983-84, the financial year we have just been through, was the best year for economic growth since the 1930s; indeed, it was the best year since we have kept records of our national accounts. We had 3.7 per cent growth in employment and falling unemployment, falling interest rates and falling inflation rates. By any standards it was a tremendously good year for the Australian economy. This Government has shown that it has what it takes in regard to economic policy.

This Budget provides a sound basis on which the enormous gains of 1983-84 can be consolidated and continued. It strikes an appropriate balance between the need to reduce the deficit and the need to ensure a continuance of economic activity until private investment picks up. As all the indicators show, that will be the case in the second half of this financial year. The Budget provides additional incentives to business to encourage further private investment. It protects the prices and incomes accord by providing substantial tax cuts to wage and salary earners, thereby providing a sound basis for expecting strong growth of output and employment during this financial year. It protects the most needy in our community by concentrating expenditure and welfare benefits on them. It clearly is a Budget which deserves the strong support of every person in the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia in 1984 is in even greater danger than it was in 1975. Heaven knows that in the dark years of 1972 to 1975 the Whitlam Government brought this country to the brink of bankruptcy and it endangered, indeed wounded, the fabric of our society, the structure of our federation, the strength of our institutions and the traditional Australian way of life. The great threat confronting all Australians today is the threat of the Hawke socialist Government and the risk that this Government may con its way into a second term in office.

SPEECH.PARA: I have always referred to the Hawke socialist Government as such because that is what it is. Let me say very bluntly that we have now reached a stage in the political history of Australia when a spade must be called a spade. I am sick and tired of people who talk to me about the Left and the centre Left and the medium Right and the unity faction and all those other terms. The plain fact is that this country is under the control of a government, the Prime Minister of which is a committed, dedicated and thoroughly ruthless socialist. I remind everybody listening to this broadcast and those in the chamber that some 12 years ago the Sydney Morning Herald on 4 September 1972 had a very interesting news report. Under the headline 'Labor is Socialist Hawke Says', the following appeared:

The Australian Labor Party is a Socialist Party, ACTU President Mr Hawke says. He had no respect for anyone who denied this, Mr Hawke said last night. Mr Hawke was speaking at Belmont, a Newcastle suburb, at the opening of the Federal campaign for the seat of Shortland in support of Mr Peter Morris.
that is, the present Minister for Transport-
Mr Hawke said the Labor Party was a Socialist-based organisation.
'I have never at any time tried to walk away from the fact that I am a dedicated and convinced Socialist myself', he said.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he say that in the 1940s or the 1950s?
—He said that in 1972. Just 12 years ago the present Prime Minister of Australia said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have never at any time tried to walk away from the fact that I am a dedicated and convinced socialist myself.
The newspaper report goes on:

He believed that overwhelmingly his colleagues within the Parliamentary Labor Party were convinced that the best way to run Australia was by organised socialism. But he warned that Australians were not yet ready to vote for a program of Socialisation.
The report continued:

If you went out tonight between now and the next Federal Election and said you were going to bring in Socialism, you would not get in because for too long the people of Australia have been brainwashed into believing Socialism is something evil, Mr Hawke said.

The present Prime Minister said that people had been brainwashed into believing there was something undemocratic about socialism. There we have the words of the then President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, now the Prime Minister of Australia. 'I am a dedicated and convinced socialist myself', he says. 'The best way to run Australia is by organised socialism'. But then he says: 'We do not want to say too much about it because the people of Australia are not yet ready for it'.

What have we seen in the last 17 months? We have seen the charade, the fraud and the confidence trick of a socialist government pretending that it is not socialist, a socialist government going quietly in its first term because, having conned the electors once, it thinks it can do so again. Every single member of the Australian Labor Party is bound by a platform, one of the fundamental commitments of which is the socialisation of Australia.

I say bluntly and unequivocally that Australians ought to wake up because the man who is Prime Minister of Australia, the man who parades himself as Mr Consensus and Mr Sweet Reason, is a self-confessed dedicated socialist. Looking at his track record, do not think for one minute that he will waste a second in getting implemented the objectives that he wishes to see implemented to turn this country into a socialist republic. The Prime Minister, a self-confessed socialist, is also a self-styled President of what he likes to see as some Australian socialist republic. I believe that he single-handedly poses a greater threat to the future of this nation than Mr Whitlam and his Government ever did.

We have in office a Prime Minister who gained the leadership of his Party in brutal fashion. We have in office a Prime Minister who conned his way to power on election promises which he knew or ought to have known he could not possibly honour. We have in office today a Prime Minister who quite blatantly seeks to rewrite history by misrepresenting the position as it was when he came to power and who repeatedly misrepresents the position as it is today. I wonder how many people listening to this broadcast will remember those stirling words on the stage of the Sydney Opera House when in one of the greatest theatrical performances of Australian political history this century, the then honourable member for Wills, now the Prime Minister of Australia, said: 'My Government will introduce immediate tax cuts for 99 per cent of Australians'. He gave this clear and unequivocal commitment: 'My Government will introduce immediate tax cuts for 99 per cent of Australians'. What do we see 17 months later? We see a situation in which from the time of the Government's election until the day of the delivery of the Budget last week, the people of Australia are paying an extra $ 22.41 a week in taxes under the Hawke socialist Government than they paid when Malcolm Fraser was Prime Minister. As I have said before and I will say again, the secret wicked taxation by stealth of Prime Minister Hawke starts to make Malcolm Fraser look a bit like Father Christmas.

On the day of the Budget in came the members of the Government and said: ' Marvellous, here are your immediate tax cuts'-17 months after they were promised . What do the cuts turn out to be? They turn out to be a miserable tax cut of $7 .60 a week. 'But' they say, wait for it, in the Budget itself your taxes will go up by $8 a week. So even with the phoney tax cuts these people are 40c worse off . If one cares to add that figure to the original $22.41 by which people were worse off before the Treasurer (Mr Keating) uttered a single word of the Budget Speech, every average Australian worker today under the Hawke socialist Government is paying $22.81 a week more in tax than he paid under Malcolm Fraser .
What was the second promise that the Prime Minister made upon which he conned his way into power? He said: 'My Government will not take any money out of the pensioners' cheques'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—My very good friend the honourable member for Moreton is here. My word, if ever there were a member who has fought for the pensioners in the electorates he has represented in his distinguished career in this Parliament, it is the honourable member for Moreton. What did this Prime Minister, the man who said he would bring Australia together, decide to do? First and foremost he decided he would declare war on the elderly-the pensioners, the superannuitants, the grandfathers and grandmothers of Australia, the men and women who have made this country what it is today. Mr Speaker, I remember last year saying something by way of interjection in this Parliament, and you very kindly did not rule it out of order. I said to the Prime Minister: 'Why don't you pick on someone your own age?' Look what he did. Within weeks of coming to power the income test on the over-70-year-olds was promptly reintroduced. The superannuation tax slug was next in line. The promise to lift the pensioners' tax threshold went out the window. Pension increases were reduced by the rigging of the consumer price index in the infamous Medicare fiddle, whereby over $200m has been snatched out of the hands of Australia's senior citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: Last, but not least, this cruel and heartless socialist Government pushes on with the Hawke assets test, pushing it through the Parliament this week. Knock, knock. 'Who's there?' 'It is one of Bob Hawke's stormtroopers'-one of the 1,500 inspectors who will persecute the pensioners of Australia. I say in passing that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) ought to be renamed the Minister for Gold Fillings. Nearly three months ago I pointed out to the Government that the way in which the legislation has been drawn up means that gold fillings in one's teeth constitute an assessable asset under the Hawke assets test. I was told that in the Senate on Tuesday Senator Grimes said that my statement was outrageous. The plain fact is that it is the truth. It was pointed out to the Hawke Government and it has not moved to amend the legislation. As I indicated in this Parliament this afternoon, a leading Australian dental surgeon has pointed out to me that many of our elderly people who have had extensive dental reconstruction would have at least $500 worth of recoverable gold in their mouths.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is disgusting; it is not true.

—The honourable member for Lilley can laugh and make fun of this but I have pointed out that the honourable member's cruel and heartless Government has done nothing about the situation. I challenge the Government to deny the fact that it has had legal advice that even the gold fillings in the teeth of pensioners of Australia constitute an asset under this wicked Hawke assets test. The most frightening thing of all is that I am told that as a matter of law these fillings will be an asset whether an elderly person is alive or dead.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government thought it had the pensioners in its pocket but grey power will rise up as its nemesis. I predict that thousands and thousands of pensioners, senior citizens of this country who may well have voted for the Labor Party in the past, will certainly not be voting for the Hawke socialist Government when we go to the polls later this year. The whole principle of bringing in an assets test which, on the Government's new figures will cost the people of Australia $ 55m in year one and which will terrorise thousands and thousands of our senior citizens, indicates how absolutely cynical the Government has become towards those people whom I believe really made Australia great today.

The Government intends to appoint 1,500 inspectors. We heard today the mealy- mouthed Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security in this place, saying: 'Of course, the inspectors will not have the power to enter people's property'. The Minister had better have a good look at the Income Tax Assessment Act. He had better have a look at the principal Act relating to this question, because I do not believe him. I do not think the pensioners in Australia will swallow his nonsense. What is the point in having an assets test if the Government is not giving someone the authority to implement it? It will be a case of, knock, knock, 'Who's there?' unless the people of Australia wake up to what is happening to them and make sure that this Government comes to the end of its term at the next Federal election which will be held this year.

Let us look at the next promise that the Government made. The next promise was that the Government would create 500,000 new jobs for Australians. As recently as the week before last the Prime Minister was falsely claiming that the Government was on target in honouring this promise. What a gross misrepresentation that was. On what possible basis could the Prime Minister make that claim? On 2 May in this Parliament the Prime Minister claimed that since April 1983, in 12 months, his Government had created-and I emphasise the word ' created'-210,000 new jobs. What did the media have to say about this claim? In stark contrast to the Prime Minister's claims, the Australian Financial Review said that the number of additional jobs created between February 1983 and February 1984 was only 101,000, that is, less than half the number claimed by the Prime Minister to have been created between April 1983 and April 1984. Even that, I suggest, was not due to the efforts of the Hawke Government. It was due to the economic strategy that was in place when the Fraser Government went out of power, the return to economic prosperity internationally and the breaking of the drought.

Does the Prime Minister really expect this Parliament and the people of Australia to believe that his Government has actually created 108,100 new jobs in just two months between February and April of this year? That is absolute nonsense. The Prime Minister must think that the people of Australia are a bunch of fools who will accept anything that he says just because he says it. On those three fundamental promises, immediate tax cuts, not taking money out of the pensioners' cheques and creating 500,000 new jobs, the Hawke socialist Government has betrayed the people of Australia because each of those promises has been dishonoured.

Let us have a look at the tax record as is demonstrated by the statistics for last year and this year. I am sorry that the Minister has fled from the chamber because he said he wanted to hear a little bit about economics. Personal income tax receipts rose in the first year of the Hawke socialist Government by 7.6 per cent, that is, in the 1983-84 financial year. In the 1984-85 financial year, the one we have just commenced, personal income tax receipts will rise by 23 per cent. In the space of just 12 months we have a situation in which personal income tax receipts will rocket by 30.6 per cent. What really frightens me is the fact that the growth in 1984-85 will be four times as fast as it was in 1983 -84, and, heavens knows, that was bad enough. Provisional tax receipts for the small businessmen, the farmers and the battlers who want to start their businesses, the people who are taxed in advance by this wicked socialist Government will go up by 44.7 per cent. If ever I have seen a government go from low gear to overdrive in less than 17 months, I have seen it with the Hawke socialist Government and what it has done on taxation.

Let us look at the terrible, wicked Malcolm Fraser, as the Prime Minister would like the people of Australia to believe he was. Of course Malcolm Fraser was not terrible and was not wicked. More and more people in Australia are ruing the day that this country put him out and this imposter in. In the last year of the Fraser Government income tax receipts were $22,967m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Say, $23 billion.

—All right, $23 billion. In the first year of the Hawke Government we see tax receipts go to $30.383 billion, which is an increase of $7 billion in just one year. It is an increase of 32.3 per cent-and this is the Government which says to the people of Australia: 'We have done you a very good turn. You have got some tax cuts. You are doing very well indeed'. I do not think the people of Australia will swallow that and I think they have already noted that the tax refund cheques this year are the smallest that have been delivered to any Australians in nearly 20 years. I hope that a few hundred thousand more of these tax refund cheques come out between now and the election.

SPEECH.PARA: Do I need to say anything about the way in which this wicked, rotten and corrupt Government has treated Australia's smallest but most beautiful State. The treatment of Tasmania in the 1984-85 Hawke socialist Budget is the worst that our State has ever endured in living memory. Let me give some good examples of how this bully boy Prime Minister, this self-styled President, takes it out on the smallest State in Australia. Madam Deputy Speaker, you love Tasmania, you have links with the State and Tasmanians like you. Let me remind you that in the last year of the Fraser Government, the Commonwealth capital works program for Tasmania, Australia's tiniest State, was $35.7m. What is it this year? Commonwealth capital works new projects for Tasmania total $3.5m.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was that figure?

—It was $3.5m, less than one-tenth than what it was under the Fraser Government. As we are on air at the moment, I should mention the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. It was expecting the magnificent new ABC headquarters to be built right in the centre of Denison. What is the appropriation for this magnificent multimillion dollar project? It is a project which is desperately needed because the only two major Commonwealth capital works projects in Denison , the Commonwealth Law Courts and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Marine Laboratories, both Fraser Government projects, have now reached conclusion. How much has been appropriated for the ABC's headquarters? Only $300,000.
—This Government hates Tasmania.

—Yes, it absolutely hates Tasmania, because $300,000 would not even cover the cost of plans and specifications, and for building an amenities block or, if you prefer to call it, a dunny for the workers on that new job. But as the Mercury so correctly pointed out, Mr Hawke has obviously decided that there is no point in trying to buy seats in Tasmania because Tasmania is the one State which has seen through him from the word go. The time allotted for this speech has nearly gone but I warn once again the people of Australia: Do not give this man or this Government another term of office because what they will do to Australia will make it unrecognisable. Gough Whitlam and Jim Cairns look like a couple of choir boys compared to Robert James Lee Hawke and his socialist Government. The people of Australia have just 12 weeks to make up their minds. I love Australia and I do not want to see this shameful Government get another term in office.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate I wish to speak about some of the Budget accomplishments of a decent honest government, particularly as they relate to North Queensland. One hundred and sixty kilometres south-south-east of Townsville on the boundary of the Bowen and Dalrymple shires is the site of the Burdekin Falls Dam. In November last year the Hawke Government, an authentic Australian government, approved the acceptance of the lowest conforming tender to build the Burdekin Dam. That tender was won by Leighton Contractors Pty Ltd. It was an historic moment for the people of North Queensland. Since the beginning of this century north Queenslanders have dreamed of taming the mighty Burdekin River. There have been promises to build the Burdekin Dam virtually continuously since the Second World War. The Hawke Government's decision to proceed with the construction of the Burdekin Dam wall is probably the most significant boost to the north Queensland economy since the establishment of the sugar and mining industries.

SPEECH.PARA: The $276m Burdekin Dam project is of national significance. This joint Federal- State Government project will provide water supplies for further agricultural development and for large scale increases in urban and industrial development in Townsville and the region until well beyond the year 2000. Previous Liberal- National Party Federal governments treated the Burdekin Dam project with disdain . They rebuffed persistent requests from the people of north Queensland to commence construction of this great project. The Hawke Government, in its first Budget, allocated $13m towards the cost of construction of the Burdekin Dam. The second Keating Budget has allocated $19m. Generations of north Queenslanders had pursued the quest to build the Burdekin Dam. This decision of the Hawke Government will forever more be saluted by the people of north Queensland

The Burdekin Dam project is the first major construction program of its kind since the completion of the Snowy River scheme. North Queenslanders are fortunate that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has committed the Federal Government to completing the Burdekin Dam as a national priority. The Federal Government's decision to build the dam reflects its commitment to integrated and forward looking development of Australia's natural resources. Any future expansion of industry, agriculture and population in this region cannot take place without an adequate water supply. The construction of the Burdekin Dam will provide an enormous boost to the construction industry, irrigation works and job opportunities in north Queensland. Last year the Queensland Commissioner of Water Resources said that the completion of the Burdekin Dam project would herald a $1,000m injection into the north Queensland economy. There will be new contracts for new projects, new jobs, new demands for goods and services and new confidence in north Queensland for investors.

The Burdekin Dam will contribute substantially to the industrialisation of north Queensland and assist the development of a strong and healthy industrial base for the region. Equally as important, it will provide a guaranteed water supply of high quality for more than 130,000 people who live in the Townsville- Burdekin region. The people of north Queensland are fortunate that the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), is no longer Treasurer. Last year he was quoted in the Age newspaper as saying:
I wouldn't have regarded the Burdekin Dam as any more sacrosanct than other areas. I would have put it into a hotch potch with some of the other things.

That negative, anti-north Queensland attitude of the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party is a great source of concern to me, for his statements have never been repudiated by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) or by the National Party. Fortunately, north Queenslanders can depend on the Hawke Government to complete the Burdekin Dam. History was made last Monday when workmen poured the first batch of concrete for the dam. The Queensland Minister for Water Resources when describing it stated:
. . . an historic moment-a major milestone in the development not just of this State but of the nation.

Stage 1 of the dam will be 37 metres high and 875 metres long. It will impound 1 .86 million megalitres of water, covering an area of 22,400 hectares. The dam is capable of subsequent enlargement up to 8.5 million megalitres capacity for future hydro-electric power generation of up to 500 megawatts. Into the huge dam wall will go 630,000 cubic yards of concrete, requiring 88,000 tonnes of cement and 800 tonnes of steel. The Burdekin Dam workforce is building up. Currently almost 150 people are on site. The population of the Burdekin Falls township is expected to reach 800. The village has bitumen roads, sewerage, treated water supply, swimming pool, community hall, licensed canteen, school and picnic areas . A multi-channel radio telephone link has been established and tenders are currently being called for a satellite television receiver. Work is well under way to completely seal the entire 120 kilometres of unsealed road to the Burdekin Falls site. An all weather airfield, adjacent to the dam, has been completed. The dam is programmed to be fully operational and storing water during 1988. It is a tremendous project by the Hawke Government. It will enable north Queensland to leap to the forefront of Australia's most productive regions . It will also enable Townsville to lay the foundation as the economic and industrial giant of north Queensland.

The Hawke Government has continued its determination to increase dramatically the prosperity of north Queensland through a multitude of initiatives contained in the second Keating Budget. The community employment program has received a major increase in funding for 1984-85. Expenditure on projects under the community employment program will be $410m-a 44 per cent increase over community employment program expenditure in 1983-84. Queensland will be allocated $58m for projects under the community employment program in 1984-85. This sum includes $ 11.6m for jobs on local roads programs. Already 67 projects under the community employment program, valued at about $5.5m, have commenced in the Herbert electorate. More than 540 north Queenslanders have been employed through these programs.

The Budget has allocated $258.8m for Queensland roads-a 44 per cent increase over the two-year period 1982-83. Funds to local governments for local roads have increased by 60 per cent since the Hawke Government came to office, to a record level of $293m in 1984-85. The threat by one of the Opposition spokesmen on transport that a Liberal-National Party government would not directly fund local and arterial roads but would leave it to the State is a savage attack on local government. This would mean that for every bridge or arterial road-in fact , any stretch of construction or maintenance-local governments in north Queensland would have to go cap in hand to the National Party Government in Queensland and beg for the money to fund projects. The cost of providing urgent road works is already beyond the resources of almost all local councils in north Queensland. The Opposition policy amounts to a slap in the face for local councils in north Queensland. It is a callous and brutal policy of discrimination against local authorities.

By contrast, the Hawke Government has done more for arterial and local roads than any other government. This year the Budget has allocated Queensland $99.4m for arterial roads and $47.7m for local roads. The notorious and dangerous Bruce Highway is being reconstructed to a safe standard by the Hawke Government. The Budget provides $111.7m for national highways in Queensland. The bulk of these funds will be used by the Hawke Government to continue upgrading the Bruce Highway. During the past 17 months single lane timber bridges along the Bruce Highway in the Herbert electorate are gradually being replaced. Major road reconstruction projects have been undertaken. New bridges have been built. There is a new confidence, a new spirit of prosperity in the Herbert electorate as a result of the Hawke Government's interest in north Queensland.

The needs of Federal public servants were recognised by the provision of $7.5m in the Budget to enable completion of the Commonwealth Government Centre at Townsville. This highly acclaimed $13m project will provide accommodation for more than 20 government departments when completed in March next year. As an election stunt the Fraser Government promised to provide a new domestic air terminal at Townsville. Nothing was done. The Budget provides $115.3m for a new domestic air terminal at Townsville, of which $300,000 has been allocated this year to enable demolition and other works to be carried out. The completion of the new domestic air terminal in association with the Townsville international air terminal will provide northern Queensland with air terminal facilities equal to the expectations of travellers and the pride of north Queensland.

Tourism is a major growth industry in northern Queensland. With increasing international and domestic air traffic through Townsville, this area of northern Australia must surely become one of the major tourist destinations of this country. The recent announcement by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) of a new air fare package will not only encourage Australians to holiday at home but also international visitors will be able to obtain the benefits of cheap travel to the Great Barrier Reef. An air fare of $ 500 will enable Australians to travel up to 6,000 kilometres anywhere in Australia. Another fare of $800 will entitle people to travel up to 10,000 kilometres. The discounts on both fares average around 35 per cent but can be as high as half the price of the normal scheduled fares depending on the distance travelled. In other words, people will now be able to fly to just about any destination in Australia for around 8c a kilometre, which is one of the cheapest fares currently available anywhere in the world. Broadly speaking, there are only two main conditions to the new fares. First, the duration of the journey must be between 10 and 45 nights and, secondly, passengers must visit one port other than a capital city for at least four nights. The Hawke Government is committed to the development of tourism particularly in north Queensland. This can only result in benefits to all Australians.

A total of $54m has been allocated to enable the continuation of the first home owners scheme. More than 1,000 householders in the Herbert electorate have benefited from the first home owners scheme since its introduction and this has provided a much needed boost, through our infusion of millions of dollars, to the housing industry particularly in Townsville. The Australian Institute of Marine Science and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority have also received increased allocations of funds in this Budget. An amount of $2.2m has been allocated to continue with the provision of a second radio regional network in north Queensland.

Townsville is host to the 3rd Brigade, and the Royal Australian Air Force base at Garbutt. The operational deployment force is a vital component of the Australian Defence Force. North Queenslanders applaud the efforts of the Hawke Government to provide an adequate Defence Force for Australian people. This year 's Budget allocation for defence is $5,820m. This represents an 8.1 per cent growth in money terms over last year's defence spending and a real growth of around 3.3 per cent.

In the Hawke Government's first two Budgets the average increase for defence has been 3.7 per cent compared with an average of 2.5 per cent in the previous seven years under the disastrous Fraser Government. In this Budget the capital equipment share of defence expenditure will increase to 23.5 per cent, from about 22 per cent in 1983-84 and from 16 per cent in 1980-81 during the term of the Fraser Government. This year, the total amount of expenditure on capital equipment will be $1,315m. The majority of this expenditure is dominated by projects such as the FA18 fighter, additional PC3 Orion maritime patrol aircraft , guided missile frigates and destroyer updates. At the same time, there is continuing expenditure on, for example, Army trucks and guided weapons. For maritime defence, helicopters will be acquired for our guided missile frigates. The Hawke Government will also acquire air defence and anti-shipping missiles, and new electronic warfare equipment for the 10 PC3 aircraft. For ground defence , provision is made for the acquisition of new 105 millimetre guns to be produced in Australia.

An amount of $48m will be spent on new and better service housing in 1984-85. This is a 30 per cent increase over last year and a further indication of the concern of the Hawke Government for the welfare and living standards of individual service men and women. Since the election of the Hawke Government service homes in Townsville have been progressively upgraded. Maintenance works include painting and structural improvement of houses, and service men and women are grateful for this support.

A milestone in the development of the conditions of service for defence personnel was achieved by the Hawke Government with the passage of legislation to establish a Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal. The new tribunal will have the power to determine salary and salary related allowances for members of the Defence Force. It will be able to review salaries at least every two years and the Parliament will not be able to disallow its determinations. These are significant initiatives from this Government. A statutory appointment of Defence Force Advocate is also to be made, and this will ensure that the Defence Force is not disadvantaged before the tribunal by not being unionised. I am sure that these changes are welcomed by all members of the Australian Defence Force. The real growth that defence is receiving in this year's Budget recognises the expenditure requirements of existing commitments and it also provides for a number of new, high priority projects to commence in this year. The defence budget this year reflects a continuing commitment to defence by this Government.

A major Queensland weekly newspaper estimated that the Herbert electorate has received approximately $50m from the second Keating Budget. No greater affirmation of faith in the destiny of northern Queensland has ever been made by any previous Federal Government in the history of our Federation than by the Hawke Government. North Queensland is a thriving part of Australia which has been hampered and stifled by the failure, over a long period, by many governments to match local initiatives and hopes with the provision of services and resources upon which greater development could be founded. The Hawke Government has pledged itself to the pursuit of national reconciliation, national recovery and national reconstruction. It is determined to place north Queensland firmly on the road to dynamic economic growth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Hawke Government may well have made those commitments in northern Queensland and it may well have fulfilled some of its promises in that part of Australia. However, the majority of Australians are far worse off from this Budget. It is a Budget with the objective of making everybody happy enough so that the Government wins the next election. That objective will fail simply because the people have seen through the facade of what is being done by the Hawke Government.

SPEECH.PARA: An indication of how responsible and how lasting this Budget will be is the fact that the chief official of the Department of the Treasury, who gives advice to the Government on these matters, would not put his name to it. He resigned five days before the Budget was brought down. Does the community need any further indication then that the Public Service and economic advisers will not take the cheap political tricks that are put forward in this Budget? A magnificent, superb and huge tax grab is in line for the Australian people, the biggest tax grab since World War II-a 23 per cent increase in the size of personal income taxes before the end of the financial year. An extra million people will have to face the fact that they will lose half their wages in taxes. One million more on average wages will go into the 46 and 48 per cent tax bracket. That is where the money is coming from to fund this heavy spending and heavily committed Government.

On top of these factors the Government has hit the pensioners and the retirees with the assets test. At a cost of $54m the Government will bring hardship and heartburn to the pensioners and retirees of Australia. The broken promises to the electorate will not be forgotten, neither will the community forget the promises that have been kept to the union movement. The extra members of parliament, the prospective capital gains tax, gift duties and gift taxes, together with the lump sum tax on superannuation, are part of the armoury of the Labor Government in attacking the average member of the community.

The concept of managing the affairs of government, so that broad sections of the community are attended to, their needs assessed and proper strategies designed to assist, support and encourage, is not part of the thinking of this Government. There is no concept about the average family, where the various threads of tax, welfare, education and support systems are considered in toto. The Government rejects that concept and, in fact, selects specific groups in the community which it assesses are doing better than they should be. There is no prospect within this Government of assessing what the work place is all about so that the combination of effort by an employee and employer is considered and so that they are complementary and mutually productive. The concept of a federation is beyond this Government because it really does not believe in the States and the role that they should play in a federation.

As for defence and foreign affairs-the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) roams the world willy-nilly and on every occasion has to be brought back, corrected, or have his announcements altered by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Despite some growth in capital expenditure in the defence area the bulk of spending is a declining resource for this Government. As for our trade and resources area-the other large, significant area of government activity-the relationship between the work place, the commitments, the transportation, the negotiations, the settlement of trade agreements and the development of our resources is not attended to in a precise but all-encompassing way.

I believe this Government acts by a process of identifying those things within its philosophy to which it has some particular attraction or antipathy and taking those singular and specific instances to deal with the community without looking at the broad issues. I need only refer the House to the policy statement made by the present Prime Minister when he was delivering the Australian Labor Party's policy speech on 16 February 1983 at the Sydney Opera House theatrette. On that occasion he said:
I believe the Australian people have had enough of election promises made only to be broken. I offer no fistfull of dollars to be snatched back after the election.

In that speech the Prime Minister went on to promise the Australian community immediate tax cuts. Those tax cuts were not delivered until 18 months later, when their significance is not as great. But linked with those tax cuts is a massive disguised tax grab which shows up in the Budget, to which Mr Stone would not give his name. He saw through it-the massive confidence trick of delivering some tax relief in a marginal way on 1 November but finishing the year 23 per cent in front. If a shyster selling motor cars was doing that in New South Wales , Neville Wran would be down there terrorising him. Not this Government though- Mr Wran, the State governments and the community of Australia need to know that the Hawke Government is offering a facade of a commitment with these marginal tax cuts. Yet the Prime Minister said in his election speech:
I offer no fistfull of dollars to be snatched back . . .

What was in the Budget? A small amount of dollars was given which has been snatched back 100-fold. Not only has the Prime Minister snatched back the dollars that he has given away in this one year but also average families in his 18 months of government are $22 worse off. They have lost $22 and been given a marginal concession, but on top of that $22 there is a grab of 23 per cent. The grab of 23 per cent for an average wage earner is roughly $40 a week. So if we add $60 and $22, we get $82 by which the wage earner is worse off, and that is over a period of two and a bit years. The gift back, the fistfull of dollars that was not going to be grabbed back, is a lousy $7. Now what manipulation! No wonder anybody with any sense of decency, such as the Secretary to the Treasury, could not give his name to it.

I am ashamed to think that some members of principle on the Government benches will not expose what is happening to the community and to the families of Australia. Mr Hawke in that same speech in February 1983 when talking about these great matters said:
. . . as in everything else in this campaign and beyond, I am not in the business, and the Labor Party is not in the business, of making promises that cannot be fulfilled.

Then he went on to make the promises that have not been fulfilled. Some of them are tax reductions for low and middle income earners. If we examine the scales of tax reductions given in the Budget we find that the low income earners miss out completely. In terms of marginal difference they are the worst of any section of the community. The group that did the best are the middle income earners who collected a total of $7 a week. But they have already suffered the worst of any group. Then the Prime Minister said:
Another commitment that we will not break is the widening of opportunity for borrowing by business, farmers and home buyers.

I do not know how he could have made that promise because there has been no prospect for farmers, businesses or home buyers. In fact, home buyers are starting to turn away from their commitments. The real cost of interest is too great for them. One only needs to go around the home building companies of Australia to find out how concerned they are. We can look at Treasury figures and listen to the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford) whose figures are three to four months late. He gets up in this House and says what great things are happening in the housing and construction industry in Australia . However, I advise members of the Australian Labor Party to get out there on the ground and just find out what is happening. People are not sustaining the impetus that occurred during last year and already there are problems in the housing industry.

Of course, the Prime Minister made the commitment that he would provide support for private sector investment. The worst feature of the Australian economy is the extent of capital investment. The economy relies on people actually backing the confidence of this Government by saying: 'We can produce, expand, manufacture and improve employment and the prospects for the community.' But that is not happening. There is great stress and uncertainty in much of our manufacturing industry. The Prime Minister said that Labor's tax reform program would have the objectives of increasing the real value of the pay packet and stimulating demand in the economy. A 23 per cent increase in taxation in one year for employees can hardly really be offered as putting real value in the pay packet. It is a declining value.

I would like to point out to employers the other impact of some of the Government's decisions in regard to their wages. I have talked about tax and the take home part of salaries and wages. However, people need to be aware of some of the imposts that are part of their total wage, a part that they do not gain real benefit from while they are on the job although there may be some indirect benefit. However, these imposts are a real cost of the total wages outlay. I have dealt with tax which must be met by the employee. However, the employer, and not the employee, does have to meet the cost of workers' compensation which has risen by 30 per cent in the last 12 months. Employers also have to meet the cost of redundancy payments that have been approved by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. They also have to meet the cost of the affirmative action process which, good as it may be in some areas, is a cost factor that the Government must recognise. Voluntary participants in the program have said to me that there are cost factors that they can identify and that the cost is greater than was anticipated. National superannuation is also a wages on -cost. The details of this program are being settled between the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and the union movement. All of these things add up to a considerable cost.

It is no wonder that total wages rose by 14 per cent last quarter and this pattern is going to continue. Whilst the level of take home pay will not increase, the cost of wages will and the real benefits to employees will be reduced. Not only will the real benefit be reduced but also job opportunities will be reduced because the same amount of money will actually purchase less time on the job. Therefore, the working community of Australia is starting to lose out.

This Government is rushing to an election because it knows the cumulative effect of all of the things it has put in place or agreed to. It knows that an election must be held by Christmas because that would be its best opportunity to take advantage of a good sound economy and to present itself well to the Australian electorate. But what the electorate knows and suspects is that in 1985 it will feel the pinch of this Government's policies. The Prime Minister would consider it unwise to call an election in such circumstances no matter how ethical allowing a parliament to run its full term might be. It is interesting to read in the speech the Prime Minister made at the time of the last election how important it was for governments to run their full term. He gave an unequivocal commitment. The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), who is sitting at the table, will remember that he said: 'There will be no short term government. We will go our full time'. Now, suddenly, we have a government going to the people within 18 months of being elected; but that is another promise that has been put aside and neglected. The Prime Minister has said to the people of Australia: 'We need to go now because there is something about the Senate being involved'. Of course, the people say: 'Oh yes, there needs to be another election and therefore it is a good idea to have an election for the Senate and the House of Representatives before Christmas'.

The real reason that an election will be held before Christmas is the fear by the Government of the repercussions of its decisions and the state of the international economy in 1985. The Government does not have the guts to sit here and see the time out. It does not have the guts to face the people at the proper time. It wants an early election so that it has a better chance of winning. That is all right, but let the people of Australia understand just precisely what the Government intends to do. The Government has a tax grab set in place. It proposes to change the whole tax structure. I have been through about half a dozen of the promises that the Prime Minister made before the last election and broken.

The Prime Minister gave a commitment just in the last few days to the Confederation of Australian Industry that he would not increase taxes. Who can believe that commitment when promises have been made not to break promises and those promises are broken? That commitment was made before the last election. Who would believe his commitment that he has given now in that respect? The more he affirms his commitment, the more the community worries because it knows that the promises that are most strongly held are the ones that are most likely to be broken. So the Australian community needs to fear and be concerned about the commitment not to increase taxes beyond the present limit.

I think we all remember the Prime Minister's comments to Cliff Dolan in Canberra at the National Economic Summit Conference when he said that there would be no lump sum taxation on superannuation. He said: 'Mr Dolan, I give you my commitment as a former President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions that I, as a brother unionist, will not impose a lump sum tax on superannuation' . Of course, within a few weeks he had done just that. So the commitment to Australians that the restructuring of the tax scales will not mean extra tax is something that is fallacious and should be regarded, as should so many of the other promises of the Prime Minister, with absolute caution. In fact, I would go so far as to say the community should disbelieve the Prime Minister in regard to these matters. His track record indicates that we cannot believe commitments of that kind. As the pensioners, Cliff Dolan and many others have found it is dangerous to believe commitments such as that.

Should the Prime Minister be successful at the next election we will find that down the track there will be capital gains taxes, gift duties and taxes and all of those other weird and wonderful taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Death duties.
—Well, death duties are half there with the assets test.
—Teeth.

—Yes, I am aware of the things that the honourable member has raised. But with the assets test and gift duties it is part way there. It needs only a little extension-a running out of a figure or two and, zingo, we have it; no problem about that.

SPEECH.PARA: What about the other commitments of the Government? I have run through the Prime Minister's commitments at the last election but I need just to remind the community of the commitments that have been kept. They are very narrow but then they are in a very select field. They all relate to the union movement. One of them is:

The Government will endeavour to create a better industrial relations climate by itself adopting and encouraging other employers to adopt a rational and less confrontationist approach to industrial relations.

The Government has done that because it has agreed to national superannuation. It has agreed to Mr Dolan's Budget and it has agreed to every proposition that the union movement has put to it. It has even started to remove the common law sanctions and the penal aspects of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Another commitment is:
The Government will establish . . . an Inquiry into the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.
That is on the way. It has kept that commitment. Here is another:
The Government will support the establishment of rights for employees-

That is running hot and strong. Mention is made of the introduction of compensation for technological change. Yes, that came through a week or two ago, right on line-there will be extra payment for technological change. Another commitment relates to fair redundancy protection. For the sake of honourable members of the House and those listening, I am reading from a copy of the agreement between the unions and the Government. I got this copy courtesy of the Amalgamated Metals, Foundry and Shipwrights Union. It is very generous in handing out leaflets of this sort.

We see that the Government has kept its commitment to the union movement but for the rest of the community promise after promise has been broken. It is a tragedy that the Prime Minister, who is so much up front in taking credit for such modest things as breaking the drought, winning the America's Cup and all those other things he has done, will not take credit for the mess that he has created in the lives of people by putting commitments out in the public arena- commitments that people believed-and then breaking them. I warn the community that every commitment made by the Prime Minister coming up to the next election cannot be believed because there are few that he is prepared to keep.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall Mr D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The essential difference between the Australia of September 1984 and that of February 1983 is the mood of confidence which has captured the Australian people. This confidence is a direct result of Australia' s strong economic performance and of satisfaction with the national leadership displayed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Any impartial examination of the economic indicators reveals the extent of the growth and serves to contrast our economic inheritance after seven years of rule by the Liberal Party of Australia .

SPEECH.PARA: Under Labor, employment has increased. From April 1983 to June 1984 employment increased by 4.1 per cent or 250,000 people. Unemployment has fallen now to 8.8 per cent of the work force, compared with 10.4 per cent unemployment rate in March 1983. These improvements have not occurred by accident. They have been part of responsible economic management, a level of responsibility our predecessors never showed during seven disastrous years. The Government's community employment program, established in 1983, has been part of a deliberate process to reduce unemployment for those who have been denied work for so long. The scheme has given some of these people some self-worth, some feeling of confidence to re-enter the work force. I am pleased the Government has increased its allocation to this worthwhile scheme by 43.7 per cent in this Budget.
