In my own State of Queensland, there has been a 40 per cent increase in allocation to $57.96m in 1984-85. This will provide an estimated 11,000 jobs for my fellow Queenslanders.

No matter how worthwhile such schemes are, they will sustain Australia's economic recovery only if an investment climate is created. Unlike the previous Government which ruled by division and fear, this Government has fostered a climate of trust and understanding between business, Government and the trade union movement. Following on from the historic National Economic Summit Conference, the Government has developed continuing consultation through the Economic Planning Advisory Council. These consultations have given a climate of predictability about the direction of this Government's policy and the result has been the highest rate of growth through 1983-84 of any nation of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development.

Whereas the previous Government devised a policy of tackling inflation by driving unemployment upwards, this Government has addressed the two evils of unemployment and inflation simultaneously and successfully. The prices and incomes accord signed between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions has been a part of the consultative process, but has been a vital step in setting Australia on the path towards economic growth and development. The accord has enabled wage justice for all wage and salary earners to occur. It has also given business, both small and large, some predictability in wage costs for the year. These measures have caused a decline in industrial disputation giving Australia the lowest level of industrial stoppages for some 15 years. Additionally, there has been a near universal adherence to the 'no extra claims' provisions of the new wage fixing arrangements. Whilst award rates have increased in 1983-84 they are still well below those of the wages explosion of 1982-83.

The tax cuts announced in the Budget are a further extension of the prices and incomes accord. The $7.60 a week tax cut not only honours our election promise on taxation but also offers hope to business and the trade union movement. A $7. 60 tax cut is the equivalent of a $14 a week pay rise and will give wage and salary earners additional spending power which will flow through to the private sector.

'How will the Budget address the problems of small business in Australia?' is a question often asked. Let us take the building industry around which is based industries like wholesale and retailing, construction, finance and community services. In a paper entitled 'The Enterprises of Australia in 1980', these industries accounted for 50 per cent of small businesses employing less than 10 people. The economic upturn has probably given much higher significance to this percentage. Nevertheless, the housing policies of this Government have been a central plank in assisting small business.

The Government's housing policy has been developed on two levels-public housing and the first home owners scheme. Expenditure in this Budget for housing is estimated $1,252m, an increase of 21 per cent on 1983-84 and a staggering increase of 69 per cent over the last year that the Liberals reigned in this country. Of this amount, $82m will be spent for public housing in Queensland under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. The aims of this scheme will be the alleviation of housing related poverty and, as far as is possible, the fair provision of housing assistance between renters and home buyers.

At another level, the Government is committed to first home buyers. In particular, the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford) is deserving of the highest praise for the efforts he and his Department have made. This year expenditure will be $265m-an increase of 85 per cent over that of last year. These amounts represent a magnificent turnaround for the housing industry. In 1982-83 the housing industry was stagnating at a 20-year low of only 105,000 dwelling commencements. In fact throughout the fiscal year 1981-82 there was an annual decline of 12.9 per cent. The upturn in the housing industry throughout the year of operation is quite marked, with approvals for housing in November of last year 71.9 per cent greater than the previous year.

These figures illustrate the strength of the growth and prosperity since March 1983. In the last financial year, some 55,000 Australians were assisted into home ownership with around $141m in tax free grants. Over 11,000 of these households were in Queensland, with 135,000 dwelling commencements in Australia at large. In Queensland, building activity has increased by 25 per cent with 30, 500 dwelling commencements in 1983-84. For the future, the Government is hopeful that there will be a 7 per cent increase to about 145,000 dwelling commencements in Australia. Of these, 33,000 will be in Queensland-an increase of 8 per cent.

These housing policies have a direct impact upon my electorate which has a social mix of low income earners who will benefit from our public housing policies, and young home owners who have been assisted by our first home owners scheme. As well as assisting the many thousands of people in my electorate, the housing policy has spawned many small businesses directly dependent upon it. Real estate agencies, financial companies, nurseries, small corner stores, professional agencies and larger business corporations are following in the wake of the population boom in my electorate. As the housing industry has benefited from lower interest rates, so too have small businesses directly benefited. Similarly, the tax cuts given to wage and salary earners will be a stimulant to small business operations because of the extra money they will be spending.

Indeed, financial corporations have recognised the importance of the housing industry as a stimulant to the economy. In Queensland the Metropolitan Permanent Building Society has dropped its interest rate by one per cent for first home buyers. The Queensland State Government Insurance Office Building Society has also announced a one per cent cut to 12 per cent for first home buyers. A one per cent reduction for home buyers in the range of $35,000 to $50,000 has also been granted by the Society. I applaud these actions and hope that other lending institutions will develop their own innovations in interest rate reductions to assist small businesses to encourage growth and development in the Australian economy.

Of a more direct assistance to small business is the Budget proposal to double the allocation for programs to help small business owners develop their managerial skills. The total of $360,000 to be provided will develop the highly successful 'Managing the Small Business' series and new management training courses, including specific courses aimed at particular industry sectors, and a special training course for small business counsellors. A recent research paper entitled 'Small Businesses in Australia' defined the two major problems facing small business as access to finance on reasonable terms and the need to raise the level of business knowledge, education and training of many small business entrepreneurs.

This Government has undertaken many initiatives to free up the financial sectors in the Australian economy. I have already told the House of special arrangements made to help first home owners. I hope that the financial institutions can modify their lending arrangements to assist the small business sector. I have shown too how this Budget has addressed the second of these problems. It is worth noting that in Australia there is considerable freedom in establishing a small business. In other countries, adequate skill, training and education are to be displayed before registration of a business. The Government, through this Budget, has gone part of the way to addressing this problem. It is worth noting that the paper on small business had to look to general economic recovery for improved prospects rather than specific programs of government assistance. Clearly, all the economic indicators have significantly improved and it is, therefore, fair to say that the small business sector will also undergo a revival.

This Budget has also addressed the plight of the pensioners and the needy. These groups are those less able to withstand any economic downturns. Pensions will rise by $2.50 a week for single people and $4.20 a week for married couples . It is well to remember that the basic rates of pension are increased automatically every six months in accordance with the movement in the consumer price index. As a result of the fall in the CPI, no movement in pensions would have been expected. However, the Government has honoured its election promise by increasing the real rate of pensions and benefits. Additionally, assistance will be given to pensioners who rent homes. Rental assistance will go up by 50 per cent to $15 a week and additional pensions and benefits for children will increase by $2 to $14 a week. Those people are the ones in our society who can least afford to meet the increasing cost of living. Therefore, the Government has addressed these problems. I feel the Budget has been well received by the Australian community. It will ensure that no matter when the election is held the Hawke Government will be returned to office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be appropriate for me to make a few general observations on the Budget before dealing with certain specific aspects of it. In general terms the Budget can be described as one in which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has compromised himself to the benefit of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and its President, Mr Cliff Dolan. It is a very sorry day when the whole of the financial arrangements of this nation and this Parliament are left at the whim of the de facto government. That is what I think we can call the trade union movement and its bosses. The second compromise was in subrogating what was good for the long term future of the nation to the political expediency of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for an early election this year. While admitting to the desirability, not the need, of an early election, to tie in with a half Senate election, this could be accommodated with an election as late as May 1985. So the whole aspect of subverting the interests of the Australian nation to that of an early election is not only humbug but also irresponsible, and I need not mention the all too frequent cost of $21m to hold an election.

SPEECH.PARA: I mentioned the subrogation of long term national interest to short term political expediency. In no way is this better demonstrated than by reference to the 9 per cent of the 1984-85 Budget outlays which are appropriated to the national debt interest. I want to draw the comparison of the last 10 Budgets whereby the figure has doubled from 4.4 per cent of Budget outlays in 1975-76 to 8.8 per cent of Budget outlays in the current Budget. This can only increase as this year's deficit is added to the national debt. The real tragedy of this year 's Budget is that, in spite of the windfall income expected from the growth in personal income tax, excluding Medicare, of about 20 per cent-a windfall of almost $6 billion-it has been absolutely squandered on a resurgence of public expenditure.

If last year's record expenditure deficit of $7.9 billion was justified, as it was by the Labor Government, as encouraging spending in a sluggish economy, there is not the same justification this year. If, as the Prime Minister recorded in answer to a question the day after the Budget was announced that employment growth will be about 3.25 per cent, growth in the economy will be 5 per cent and the rate of inflation is 5 per cent. Why is it necessary, if prospects are so favourable, to go into another spending spree when the needs should be so much less? There is only one answer: The Government has disregarded every economic principle in presenting this Budget to paper over the real and urgent problems that face Australia today. There can be no other reason for the Secretary to the Treasury, Mr Stone, a great Australian, resigning to dissociate himself from the irrationalities of the Dolan Budget. The windfall increase in personal income and company tax should have been used to reduce the deficit considerably below the $6,745m result achieved in this Budget. I understand that the total capital expenditure in the Budget is $5,630, which is considerably below the figure of the deficit.

It is fitting that I should draw the attention of Ministers to a paragraph in their own Budget Papers. Page 382 of the Budget Statements shows the slide that capital works has taken as a priority for funding over the last decade as compared with the tremendous increase in non-capital outlays. If they would care to look at it, the paragraph reads:
The past decade has witnessed a pronounced shift in the composition of budget outlays.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote this?
—I imagine the Treasurer did. He reckons he understands every word contained in the Budget itself.
—No, who wrote the speech?
—I did. At least I read the Budget Papers, which is more than Ministers do. Mr Deputy Speaker, I am being affected by these interjections. Can I keep going?
—The honourable member will direct his remarks through the Chair. The Minister for Finance will cease interjecting.
—This indicates the big switch over the last few years. The paragraph continued:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1974-75, total budget payments for capital purposes comprised one-quarter of total outlays. That proportion had declined to less than 9 per cent in 1981-82, a level around which it has since remained. Outlays for non-capital purposes increased in real terms by some 40 per cent over the same seven years.

In effect this means that the nation will be borrowing for the Prime Minister to hand out his election goodies. The Treasurer himself is bankrupt of any economic principle when such rationale is applied to the Budget. Perhaps the same can be said the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) who has left the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —You embarrassed him; he had to leave.

—That is right. I am glad that he took the hint and removed himself. Perhaps he has gone to read his own Budget Papers. What about the morality when this Government asks today's youth, that is, tomorrow's taxpayers, to pay more to service the public debt interest than it spends on education. At the same time, the Government burdens future governments and taxpayers with funding programs necessary only to gain sufficient time to go to an election on the most favourable terms. Soft options took over the hard decisions in this Budget. I question the morality of any parliamentary institution that frames its Budget to commit children not yet born, or children not yet taxpayers, to meet at some time in the future the penalty of our indulgence today.
—They are born with a mortgage.

—That is right. I will come to that in a moment. Let us put this matter into its proper perspective. All children born today, 6 September 1984, equal in the eyes of God, will be loaded with their share of the national debt of $5,000 before they receive one benefit from being born an Australian.
—That is their first day of birth.

—Their first day. Each family, which has been savagely ravaged in this Budget and made a second class unit, now bears a debt of $22,000. So much for this being a family Budget. In this year, 1984-85, taxpayers--
—It gives them something to aim for, doesn't it?

—I ask the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment to listen as this is interesting. In this year, 1984-85, each taxpayer will contribute $900 in taxes alone just to service the interest on the Government's public debt; not the redemption, just the interest on that debt. So much for the morality of a Budget that increases public expenditure to produce a deficit when that public expenditure produces an expectation of a continuation of benefits given only to try to secure a political party in government.
—You worry about your extension; I will worry about mine.

—A $6.7 billion deficit is not a bad public contribution to an election by a government to get itself back into government, and that is basically what it is. The public expenditure on elections that we have heard about before shrinks into insignificance when we point to the $6.7 billion.
—What about what you did? Nine billion dollars and you would not tell anybody.

—I think that has been properly explained. The Minister is creating a mischief by continuing that line because the Government's own Treasurer admitted that the deficit under the previous Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), would have been considerably less than the figure the Minister is spouting at the moment. So the Minister should talk to the Treasurer. Will our future be to belong to a banana republic like Mexico, Brazil or Argentina, which cannot meet their debts? As a result of deficit financing over the past 10 years alone-I include all governments in this statement-we have doubled our commitment from 4.4 per cent to 8.8 per cent of outlay towards our national debt. We are now facing the second largest deficit in this Parliament's history of $6.7 billion. What will be the commitment in the next 10 years? What happens when the nation's credit rating becomes so poor that we cannot even roll over our debts and we cannot pay the interest, at a time when Australians have indulged themselves to the extent that they cannot or will not compete in the world and on Asian markets. From such events, banana republics are formed.

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget will not move the economy or business. It can lead only to a supplementary Budget, if Labor wins the election, to introduce extra taxation measures, such as capital gains, capital value, a wealth tax and death duties. In fact, if the economy will not move under Labor, it is determined to tax everything that stands still or dies, and that is basically what will happen. That is the legacy that it will hand over to next year's taxpayers and to the succeeding government. The present Budget is a Budget of short term convenience for the Government to seek a further term for itself. It is a Budget of give now , but pay later.

I want to address a few remarks in relation to local government, which is my responsibility as shadow Minister. It, like many other areas, has lost out in this Budget. General revenue grants under personal income tax sharing have again been set at less than the inflation rate. Over the two years of Labor Government , local authorities have now received $29m less than they would have received if Labor had lived up to its election promise that 'general revenue grants in any year will not be of less value than those of the previous year in real terms'. The Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) and this Government do not appreciate that the consumer price index does not even come close to the local government's increase of annual costs, which one local government authority advised me was about 10 per cent for 1983-84.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—Ten per cent, after the medifiddle of about 6 per cent. This was con- firmed by the New South Wales shire councillors who came yesterday to meet members. Rates have had to be increased to absorb the loss from the general grant funding. Also I understand that some States in charges alone have taken back 40 per cent of personal income tax. This has been absorbed in New South Wales, I understand, by extra charges on local government or a withdrawal from services that were normally provided. That shows how much use PIT from a Labor government is when it is hooked into another State Labor government.

SPEECH.PARA: Worse than that, Labor has indexed the bicentennial road development fund levy. Again, the revenue from that indexation has gone into Consolidated Revenue, not to local government roads. The outcome is that local government has lost another $9m from its road funds while being asked to absorb the six-monthly indexation of those same fuel costs into its own costs. This has occurred in spite of opportunities that the Opposition so generously gave the Government last year to accept our amendments to place those funds where they were most needed-into local government and into roads. What did the Government do? It ran away from them and voted against the amendments that were moved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every single one of them.
—Every single one. There was not one deviation.
—Not the honourable member for Eden-Monaro.

—He is the only one here, so we cannot speak for the others. The Minister will say that the Government has considerably increased other grants to local government. Let us have a close look at those other grants, as these are outlined in Budget Paper No. 7. In so doing, we find that nearly all of those programs are community based, in which the Commonwealth provides part of the funding and has total responsibility: Nursing homes, aged persons' homes, Meals on Wheels, handicapped persons' programs, children's services, homeless persons' programs, migrant services, the arts and a host of others. All of these are programs which can be provided by community organisations or local government. In many communities they are provided by community organisations. This is not funding of local government. This is funding of community programs which are Commonwealth programs and actually Commonwealth responsibilities. So why does the Government have to be so flash when it dishes out moneys on specific grants for specific areas when that is its responsibility?

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the aerodrome local ownership plan and the community employment program. Both of these areas-aerodrome development and employment creation-are traditional areas of Commonwealth responsibilities which are now being foisted on local authorities without a commensurate allocation of funding. In other words, the aim of the Commonwealth is to have local government use rate revenues to support Commonwealth programs. The reduction of the CEP requirement to 20 per cent funding from the sponsor was in response to local government's complaint of the cost being too high just to convey a Commonwealth program. I must say to the Minister that we welcome that change from 30 per cent to 20 per cent in the sponsor contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of what?

—I thought that the Minister was not listening. I turn to he local government improvement program and the local government development program. It is unfortunate that the Government has apparently changed its experimental program away from community development towards community services. Some were keen to see the outcome of this trial self co-ordination and self help . The Minister will be aware that part of my electorate of Dawson was keen to participate in this project. With regard to road funding, the Government has added nothing to the pre-existing commitments of the previous Government which were put in place by the then Minister, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt). We had already written the program into the Roads Grants Act and the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act, which Labor cannot change. Indeed, as I said before, the Government has taken away from road funds by indexing the ABRD levy and not passing it on to road construction.

SPEECH.PARA: On the whole, in the areas of real assistance to local government-that of general revenue grants and road grants-this Government has cut back on funds to local government. The only thing that has been given-it is appreciated-is the extension of the exemption from the bank accounts debit tax. Even here, we must wait for the proper interpretation of incidentals to be made to know whether local governments in total are exempt. The Government has done nothing to move towards the allowance of election expenses of local government elected representatives and candidates as tax deductions to bring them into line with Federal and State candidates. The Government has done nothing to recompense local government for the loss of rate revenue through the occupation of ratable land by Commonwealth Government buildings.

The Government has set up a committee of inquiry into personal income tax sharing. It is a committee made up of academics and bureaucrats, with no elected representatives among its members. But it is the elected representatives who carry the can at the next election if local government does not function. The Government has put itself at risk of being charged with rigging the inquiry for its own purposes, particularly if the inquiry comes out with a report unfavourable to local government. Also, why not widen the inquiry to ascertain the impact of government occupation of ratable lands and the impact of the Government's charges on local government costs, such as fuel excise, bank account transactions and also the cost to local government for the delivery of Commonwealth programs. I am sure the inquiry would be better received if those aspects could be included.

I would like to deal with aspects of the family that have been the criteria of some of the speakers for the Government. One of the greatest areas of cost in this Budget is against families and I say against families. We are all aware that the family rates very low with this Government after last year, and particularly this year. It is too interested in wiping away the meagre supports which do exist for the family unit and extending others to de facto and homosexual partnerships. The Sex Discrimination Act and the affirmative action program are aimed at driving women into the work force and promoting them above men, regardless of suitability for the job, in the interest only of reaching set quotas, or as some want to call it, preferred balances. We have had massive increases in child care funding and in subsidies to middle income families, but only for child care centres and family day care schemes which have predominantly full time placements. Which families want full time places except for employment reasons? But because of preferences set by this Government and the Office of Child Care, child centres are filled with children from two-income families, and no subsidised child care places are available for the parent who works in the home, the traditional mother caring for the family's pre-school aged children.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are an endangered species under this Government.

—That is exactly right; they are becoming an endangered species. The mother from the one-income family gets no relief from the strain of caring all day-no relief to do the shopping, to visit the doctor, or to play sport or to have a social outing. These tasks are just as important to the effective functioning of that family as the family where both partners choose to work; yet , under this Government's priorities the family with both parents working pays only $35 for the full time care of two children, on a family income of $25,000. The full cost of that child care is actually $200 per week. On what basis does that family receive the $165 subsidy, when the family next door, perhaps on a lesser income, gets nothing, because a parent chooses to stay at home and rear the children?

SPEECH.PARA: In the two years since the last National-Liberal Party Budget, families have had to endure an inflation rate of 18.5 per cent, but families have received next to no benefit from this Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?
—Two years.
—We have not been in office for two years; we have been in government for 18 months.

—Twenty-one months, yes-a bit too short a period after which to go to an election, I remind the honourable member too. This is what has happened . There have been no benefits from this Budget. Families have received no increase in their family allowances. They have received no increase in the spouse rebate. They have lost their health insurance rebate. They have lost their home mortgage interest tax rebate. They have received no increase in the zero tax threshold. After allowing for the tax cuts, families have endured a 27 per cent increase in personal income taxes, plus the Medicare levy, adding another 6 per cent. Food cost components have led the consumer price index. Health costs, now made up of Medicare and private health insurance, have skyrocketed, but topping up is still required from consolidated revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: The massive deficits of the past two Budgets that I have mentioned have put an average cost on taxation for the average family of about $1,500 just to meet the interest. These same deficits have maintained interest rates, particularly home purchase rates, well above the real interest rate of 7 per cent-and for what? Where are the jobs for the unemployed and the young school leavers? They have gone. They have gone in increasing wages for those employed, in increasing redundancy payments, in the building unions' superannuation deal, in preparing for next year's superannuation/productivity trade-off, and in keeping the Australian Council of Trade Unions on side. As Mr Stone said, 'It has been wages , wages, wages, not jobs, jobs jobs'.

The Government can find no money to increase the legitimate spouse rebate but it can introduce a rebate of the same value for a de facto spouse, so why have a legitimate marriage and a traditional family? I wonder whether the speech of the honourable member for Canning (Ms Fatin) in this Budget debate was indicative when she claimed that the traditional family was no longer the legally married family but the one-income family and that that is where we should be putting our preferences. So said the honourable member for Canning. I wonder if that is an indication of not only her thinking but also the Labor Party's thinking-that the one-parent family is what we should be encouraging in not supporting the traditional family. One wonders exactly what the Labor Party has introduced through this Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eighteen months after losing office, the Opposition is talking about an escalating deficit. It walked out of the kitchen leaving the deficit boiling over, one of nearly $10 billion, and when a new cook, the Hawke Labor Government, turns down the heat by $2 billion, Opposition members say that it is still too hot. They had seven years in the job. They were too scared to deregulate the dollar, to return it to its true worth, to give our rural and other exports the returns they are worth from overseas sales. They were seven years in the job, unable to realise that a fair go for education returns a dividend to the community. There were seven years in the job, too confrontationist to consult the unions, the farmers and social welfare organisations, even business; they preferred standing up to the unions, as they called it. They preferred confrontation. Their wage freeze hurt wage earners and small businesses that had the Government as a customer. Their confrontation exacerbated industrial disputes. They were seven years in the job, and the tax system discriminated against low income earners, who are most income earners in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: In 18 months in the job, the Hawke Labor Government had the courage to deregulate the dollar, the foresight to recognise the importance of education and the good judgment to encourage discussion and agreement between unions, business, farmers, the professions and, most importantly, social welfare organisations. This discussion, and the Economic Planning Advisory Council which now operates, has led to a drop in inflation. It has led to lower pressures on wages and prices-the very thing that the Coalition failed to achieve with confrontation. In 18 months the Hawke Labor Government-every member of it has played a part-has turned the tide against unemployment and inflation and has reduced taxes. The tax rate for low income earners and part pensioners is no longer 32c in the dollar but 25c. As one pensioner told me, 'This is the most welcome part of the Budget for me'.

These changes are not the achievement of just our Ministers, the best team that Australia has seen for many years; they are the combination of day to day initiatives by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his team, along with carefully planned legislation, in which each member has had a hand, on the various policy committees of the parliamentary Labor Party. Add to this the vital role of the Party's rank and file policy committees in longer term planning and we see the reasons for our successful economic management, our teamwork and the refreshing success of our policies. More has been achieved in one and a half years than in the previous seven and a half years. This is a government strong enough to make the hard decisions yet flexible enough to take into account the community's views, and even to change direction if necessary, consistent with economic and social recovery.

The Opposition's main object in this debate has been to whitewash its past, to frighten by deliberate misinformation the retired people in our community and those on social security benefits, and to mislead taxpayers. What do Opposition members think the people of Australia are? Do they think that the people are all tranquillised, living in blissful ignorance of the seven years of uneasy life under the Liberal and National parties? Our back benchers, including company directors, unionists, farmers, professional people and small business operators, all now members on this side of the House, work with Ministers involved in legislation. That is why this Budget will reduce the enormous rise in small business bankruptcies over those seven and a half years. That is why the investment allowance for businesses and farmers will be extended by one year after it was due to finish. That is why the depreciation allowance on buildings will operate over 25 years instead of 40, and provisional tax will have its loading reduced by one per cent.

One of the National Party members called out, 'What have you done for the farmers?' Economic recovery-that is what we have done for the farmers; deregulation of the dollar-that is what we have done for the farmers. Our small business legislation has also helped farmers, including the extension of the investment allowance. Not only have we worked for the farmers; we have worked with the farmers. We have worked with them in a soil conservation program and on biological control legislation. Honourable members opposite must admit that it was not only with farmers but with farm organisations as well. Current export programs are working with farmers. The fishing industry programs, which the coalition parties were too scared to introduce, have been worked in conjunction and in full consultation with fishermen. The feral animal control program, introduced for the first time under this Budget, followed a search conference which I convened in my electorate, at Snowy Station, in Eden-Monaro. This is a policy which has come from working with farmers.

We have also taken other initiatives which will help people in this region and throughout Australia. The Australian people's enterprise, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation, will be restored to viability as an outstanding engineering consultancy firm, with a long history of successes in Australia, as a result of the Government's economic decisions. The Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation does not normally receive funding in a Federal Budget. However, because the previous Government allowed the Corporation to wither without attention, this Government decided to inject a capital grant of $6m for its restructuring and revitalisation. The Government's previous Budget provided $4m for this purpose and this Budget completed the grant with a further $2m.

An amount of $294,000 had been provided to carry out a further program of pollution abatement works at Captains Flat. It is great to see the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) here in the House at the moment. I thank him and the Government for this program. At its peak Captains Flat was the largest mine in Australia next to Broken Hill. Lake George Mining Co., a 100 per cent British owned company, took profits from an Australian resource and the labour of Australian miners. When profitability slowed down some years ago it showed no responsibility to the Australian workers or the environment. Mines were flooded, keeping workers out and rendering the mines unworkable. Mountains of highly toxic slag heaps were left untreated and uncovered to subside and seep into the surrounding waterways. Pollution from the Captains Flat mines killed all fish life in the Molonglo River, polluted the town's water supply with high levels of zinc and polluted Canberra's Lake Burley Griffin. A Labor government moved to correct the ecological disaster left by the Lake George Mining Co. and ignored by the coalition Government. I thank the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment and the previous Minister for Urban and Regional Development, now the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren), for the pollution abatement works which he began at Captains Flat.

The Government through the Budget has stimulated consumption. To do that, it gave a 17 per cent tax cut to people who spend, the poorer people, those earning less than $12,500 a year, and pensioners and social security recipients whose benefits were increased by $2.50 per single person and $4.20 per couple with a 50 per cent increase in rent assistance. The Government has increased the tertiary education assistance scheme and the secondary assistance scheme allowances by 10 per cent and 15 per cent respectively. That long overdue but welcome measure has come with the Hawke Labor Government. The family income limit has been increased by 10 per cent.

The Government has had great success with employment in the region surrounding Canberra. There has been a great response to the stimulatory activities of the Government. They have not brought with them inflation, but have brought more jobs. In Eden-Monaro the number of jobs notified grew by 57 per cent, yet the number of unemployed people on social security benefits dropped 8 per cent. We believe that it is still unacceptable to have an 8.8 per cent unemployment level with more than a third of those who are out of work being people who have been out of the work force for more than nine months. For this reason, the Government has increased by 44 per cent the funding for the community employment program which aims at helping long term unemployed.

Let no one make the mistake of believing that any member on this side of the House has abandoned the democratic socialist quest for justice. Let no one make the mistake of thinking that the labour movement or the union movement can or will walk out on hard fought standards. Australia will move, along with other governments, particularly the democratic socialist governments of Scandinavia and now New Zealand, to achieve strong technologically based industry which, added to our strong primary industries, will achieve economic properity under the Hawke Labor Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Drummond Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1984-85 Budget has aptly been called the vote now, pay later Budget. Australians will pay new and heavier taxes in 12 months' time. We will pay either directly or indirectly for our mushrooming public debt burden. At the same time one group of Australians has absolutely no illusions about the Budget, because it will be paying already. I refer, of course, to the producers of quality wines in the seat of Forrest and to those others throughout Australia, and to the people whose livelihoods are dependent on this industry. Although I have had the opportunity to speak very briefly on this issue within the last couple of days, I must emphasise that we are looking at a Budget measure that will not merely result in restriction and inconvenience but will threaten the very continuation of a pioneer rural industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The small quality wineries in the south of Western Australia have hardly led a feather-bedded existence until now. They have had to overcome serious problems with natural pests and the environment. Establishing markets and economies of scale have been tough going. Currently, 17 wineries operate commercially in the Margaret River area. Two of these face closure because this tax has tipped the scale against their financial viability. Seven wineries, small ones admittedly, had already been forced to close prior to the announcement of the new tax and the lessening of the effective import duty. The market place has already put some operators out of the industry. The Government has now added a new and savage means of restructuring the boutique wine industry, only this time I fear it may even restructure it out of existence as far as the south west and Great Southern producers of Western Australia are concerned.

The economic importance of this industry to the south west of Western Australia really is beyond question. Prior to the establishment of the first vineyards after 1966, the area was a rural backwater. It now boasts an industry that pays $1m each year to permanent employees and $2.5m to contract labourers. Many of these are young people who might otherwise have no jobs. It is well known that this part of the south west has many residents who have opted for a simple lifestyle that can be sustained on small incomes aided by this kind of casual work. Without the wine industry and those other enterprises that have grown with it, these people would be forced to depend upon social security with the cost coming back to the taxpayer. Again, I emphasise that the tourist trade in the south west of Western Australia is virtually dependent on the wineries, about half of which conduct door sales and tastings. The South West Regional Development Authority attests to the fact that the wineries are a leading State tourist attraction with a big proportion of international visitors.

In summary, a 10 per cent sales tax on wine impacts most heavily on that section of the wine industry least able to carry the additional cost. It is a tax on excellence in that the much higher price rise will discourage consumers from buying quality wines. They will not be discouraged from cask wines, the increased price of which will be scarcely noticed. What is particularly unfair and destructive of tourism is the application of the tax to wines used in tasting. One bottle in seven produced at Margaret River is used for free tastings by the public. It may well boost sales, but it is a major service to tourism. For this, the wineries are to be punished by the Hawke Government.

There is an additional danger to small wineries through another Budget measure. Group taxation of companies can help the larger producer at the expense of the smaller. We can foresee what may happen when a major winery is 100 per cent owned by a conglomerate that can easily afford to have its subsidiary run at a loss for a while to increase its share of the market. One could name such very significant subsidiaries around the country. So I say that the Australian Labor Party Government cares more for the big corporations than for the smaller producer.

I previously stressed that the effective loss of protection against foreign imports is as serious a blow to the wine industry as the new sales tax. On the basis of the Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 5) the price of an imported bottle of champagne with a combination of 10 per cent duty and 10 per cent sales tax will rise by 6c a bottle. The price of the local product will rise by $1.10. A difference of $2.16 has been reduced to $1.14

This Labor Government simply asserts that the cheap foreign imports will not be a problem and that any significant increase in wine imports is not expected. I can only suggest that the Government does not understand the facts or has not bothered to check them. I ask honourable members to consider the following: European wine makers can land their product in Australia at less than $1 a bottle. Bulk wines can be bought from Europe for as little as 30c a litre for blending within Australia. If the price of local wines is forced up while that of imported wines remains effectively the same, surely imports will increase.

It is not a matter of allowing the free market full rein when we remember the existence of the wine lake of the European Economic Community, a fact that the Premier of South Australia knows even if his Federal colleagues choose to remain ignorant of it. Imported French wines selling for $3 a bottle would cost $12 if it were not for the blatant subsidisation of primary production by the EEC. This amounts to something like $1 billion for wine growers in the EEC on top of the subsidies for freight, insurance and promotion. As sure as night follows day the European wine makers will swamp our local production. With incredible irresponsibility the Hawke Government has ignored the warnings of the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation on the dumping of European wines. Imported wines are estimated to have increased their share of the market by 24 per cent over the last year, and this is before the level of protection is halved.

The Australian Labor Party has shown equal ignorance of the wine industry in the past. Past taxes on brandy and fortified spirits ignored the role of this part of the industry in absorbing unwanted grapes in times of surplus. Taxes on long term maturing wines forced dry reds on to the market too soon and seriously damaged red wine production. Nor does the current attitude of the ALP inspire any confidence that this Government is at all concerned about the wine industry. It retreats to a kind of threadbare inverted snobbery by asserting that the Opposition hates beer drinkers. I certainly agree that beer has been taxed beyond its proper limit but I await an explanation from the Government as to how the manufacture of beer can be compared with wine growing as a form of primary production in my electorate. I certainly await that explanation. It should be noted in the south west of Western Australia that one of the Australian Labor Party senators who is supposed to have a special interest in our region is in support of his Government's action against the Western Australian wine industry. I will be interested to hear what he has to say to those losing their jobs as a result of the Government's decision.

I make no apologies for the stress I have placed in my contribution to the Budget debate on the damage done to the wine growing and tourist industries throughout Australia, particularly in my area where these activities are so important to the people at the grass roots. It is relevant to all Australians to recall that on 20 February 1983 the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at his rural policy launch at Griffith pledged that there would be no wine tax under Labor. We should note the use of the word 'pledge'. We are warned that all ALP pledges are expendable. It has taken only three days from the delivery of the Budget Speech for the honest member of the Hawke Government, the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones), to give away the deception relating to tax and to admit that the Government will have to raise taxes next year. Again, at this juncture, we should remember that the new ALP king-makers, the members of the Centre Left, admitted after the ALP conference that they only opposed the calls of the Left for the vicious paraphernalia of wealth taxes, gains taxes and coffin taxes for tactical reasons in an election year, and that they fully supported those aims in principle.

This Budget gives to some of us a $7.60 tax cut, after increasing the tax burden over the last two years by $22. The next Budget is almost certain to, and has to, hit us with new taxes. Taxation is one area of major deception in this Budget. Another is the argument that the Government is being responsible in its management of the deficit. This myth too has been exploded since 22 August by that far-sighted and courageous Australian, John Stone, who noted:
Democracy is always hopeful of disposing of economic facts by manipulation.

He pointed out that the term of the Hawke Government has seen the public sector borrowing requirements double from 4 per cent of gross domestic product to 8 per cent. The slight cutting of the deficit in 1984-85 is made possible only through a one-off surge in revenue. We have to recognise that this growth in borrowing is nothing more than stealing from future generations. What else is it when we borrow today not for long term national investment to provide a return for future generations but to spend on ourselves and on the needs of today?

The public debt is not just a matter for arid economic debate. It is an issue that will matter very much to the ordinary Australian when we look ahead to June 1985 and realise that each employee will have as his share of the accumulated debt a sum of $14,000 and an interest payment over that year of $875 or $17 a week of his taxes. This is what a public debt of nearly $90 billion will mean in practical terms. The Federal Government in this Budget has reached a new high of 31.7 per cent of GDP. When State and local governments come into the picture we find that total public sector outlays have reached over 42 per cent of GDP. This must squeeze the private sector, which is still expected to produce 75 per cent of the jobs throughout Australia. The interest bill on the public debt will be met through taxes or higher interest rates. Eventually the ordinary Australian will be hit by both of these; he will just have to be to meet that debt.

One of the three biggest rises in Budget expenditure falls under the heading of public debt interest, where outlays are up over 29 per cent. In dollar terms the only items showing a rise larger than the public debt interest figure of $1.27 billion are health and social security. The biggest rises in spending are not in the productive areas which would increase national wealth and long term jobs. In percentage terms the item with the biggest growth in 1984-85 is legislative services-up by 53 per cent to more than $300m. While the new Parliament House will be a permanent national asset the other causes of this mushrooming spending are the increased size of the Federal Parliament and the early election for which this whole Budget was designed. It says a lot for the priorities of the ALP in government. Neither side of politics is not guilty of putting electoral self-interest before long term national good, as John Stone brought home to us, but the Hawke Government has taken this to a new pitch.

The biggest rise in expenditure in dollar terms, a rise of $1.7 billion and the second largest percentage rise of over 40 per cent, is in the field of health. This single fact bears witness against the catchcry that we have a pragmatic, middle of the road government. The $6 billion, nearly a tenth of total outlays, is a monument to the dogmatism of the Australian Labor Party in pursuing its goal of socialised medicine regardless of cost or efficiency.

The inevitable response to criticism of the scheme is that the ALP got elected in 1983 and it intends to do as it pleases. It is highly debatable that health policy in any way led to the change of Government, but it is significant that while pledges to wine growers and taxpayers in general are disposable under the Hawke Government, that Government will press ahead with Medicare regardless. The people of Forrest are already learning that they are paying more for inferior health cover. They have no guarantee of getting public patient status even in the largest hospitals in Bunbury and Albany, as non employs salaried doctors. Every family, other than those on low incomes, places itself at serious risk if it does not maintain private hospital cover. Yet this Budget pours money into the new black hole of Medicare, with a 60 per cent rise in medical benefits and hospital funding. The outlays in medical benefits will reach $2.4 billion, but the Medicare levy will raise only $1.2 billion. Inevitably, with an election out of the way this Government plans to be back here next year boosting this levy up to 2 per cent of income or more. If it does not how is it being honest, as speaker after speaker has pointed out that the one per cent falls short by $800m of covering the Medicare bill? If the Government wants to be honest it will have to put up the percentage of income.

Although social security remains the largest category of expenditure, with over $18 billion, the actual rise is less than 10 per cent. Rises in indexed pensions and benefits by $2.50 for single pensioners and $4.20 for couples merely allow the aged and the single parent to stay where they are. The Hawke Government had already reduced indexed pension rises by its artificial removal of health care costs from the consumer price index. This supposed generosity does nothing but restore the balance. Clearly as a Liberal I would not urge any government to go out and spend big unless it were absolutely essential. Yet if a government is raising outlays it should surely look to raising the real incomes of poorer Australians in preference to building an ideological monument in Medicare.

The largest employer in Australia is small business, which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) accused of seeking special treatment and handouts. These are sought by neither the Liberal Party nor by small business leaders. What is needed, what the ALP has failed to tackle, is a lifting of some of the burdens that restrict small business and discourage it from creating jobs. All the Government needed to do was carry out some of its 1983 election promises that involved neither handouts nor heavy cost to the revenue. The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) in his speech here in the last day or two has aptly made that point.

The abolition of Division 7 of the tax Act could have allowed for the reinvestment of all profits of small businesses, rather than have 30 per cent compulsorily distributed to shareholders. It is that kind of regulation that helps keep small business small. Payment of provisional tax by quarterly instalments would be another easing of financial constraints on small business without in the end any cost to the revenue. So, too, would the extension of sales tax remittance dates, another forgotten ALP election promise. That fact has been pointed out by the honourable member for Higgins. Small businessmen know better than this Government that while the tax has to be paid within 21 days, actual payment to the small businessmen could take two months or more.

When this Government remembers business it is large business. This was what John Stone meant in his reference to the corporate state of the Government, unions and capital. This corporate state is akin to facism. I welcome an increase in the depreciation allowance from 2.5 per cent to 4 per cent as it will continue the Fraser Government's initiative in aiding the tourist accommodation industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wells Mr D.McM.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight's debate concerns the Budget and tonight I want to talk about how the Budget affects ordinary people who benefit from the changes introduced in the Budget. I want to talk about a variety of these people . One of the most sorrowful but most appreciated duties which many members of parliament undertake is to write to families of constituents who have died and offer those families sympathy and, if needed, assistance with the arrangements that they have to make. Recently I wrote to a family in these circumstances and in reply I received a thank you card and a letter. The letter was the most eloquent piece of prose I have ever read. I will read it now:

SPEECH.PARA: Thank you for your expression of sympathy. Our son's death was tragic. He in a moment of desperation and irrationality shot himself. Life, for him offered no hope. His self-worth was eroded by the lifestyle he and so many others live today-a fortnightly handout was and is all they could expect. Society does not need them, they are the 'paid off ones'. Drugs relieve that pain of alienation for they alter one's perception of reality, but in so doing erode further their dignity as fully functioning human beings. Until our society puts together a more humane way of support for those not absorbed into the work place, Australia will lose to death, sickness, mental institutions and disease many of its young before they even get a chance to flower into people with a sense of dignity and purpose.
I write to you openly for our Government must halt the destruction (and we do not need to shoot ourselves to be destroyed). You, as our representative, must state our case to avert further tragedy.

The letter was signed 'Sincerely in hope' by the mother of the young man in question. There is nothing that I could possibly say which would add to the force of those words. They confirm me absolutely in my conviction that the removal of the blight of unemployment should continue to be this nation's No. 1 priority.

Recently I visited the Redcliffe community youth support scheme facility. About a dozen young women attending that facility had completed a receptionist's course, and the purpose of my visit was to present certificates testifying to the skills to which they had been introduced. Community youth support schemes are Federal Government facilities which offer training and retraining for young unemployed people. After presenting the certificates I spent some time talking with the young women who had just completed the course. They were without exception intelligent, well spoken, well dressed and attractive. Had they been born 10 years earlier they would have been an asset to any organisation which employed them. They would have been snapped up very quickly by the labour market . They were born at an unfortunate time. All these young people had been unemployed for more than three months, some for much longer. Yet none of them were members of the groups in the community which are regarded as those suffering the worst unemployment rates. Of this particular group none was handicapped, none had disabilities. There is also high unemployment among migrant groups, but of this particular group all were Australian born.

Since the election of the Hawke Labor Government the rate of unemployment has come down decisively and the number of jobs in the economy which has been created since then is impressive. The number of discouraged job seekers who had simply stopped seeking work has declined and many of those are now once more actively in the job market. Things have looked up tremendously, but we should not let these facts dazzle us and prevent us from seeing the extent to which unemployment remains the blight on the soul of the nation. At the Commonwealth Employment Service office where these young people registered for work, the Redcliffe CES, the rate of unemployment among those of their age group, 15 to 25 years, is dramatically high. Of those seeking work at that CES office, 47 per cent are in the 15 to 25 age group.

The unemployed are not, however, the only people in our community who are getting a rough deal at the moment. My electorate has a very high proportion of pensioners, particularly age pensioners. Many of these are concentrated in the city of Redcliffe. They have retired after having served Australia all their lives and have chosen, and chosen wisely, to spend their retirement with dignity in that beautiful seaside city. However, one statistic tells a powerful story. The suburb of Woody Point has the lowest household income in the whole of south- east Queensland. This is solely because of the very high concentration of age pensioners. I regularly have the pleasure of meeting many of my constituents at community cere- monies, celebrations, meetings, sporting clubs, service organisations, community groups and so on. Queenslanders are traditional people and certain formalities are observed at such events. Often at such functions the procedures will be formal. Participants will wear suits or other better than casual clothing and begin by toasting the Queen with wine and settling down to a three course meal. I have often attended such functions in Redcliffe, however, where the participants wore suits, the Queen was toasted with water and we sat down to a meal of sandwiches. The expression of loyalty was no worse for that, and the nourishment was probably better. Nevertheless, such an event is a dramatic illustration of the relativity of the amounts of disposable income available to different sections of the community.

Our Government has taken some steps recently to improve conditions for age pensioners but I would be less than frank if I said it was enough. For years pensioners have received only consumer price index increases which barely kept pace with inflation. However, in the last Budget a CPI increase would have meant no increase at all for pensioners because, to their benefit, as well as to the benefit of the rest of Australia, there was no significant movement in the CPI in the last quarter. For the first time since the days of the Whitlam Government pensioners have received an increase which was over and above CPI increases. This came in the Budget. This was a welcome move but much more of the same remains to be done, and I and many of my colleagues hope that it will be done very soon.

Age pensioners are not the only class of social security beneficiaries who have been suffering in recent years. I recently received a letter from one of my constituents, a supporting parent. She had been working for the last couple of years and had been on the supporting parents benefit before entering into employment. She had to terminate her employment for family reasons and return once more to a supporting parents benefit. To express her astonishment at the escalating costs of basic essentials, she wrote to me in these terms:
My electricity bill was approximately $80--
that is, before she went back to work-

and now its $129 a quarter. The amount of electricity used is the same as before and I have the same appliances and same conditions as before. Also, the house rates have jumped by about $150 in two years, with car registration increasing $ 60 in the same period.

It hardly needs to be pointed out that most of these increases in costs which my constituent is complaining about are State Government taxes. Even the rates which have gone up recently have gone up largely as a result of the State Government forcing municipal councils to collect a fire levy for it. The people of Queensland might very well wonder why the State Government of Queensland is prepared to grant electricity concessions to transnational corporations but makes ordinary citizens, including those on the breadline, pay the full price. My constituent went on to discuss some other matters which bear on Federal responsibilities. For some years we have needed in this country a thorough review of the social security system. What my constituent writes is conclusive proof of the need for such a review. She writes:

Also I have been told that when my youngest son is 16, as I will only be 41, there is a gap of four years when I will not be eligible for any supporting parents or widows pension and would have to go on unemployment benefits unless my son is still at school. As I have a part-time job I would not be eligible for unemployment benefits, so we would have to live on my part-time earnings . . . and whatever my son would be able to contribute, depending on whether he was working or not. If he was unemployed, most of his benefit would go on transport to look for work, so I would still be sole support. I am not a bludger, and am studying at night school in hopes of bettering myself and family, but with employment being so hard to find, especially for young people. I'm very worried about the future.

My constituent's fears are certainly very important and meaningful ones. According to the Department of Social Security, in my electorate of Petrie there are 2,211 female supporting parents and 125 male supporting parents. Many of these supporting parents are young widows and deserted wives, and their children , future citizens of Australia, have as much right to the fruits of our civilisation as any other young Australians. One difficulty is that when they get part time work, as a great number of them do-of all social security beneficiaries, it is supporting parents who try the hardest to get into the work force, motivated as they are by the desire to give their children a good start in life-many of them lose their eligibility for various pensions and benefits once their income exceeds a certain weekly figure. This is an anomaly, particularly in the case of this group of social security beneficiaries.

As I said before, the whole area of social security needs to be reviewed, and indeed such a review is to be undertaken by this Government at ministerial and Government policy committee level. The social security system, which has been administered parsimoniously and sometimes in a miserable way by the Liberal and National parties for 30 of the last 34 years, is largely an ad hoc system hardly deserving of the title of system. The task ahead of sorting out its anomalies is a large one.

This Budget comes to us in circumstances of economic management which have seen in this country a decline in the deficit, a considerable fall in unemployment, an increase in labour force participation and the number of jobs created in the economy, a dramatic fall in inflation, a fall in interest rates, an increase in capital investment, the highest consumer confidence in this nation since figures were first kept, an increase in the non-farm domestic product-that is, the domestic product which does not have anything to do with the breaking of the drought-and the highest growth rate in the Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development, indicating that our achievement in this country is not just an imported phenomenon. This Budget is one which is bringing Australia forward. There is much more work to be done but the people of Australia should know that this is a government committed not only to responsibility but also to justice, and as we return to prosperity so justice as administered by the Hawke Government will increase and be distributed to more and more Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join a lengthy queue of speakers for the Budget debate. The first thing I wish to say, which has been said before but bears repeating, is simply that this is a facile election Budget which has been well described as a vote now pay later Budget. It is the biggest spending Budget in the history of this country. The Government said it would cut taxes and reduce government spending but it has brought in the biggest spending Budget in the history of Australia. As with any budget, whether it is a family, business or government budget, if the money is coming in one can spend it. But if money is not coming in, where does it come from? We are borrowing on the never-never again and again to pay and we are building up a legacy for the future, for ourselves and for our children who will eventually have to meet the debt being accumulated by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: As usual, it is the taxpayers who will pay for it. In the next 12 months, one million people will move into a higher tax scale. The average weekly earner is now in the 46c in the dollar tax bracket. It means that he works at his job for the Government until lunchtime Tuesday and he can put the rest of his pay in his pocket, apart from all the other hidden taxes. Australia is accumulating a big debt and the Government thinks that people do not understand what that debt is. They might not understand the details, but they understand very well that the Government is putting us in a position similar to that of many South American countries. It is something the people of Australia do not like.

According to Government predictions personal tax to pay for this debt will increase by 23 per cent in the coming year, not because more people are employed , as current figures indicate, but because they are moving into a higher tax bracket. It is estimated that provisional tax will go up 44 per cent not because there will be another breaking of the drought next year but because of the breaking of the drought last year. That money is going to be raked in in provisional tax. Total tax receipts, the Government predicts, will be up by $9 billion. Instead of using some of that to pay off the debts that have been accumulated-some $17 billion in the last two years-what happens? We save $1.2 billion and make a big fuss about that, and spend the rest. The public debt for the Commonwealth alone is now $30 billion. By the end of the year it will probably be $40 billion. The interest on that is $5.6 billion, slightly more than the total amount we spend on education and slightly less than the total amount we spend on the defence of this country. What it amounts to is that Australia is in hock.

Not so long ago we were laughing at South American countries and wondering how they could get into such a mess, but if we take a good look at ourselves, and there are many people who are doing that, we will laugh no longer. We have to ask: How is it going to be paid for? There is no way that if, by mischance, the Government is returned next year it will wind down these expensive projects. They will be paid for by all the taxes that I have been talking about, plus extra taxes on companies and individuals, capital gains taxes and death duties. One after the other people on that side of the House tonight have been getting up and saying that capital gains taxes and death duties are the way to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is only your side.

—Enough Government members are saying that to indicate the general feeling about exactly which way we will go. The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) to his credit, spelt it out quite clearly and correctly. He said that a government spends big when an election is coming up but taxes heavily once the election is over. He will not get any credit for saying that-it will be repeated around the country in the next few months, to the Government's disadvantage-but he got it right. There is no money for science because there are no votes in science, despite all the rhetoric that has been going on here month after month about how important it is to restructure industry, to introduce new technology, to introduce new ideas into industry in Australia. What happens when the crunch comes? Where do the Minister and his Department of Science and Technology finish up? They finish up with absolutely nothing.
—Under the table with not even enough for dinner.

—Not only under the table, but kicked to death in the process. If anybody in Australia is looking for smaller government and smaller taxes while this Government is in power, they can forget it. There is no way that the Government's programs will be wound down. For example, let us take what might be described as a small part of the Government's program-the extra politicians who have been foisted on the Australian public, 35 extra politicians at a time when people are struggling and we are trying to get out of the mire. Australia already has something like 900 politicians. It is interesting to look at--
—God help us if they are all like you.

—That is a bit unkind. It is interesting to look at the cost of the Australian taxpayer of a politician. Each politician costs the taxpayers about $ 200,000 in direct costs, in salary, staff, office accommodation and travel. About $500,000 is the politician's share of running this Parliament. Before we even complete the new Parliament House we are talking about an extra $40m to accommodate another 35 politicians. I repeat that there will be $200,000 in direct costs, half a million for running the Parliament and $40m to extend the new Parliament House.
—What does all that add up to?

—Well, if the honourable member multiplies that by 35 he will get the answer. I wish to say a few words about the unions. Tonight we are debating the Budget and the economic future of Australia. If there is one cancer on the future of this country that we all live in, it is the union movement. It must be without doubt the biggest single obstacle to economic growth that any of us face . It is continuing to make impossible demands on the economy, on the employers and on the taxpayers that no country can ever meet. What is more, it is getting what it is asking for from a government that is too frightened to say no. The Government has a tiger by the tail and it cannot let go of it because if is locked into this mystical prices and incomes accord which will devour the Government in the end.

SPEECH.PARA: There was a time when the unions in this country devoted their energies to looking after their members. Now they are simply looking after those members who are employed and to hell with all the others, to hell with Australia and its future and to hell with those who create employment. If honourable members doubt and laugh at these things, how many of them have faced union leaders who have said exactly that to their face? If they have not, they have certainly said it to me. Union leaders say: 'I don't care about the unemployed or the future of Australia. What do I care about that company? All I am concerned about is the union members who are employed because if they don't get bigger and better I will be out of a job'. They ignore the unemployed, the capacity to pay and the plight of those juniors whose wages they have jacked up year by year until 25 per cent of under 19-year-olds are unemployed. They ignore the international competitiveness of Australia and the burdens that employers have to carry, for example the redundancy provisions which were handed down the other day by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. We once talked about union power and people were worried about it. But we have gone past that stage. We are now talking about union authority and it is that authority that should concern us.

There used to be a time when employers and governments consulted unions but now it is not a matter of consultation, it is a matter of unions determining the policy which the Government in this country follows. There is no future for this country if we follow this slippery road to oblivion. The prime reason for it is that the Government is locked into the accord. It has become the centrepiece of government economic authority. It means that one section of this country is determining our future policy. A pressure group is running the country. It is not without interest to note that the Western country that has produced the most jobs in recent years is the United States of America. In America the union movement is on the decline. Some 25 per cent of employees are unionised. In Australia, with 320 unions all busily fighting each other and determining government policy, some 55 per cent of our employees are unionised. I am happy to say that that figure is declining, but it is still significant. There is no doubt that under this Government the unions are getting stronger. Let me quote from an article from the Business Week which mentions unions in America. It states:

A revolution in the way workers do their jobs is beginning to take hold throughout America's basic industries. Changes in work rules are moving the workplace away from rigid labor practices . . . Instead, a more flexible structure is evolving that can adapt to advanced technology, provide new products at a competitive cost, and release the nation from the stranglehold of stagnant productivity.
If we had any sense, that is the model we would be following. Let me talk a little about the decision handed down recently by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Television Services: East Gippsland-Mrs Betty Powell-Small Business-Commonwealth Employment Service-Mobile Telephones-Eye Banks

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m. I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 March this year I addressed the House on the problems of communications for East Gippsland. In particular I drew the House's attention to the problems being encountered by the residents of Cann River, Genoa and Mallacoota who are unable to receive Victorian television or radio. Regrettably, I have to inform the House that the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) and his Department have failed to act in the ensuing months. They have failed to act by permitting GLV8, the regional television station which broadcasts from Traralgon, to instal a very high frequency translator in Cann River in place of the required ultra high frequency translator.

SPEECH.PARA: I called on the Minister through the Parliament and through correspondence, to permit some flexibility. Otherwise, it is commercially impossible for GLV8 to install a UHF translator, thereby depriving the residents of East Gippsland any possibility of receiving commercial television. When I last spoke on this subject in the Parliament, I called on the Minister to permit the installation, as he has committed himself to doing, of an Australian Broadcasting Corporation translator in the region so as to allow the residents of East Gippsland access to ABC television. Again, although communication between the Minister and me goes back several months-in fact, well over a year-nothing has been done. This is despite the fact that I have lodged in this Parliament a petition with several hundred names calling on the Minister to act. The signatories to that petition are people from Mallacoota.

I again implore the Minister and this Parliament to act so that a significant population is not deprived of the same rights that other Victorians, not to mention other Australians, accept as of right. Further problems arise because of the Minister's insistence that translators now be UHF. I received a deputation on behalf of the Ensay television committee led by Mr Bill French and Mr Oscar Thoms. You will appreciate, Mr Speaker, that Ensay is another part of East Gippsland although somewhat removed from the Genoa- Mallacoota region. The committee wishes to install a translator but, again, there is a problem in that the Minister and his Department require that the translator be UHF thereby making it almost financially impossible for the local community, through the Ensay television committee, to install a translator. It is the committee's opinion, based on some technical expertise, that a VHF translator is more appropriate, not to mention far less expensive and more affordable to the local community than a UHF translator. Moreover, the Ensay television committee needs approximately $3,000 to purchase and install the translator. It has raised a great deal of money already to install smaller translators and is now calling on the Government for assistance.

One wonders how often matters of importance such as this have to be drawn to the attention of the Minister and the Parliament before action is taken.
