It seems there is a great deal of discrimination as there are examples in the last few months of the Minister for Communications allowing VHF translators to be installed in other parts of the country. Why, then, can he not act in relation to the matter that has been put before him several times so that a significant proportion of the Gippsland population who are my direct responsibility can enjoy the same communications as are enjoyed by other Victorians because, after all, they pay the same taxes as all other Victorians? It is the responsibility of this Government and the Minister to ensure that this need is met. A great number of people in Gippsland will no longer tolerate the Minister's inaction. We now call on the Government at long last to take this overdue action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —When Betty Powell of Queanbeyan parted from the Australian Public Service, she left it as a woman whose health had been affected by intensive treatment. Even her department-Social Security-admitted liability for her health. Under the Freedom of Information Act provisions Mrs Powell was able to examine her personal and medical records. These records include medical reports, family history-or purported family history-an above average work record and excellent relationships with senior and other officers within the Department of Social Security. It is a small wonder that Mrs Powell is now unfit for further service.

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened to Betty Powell is a warning to people in bureaucratic situations and happens all too often to Australian public servants. Mrs Powell has been denigrated and defamed under the legal guise of 'medical opinion recorded at the time'. The official medical records wrongly stated that Mrs Powell's problems at work related to personal and family problems. An examination of her records show that her health problems were work related as substantiated by her referee reports and admission of liability by the Department. A Government medical referee made a host of inaccuracies and I will refer to only one of the less derogatory: He said Mrs Powell had undergone unnecessary operations. Her other medical records first show clearly that any operation she had undergone was necessary and, secondly, that her operations had nothing like the effect of work related problems on her health.

I do not want to delve deeply into Mrs Powell's personal records, suffice it to say that the Commonwealth referee is continually contradicted by records of other medical experts who examined Mrs Powell. The tragedy is that the Commonwealth referee's files are still held. These reports, accepted by Government departments, entirely misrepresent the environmental reasons for Betty Powell's ill health.

Betty Powell is known personally to a great many politicians, Clerks and others on the parliamentary staff of both Houses and many people in the Canberra- Queanbeyan community. She has, in the past, given great service and loyalty to this Parliament, as a servant of the committees of Parliament and its elected representatives, and Clerks of the Parliament, and as an electoral secretary in Queensland where she showed efficiency and the ability to liaise with people from all walks of life. She gave great service and loyalty to the Department of Social Security and had an excellent work record in spite of her tragic personal circumstances. Other elected representatives on both sides of Parliament agree with me that she has been put through a whole series of ordeals by a department which can ill afford an intrusive reputation.

The Department of Social Security was asked to remove the offensive medical report but made only side notations and then informed the Minister for Health ( Dr Blewett) that the records were amended in April 1984. I ask the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford), who is at the table, to refer this matter to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) and have removed from the record unfair, defamatory and unjustified references to Betty Powell and her family situation. It is probably too late to help Betty Powell but it is not too late for Government departments, doctors and senior public servants to be warned that unsubstantiated opinions can devastate the lives of individuals and their families. Honourable members will understand why I cannot go into the full medical records of this person.

Betty Powell's employers were right about her excellent work record; let them remove the unfair, unsubstantiated and distorted medical and family records. Betty Powell has told me that without the support of her many friends from all walks of life in Australia, whom she wishes to thank, she would not have endured .

I will place the medical reports before the Minister for Health and will ask for an investigation into their inaccuracies, their inconsistencies and their irrelevancies. I also ask the Minister to seek an explanation from the doctors concerned. At the very minimum, I ask the Ministers for Social Security and Health that anything defamatory, derogatory or damaging to Mrs Powell be removed . There have been other complaints about the medical referee in this case. People must be protected from such procedures. Safeguards may have to be introduced and freedom of information taken to its logical extension, freedom from misinformation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in this debate about the devastating effect on small and medium size businesses in Australia of the job security decision handed down this week by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission upon an application by the employers to review that case. On Tuesday the review was dismissed by the Commission. I was in the courtroom that morning and I saw large numbers of owners of small and medium size businesses who came to that court to see that decision handed down. There has never before in Australia been such a reaction by employers and businesses to a decision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: This decision will change the character of business and employment in Australia . It will result in the small business revolution that is underway, gathering further momentum. This job security decision will have a most damaging effect on the ability of young people to get jobs. Small and medium size firms are discouraged from taking on employees by this decision. As it comes at this time of high unemployment in Australia in 1984, it is particularly damaging to those who will be leaving school at the end of this year and looking for jobs in 1985.

Small and medium size businesses which are the major area of job opportunity and should be the major area of job opportunity for school leavers in Australia will be deterred by this decision from taking on employees. I was talking with one businessman in the courtroom who said that as a result of this decision he would not take on any more apprentices. That is a direct result of this job security case decision. At this time of economic uncertainty, a tribunal should not be handing down a decision that adds an extra cost burden on the business sector. Governments and tribunals in the conciliation and arbitration area should be supporting business, employers and the private sector.

What has happened here has been an application by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, supported by the Federal Government and every State government. Extra cost burdens will be placed on the small business sector. This decision will have the most damaging effect on the value of the assets of small businesses in Australia today. The value of shares, the value of goodwill in every business in Australia will be reduced by the amount that that business has to set aside for contingent liabilities in its accounts, those contingent liabilities being in respect of the severance payments that will need to be included in the accounts of the company or business because the job redundancy case provides that every business has to provide retrospectively for redundancy payments. One day before the decision, there was no such liability. When the Commission hands down the decision, all of a sudden there is a retrospective liability on every small and medium size firm in Australia. It has to be included in the accounts of companies and businesses. To small businesses particularly, these amounts will be staggering.

As I have said, the operation of the decision is retrospective. Businesses have to fund out of existing assets the amounts to be put aside to pay for these severance payments. Many small businesses will find that the value of their business is wiped out overnight by this decision. If a milk bar employs one person and suddenly finds as a result of this decision that it has to account in its books and provide for redundancy payments when that employee is made redundant or leaves the business, the goodwill that the owners of such a milk bar might get on the sale of that business could well be wiped out by the amount they have to provide for that employee. In other words, people who have worked hard in small businesses, say, in a milk bar of the nature I have indicated to the House tonight, will suddenly find the total value of their asset wiped out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this House on 7 May 1984 honourable members were witness to yet another assault on the morale of the unemployed people of this nation by the honourable member for Hume (Mr Lusher). The target of his most virulent attack of this occasion was the Commonwealth Employment Service. The honourable member made scathing and wide-ranging criticisms of a service which has earnestly and loyally served the Government, employers and unemployed people of Australia since its inception in 1945. Working in the CES has always been hard. In particular the years of Fraserism were not easy ones for the dedicated staff of this organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: The celebrated Australian author Gabrielle Lord spoke of her years working in the CES in the late 1970s as part of an article in the National Times of 30 December last year. I will now quote selectively from this article for the benefit of those members on the Opposition benches who have not considered what life has been like over the last few years for CES personnel. She says:
And so they came in their hundreds of thousands to the offices of the CES and the first person they spoke to was the counter clerk.

If we found ourselves becoming angry, our instructions were to walk away and turn the aggressor over to someone else. One young clerk walked away all right. Right out of the office and wasn't seen again for some time.

'Most office managers were sympathetic but what could they do? They knew we were hopelessly understaffed and with ceiling imposed on further recruitment we just had to do our best with what we had. Morale was abysmally low, and electorally servile remarks about decreasing the size of the Public Service so that there would be 'less snouts in the trough' made us wonder who the pigs really were. We were the shock troops, and it was hard for us not to feel that ' us versus them' dichotomy, as the unemployed came over the top wave after wave.

The personal tragedies were uncountable. The times you'd cross 'married' on the job seekers card and substitute 'separated' and wonder what hell they'd endured before that happened. Kids thrown out of home because they couldn't find work.

Good men and women worked those; people who often contacted clients after hours , or dropped mail off for them in their own time. Not many of us deserved the bad reputation we seemed to have. But it was hard to be saintly all the time.
We lent money (strictly against orders) we knocked back bribes
'The CES taught me staying power, it gave me a lot and it took a lot. It very nearly took from me everything I valued.

Such an unfounded attack as that made by the honourable member for Hume not only affects the morale of the front line troops of the CES but also reduces the level of confidence unemployed people have in them. The honourable member received universal criticism recently for his farcical attempt to survive on the unemployment benefit for a week. I sincerely hope that this similarly ludicrous exercise in publicity seeking will draw the same response from members who do know what they are talking about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. My point of order is that it is customary for members of this House to inform other members that they will be making a personal attack on them. I just wondered-
—The Chair is in no position to know whether members have informed other members, and the Chair is not required to ask.

—Does the honourable member know that I did not do so? That the honourable member for Hume does not know what he is talking about becomes obvious from the number of facilities in his speech of 7 May. He implies that the role of the CES is a duplication of that performed by classified advertisements. This demonstrates an appalling lack of understanding. It would be such a simple matter for him to obtain CES vacancy lodgment statistics for any of the major towns in his electorate and compare them with numbers of job vacancy advertisements in newspapers in the same town. He would find those newspapers receive several hundred per cent fewer vacancies.

SPEECH.PARA: Inquiries made of staff in all the CES offices in the electorate of Hume reveal that the honourable member has never visited one of those offices. Likewise, despite his desperate concern for the plight of the unemployed he has never visited a community youth support scheme project in his own electorate. I ask: How can someone like this have any understanding of the complete role of the CES when he does not even know that unemployment benefit forms are not lodged at CES offices?

I have in my office a copy of a telex sent to the CES office in Tamworth in May from the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) dissociating himself from the views of the honourable member for Hume and praising the work of the CES. I challenge the honourable member for Hume to arrange to attend a staff meeting at any CES office in his electorate in order to debate with the staff the contents of his speech. I also challenge the Opposition spokesman on employment and industrial relations to denounce publicly--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just seen another example of the lack of moral courage that characterises certain members of the Australian Labor Party. The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Hollis) has just made a statement without getting in touch with the honourable member concerned.
—How do you know I didn't?
—Because you did not, and you know you did not. You do not have the courage to do it. You will not be a member of this House for long anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I want to raise the matter of the provision of mobile telephones within private cars. Unfortunately, a very grave matter has arisen in relation to the privacy achieved by the use of these mobile telephones. A constituent of mine has found himself in a position whereby his private telephone conservations, when using the mobile telephone, have been intercepted by outside bodies. This is a very serious matter because it costs a great deal of money to hire one of these telephones. In fact, the unit was purchased for the business purposes of this gentleman at a cost of over $5,500. It costs $200 a quarter in network rental and calls are metered at the subscriber trunk dialling rate.

The matter of the privacy of mobile telephones was brought to the attention of the authorities last year. A routine letter was issued by Telecom Australia on 17 October last year to all customers who had acquired mobile telephones. The letter said:
Dear Customer,

Safeguarding privacy on your mobile telephone. As you are aware, radio scanners which allow entire frequency bands to be scanned and individual channels to be selected and monitored are readily available on the market. To further safeguard privacy on mobile telephone services, MTS, conversations, Telecom has determined a method whereby one direction only of conversation, fixed network to mobile telephone, will be transmitted to air on any frequency. This will effectively remove most of the intelligence of a conversation which happens to be overheard.
A minor alteration to each mobile telephone unit, also modification to the channels, will be required for introduction of this enhancement to the Sydney MTS by the end of this year.
Remember, that is, last year, 1983. The letter continued:
The alteration of your mobile unit will avoid an undesirable lack of side tone caused by the channel modification. To assist in our speedy implementation of this plan would you please contact-

The letter goes on. The fact is that despite that modification and despite that letter of 17 October 1983, the interception of conversations on mobile telephones is still taking place. This constituent of mine was telephoned by a television show because he had made some complaints about the interception previously. Following the modifications to the mobile telephones, he agreed to discuss the matter. When he was in a position to discuss the matter the person who was to interview him arrived with a crystal clear recording of a conversation that this constituent of mine had had the night before and, in addition, gave details of several other conversations that this person had had previously.

This is a most serious matter. Discussions and conversations of a highly personal nature take place on these mobile telephones. If they can be readily intercepted, obviously the privacy of those conversations is very much at risk. Not only personal details relating to the lives and practices of the people who have these telephones but also the business dealings of many people who use these telephones can be intercepted. If Telecom charges a great deal of money for the use of these mobile phones it is up to Telecom and the Government to do something to protect the privacy of people who pay, as I say, a very great deal of money for the privilege of using them. If this matter is not taken seriously the professions of concern about civil and personal rights of which we hear so much from Ministers will be shown to amount to nought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two nights ago I spoke on the adjournment debate about the provision of an eye bank network in Australia. I wish to add to my remarks on that subject. The only offspring of Mr Stanley Fitzroy-Mendis II is his 11-year-old son of the same name. Master Stanley Fitzroy-Mendis III. He attends a boarding school in the United States of America, on the advice of psychiatrists who are concerned at the bad emotional effect upon him by his mother who is practising medicine in Australia. This personable and intelligent boy, whom I have actually spoken to by telephone, is to present to Mr Sandber of the United Nations on 11 September at 10 a.m. and to a later Press conference his father's petition indicting Australia for failure to uphold the interests of patients in Australia and other countries. The Australian International Eye Bank and Research Foundation, the AIEBRF, may transport, free of charge, eyes and dehydrated corneas in accordance with the international code of ethics and the practice accepted in all other countries with eye banks and in accordance with uniform laws throughout Australia regarding the use of human tissues. Such transport was approved by the Federal Department of Transport in 1978.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) on 9 August 1984 for a letter of support to the Russian Consulate in Sydney to receive a visa for his constituent, that is, Mr Stanley Fitzroy-Mendis III, to seek treatment for his chlorocort damaged eye at a famous Russian clinic. I trust that the Ministers will hasten their response as the patient believes his sight is failing. I appeal to the Health Minister, the Foreign Minister, the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to ensure that these scandalous situations are corrected promptly, including the use of chlorocort, the eye bank's procedures and policies on supply to other countries; in other words, they do not want any eye tissue to be supplied to any other country.
Dr Roberts, a Sydney ophthalmologist, told the Eye Banking Association of America Inc. Board of Directors on 19 October 1978 in Missouri in response to an address by Mr Fitzroy-Mendis:
There is a large eye bank in Sydney. Some tissue is exported to the nearest Asiatic countries.
According to Mr Fitzroy-Mendis, the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmologists was on record in the Medical Journal of Australia of that month as opposing the import and export of eye tissue.

Australia has led the world for long periods in the recent past in blood bank development and has joined in international exchange networks, especially as a major resource centre for the South West Pacific. We have an unrivalled opportunity to provide a similar service for many sight impaired people, removing the professional restriction of access to corneal grafts apparently being exercised in Sydney. Such an expansion of curative services would provide dozens of skilled and satisfying jobs, restore constructive capacity of our own citizens, reduce stop-gap welfare arrangements, which are already costing the public purse money, and enhance the international good will of Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
House adjourned at 10.59 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following notices were given:
Mr Young to move-

(1) That, in accordance with section 54 of the National Crimes Authority Act 1984, matters relating to the powers and proceedings of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority shall be as follows:

(a) That the committee consist of 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Prime Minister, the Leader of the House or the Government Whip, 1 Member of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition or the Opposition Whip, 1 Member of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Leader of the National Party, the Deputy Leader of the National Party or the National Party Whip, 3 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 1 Senator to be nominated by any minority group or groups or independent Senator or independent Senators.
(b) That the committee elect a Government member as its Chairman.

(c) That the committee elect a deputy chairman who shall perform the duties of the chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee, and at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee, the members present shall elect another member to perform the duties of the chairman at that meeting.
(d) That 5 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.
(e) That the committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of 3 or more of its members and to refer to such a sub-committee any matter which the committee is empowered to inquire into.

(f) That the committee appoint a chairman of each sub-committee who shall have a casting vote only, and at any time when the chairman of a sub-committee is not present at a meeting of the sub-committee, the members of the sub-committee present shall elect another member of that sub-committee to perform the duties of the chairman at the meeting.
(g) That the quorum of a sub-committee be a majority of the members of that sub -committee.

(h) That members of the committee who are not members of a sub-committee may participate in the proceedings of that sub-committee but shall not vote, move any motion or be counted for the purpose of a quorum.
(i) That the committee, or any sub-committee, have power to send for persons, papers and records.
(j) That the committee, or any sub-committee, have power to move from place to place.
(k) That a sub-committee have power to adjourn from time to time and to sit during any adjournment of the Senate or of the House of Representatives.
(l) That a sub-committee have power to authorise publication of any evidence given before it and any document presented to it.
(m) That the committee have leave to report from time to time.

(n) That, in carrying out its duties the committee, or any sub-committee, ensure that the operational methods and results of investigations of law enforcement agencies, as far as possible, be protected from disclosure where that would be against the public interest.
(o) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.
(2) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution and requesting that it concur and take action accordingly.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Minister for Trade: Visit to China

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 21 August 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he fly Cathay Pacific on his trip to China in May 1984.
(2) Why did he fail to use Australia's flag carrier, Qantas, for at least part of this journey.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The trip actually took place in June 1984.

(2) There were no Qantas flights via Hong Kong available on the days appropriate for travel given the program arranged with my Chinese hosts and my commitments in Australia. Alternative routes using legs where Qantas had a service available were thoroughly explored with Qantas by my Principal Private Secretary before my travel details were finalised.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 21 August 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: When will the Minister be in a position to comment on the attendant care pilot program which commenced in 1983 with a sample of 25 individuals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The attendant care pilot project commenced in February 1984 with 24 participants. All indications to date are that the project is proceeding satisfactorily. The first six-monthly progress report has recently been prepared by the University of Sydney, which is conducting an independent evaluation of the project. This report is being examined and specific comment cannot be made until that examination is completed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 21 August 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister consider extending the criteria of the mobility allowance to include all people with transport handicaps, irrespective of employment status.
(2) Will the Minister also consider increasing the allowance to a more realistic level.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) My Department is currently undertaking a general review of mobility allowance, including questions of level of payment and eligibility criteria. As part of this review a survey funded under the Community Employment Program will be made of people with transport handicaps to assess:
the extent the mobility allowance assists in meeting the transport costs of those who receive it
to what extent the mobility allowance would be of assistance to people who are unable to use public transport but who do not meet the mobility allowance eligibility criteria
What other forms of assistance people with transport handicaps require.
The review is expected to be completed by the end of the year.
I expect that the review will provide a basis on which the Government may consider the possibility of any changes to the present allowance.
